NAGER--Philip. 100 years- 33 missing you. Thank you for your wisdom. Robert

ZWEIBEL--Joel B.,beloved husband of Chrystine, father of Jane and Emily, stepfather of Todd and Jeff, grandfather of Nicolas, Gabriella, Sam, Alaina, and Elias, died at home Tuesday. An esteemed bankruptcy attorney and dedicated mentor to his beloved "mentees," Joel made a profound impact in this world. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Joel B. Zweibel Pre-Law Honors Scholarship/ Baruch College Fund, Box A1603, Baruch College, New York, NY 10010.
TRAMONTINE--John O. Correction: Memorial hours are on Friday September 27, 2013, 5 to 8pm at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville.

SUTLEY--Sara Alicia nee Mitlag. Born April 17, 1925 in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Died September 22, 2013 in Hillsborough, New Jersey. Sara is survived by her husband of 57 years, Bruno, daughters Suzanne and Nancy, son Steven and grandson Nick. Sara taught Junior High School Spanish in the New York City public schools for over 15 years. After her retirement, Sara split her time between Hampton Bays, NY and Pelican Cove, Sarasota, FL. Sara was active in the community, volunteering at, among others, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, NY and at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to ARF, The Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons. (P.O. Box 901 Wainscott, NY 11975 or at www. arfhamptons.org.)

STEINBERG--Wendy Walker, of Randolph, NJ, passed away peacefully at home, surrounded by family, on September 23, 2013, at the age of 52. She is survived, by beloved sons, Jonathan and Adam Steinberg of Randolph, NJ; loving father, Arthur W. Walker and step-mother, Jacqueline Adler Walker of Harrison, NY; brother Jay S. Walker and wife Eileen of Ridgefield, CT: nephew Evan Walker and wife Jaclyn of Bedford, NY; and niece Lindsey Walker of Arlington, VA. Wendy was pre-deceased by her mother Jeannette Cane Walker.

SHERMAN--Edith, of Ardsley, NY, died on September 25th at the age of 82 after a long illness. Daughter of Abraham and Beatrice Steinhouse, she is survived by her husband Bernard, her sons Leonard and Eric, daughter-in-law Betsy, a sister Rosalind and four grandchildren, Andrew, Gillian, Emily and Sarah. She was a dedicated social worker for many years in the NYC schools. Funeral services will be held on Friday, September 27th at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 9am.

MAGID--David H.,of Great Neck, NY and more recently Boca Raton, FL, devoted and loving husband to Lois for 67 years, loving and much beloved father, grandfather, uncle and great-uncle, would have been 97 years old today, passed peacefully on September 15, 2013, but remains in our hearts.

JOHNSON--Richard A.M.C.,former investment executive, died Tuesday, September 10, 2013 at his home in Santa Barbara, California. Dick was born in New York City on June 15, 1921 to Helen Sentner Johnson and Theodore Demott Johnson. He attended Trinity School in New York, Yale University, and completed his MBA at Columbia University. He proudly served in WWII as a pilot. Dick started his career at J.P. Morgan at age 19 as a mail clerk and became a Vice President. In 1967 he joined the Dreyfus Corporation as Vice President and manger of the Dreyfus Fund. He was also instrumental in forming and managing a joint venture between the Dreyfus Corporation and Marine Midland Bank. In the 1970s Dick joined Allen& Co. as a Senior Vice President where he managed an investment vehicle, Brandon Partnership, and originated several Private Equity Investments. In 1983 he retired to Santa Barbara, California where he enjoyed many good friends, travel, tennis, the Burnham Wood Country Club and still found time to serve on the financial committee of the Santa Barbara Hospice Board. Dick is survived by his wife Lorinda Johnson, his son Richard Johnson, Jr., his three daughters: Bonnie Newman, Janet Johnson, June O'Brien and his three grandsons: Douglas Johnson, Timothy Johnson, Paul Johnson.

HUNEKE--The Rev. Dr. John G.,Pastor of The Lutheran Church of the Reformation, Barbey Street, Brooklyn, since November 1972, passed away on September 20th at the age of 82. Reverend Huneke graduated from Columbia College, Class of '53. He also studied at Union Theological Seminary and Harvard Divinity School and was ordained in 1958. In May, 2010, he received the Degree of Doctor of Divinity from The Lutheran Theological Seminary at Philadelphia. Pastor Huneke served St. John's Lutheran Church in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, for thirteen years and has served The Lutheran Church of the Reformation for 40 years. He will be greatly missed by his fellow clergy and his devoted and loyal parishioners and friends. He is survived by his wife, Clare Feger Huneke. The Rev. Dr. Huneke will repose at: N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 87-34 80th Street, Woodhaven, NY 11421. Telephone: 718-296-4343. Visiting Hours: Thursday, September 26, 25pm and 79pm. September 27, 10:30am Service at the Funeral Home. The Rt. Rev. Robert A. Rimbo, Bishop, Metropolitan New York Synod of the ELCA presiding. Memorials may be sent to The Rev. Dr. John G. Huneke Endowed Scholarship Fund at the Lutheran Theological Seminary in Philadelphia.

FONTAINE--John C. Hughes Hubbard & Reed mourns the passing of its esteemed former Managing Partner, John Clovis ("Jack") Fontaine. Jack's intellect and judgment made him an extraordinarily gifted lawyer and we are honored to have called him our partner. During his varied and productive career, he served in numerous notable positions including as a President of Knight-Ridder, Inc. and Chairman of the National Gallery of Art, the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and the Florida Philharmonic, and a Director of numerous corporate Boards. Jack remained a friend and trusted advisor until the end. We are grateful for the time we had with him and send our deepest condolences to his family.

GOLDFEIER--Moritz. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed Director and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Professor William Schwartz, Chairman Walter J. Molofsky, M.D., President

FONTAINE--John C. The Board and Staff of Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival mourn the loss of John C. Fontaine, whose guidance over more than three decades has been stalwart and essential. Throughout multiple Board terms and crucial leadership as Chairman, Jack offered infinite wisdom and unconditional support. Our deepest sympathy and love goes to Betty and the entire family.

FONTAINE--John Clovis, of New York City and West Stockbridge, MA, died Monday of the complications of pancreatic cancer. He was 81 years old. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, the former Elizabeth Ellis (Betty); daughters Lizanne (Robert Buckholz), Amy (Mete Kok) and Alison Engel (Peter); eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild; his brother, Edward Fontaine; his sister, Anne Marie Fontaine; and his brother's widow, Carole Fontaine. Jack graduated from the University of Michigan and Harvard Law School. He was a partner at Hughes, Hubbard & Reed in New York and later was General Counsel, Executive Vice President, and then President of Knight-Ridder, Inc. He was a member of the board of Century Aluminum Company. Jack was the former Chairman and Trustee Emeritus of the National Gallery of Art; Chairman of the Samuel H. Kress Foundation; and Chairman of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and the Florida Philharmonic. On Saturday, September 28, 2013, there will be a gathering in his honor from 4pm to 7pm in the Reception Room at Plymouth Church, 75 Hicks Street, Brooklyn NY. On Monday, December 9, 2013 there will be a memorial service at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Fontaine Family Fund, Berkshire Taconic Foundation (www.berkshiretaconic.org) or the Berkshire Medical Center (www.berkshirehealth systems.org/bmc), in gratitude to Dr. Jeffrey St. John.

BARASCH--Rita Gewant, passed away, peacefully at home on September 24, 2013 at 80 years of age. She was a loving wife to the Honorable Melvin Barasch, her husband of 53 years, a beloved mother to daughters, Susan, Patricia and Abby, mother-in-law to David, Paul and Wendy and proud 'Nana' to Rachel, Emily, Jessica, Cassidy, Matthew and Kieran as well as a cherished aunt and cousin. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Rita graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Brooklyn College with a BA in history. She taught Social Studies at Midwood High School before becoming a guidance counselor at Sheepshead Bay High School. Committed to helping students, she became a guidance counselor to struggling teens at the alternative high school, City-as-School in Manhattan. An outspoken, champion of equal rights; Rita was an inspiration to .many, a loyal friend and truly, "a woman ahead of her time." She was a 33 year survivor of breast cancer, but succumbed after a nearly 10 year battle to the ravages of Alzheimer's disease. She will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing her. Funeral Services will be held on Friday, September 27 at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York, NY, followed by interment at Beth David Cemetery, 300 Elmont Rd., Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's organization of New York City Chapter or the Breast Cancer Research Fund (BCRF).

DASH--Robert Warren. It is with great sadness that the Board of the Madoo Conservancy announces the passing of Robert W. Dash, a poet of the New York School, a painter of the Long Island School, author and the creator of the internationally acclaimed Madoo Gardens, on September 14, 2013 at the age of 82. A memorial service will be held in the Spring. Contributions may be made to the Madoo Conservancy, PO Box 362, Sagaponack, NY 11962.

AUBRY--Blossom McKinley, age 94 on September 16, 2013. Adoring and devoted wife of Marcel, kind and loving mother of Philippe and Michel, and daughter-in-law Doreen, and grandmother of her beloved Nicholas. A veteran of nearly 40 years at the United Nations, Blossom was born on Long Island, but moved to Manhattan at an early age, and lived there her entire life. She dearly loved Paris, Nantucket, and her mother's native Sweden. May she rest in peace, her memory forever secure in our hearts. Memorial Service will be private.

GARY--Shirley Spaulding, 93, passed away September 25 at Meadow Lakes, New Jersey. She was the Editor of Fashion Trades, the New York Fashion Industry Newspaper in the 1940s. Most recently, Mrs. Gary was a contributing author for the Braille Mirror, a publication of the Braille Institute, where she served on the Board of Directors. As a crusader for the blind, she followed the path of her father, Sir Neville Pearson, Bt. who served as President of St. Dunstan's for the War Blinded, UK. She was formerly married to Rutherford Hatch of New York - a member of the Vanderbilt family. Her husband of forty years, Wyndham Lewis Gary died in 1990 and was a New York lawyer and Member of the Board of J.P. Stevens and Company. She is survived by her son, Wyndham Bradford Gary of Palm Beach, Florida. A memorial service will be conducted at St. Georges by the River in Rumson, New Jersey on Friday, September 27, 2013.

Fontaine--John C. World Monuments Fund mourns the loss of John C. Fontaine, a wonderful champion of the arts who served as WMF's Secretary during an important period of the organization's growth. His leadership, support, and advice were invaluable. Our thoughts are with his family.

FONTAINE--John C. Hughes Hubbard & Reed mourns the passing of its esteemed former Managing Partner, John Clovis ("Jack") Fontaine. Jack's intellect and judgment made him an extraordinarily gifted lawyer and we are honored to have called him our partner. During his varied and productive career, he served in numerous notable positions including as a President of Knight-Ridder, Inc. and Chairman of the National Gallery of Art, the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and the Florida Philharmonic, and a Director of numerous corporate Boards. Jack remained a friend and trusted advisor until the end. We are grateful for the time we had with him and send our deepest condolences to his family.

EDELMAN--Melvin A. Died Thursday, September 19, 2013, at Cranbury Center, Monroe Township, NJ. He was 74. Born in the Bronx, NY, he resided in Queens, NY, before moving to South River, NJ in 1975. Prior to retiring in 2001, he was a printer for the New York Times, Manhattan, NY, where he worked for 31 years. A US Army veteran, Mr. Edelman served during peacetime. Surviving are his wife of 49 years, Erica Welches Edelman; his two sons, Todd and his wife Jennifer of Monroe Township, NJ, and Jay and his wife Karen of East Brunswick, NJ; a brother, David Edelman of Las Vegas, NV; and four grandchildren, Adam, Juliana, Elizabeth and Zachary. Funeral services were held Monday, September 23, 2013. Memorial contributions may be made to the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, Heart Center, One Robert Wood Johnson Place, New Brunswick, NJ 08903.

DASH--Robert Warren. It is with great sadness that the Board of the Madoo Conservancy announces the passing of Robert W. Dash, a poet of the New York School, a painter of the Long Island School, author and the creator of the internationally acclaimed Madoo Gardens, on September 14, 2013 at the age of 82. A memorial service will be held in the Spring. Contributions may be made to the Madoo Conservancy, PO Box 362, Sagaponack, NY 11962.

CASSIDY--Patricia Crawford, formerly of Stamford and Old Greenwich, CT, died on September 8, 2013 in Sonoma, CA. Beloved wife of 49 years to recently deceased John FK Cassidy. Mother to Anne Cassidy of Sonoma, CA, Sarah Cassidy of Duvall, WA, and John Cassidy of Westfield, NJ. Mother-in-law of Sam Turner, Luke Woodward and Rebecca Kelly. Grandmother of Grace, Jack, Lily, Maggie, Pearl, and Alice. Sister to Joan Crawford Daly of Rochester, NY and the late Edward Crawford, Elizabeth Crawford Connelly and Virginia Crawford Murphy. Graduate of Oswego High School and the College of New Rochelle. Before settling down to raise her family, Patty worked as a school social worker and teacher. Patty's famous smile, sparkle, and style will remain as inspiration for her family and friends. A service will be held in New York at 11am on Saturday, October 12th at the Central Park Conservatory North Garden. In lieu of gifts, please donate to Peace Action: http://bit.ly/19aWLXU.

ANSTENDIG--Howard S.,74, of White Plains NY, passed away peacefully, surrounded by family, on September 25th 2013. He is survived by loving wife, Linda, and devoted children, Mark (Jennifer) and Karin Mosk (Matthew). Adoring poppa to Samantha and Bennett, Ethan and Shane. Howard was an accomplished orthodontist; a valued teacher; an exceptional woodworker; and a top-notch golfer. He touched many lives, and he will be remembered for his strong and gentle spirit. Memorial services will be held at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home 491 Mamaroneck Ave. White Plains, NY 10605 (914) 949-7777 (mcmahonfh@optimum.net) on Sunday, September 29th at 10:30am. Donations may be made to the National Brain Tumor Society or Alpine Learning Group.
LANDRY--Susan died Sept 27, 2011. A rare Egomise New Orleans folk artist, largely unrecognized. View and Celebrate her life & work at www.ariodantegallery.com/ Susan--Landry.html
FONTANE--Paul Francis. Sept. 27, 1920- Oct 8, 1979. You left us too soon. Your love and light shine within us. Forever missed and loved.
BECKMAN--Cecille. Mom, Keep on whispering in my ear! I love you, Marcia
ZWEIBEL--Joel B. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Joel B. Zweibel, and send condolences to his family.

ZWEIBEL--Joel B.,beloved husband of Chrystine, father of Jane and Emily, stepfather of Todd and Jeff, grandfather of Nicolas, Gabriella, Sam, Alaina, and Elias, died at home Tuesday. An esteemed bankruptcy attorney and dedicated mentor to his beloved "mentees," Joel made a profound impact in this world. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Joel B. Zweibel Pre-Law Honors Scholarship/ Baruch College Fund, Box A1603, Baruch College, New York, NY 10010.

WECHSLER--Bernice, born May 23, 1924, died September 26, 2013. She loved her family, opera, classical music, art, literature, baseball and travel, especially to Israel. She enjoyed lively political conversation. She helped loved ones through difficulties and rejoiced in their victories. She handled adversity with grace right up until the very end. We will miss her. Graveside service at New Montefiore Cemetery, West Babylon, NY on Sunday, September 29 at 10:30am.

TARNOFF--Jeffrey, 66, of Steamboat Springs, CO and New York, NY passed away suddenly on Friday September 20 at home. A professional investment advisor, he worked for the past 11 years at the Winchester Group in New York, NY and for the previous 18 at Oppenheimer Capital, New York, NY. He graduated from Milford Academy, cum laude from Lehigh University and held an MBA from the University of Chicago. He was a member and past president of the Perry Mansfield Arts Camp board, a former trustee of the Pomfret School, the Town School and the Brownstone School. He was also a member of Lehigh University's School of Business Board of Advisors and the University of Chicago Booth School's Business Advisory Council. He leaves his wife, Diane Seaman Tarnoff, his daughter and son-in-law, Sarah and Todd Nelson, his mother, Betty, his brother Peter and his nephews Nicholas and Alexander. Donations in Jeff's name may be made to either Perry Mansfield or HFYV in care of Yampa Valley Funeral Home, POX 776090, Steamboat Springs, CO 80477.

SYRACUSE--Richard Michael, died at home in New Rochelle, NY, on Wednesday, September 25, 2013, of congestive heart failure. He is survived by his daughter, Maleyne, and her husband, Michael Trenner, of New York, NY and Milford, PA; his daughter, Andrea, and her husband, Randy Silverstein, of Pelham, NY; his son Richard and his wife, Rose, of Saugerties, NY; his daughter, Rina and her partner, Albert Monteleone, of New Rochelle, NY; and his grandchildren Sarah and Jason Silverstein, of Pelham, NY. He is also survived by his close friend, Ethel Cohen, his lifelong friends, Milton and Mae Kramer, and numerous nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Claire (nee Coppola) and his brothers, Joseph and Donald Syracuse. Family and Friends may call Sunday from 3pm to 7pm at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Pl., New Rochelle, NY 10801. A Funeral Service will be held Monday September 30, 2013 at 11:30am at the Funeral Home. Interment will follow with full Military Honors at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY

STUPNICK--Florence, passed away September 24, 2013 at age 100 years. She was the loving wife of Louis R. Stupnick (deceased) for 63 years. Both longtime residents of Great Neck and recently Manhattan. She will be greatly missed by her family. She was the beloved mother of Nancy, Lois and Nina and the adored mother-in-law to Jan, Albert and Lawrence. Florence will be greatly missed by her seven grandchildren Daniel, Nicholas, Rebeca, Sarah, Isabel, Amy and Brian and her 16 great-grandchildren. The family is grateful to Myra Chavez for the kindness and love she extended to their parents for the past 15 years.

SINDLER--Lillian F.,died September 13, 2013. Age 88. Beloved wife of Jerome L. Sindler and devoted mother of Tamra S. Carboni and Mark J. Sindler. Phi Beta Kappa Graduate of Hunter College. Frequent charitable contributor and, as an accomplished driver, drove many needy individuals to their medical appointments. She had a great love of the creative and performing arts which she instilled in her children, both of whom are Phi Beta Kappa college graduates and continue to work in the cultural sector.

MOHR--Lawrence J. (April 9, 1921 - September 26, 2013) of New York and Palm Beach. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. A man of many accomplishments and interests, including law, real estate and sculpture. Lawrence served in World War II and retired from the reserves as a Major. He is survived by his wife Madeline, his three children, Elizabeth Estrine, Susan Silverman and Andrew Mohr, and seven grandchildren, Jill, David and Billy Silverman, Amanda Estrine, and Rebecca, William and Edward Mohr. Shiva at 45 Sutton Place South.

GELLES--Carol Schrier, passed away at the age of 84 on Sunday, September 22 at Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle. Devoted wife of Walter, with whom she shared a rewarding 62 year marriage, loving mother of Robert (Diane) and Richard (Susan), nurturing grandmother of Andrew, Danny, Kevin and Thomas, loyal sister of the late Suzanne Heimerdinger, faithful sister-in-law of Edith Gelles (Michael Weiss), David (Pam) Gelles, Carol Gold Gelles (Henry Gelles, deceased), and John (Marilyn) Heimerdinger, and caring aunt of 12 nieces and nephews. During her lifetime, Carol touched many other lives with her warmth, generosity and love. In her role as homemaker, she was a wonderful wife and mom, and her passing is a tremendous loss to her husband and children. She was an excellent friend who valued the people in her life. She was an optimistic and creative person who always enjoyed learning and trying new things. She loved playing the music of Rodgers & Hart, Rodgers & Hammerstein, Frederic Chopin and Claude Debussy on her piano, reading the autobiographies of such people as Alec Guinness, Sonia Sotomayor and Marcia Davenport, and writing letters (and in more recent years, emails) to family and friends. We will all miss Carol very much. A funeral service is scheduled for Sunday, October 6 at 3pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Carol's memory can be made online to Temple Israel of New Rochelle, Temple Israel Cares Fund, by going to their website at http://tinr.org and following instructions.

David is survived by his wife, Michelle Summerlin, and their daughter Evangeline (Evy), both of Saratoga Springs; mother Joan Yergan of New Rochelle; brother Steven Yergan, currently from Connecticut; and sister Donna Yergan White (Charles) and their children, Justin and Jordan, of New York City. A memorial service will take place in the Theater Department at the end of the fall semester.

STIFEL--Henry George Jr.,85, of Vero Beach, FL and Jackson Hole, WY and formerly of Short Hills, NJ, died on September 18, 2013. "Hank," as his many friends and colleagues called him, lived a full life as a distinguished business executive, civic leader, philanthropist, Air Force veteran, and family man. Motivated by an automobile accident that left his seventeen-year-old son Henry G. Stifel III in a wheelchair in 1982, Hank dedicated much of his life thereafter leading efforts to find a cure for paralysis caused by spinal cord injury. Conventional wisdom at the time was that spinal cord injuries were permanent, and as a consequence there were very few researchers (or research dollars) in the field. Hank and his wife Charlotte refused to accept this supposition. With the help of friends and others who were touched by spinal cord injury, Hank founded and was President, CEO, and Chairman of the Stifel Paralysis Research Foundation (SPRF) whose mission was to raise funds and encourage research for a cure for paralysis and related neurological disorders. Several years later, Hank became Chairman and CEO of the American Paralysis Association (APA), into which he merged SPRF. In 1995 Christopher Reeve, the actor best known for his role as Superman, was paralyzed in a horse riding accident. Reeve reached out to Hank, and Chris and his wife Dana soon committed themselves to "the cure," subsequently joining the board of the APA. Shortly thereafter the APA was renamed the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation, Chris Reeve became Chairman, and Hank became Chairman Emeritus. With the Reeve Foundation as a leading fund raising organization, great strides in research have created therapies and treatments that have helped thousands of spinal cord injured victims regain function and dramatically improve their quality of life. There is now significant optimism that a cure is on the horizon. Hank was a successful business leader. In 1959 Hank became Vice President & General Manager of Xerox of Canada Ltd. where, under his eight years of leadership, Xerox grew dramatically. Hank subsequently joined Armotek Industries, Inc., Palmyra, NJ, in 1964, from which he retired in 1988 as CEO and Chairman. Under Hank's leadership, Armotek became a leading engraver for the gravure and flexographic printing industries. Hank also served on the boards of Titanium Industries, Inc. and Banker Securities Life Insurance Company. Hank Stifel was also a Founding Partner of the New York Islanders, an NHL hockey organization. Hank generously supported education, the arts and the environment. He served on the boards of The Pingry School, Martinsville, NJ and the Choate Rosemary Hall School, Wallingford, CT. In honor of their son, Hank and Charlotte established the Henry G. Stifel III Scholarship at Choate Rosemary Hall and The Pingry School, which is awarded to individuals who have overcome adversity and exhibited qualities of courage, endurance and optimism. Hank served on the boards of the Vero Beach Museum of Art, Vero Beach, FL and The National Museum of Wildlife Art, Jackson, WY. He also served on the board of the Indian River Land Trust, Vero Beach, FL. Hank was an avid golfer, skier, sportsman and traveler. Whether he was heli-skiing in Canada (at age 72), looking down from a hot air-balloon at the migration of the wildebeests in Kenya, pedaling a bike from vineyard to vineyard through Burgundy, hiking in the mountains of Nepal, or trekking through the deserts of Morocco on a camel, Hank was always on the go. His club memberships include the Princeton Club of New York, Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, NJ, the Short Hills Club, Short Hills, NJ, the Johns Island Club, Red Stick Golf Club, and Windsor Club, Vero Beach, FL, Ekwonok Country Club, Manchester, VT, and Teton Pines Country Club, Jackson, WY. He was a co-founder of the Bombay Bicycle and Ski Club. Hank attended the Choate School, Wallingford, CT. and was captain of its varsity basketball team. He graduated from Princeton University (Class of 1949) with a degree in Psychology. While at Princeton, he played varsity basketball, was advertising manager of the Nassau Sovereign, and was a member of the Elm Club. From 1951 to 1953 Hank enlisted in the Air Force and served as Lieutenant, Wheelus Air Base, Tripoli, Libya. Henry George Stifel, Jr. was born on December 15, 1927 to Henry G. Stifel, Sr., and Elizabeth P. Stevenson in Wheeling, WV. He is predeceased by his sister Elizabeth Stifel Kline. He is survived by his loving family: his wife, Charlotte Snead Stifel; three daughters, Wendy Hansen, Mountainside, NJ, Stephanie Coughlan, Wellesley, MA and Amy Quinn, Denver, CO; his son, Henry G. Stifel III, New York, NY; and nine grandchildren. The celebration of Hank's life will be held at Christ Church, 561 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ. The service will be Saturday, October 12th at 4pm. Relatives and friends are invited to visit with the family at the church on Friday, October 11th from 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm. Services are made by William A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham, NJ. For further information or to send a condolence, please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes.com. A memorial reception will be held at the Vero Beach Museum of Art, Vero Beach, FL on Friday, November 15 at 5pm. Contributions in memory of Henry Stifel can be made to the Vero Beach Museum of Art, 3001 Riverside Park Drive, Vero Beach, FL 32963 www.verobeachmuseum.org; or to the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation, 636 Morris Turnpike, Suite 3A, Short Hills, NJ 07078 (www.christopherreeve.org).

FONTAINE--John C. Hughes Hubbard & Reed mourns the passing of its esteemed former Managing Partner, John Clovis ("Jack") Fontaine. Jack's intellect and judgment made him an extraordinarily gifted lawyer and we are honored to have called him our partner. During his varied and productive career, he served in numerous notable positions including as a President of Knight-Ridder, Inc. and Chairman of the National Gallery of Art, the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and the Florida Philharmonic, and a Director of numerous corporate Boards. Jack remained a friend and trusted advisor until the end. We are grateful for the time we had with him and send our deepest condolences to his family.

FONTAINE--John C. The trustees and staff of the Samuel H. Kress Foundation mourn the passing of the Foundation's esteemed Chairman Emeritus, John Clovis ("Jack") Fontaine. With gentle wisdom and inspired leadership, Jack profoundly shaped the course of the Foundation's history over many years. His abiding contribution to the Foundation's mission is embodied in the endowed Kress-Fontaine fund for Scholarly Publications on European Works of Art in the Classical Tradition at the National Gallery of Art. Jack was committed to the highest standards of excellence in the arts, and in the course of his exemplary career, he also played leadership roles at the National Gallery of Art, the Salzburg Global Seminar, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, the Florida Philharmonic, and the law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed. Jack remained a trusted friend and advisor until the end. We are honored to have known him and send our deepest condolences to his family.

SUTLEY--Sara Alicia nee Mitlag. Born April 17, 1925 in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Died September 22, 2013 in Hillsborough, New Jersey. THORNHILL--Dorothy. Dorothy Margaret Thornhill, 89, died on September 24, 2013 after a long illness. Daughter of John and Margaret Matheis, Dorothy was the wife of Arthur Thornhill, Jr., and lived in Charlottesville, Virginia, Edgartown, Massachusetts, and Vera Beach, Florida. She graduated from the Dwight School for Girls in 1942, and attended Vassar College, class of 1945, leaving to marry Arthur during World War II. At that time she took a position as assistant teller at the New York Trust Co. After the war, she worked in the Princeton University Mathematics Department and at the Princeton College Board Company while her husband finished his education at Princeton. Over the years she was active as a member, and then President, of the Boston Vassar Club. She also was a docent at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, class of 1984. As her husband was the head of a book publishing company for many years, she entertained many of its authors, including Norman Mailer, Herman Wouk, Ansel Adams, Lillian Hellman, John Fowles, and Henry Kissinger. She was a member of the Chilton Club, the Edgartown Yacht Club, the John's Island Club, and the Farmington Country Club. She is survived by her husband, a daughter Sandra Brushart and her husband Dr. Thomas Brushart, a son Arthur Thornhill III and his wife Lucy Lower, as well as grandchildren Suzanne and Elizabeth Brushart and Henry and Hugh Thornhill. A memorial service will be held later in Duxbury, Massachusetts.

STUPNICK--Florence, passed away September 24, 2013 at age 100 years. She was the loving wife of Louis R. Stupnick (deceased) for 63 years. Both longtime residents of Great Neck and recently Manhattan. She will be greatly missed by her family. She was the beloved mother of Nancy, Lois and Nina and the adored mother-in-law to Jan, Albert and Lawrence. Florence will be greatly missed by her seven grandchildren Daniel, Nicholas, Rebeca, Sarah, Isabel, Amy and Brian and her 16 great-grandchildren. The family is grateful to Myra Chavez for the kindness and love she extended to their parents for the past 15 years.

STIFEL--Henry (Hank). The Board of Directors and staff of the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation express sadness at the loss of our founder, Henry G. Stifel. In 1982, Hank's only son suffered a devastating spinal cord injury and he and his wife Charlotte and their family and friends began the Stifel Paralysis Research Foundation. It grew into a national movement and several mergers later, became the Reeve Foundation. Hank served as its Chairman Emeritus until 2007. He was a pioneer at a time when spinal cord research was virtually nonexistent. Now, more than 30 years later, because of his vision and passion, the spinal cord community is on the cusp of effective therapies. We will remember Hank's wisdom, his wicked sense of humor and contagious smile, and his legacy will serve as inspiration for the Foundation. Our thoughts are with Charlotte and her family and in particular, Henry G. Stifel III, Vice Chairman of the Reeve board.

STIFEL--Henry George Jr.,85, of Vero Beach, FL and Jackson Hole, WY and formerly of Short Hills, NJ, died on September 18, 2013. "Hank," as his many friends and colleagues called him, lived a full life as a distinguished business executive, civic leader, philanthropist, Air Force veteran, and family man. Motivated by an automobile accident that left his seventeen-year-old son Henry G. Stifel III in a wheelchair in 1982, Hank dedicated much of his life thereafter leading efforts to find a cure for paralysis caused by spinal cord injury. Conventional wisdom at the time was that spinal cord injuries were permanent, and as a consequence there were very few researchers (or research dollars) in the field. Hank and his wife Charlotte refused to accept this supposition. With the help of friends and others who were touched by spinal cord injury, Hank founded and was President, CEO, and Chairman of the Stifel Paralysis Research Foundation (SPRF) whose mission was to raise funds and encourage research for a cure for paralysis and related neurological disorders. Several years later, Hank became Chairman and CEO of the American Paralysis Association (APA), into which he merged SPRF. In 1995 Christopher Reeve, the actor best known for his role as Superman, was paralyzed in a horse riding accident. Reeve reached out to Hank, and Chris and his wife Dana soon committed themselves to "the cure," subsequently joining the board of the APA. Shortly thereafter the APA was renamed the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation, Chris Reeve became Chairman, and Hank became Chairman Emeritus. With the Reeve Foundation as a leading fund raising organization, great strides in research have created therapies and treatments that have helped thousands of spinal cord injured victims regain function and dramatically improve their quality of life. There is now significant optimism that a cure is on the horizon. Hank was a successful business leader. In 1959 Hank became Vice President & General Manager of Xerox of Canada Ltd. where, under his eight years of leadership, Xerox grew dramatically. Hank subsequently joined Armotek Industries, Inc., Palmyra, NJ, in 1964, from which he retired in 1988 as CEO and Chairman. Under Hank's leadership, Armotek became a leading engraver for the gravure and flexographic printing industries. Hank also served on the boards of Titanium Industries, Inc. and Banker Securities Life Insurance Company. Hank Stifel was also a Founding Partner of the New York Islanders, an NHL hockey organization. Hank generously supported education, the arts and the environment. He served on the boards of The Pingry School, Martinsville, NJ and the Choate Rosemary Hall School, Wallingford, CT. In honor of their son, Hank and Charlotte established the Henry G. Stifel III Scholarship at Choate Rosemary Hall and The Pingry School, which is awarded to individuals who have overcome adversity and exhibited qualities of courage, endurance and optimism. Hank served on the boards of the Vero Beach Museum of Art, Vero Beach, FL and The National Museum of Wildlife Art, Jackson, WY. He also served on the board of the Indian River Land Trust, Vero Beach, FL. Hank was an avid golfer, skier, sportsman and traveler. Whether he was heli-skiing in Canada (at age 72), looking down from a hot air-balloon at the migration of the wildebeests in Kenya, pedaling a bike from vineyard to vineyard through Burgundy, hiking in the mountains of Nepal, or trekking through the deserts of Morocco on a camel, Hank was always on the go. His club memberships include the Princeton Club of New York, Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, NJ, the Short Hills Club, Short Hills, NJ, the Johns Island Club, Red Stick Golf Club, and Windsor Club, Vero Beach, FL, Ekwonok Country Club, Manchester, VT, and Teton Pines Country Club, Jackson, WY. He was a co-founder of the Bombay Bicycle and Ski Club. Hank attended the Choate School, Wallingford, CT. and was captain of its varsity basketball team. He graduated from Princeton University (Class of 1949) with a degree in Psychology. While at Princeton, he played varsity basketball, was advertising manager of the Nassau Sovereign, and was a member of the Elm Club. From 1951 to 1953 Hank enlisted in the Air Force and served as Lieutenant, Wheelus Air Base, Tripoli, Libya. Henry George Stifel, Jr. was born on December 15, 1927 to Henry G. Stifel, Sr., and Elizabeth P. Stevenson in Wheeling, WV. He is predeceased by his sister Elizabeth Stifel Kline. He is survived by his loving family: his wife, Charlotte Snead Stifel; three daughters, Wendy Hansen, Mountainside, NJ, Stephanie Coughlan, Wellesley, MA and Amy Quinn, Denver, CO; his son, Henry G. Stifel III, New York, NY; and nine grandchildren. The celebration of Hank's life will be held at Christ Church, 561 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ. The service will be Saturday, October 12th at 4pm. Relatives and friends are invited to visit with the family at the church on Friday, October 11th from 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm. Services are made by William A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham, NJ. For further information or to send a condolence, please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes.com. A memorial reception will be held at the Vero Beach Museum of Art, Vero Beach, FL on Friday, November 15 at 5pm. Contributions in memory of Henry Stifel can be made to the Vero Beach Museum of Art, 3001 Riverside Park Drive, Vero Beach, FL 32963 www.verobeachmuseum.org; or to the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation, 636 Morris Turnpike, Suite 3A, Short Hills, NJ 07078 (www.christopherreeve.org).

SPEAR--Harold Charles, MD. Harold Charles Spear, MD, was born on September 29, 1923 and died on August 29, 2013. His father, Harold Spear, was the founder of the New York Stock Exchange's specialist firm, Spear, Leeds, and Kellogg and he saw to it that Dr. Spear had a magical childhood. He grew up on a New Jersey farm called The Meadows which was dedicated to growing crops and poultry for the household and also had a stable of polo ponies which often were used in tournaments on the grounds of The Meadows and elsewhere. When Dr. Spear was age two, he went with his grandfather to Paris where he could remember putting his toy sailboat in the Grand Bassin located in the Bois de Boulogne along with other French children. When a little older, he traveled by yacht, again with his grandfather, down the Intracoastal Waterway from New Jersey to Miami, stayed at the Royal Poinciana Hotel in downtown Miami, then they went around the straits of Florida to Florida City. Later Dr. Spear attended Collegiate School in New York City, The Lawrenceville School in New Jersey, and then went on to Yale where he was in World War II's accelerated pre-medical school classes. He graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1947, married Suzanne Bowmall McLaury that same year, and had three children, Laurinda Hope Spear, Harold Charles (Tex) Spear, MD, and Alison Leelyn Spear. He interned at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City, then went on for residencies at Yale, Mayo Clinic, and finished them at Yale. Dr. Spear was taken into the United States Air Force as Chief of Surgery at Ellington Air Force Base in Houston, Texas. There he was joined as his Assistant Chief of Surgery by Paul S. Russell, MD, now the John Homans Distinguished Professor of Surgery at Harvard Medical School, then and until Dr. Spear's death, his best friend. While Dr. Spear was in Houston, in 1951 one of the country's most virulent polio epidemic swept through the city and his son, Tex, only six months old, contracted infantile paralysis as it then was called, which has left him handicapped until the present day. The Salk vaccine inoculations for children against polio were not available until 1954. Because of the responsibilities of raising a crippled child, Dr. Spear moved to Miami in 1956 where the warm climate and the availability of year round swimming would be an invaluable asset for his son. In Miami, Dr. Spear joined the city's first thoracic surgical partnership, DeWitt Daughtry, MD and John Chesney, MD, which soon was known as Daughtry, Chesney, Spear. They taught at the University of Miami School of Medicine and did experimental work during the early days of heart lung machines, heart transplants, and pace makers while continuing to have a busy private practice. Dr. Spear was an early proponent of the correlations between good health, exercise, and diet. He was vehemently against smoking long before the tenet became common knowledge. He exercised daily and was one of the first crack of dawn joggers in Miami Shores where he and his family lived, much to the consternation of his neighbors. Dedication was Dr. Spear's lode star. He was dedicated to his family, his patients, and to his profession, the practice of cardiothoracic and vascular surgery. He valued his association with other physicians and countless of them were his friends. Always Dr. Spear was honored when his medical peers came to him for treatment themselves, or sent him their families for surgery. Not only were they from Miami and other parts of Florida, at times they would come to him from other states. In his practice, never did he charge other physicians or their family members any fees. Most people have some sort of prejudices. Dr. Spear was a man with none. He saw the human spirit within each individual, the person sweeping the hospital floors was as important to him as the CEO of a large company. He never seemed rushed with people or his patients and he always was calm and soft spoken in the operating room. The only complaint operating room nurses ever made about him was that during operations, he talked mainly about one thing with his associates and residents, football. Football was his delight. Dr. Spear has written a memoir about the early days of cardiac, thoracic, and vascular surgery at Harvard, Yale, and Mayo Clinic, and at the start of his career during the early days when Miami was a quiet Southern town, which will be published in the near future. Some of his early Miami adventures included practicing in about ten hospitals, occasionally he would mention them to his family and friends just as a matter of fact, always modestly, he had to cover them all. Before the I-95 expressway was built, Dr. Spear faced the challenge of reaching the hospitals often by back roads, at times in the dark, because as a specialist, he was on call for many emergency rooms. He would say, "Between midnight and 4:00am, that's when there's trouble." Yet he never complained about getting up around 2:00am after a long day in surgery, getting dressed in a suit, shirt, and tie, then driving alone through the night in response to the call. Truly, Dr. Spear was a man for others. A private celebration of Dr. Spear's life was held on September 7, 2013. He is survived by his wife, Suzanne Bowmall McLaury Spear, daughters, Laurinda Hope Spear, Alison Leelyn Spear, sister, Nancy Rossbach and family, a son, Harold Charles Spear Ill, MD, sons-in-law, Bernardo Fort-Brescia, Alexander Stevens Reese, grandchildren, Marisa Rose Fort, Alexander Charles Paul Fort, Nicholas McLaury Fort, Raymond August Fort, Harold Emil Fort, Gabriel Bernard Fort, Leslie Caylin Spear, Harold Arthur Spear, Charlotte Rosalind Spear, Jeremy Acheson Spear Platt, Carolina Clare Spear Gomez, Isabella Clementine Bliss Reese and great-grandchildren Gil Spear and Emilia Hope Adams.

SOLOMON--Ruth. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our beloved Ruth on September 27. She was born on July 26, 1931 to Sarah and Jacob Rubin. She and her brother were raised by her aunt Gittel and uncle Morris, who treated them like their own children. She was the devoted wife of Irwin, who was the love of her life. She was the beloved brother of Burton. She was the doting mother of Joel, Jonathan, Steven, Emily and Karen. She was the adoring grandmother of Erica, Isabelle, Sarah and Jake. She was the loving aunt of Ellen, Nina and Anne. She was close with her cousins Betty, Ruth, Buddy and Florence. Ruth was the center of our family. She was warm and unconditionally loving, with a famous sense of humor. The bravery, optimism and humor that she displayed in her battle with lung cancer will be an inspiration to her friends and family.

Mohrman--Arthur J.,91, with a keen mind and aware of his family's love, passed peacefully on August 31, 2013. MEYNARD--Michel Jean, of Weston on September 21, 2013. He was the beloved husband of Arlette of which he spent 50 years. Devoted father of Philippe and his wife Lee. His passion for life, speed and design impacted everyone who crossed his path. In lieu of flowers anybody who wishes to do so may make donation to: (wspa-usa.org).

McKINNON--Diane Kay, born September 27th, 1963 in Calgary, Alberta Canada. After a long and courageous battle, Diane succumbed to complications from cancer on September 13, 2013 at home in Austin, Texas surrounded by her loving family and friends. A graduate of The Kinkaid School in Houston, The University of Virginia at Charlottesville and The Parsons School of Design in New York City, Diane enjoyed a successful and creative career in film production, media and advertising. Diane embraced her life and friends to the fullest. Her curiosity was boundless and her sense of humor a joy to us all. Preceded in death by her beloved father Murray, Diane is survived by her mother Jan of La Jolla, CA, her sister Caroline and brother Douglas of Denver, CO. To those friends who were able to visit Diane thank you again for coming together to remind us of how special our beloved Diane has been to so many people. You all made Diane's life so rich and exciting we are forever grateful. As Diane wished, her ashes will be offered to the Pacific Ocean at La Jolla, California following a family service. A celebration of Diane's life will be held in Austin, Texas later this fall. Contributions in Diane's name to the Breast Cancer Research Center of Austin www.bcrc.org would be most welcome.Audentes Fortuna Juvat

MARKS--Edwina Hilton. Born 1933. Lived her entire life along the South Shore of Long Island, always close to the ocean, and in later years had a romance with Manhattan. Edwina was the devoted daughter of Ruth and Ed Simon of Long Beach, NY, loving mother of Bonnie and Elyse, who both made her so very proud; wife of Marvin; gramma of Shulian; and best friend of Honey, Daisy and Dorothy. Her working days took her from Haitian Art to Edlaw Pharmaceuticals, where she became a gutsy entrepreneur, and a generous and caring employer. She often said that she was very content, had enjoyed her life to the fullest, had done all that she wanted, and seen everywhere in the world that she wanted to go. Edwina was known for her joie-de-vivre, optimistic outlook, love of humor and complete honesty. She was politically aware, an active patron of the Arts and the Theater, and attributed her long life to the skill of MSKCC and Mt Sinai, where contributions in her memory can be sent.

LEISURE--Peter K.,84, loving father and devoted husband, passed away on September 17, 2013. Former Federal Judge of the Southern District of New York, Judge Leisure is survived by his beloved wife, Kathleen, his daughters, Kathleen and Blair, and his Grandson, Ted. Memorial service will take place at 12pm on Friday, November 8 at St. James Church, NYC.

KUNZ--Gail Thea (Hyms), Of Bonita Springs, FL and New York City. Beloved wife, life companion and best friend of her husband John for nearly 55 years, passed peacefully on Monday, Sept- ember 23, 2013 with her full family by her side. Gail was the loving mother of Gregg and Scott and a generous and loving "Gigi" to her four grandchildren: Torie, Belle, Jimmie and Anna. Gail was the epitome of the 20th Century woman: Independent, beautiful, always stylish, intelligent, loyal, self-confident, kind, considerate and a world traveler. She was never demanding yet always available and loyal to her many friends. Gail was a close friend of many women across the United States, including Marguerite, Tracey, Carol, Bonnie, Jo Anne, Jenny, Barbara, Deborah, Linda, Mona, Karen, Jean, Myrna, Leslie, Jeannie, Barbie, Alina and Catherine. She prided herself as a person who never broke a confidence. Gail enjoyed the company of men, but women were her closest buddies because "women always stand up and support each other!" She had a remarkable memory and a great sense of humor. She was a born New Yorker and enjoyed everything the City had to offer. She loved travel, music, dancing, skiing, fishing, cooking, mah jong, home entertaining, sports, (particularly, the New Jersey Devils) a nice tall vodka with a slice of orange ("chilled and straight up please!") and, most all, she loved life! When frequently asked why she and John were "always on the go so much;" she always answered "We run because we still CAN!" and "I want to be remembered as a person who lived a full life - so I am doing it!" She was the "complete package" as a wife, mother, and friend and was loved by many. A "Celebration of Life" get together will be arranged to be held in New York City in the spring of 2014. In lieu of flowers, for those who desire, donations may be made in Gail's memory to Hope Hospice, Bonita Springs, FL.

KRAMER--Claire B.,91, of Scottsdale, AZ, formerly of Sands Point, NY. Loving and devoted wife of 63 years to Allan Kramer, also of Scottsdale, who survives her. Mother of Richard Louis Kramer, James Kramer and Louise Kramer, mother-in-law of Joanne King Kramer and grandmother of Gordon Kramer and Brenda Kramer. Daughter of Louis and Katharine Block, sister of the late Herbert and Bertram Block. Claire was active in her community. A graduate of Mills College, with an MA in Early Childhood Education from New York University, she supported numerous Head Start and pre-kindergarten programs as a board member and director. She was president of Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, and a longtime board member of Planned Parenthood of Central and Northern Arizona. She loved the arts, and instilled that love in her children. Services will be private. Contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood of Central and Northern Arizona or The Mayo Clinic 2013 Arizona Drive to Cure Cancer.

KAPRIELIAN--Walter, former Chairman & Creative Director of Kaprielian O'Leary Advertising, died on September 5, 2013, at his home in East Hampton. He was 79 years old. A talented graphic designer, creative director and a nurturing teacher, he began his career at BBD&O, held senior positions at Grey Advertising and Ketchum McLeod & Grove, later Ketchum International as CEO, New York. He created campaigns for accounts like Air France, Olivetti, Westinghouse, Japan Air Lines, New York Air, New York Waterways, Air Jamaica, Cayman Airways, the Cayman Islands, and won numerous awards for his outstanding work. He was also consultant to the marketing team at Newthynk, NY. Born to Armenian immigrants who escaped the 1915 massacres, he grew up in the Bronx, worked his way through art school at CUNY's City-Tech, Brooklyn, taught advertising and graphic arts at his Alma Mater and served on its Foundation Board. A past-President and longtime member of the Art Directors' Club of NY, Kaprielian was an avid fisherman and licensed charter boat captain, linking with other enthusiasts at Bertram31.com. He authored and illustrated the popular The Captain's Cookbook, now in its fourth printing. His first wife Julia, nee Hachigian, died in 1983. He is survived by his second wife of 25 years, Dinaz Boga Kaprielian, three children, Dr. Victoria Kaprielian Luis, Siran Pirani and John Kaprielian, and four grandsons, Alex and Steven Pirani, Joseph Luis and David Kaprielian. Services were held at the Armenian Church of the Holy Martyrs, Bayside. Memorial donations to Southampton Hospital Foundation, 240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968.

IRWIN--John MacPherson 1925 2013, peacefully passed away in Ottawa on Friday, September 20, 2013 at the age of 88 following a protracted struggle with Alzheimer's. Beloved husband of the late Patricia Owen Irwin (nee Heighington) and, with his first wife, Joan Irwin, father of Jennifer Irwin (Edison Hopkinson) and Sarah Irwin (Mark Everard) and grandfather of Keegan Hopkinson. Predeceased by his sister Jill Metivier. "Irwin," as he was known to many friends, was a proud University of Toronto Trinity College graduate and alumni. He started his career as a research chemist for Imperial Oil. In 1966, he moved to Manhattan to join Exxon Corporation where he became Manager of Corporate Advertising which took him all over the world as senior producer of their corporate film program. Later, as Senior Advisor Public Affairs, he was instrumental in developing the "Great Performances" series for PBS and orchestrated the corporate sponsorship of many cultural initiatives such as Twyla Tharp's Dance in America. For 30 years he and his wife, Trish, shared their enjoyment of travel, the arts, theatre, books, the New York Times crossword puzzles, as well as the company of their extended family and good friends while dividing their time between Manhattan, East Hampton, Toronto, and Muskoka Lake. He will be remembered for his rapier wit, puns, feisty temperament, and sartorial panache. Those wishing to remember him are invited to make a memorial donation to the Alzheimer's Society of Canada at www.alzheimer.ca. Condolences may be left at condolences@ WhelanFuneralHome.ca.

ILLMAN--Dr. Arnold M, 79, of Massapequa, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, on September 20, in New York. A graduate of Boston Latin School, Harvard University and Boston University Medical School, Illman was a board certified orthopedic surgeon; he completed surgical residencies at Boston City Hospital, Shriners, BU Medical Center and Lahey Clinic. Dr. Illman practiced and taught orthopedic surgery on Long Island since 1967; he pioneered the procedure of arthroscopic surgery. Until recently, he had served ISOD and the International Paralympic Committee, traveling worldwide to support disabled athletes since the 1980's. Dr. Illman served on the New York State Sports Commission. For over four decades, Illman served with great dedication on the schools committee of the Harvard Club of Long Island.
HUGHEY--Janet E.,age 83, on September 2. Mother of four, grandmother of four, friend of countless many. We miss your loving embrace, mischievous smile, and passion for New York.

HAINS--Alvin Markham. January 30, 1934 - September 11, 2013. The beloved husband of Ellen Cowan-Hains passed away on September 11, 2013. Al was born in 1934 in Topeka, KS and relocated as a youngster with his family to the Los Angeles area. In addition to his wife Ellen, he is survived by his daughters Christina (Hains) Hankwitz and her husband Rev. Robert Hankwitz, granddaughters Analise and Alyson Hankwitz, daughter Cindy Hains as well as his adored mother-in-law, Lillian S. Cowan. He also leaves many nieces, nephews, and friends who will forever miss him. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to The Gethsemane Evangelical Lutheran Church, 3734 S. Centinella Bl., Los Angeles, or The America Cancer Society, or The American Heart Association.

GUPTA--Aileen Sein, 49, passed away on August 28, 2013 peacefully in her home, surrounded by her loving family after her year and a half long battle with cancer. She is survived by her husband Jay Gupta, her 18-month old twins: son Anakin and daughter Kenley, her son Justin Diaz, her brother Louis Sein and her parents Alixa and Luis Sein. A memorial service will be held at The Unitarian Church of All Souls; 1157 Lexington Ave., NYC, October 5, 1pm. Visit Aileen's online memorial: aileen.gupta.muchloved.com.

GREENE--Joseph F.,of Bronxville on September, 26, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Joan P. Greene, loving father of Christine and Mary Alice (William) O'Connell, grandfather of Thomas and Alice, brother of Dorothy McKelvey and Joan Callahan. Joe retired as Senior Vice President of Sales at 20th Century Fox Television. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGarth & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 3 to 5pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday September 30 at 10am.

GOLDBERG--Myron H.,of New York, NY, passed away on September 27, 2013. Mike was the beloved husband of Norma Goldberg and uncle to Elyssa B. Margolis. He was a former Professor and Chairman of the School of Computer Science and Information Systems (Graduate and Undergraduate) at Pace University, New York City for nearly 30 years and member of IBM's technical support team for the first Manned Spaceflight Programs, among many other accomplishments. Memorial contributions may be made to Charlestown Scholars' Fund, 707 Maiden Choice Lane, Catonsville, MD 21228 or the Baltimore Museum of Art. Condolences at: hubbardfuneralhome.com.

FONTAINE--John C. Hughes Hubbard & Reed mourns the passing of its esteemed former Managing Partner, John Clovis ("Jack") Fontaine. Jack's intellect and judgment made him an extraordinarily gifted lawyer and we are honored to have called him our partner. During his varied and productive career, he served in numerous notable positions including as a President of Knight-Ridder, Inc. and Chairman of the National Gallery of Art, the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and the Florida Philharmonic, and a Director of numerous corporate Boards. Jack remained a friend and trusted advisor until the end. We are grateful for the time we had with him and send our deepest condolences to his family.

FONTAINE--John C. The trustees and staff of the Samuel H. Kress Foundation mourn the passing of the Foundation's esteemed Chairman Emeritus, John Clovis ("Jack") Fontaine. With gentle wisdom and inspired leadership, Jack profoundly shaped the course of the Foundation's history over many years. His abiding contribution to the Foundation's mission is embodied in the endowed Kress-Fontaine fund for Scholarly Publications on European Works of Art in the Classical Tradition at the National Gallery of Art. Jack was committed to the highest standards of excellence in the arts, and in the course of his exemplary career, he also played leadership roles at the National Gallery of Art, the Salzburg Global Seminar, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, the Florida Philharmonic, and the law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed. Jack remained a trusted friend and advisor until the end. We are honored to have known him and send our deepest condolences to his family.

FISHMAN--Roy H. 91, passed away September 15, 2013, in Scottsdale, AZ. VP of Public Relations Standard Brands and Nabisco. Survived by his wife Geraldine Robins Fishman, daughter Nancy Leopold, son Jed Fishman; four grandchildren; four great-grandchildren.

EDELMANN--Chester (Chet) Monroe, Jr.,MD, 82, born in New York December 26, 1930 died on September, 19, 2013, after a courageous four year battle with cancer, Chester passed away peacefully at home with his family in attendance. Chet was an exceptional father, renowned physician, research scientist, and, most of all, husband. During his 57 year tenure at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine (AECOM,) he held many prestigious positions, including Senior Associate Dean and Most Distinguished University Professor of Pediatrics. Chet was the recipient of innumerable scientific awards and made tremendous academic contributions to medicine. He authored 43 scientific abstracts and was a member of 25 national and international medical societies. He received his BA from Columbia University in 1951 and his MD degree from Cornell University. He completed his residency in Pediatrics as Chief Resident at BMHC. Chet is survived by his adoring wife of 60 years, Norma, three loving children: John, Christopher, and Kathy and his granddaughter, Jessica, he is also survived by his sister, Maida Heitner. Chet was a true Renaissance man; a lover of languages and their usage: a concert level pianist; a faithful patron of opera, the theatre and the philharmonic. He created fine furniture, was a loyal Mets fan, and enjoyed simple beauty. He was devoted to his wife and family, his patients, his church, science, his community and his country. He believed in excellence, honesty, integrity and above all, compassion. Chet was a rare man, contemplative, yet effective, who quietly found success in the improved health of his patients, in the happiness of his children and in the achievement of his students and colleagues. Chet touched the lives of countless people in many countries worldwide and will be missed by all, but primarily by his wife and children. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, all donations be sent to the following charities: Concordia College, Greenwich Hospital Oncology Unit, and the Sierra Club. A memorial service will be held on Saturday October 5, 2013 at 10:00am at the Sommer Center of Concordia College in Bronxville, NY. For a complete biography visit www.mcgrathandson.com.

DIMANCESCU--Joan E.,1945-2013. Born in Manhattan on March 2nd, 1945, Joan Dimancescu was a life-long resident of the Upper East Side. She left a rich legacy of love, friendship, caring, happiness and love of life amongst her family, many friends and colleagues. She graduated from the Lycee Francais of New York and received her BA from Hunter College. She obtained an MA in learning disabilities from Columbia Teachers' College and went on to receive a MPh in French Literature from Yale University. She became a talented Learning Specialist, consulting at The Collegiate School for Boys, The Spence School, then going on to become an accomplished Middle School Head at the French-American International School in San Francisco, and then Head of the Bilingual French-American School in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Upon her return to New York City, she became a passionate teacher of private students in English Composition, French, Spanish, Latin and History. She was a generous contributor to several charities, including the Young Concert Artists of New York and the French Heritage Language Program. At the age of 68, she died in her sleep on September 20th, 2013. A loving and caring wife and mother, she is survived by her husband Mihai, two sons Stefan and Marc-Mihai, and two granddaughters Madison and Victoria-Joan.

DAVIS--Henrietta Ueberall, 95, entered into rest on September 16, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Albert Davis. Loving daughter of Ethel and Ben Ueberall and sister of Eleanor Schrager. Dear mother of Larry Davis, Middleburg, VA. Proud grandmother of Richard and Denise Davis, Jonathan and Patty Davis and great-grandmother of Jack, Danielle, William and Max of Port Washington, NY. The family wishes to extend their gratitude to Arlean Fletcher who made her later years so comfortable. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Henrietta's memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County www.hpbcf.org, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, Florida, 33407.

DASH--Robert Warren. It is with great sadness that the Board of the Madoo Conservancy announces the passing of Robert W. Dash, a poet of the New York School, a painter of the Long Island School, author and the creator of the internationally acclaimed Madoo Gardens, on September 14, 2013 at the age of 82. A memorial service will be held in the Spring. Contributions may be made to the Madoo Conservancy, PO Box 362, Sagaponack, NY 11962.

COOPER--Margarett Gillespie, died peacefully on September 20, 2013 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was born in Ohio on October 15, 1913, to Ella and Isaac Nathaniel Gillespie and was the youngest among Isaac Jr., Constance and Paul. Margarett took her father's love of books and her own delight in people to Wilberforce College where she was both a stellar student and a homecoming queen. Her mentor, the college librarian, was a force for intellectual and professional ambition, and Margarett graduated in 1937 with a determination to pursue graduate study in library science. When depression era scarcity delayed Margarett's studies, she taught for two years in a WPA nursery school. She subsequently earned a Masters in library science at Hampton University and pursued additional graduate study at Columbia University. She worked as a children's librarian in Virginia, and Ohio, inspiring growth and hope in countless young people. While at Hampton University, Margarett met and fell in love with a dashing young undergraduate, George Clinton Cooper. Their marriage in 1939 lasted until his death in 2002. George was a member of the "Golden Thirteen," the first African American officers in the United States Navy. He subsequently headed the trade school at Hampton, after which the couple moved to Ohio where George continued to work in education and urban administration. After her husband's death, Margarett moved to New York, a city she had always loved. Margarett thrived on New York's intellectual richness and quickly gathered friends across its multiple cultures. A painstaking genealogist, she discovered a family history of slave resistance and proud emancipation. An ardent fan of jazz and classical music, she was, at age 97, a savvy guest host on WBGO Jazz Radio. (To see a photo and listen to the broadcast visit http://www.wbgo.org/ blog/margaret-cooper-host-hour.) Margarett was an enthusiastic supporter and goading advisor to all the people she loved. She is survived by a daughter, Peggy Cooper Davis, a son-in-law, Gordon J. Davis, a granddaughter, Elizabeth Cooper Davis, a great- grandson, Johari Cooper Davis Moses and a large and adoring circle of extended family and friends. Margarett was a generous, sharp-witted, politically passionate and spirited force throughout her 100 years. We celebrate her life even as we suffer her loss. Friends are encouraged to honor her memory with commitment to social justice. She would also be honored by gifts to the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, the Center for Family Representation, Jazz at Lincoln Center or the Studio Museum of Harlem.

CONANT--Herbert Davenport, February 24, 1924 - September 24, 2013. Herb died at his home in Cape Coral, FL after a long, valiant struggle with kidney failure. He was 89. Born in Troy, New York to Herbert S. Conant and Grace Davenport, he grew up in Bergen County, NJ, where he had been the captain of his football team, an Eagle Scout and later, scout troop leader. Fresh out of high school he became a Marine, serving in the South Pacific theatre of World War ll where he earned two Purple Hearts. Upon receiving his degree in Mechanical Engineering from Stevens Institute of Technology in 1950, Herb joined Turner Construction Company, which proved to be the start of a remarkable lifelong career. Beginning at line-and-grade, Herb rose to become President, CEO and Chairman of the Turner Corporation, his positions at retirement. Along the way, he opened Turner's Cleveland office becoming responsible for much of that city's skyline today. As someone who lived fully, Herb was an avid boater, fisherman and scuba diver as well as world traveler with his devoted wife and constant companion of 26 years, Carolyn. He is survived by his wife, Carolyn, and three children from his first marriage and their spouses: Kerry Kelso and her husband Dave, David Conant, and Muriel Garvey and her husband, Greg. His daughter Martha Brailsford predeceased him. He adopted his daughter Michelle Kenton during his second marriage. He will be missed by his grandchildren, Amanda, Cassandra, Jordan, Davey, Michael, Mathew and Malcolm. Herb will be remembered for and will continue to inspire his loved ones by his profound strength of character, keen intellect and zest for life. A remembrance will be held on November 27th in Cape Coral for family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Southwest Florida Community Foundation, 8771 College Pkwy., Suite 201 Ft. Myers, FL 33919 or online at: floridacommunity.com/give To leave online condolences, please visit www.fullermetz.com

CLEMENTS--Mark, passed away on September 26, 2013, two days shy of his 92nd birthday. A native of New York City and proud graduate of City College of New York, he was founder of Mark Clements Research, Inc. which had offices at 516 Fifth Avenue for almost 50 years. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Estelle, and his two children Stephanie and Dan. Also surviving are four grandchildren, Alana, Lissa, Amy and Dylan and two great-grandsons, Reiter and Connor. Memorials may be sent to City College Fund, Mark & Estelle Clements Scholarship Fund, 160 Convent Avenue, Shepard Hall, Rm. 166, New York, NY 10031.

CASSIDY--Patricia Crawford, formerly of Stamford and Old Greenwich, CT, died on September 8, 2013 in Sonoma, CA. Beloved wife of 49 years to recently deceased John FK Cassidy. Mother to Anne Cassidy of Sonoma, CA, Sarah Cassidy of Duvall, WA, and John Cassidy of Westfield, NJ. Mother-in-law of Sam Turner, Luke Woodward and Rebecca Kelly. Grandmother of Grace, Jack, Lily, Maggie, Pearl, and Alice. Sister to Joan Crawford Daly of Rochester, NY and the late Edward Crawford, Elizabeth Crawford Connelly and Virginia Crawford Murphy. Graduate of Oswego High School and the College of New Rochelle. Before settling down to raise her family, Patty worked as a school social worker and teacher. Patty's famous smile, sparkle, and style will remain as inspiration for her family and friends. A service will be held in New York at 11am on Saturday, October 12th at the Central Park Conservatory North Garden. In lieu of gifts, please donate to Peace Action: http://bit.ly/19aWLXU.

BUCKLEY--Hon. John T. Services were held for Hon. John T. Buckley who died September 24, 2013, aged 77. He is survived by his wife, Blanche; children Loretta and Jack; and grandchildren, Lucy and Declan. Devoted to his family, his Roman Catholic faith and his friends. Justice Buckley retired in 2010 from the New York State Appellate Division First Department, Manhattan and Bronx, having served as its Presiding Justice from 2003 2007.

BLANCO--Osvaldo Joseph, fiction writer and translator in Buenos Aires, Argentina, medical copywriter and translator for Sterling Drug, Inc. on Park Avenue, NYC from 1967-1994, active member of the American Translators Association, freelance narrator for film and radio, freelance translator of over 35 children's books, contributing author of Green Force Five, a King Features Syndicate comic strip, and Assistant Professor of Medical Translation at New York University (NYU), died on Tuesday, September 24th in Great Neck, NY. He was 83 years old. The cause of death was complications of kidney failure. Osvaldo J. Blanco, was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina on October 25, 1929 to Manuel and Preciosa Blanco who had migrated to Argentina from Spain in the 1920's. On November 21, 1960, he married his present wife, Michelle Blanco, PhD, and flew with her to New York City where they started their married life together. They became American citizens in 1970. Osvaldo Blanco graduated from Queens College in 1979 with a Bachelor's of Arts Degree in Communication Arts and Sciences. His interests included classical music, literature, theater, and poetry. He was most often described as an intellectual with a strong belief in the importance of family values. Osvaldo Blanco's wife of 53 years survives him, as do his daughter and son, Sandra M. Halvorsen and Edgar A. Blanco, and grandson, Daniel Joseph Blanco. In lieu of flowers the family gratefully requests that donations be made to Carey Dad's Club Music Fund, H. Frank Carey High School, Attn: Robert Cassara, 230 Poppy Ave, Franklin Square, NY 11010.

BEARY--Marie A.,90, of Highland Beach, FL, former Assistant New York State Attorney General and pioneering woman lawyer, passed away on September 25. Daughter of Italian immigrants, she overcame discrimination against both her gender and ethnicity to rise to a top legal position in New York State. Mrs. Beary graduated cum laude from St. John's University, New York, Law School in 1944, into a profession that accepted women as legal secretaries but not attorneys. In the 1950s, her keen interest in politics led her to the local Democratic club. Denied full membership, she turned to the Republicans, the minority party in Queens, NY, where she then lived, establishing a lifelong party loyalty, which included several campaigns for elected office. After serving as president of the Queens Women's Bar Association, in 1960, she filed suit against the Queens Bar Association, which had denied her membership, ending an 84-year ban against women members. She was the youngest woman of her time admitted to practice before the U.S. Supreme Court. In 1964, Mrs. Beary was appointed Assistant New York State Attorney General, heading litigation in its bureau of mental hygiene. She retired from the state in 1988 and moved to Florida with her husband, Patrick Beary. In 1976, Mrs. Beary received the first Woman of the Year award from St. John's University Law School and the University's President's medal in 1994. She also received commendation from the National Association of Women Lawyers for her advancement of women's rights and was nominated to the Women's Hall of Fame. Mrs. Beary is survived by her daughters Patricia, an attorney in Glendale, AZ, and Roberta of Bethesda, MD, a haiku poet and attorney; and sons, Kevin, a professor of English at the University of Florence, and David, a retired New York City captain of detectives, currently serving with the Raleigh-Durham Airport police. She also leaves eleven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Her husband of 58 years, Patrick Beary, KM, died in 2005. Viewing will be held from 9am to 11am, Friday, October 4, 2013 at Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, 745 N.E. 6th Ave., Delray Beach, Florida, followed by a funeral mass at 11:30am at St. Lucy's Catholic Church, 3510 S. Ocean Blvd., Highland Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to St. John's University, New York, School of Law.

BARKIN--Elaine Rappaport, June 14, 1913 September 21, 2013. An extraordinary and courageous woman of enormous spirit, died at the age of 100 on September 21, 2013 in Hadley, MA. Born in Brooklyn, NY on June 14, 1913 and schooled in Brooklyn at the Adelphi Academy, she graduated from Smith College in 1933 and earned her Master's in Social Work in 1935 from the Smith College School for Social Work. She worked at the Jewish Board of Guardians (JBG) where, in 1942, she job-shared her work on delinquency and family problems, and also represented the New York Jewish agencies in the court system. After leaving the JBG, she worked for the Child Adoption Committee. Later, she focused on career counseling, psychotherapy, and then geriatric services. She was appointed to boards that looked at the needs of elders throughout Massachusetts, including one at the University of Massachusetts Medical School. She served on the first board of the Franklin County Home Care for 25 years and represented her community during this time. In addition, she was appointed by the Governor of Massachusetts to be one of six national Ombudsman on the Board of Registration of Nursing Home Administrators, a position she held for a number of years. She married Solomon Barkin in 1940, a prominent labor economist, and enjoyed his companionship for almost 60 years. The family lived in Manhattan, Great Neck, NY, and Paris, France, where her husband was in the diplomatic corps assigned to the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). The family returned to live in Leverett, MA where her husband had a tenured professorship in the Economics Department at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. Survivors include her three children, David, Roger, and Amy and three grandsons, Adam, Michael and Benjamin, two great-grandsons, Jacob and Eli, and a large circle of friends. Elaine was a feisty, dedicated, socially active and colorful woman who remained mentally alert until her death. She had a life-long love of learning and appetite for life. Up until her last days she took courses in the local Five College 'Learning in Retirement' program. She was a lover of opera, music, theatre, bridge, gourmet cooking, reading and travel. She will be remembered as a deeply loving mother, a generous and devoted friend and confidant, a 'bon vivant', an extraordinary listener and advisor to the young (and not so young), a hostess, an eternal optimist, a 'raconteuse extraordinaire', and a role model for graceful aging! She was a kind and selfless person, beloved by all she met. She brightened the lives of those she touched and left footprints on our hearts, and we will never be the same. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: The Franklin County Home Care Corporation, Roseann Martoccia, Executive Director, 330 Montague City Road, Suite 1, Turners Falls, MA 01376. www.fchcc.org, 413-773-5555. A memorial service will be held in the near future.
