SPEAR--Harold Charles, MD. Harold Charles Spear, MD, was born on September 29, 1923 and died on August 29, 2013. His father, Harold Spear, was the founder of the New York Stock Exchange's specialist firm, Spear, Leeds, and Kellogg and he saw to it that Dr. Spear had a magical childhood. He grew up on a New Jersey farm called The Meadows which was dedicated to growing crops and poultry for the household and also had a stable of polo ponies which often were used in tournaments on the grounds of The Meadows and elsewhere. When Dr. Spear was age two, he went with his grandfather to Paris where he could remember putting his toy sailboat in the Grand Bassin located in the Bois de Boulogne along with other French children. When a little older, he traveled by yacht, again with his grandfather, down the Intracoastal Waterway from New Jersey to Miami, stayed at the Royal Poinciana Hotel in downtown Miami, then they went around the straits of Florida to Florida City. Later Dr. Spear attended Collegiate School in New York City, The Lawrenceville School in New Jersey, and then went on to Yale where he was in World War II's accelerated pre-medical school classes. He graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1947, married Suzanne Bowmall McLaury that same year, and had three children, Laurinda Hope Spear, Harold Charles (Tex) Spear, MD, and Alison Leelyn Spear. He interned at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City, then went on for residencies at Yale, Mayo Clinic, and finished them at Yale. Dr. Spear was taken into the United States Air Force as Chief of Surgery at Ellington Air Force Base in Houston, Texas. There he was joined as his Assistant Chief of Surgery by Paul S. Russell, MD, now the John Homans Distinguished Professor of Surgery at Harvard Medical School, then and until Dr. Spear's death, his best friend. While Dr. Spear was in Houston, in 1951 one of the country's most virulent polio epidemic swept through the city and his son, Tex, only six months old, contracted infantile paralysis as it then was called, which has left him handicapped until the present day. The Salk vaccine inoculations for children against polio were not available until 1954. Because of the responsibilities of raising a crippled child, Dr. Spear moved to Miami in 1956 where the warm climate and the availability of year round swimming would be an invaluable asset for his son. In Miami, Dr. Spear joined the city's first thoracic surgical partnership, DeWitt Daughtry, MD and John Chesney, MD, which soon was known as Daughtry, Chesney, Spear. They taught at the University of Miami School of Medicine and did experimental work during the early days of heart lung machines, heart transplants, and pace makers while continuing to have a busy private practice. Dr. Spear was an early proponent of the correlations between good health, exercise, and diet. He was vehemently against smoking long before the tenet became common knowledge. He exercised daily and was one of the first crack of dawn joggers in Miami Shores where he and his family lived, much to the consternation of his neighbors. Dedication was Dr. Spear's lode star. He was dedicated to his family, his patients, and to his profession, the practice of cardiothoracic and vascular surgery. He valued his association with other physicians and countless of them were his friends. Always Dr. Spear was honored when his medical peers came to him for treatment themselves, or sent him their families for surgery. Not only were they from Miami and other parts of Florida, at times they would come to him from other states. In his practice, never did he charge other physicians or their family members any fees. Most people have some sort of prejudices. Dr. Spear was a man with none. He saw the human spirit within each individual, the person sweeping the hospital floors was as important to him as the CEO of a large company. He never seemed rushed with people or his patients and he always was calm and soft spoken in the operating room. The only complaint operating room nurses ever made about him was that during operations, he talked mainly about one thing with his associates and residents, football. Football was his delight. Dr. Spear has written a memoir about the early days of cardiac, thoracic, and vascular surgery at Harvard, Yale, and Mayo Clinic, and at the start of his career during the early days when Miami was a quiet Southern town, which will be published in the near future. Some of his early Miami adventures included practicing in about ten hospitals, occasionally he would mention them to his family and friends just as a matter of fact, always modestly, he had to cover them all. Before the I-95 expressway was built, Dr. Spear faced the challenge of reaching the hospitals often by back roads, at times in the dark, because as a specialist, he was on call for many emergency rooms. He would say, "Between midnight and 4:00am, that's when there's trouble." Yet he never complained about getting up around 2:00am after a long day in surgery, getting dressed in a suit, shirt, and tie, then driving alone through the night in response to the call. Truly, Dr. Spear was a man for others. A private celebration of Dr. Spear's life was held on September 7, 2013. He is survived by his wife, Suzanne Bowmall McLaury Spear, daughters, Laurinda Hope Spear, Alison Leelyn Spear, sister, Nancy Rossbach and family, a son, Harold Charles Spear Ill, MD, sons-in-law, Bernardo Fort-Brescia, Alexander Stevens Reese, grandchildren, Marisa Rose Fort, Alexander Charles Paul Fort, Nicholas McLaury Fort, Raymond August Fort, Harold Emil Fort, Gabriel Bernard Fort, Leslie Caylin Spear, Harold Arthur Spear, Charlotte Rosalind Spear, Jeremy Acheson Spear Platt, Carolina Clare Spear Gomez, Isabella Clementine Bliss Reese and great-grandchildren Gil Spear and Emilia Hope Adams.

SOLOMON--Ruth. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our beloved Ruth on September 27. She was born on July 26, 1931 to Sarah and Jacob Rubin. She and her brother were raised by her aunt Gittel and uncle Morris, who treated them like their own children. She was the devoted wife of Irwin, who was the love of her life. She was the beloved brother of Burton. She was the doting mother of Joel, Jonathan, Steven, Emily and Karen. She was the adoring grandmother of Erica, Isabelle, Sarah and Jake. She was the loving aunt of Ellen, Nina and Anne. She was close with her cousins Betty, Ruth, Buddy and Florence. Ruth was the center of our family. She was warm and unconditionally loving, with a famous sense of humor. The bravery, optimism and humor that she displayed in her battle with lung cancer will be an inspiration to her friends and family.

KAUFMAN--Anne Lynch, of Huntington, NY. Devoted wife of James and loving mother of Kathryn, Jason, and Amanda. Passed away from colon cancer on September 27th, 2013. She enjoyed traveling to tropical locales, was a patron of the local community, and a supporter of numerous charitable causes. She was raised in the tight-knit community of Rockaway Beach, NY and maintained close ties to her hometown throughout her lifetime. She prided herself on being a close confidant, selfless mother, and a woman who stood up for what she believed in. She kept everything in balance, whether it was the checkbook or life in general. She is survived by her parents, Edward and Clare, her brothers Edward (Cathy), Thomas (Nancy), and Robert (Yaneth), and her sister Clare (Patrick). She is also survived by her six nephews and four nieces. Reposed Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave, Northport, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Monday 10am at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport. In lieu of flowers, donations to ASPCA, PO Box 96929, Washington, DC, 20090-6929; St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105; and North Shore Animal League, 25 Davis Ave, Port Washington, NY 11050 in Anne's memory are appreciated. (nthfh.com) Peace, Love and Sandy Feet.

EDELMANN--Chester (Chet) Monroe, Jr.,MD, 82, born in New York December 26, 1930 died on September, 19, 2013, after a courageous four year battle with cancer, Chester passed away peacefully at home with his family in attendance. Chet was an exceptional father, renowned physician, research scientist, and, most of all, husband. During his 57 year tenure at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine (AECOM,) he held many prestigious positions, including Senior Associate Dean and Most Distinguished University Professor of Pediatrics. Chet was the recipient of innumerable scientific awards and made tremendous academic contributions to medicine. He authored 43 scientific abstracts and was a member of 25 national and international medical societies. He received his BA from Columbia University in 1951 and his MD degree from Cornell University. He completed his residency in Pediatrics as Chief Resident at BMHC. Chet is survived by his adoring wife of 60 years, Norma, three loving children: John, Christopher, and Kathy and his granddaughter, Jessica, he is also survived by his sister, Maida Heitner. Chet was a true Renaissance man; a lover of languages and their usage: a concert level pianist; a faithful patron of opera, the theatre and the philharmonic. He created fine furniture, was a loyal Mets fan, and enjoyed simple beauty. He was devoted to his wife and family, his patients, his church, science, his community and his country. He believed in excellence, honesty, integrity and above all, compassion. Chet was a rare man, contemplative, yet effective, who quietly found success in the improved health of his patients, in the happiness of his children and in the achievement of his students and colleagues. Chet touched the lives of countless people in many countries worldwide and will be missed by all, but primarily by his wife and children. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, all donations be sent to the following charities: Concordia College, Greenwich Hospital Oncology Unit, and the Sierra Club. A memorial service will be held on Saturday October 5, 2013 at 10:00am at the Sommer Center of Concordia College in Bronxville, NY. For a complete biography visit www.mcgrathandson.com.

CLEMENTS--Mark, passed away on September 26, 2013, two days shy of his 92nd birthday. A native of New York City and proud graduate of City College of New York, he was founder of Mark Clements Research, Inc. which had offices at 516 Fifth Avenue for almost 50 years. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Estelle, and his two children Stephanie and Dan. Also surviving are four grandchildren, Alana, Lissa, Amy and Dylan and two great-grandsons, Reiter and Connor. Memorials may be sent to City College Fund, Mark & Estelle Clements Scholarship Fund, 160 Convent Avenue, Shepard Hall, Rm. 166, New York, NY 10031.

ZEISLER--Amy M.,age 54, of New York City, mother of Jon Zeisler, passed away on Sunday, September 29, 2013. To view her complete obituary, please visit www.LeskoPolke FuneralHome.com

RUSSELL--Mildred K. Of New Canaan, CT, passed away peacefully on September 28. The loving wife of the late William T. Russell, she is survived by Catherine Ann, Margaret-Angele, and William Thomas Russell, Jr., daughter-in-law Holly Russell, and grandchildren Liam, Aram, and Maggie. She was passionate about politics, literature, and issues that affected children, and volunteered as the Director of the Youth Employment Service and the Career Resource Center at New Canaan High School for 25 years. A memorial service will be held Thursday, October 3, at 1pm at the First Presbyterian Church, 178 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Amagansett Free Library, Amagansett, NY, would be greatly appreciated.

L'ESPERANCE--Laura Ann. Laura Ann L'Esperance died in her home on September 22, 2013. She was 49 years old. Born in New York City, she was a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis A. L'Esperance, Jr. of New York City, Water Mill, NY and Palm Beach, FL. She attended The Convent of the Sacred Heart, and graduated from St. Paul's School, Tulane University, and the Gemological Institute of America. At age 12 she was Tri-State figure skating champion and won several competitions in the Northeast. She trained at Sky Rink in New York and in Sun Valley, Idaho with Peter Dunfield. In addition to skating, Laura was an accomplished equestrian, and enjoyed open water scuba diving. She was a volunteer at the New York Junior League and made her debut there. Laura, a gemologist, worked with several jewelers, including Buzz Baumgold Fine Jewelry, Harry Winston and Kaufmann de Suisse. The funeral took place on Thursday, September 26 at The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, followed by a private burial at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Cemetery in Southampton, NY. Laura is survived by her parents, her brother, Francis A. L'Esperance III, her sister, Linda L'Esperance Lartigau, and her daughter, Winston Aylesworth Rossetter. Memorial donations may be made to the Southampton Fresh Air Home, 36 Barkers Island Road, Southampton, NY 11968. (www.sfah.org)

HIRSCHBERG--Sonya Belle. Died September 30, 2013. Loving mother of Terri Sasanow (Richard), Rorri Feinstein, Toby Deutsch, Myra Hirschberg (Tom). Beloved and extremely proud grandmother and great-grandmother of Sydney, Alexa, Allison, Barry, Silas and Jemma. Services October 1st at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. New York, NY.

FREDERICK--William C.,MD, 85 years, of Staten Island, NY, died at home surrounded by his loving family on September 27, 2013. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Joan (nee Hasson), the love of his life, his sister Lois McCutcheon of Swickley, PA, his devoted children and their spouses, Gail and Tim Donovan, Donna and Tom Kendris, Lynda and Chris Meehan, William Frederick, Megan and Larry Altavilla, Douglas and Melissa Frederick and his beloved grandchildren Kathryn and Timothy Donovan, Amanda and Thomas Kendris, Laura Kendris and her husband John Tully, Christopher, Emily and Molly Meehan, Erin Anne Frederick, Matthew and Andrew Salzano, Vivienne and Colin Frederick. A brilliant surgeon, teacher and compassionate physician, Dr. Frederick was the first to specialize in vascular surgery and established the first four year accredited surgical training program on Staten Island during his 30 years associated with the former St. Vincent's Medical Center. He was a man of many interests including golf, reading, gardening and a great crossword puzzle. Most importantly, Bill loved spending time with his family and friends. His greatest gift and legacy was his genuine respect for all humanity. The Funeral Mass will be held at St. Ann's RC Church Wednesday, at 11am.

FRANKEL--Bruno. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Bruno Frankel who with his beloved wife, Rosetta A., was a Yeshiva University Guardian and a widely revered leader in the Rockland, NY Jewish and General community where he was an outstanding industrialist and respected philanthropist. A past Board member of the Marsha Stern Yeshiva University High School for Boys where they established the Annual Shalom Frankel Memorial Lecture in memory of his father, which is a highlight of its Arista Awards Ceremonies. They also supported the high school with the Bruno and Rosetta A. Frankel Scholarship Fund and scholarships for the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS). Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Rosetta A., to his beloved children: Aaron and (Linda) Frankel and Gammy and (Marlene) Frankel, Sandy and (Rae) Frankel, his brothers: Abraham and (Phyllis) Frankel and Max Frankel and Marcia, wife of the late Rabbi Emanuel Frankel, z'l; their grandchildren and a great grandchild and to all the members of the Frankel family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

FRANK--Charlotte Lorraine (nee Fox), of Hewlett, NY and Palm Beach, FL died on September 29 at the age of 89 after a long illness. Beautiful and beloved wife of Morton Frank, she cared for him devotedly until his death in 2006. Loving mother to Peter, Jeffrey, and Jonathan; wonderful mother-in-law to Carol; adoring grandmother of Dara and David. She is survived by her siblings Ada Herring and Julius Fox. A generous aunt to Rochelle Woldoff, Jordan Fox, Kenneth Fox, Judith Rudin, JoAnn Rifkind, Cindy Cossin, and the late Sandy Herring and Barry Hilsenroth. A great-aunt to Melissa, Eric, Elisha, Benjamin, Becky, Lianna, Randi, Robert, Samantha Jo, Paul and Debbie. Charlotte was a tireless volunteer benefit organizer for the United Jewish Appeal and the National Foundation for Ileitis and Colitis, now CCFA. Known for her organizational skills and exquisite taste, she was always eager to help her immediate and extended family in their projects to make their homes lovely and inviting. Loyal and thoughtful to a wide circle of friends, she shared fully in their joys and sorrows. "She walked in grace." Services will be held on Wednesday, October 2nd at 12:15pm at Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, 11520 U.S. 441, Boynton Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society or the Alzheimers Association. Shiva will be held following the service at 3100 South Ocean Blvd., Apt. 407 S, Palm Beach, FL. until 8pm.

We extend our deepest condolences to Shirley's sons, Steven, Don, and Carl; to her daughter-in-law, Gail, to her grandchildren; her sister-in-law, Belle; and to the entire family. Alisa R. diPIERRO--Charles Joseph (born Castolo) of Brielle, NJ died peacefully on Saturday, September 21st, 2013 at the age of 85. Son of Giuseppe and Alessandra (nee Zizzamia), he was raised in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, attended Stuyvesant High School and graduated from Brooklyn College in 1951 with a BA in English. After honorable discharge from the U.S. Army 112th Infantry Regiment for service during the Korean War, he earned his Masters in English from Columbia University. He then began teaching technical writing at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, Columbia University and NYU. By 1970, he had moved his family to Westfield, NJ. There, he founded and ran Metascience, Inc., teaching writing and communications skills critical to the scientists and engineers of Bell Labs, Exxon, Aramco, General Foods, Union Carbide, Ciba-Geigy Alcoa, Rohm & Haas and others. In the world of martial arts, Charles was instrumental in the formation of what's now known as the U. S. Soo Bahk Do Moo Duk Kwan Federation and served as its first Chairman. He retired to Brielle in 2003, in a house he and his wife, Olga (nee Balas), designed, to be near his grandchildren. There, he was able to pursue his passions for reading, gardening and cooking. He also gave wise and heartfelt counsel, and provided generously to many in his family. He will be dearly missed by his wife; his sons and their wives, Charles Gian and Sara, Milan Christopher and Michelle, and Nicolas; his grandchildren, Alexa Marie and Christopher Milan; and all those who knew him. He and Olga would have celebrated their 51st wedding anniversary on October 6th. A memorial gathering was held privately Sunday, September 29th. In lieu of flowers, please consider his hometown Brielle Public Library, the Brielle EMS and his alma mater, Stuyvesant High School in New York City.

CALICK--Gladys (formerly Gladys Green) age 95. Loving wife to Paul (deceased 2001), loving sister of Harold Green (deceased), loving mother to Dedee and Stephen Lovell and Terry Roberts, grandmother to David and Lisa Roberts, Jamie Roberts and Mark Swirsky, Barry Lovell and Ellen Reinheimer, Wendy Lovell-Smith and Colin Smith, and Hope Lovell Newman and Joshua Newman and 14 great-grandchildren. Gladys was beautiful, gracious, and charming and believed that life was supposed to be fun. She managed to find humor, joy, and gratitude in almost every situation, even up to her last moments. She will be sorely missed by those closest to her, and all who knew her. Private services will be held in New Jersey on October, 2, 2013. The family requests that any donations be made to Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America.

BLYTH--Jeffrey. March 20, 1926 - September 21, 2013. Jeffrey Blyth traveled the world for many years as a foreign correspondent for The London Daily Mail. For most of the time he was based in New York. Major stories he covered included the assassination of President Kennedy in Dallas, (and the subsequent shooting of Lee Harvey Oswald in the basement of the Dallas Police headquarters), the killing of Robert Kennedy in Los Angeles, Chappaquiddick, and Castro's takeover of Cuba. Before that he covered Grace Kelly's wedding, the Suez Crisis, the Hungarian Revolution and the building of the Berlin Wall. His travels took him all over the world. In fact there were only two major countries he never visited: Australia and New Zealand. The reason, as he once explained to the Australian ambassador, was because neither country had experienced a revolution. But he did cover stories in virtually every country in South America, Europe, Africa and Asia--including Vietnam. He accompanied President Eisenhower to his "peace trips" to the Middle East and Asia. Blyth, born in 1926 in South Shields, started in journalism at the age of 16 as a "cub reporter" on the Shields Gazette. His salary, seven shillings a week. Later he worked in the Newcastle office of the Northern Echo. During WWII he was a soldier journalist, working for the British Army newspaper Union Jack in Italy. After the war he joined the now defunct News Chronicle, and then was appointed shipping correspondent for the Daily Mail in Southampton. It was there he scored his first big scoop--discovering the car in which the famous runaway spies Burgess and MacLean had fled London and then abandoned in the Southampton docks. It was the first clue to how the renegades had left Britain. Years later he discovered when he met Guy Burgess in Moscow that had even been with them in the bar of the ship in which they fled Britain without knowing it. His overseas years began when he was appointed the Daily Mail's European roving correspondent, based in Paris. He scooped the world with an exclusive interview with Prince Rainier just before his wedding to Grace Kelly. In 1957 he was sent to New York where he was the Chief US correspondent for almost 15 years. After the Mail he worked as a New York correspondent for the BBC and the South African Broadcasting Company, filing daily radio reports. At the same time he set up a company in New York, called Interpress, filing regular weekly reports on show business, media and travel for various British publications including Press Gazette for which he wrote a popular weekly column. He was one of the early members of the Overseas Press Club and a past president of the Foreign Press Association. He leaves his wife Myrna, his sons, Jonathan and Graham, and two grandchildren. He was a great journalist, an admired colleague and a much loved husband and father. Memorial service November 2nd at 3pm at the House of the Redeemer, 7 East 95th Street.

TAWIL--Fred Ezra, on September 26, at 89, of Brooklyn, NY, Hemlock Farms, PA, and Herzliyah, Israel. Much loved father and grandfather, Fred was very well informed and widely read in many subjects. Firm in his ideas, he was always open to those of others. He invited debate without rancor and civil discourse with all. Fred served in the US Infantry and went to the University of Connecticut under the ASTP program and was later assigned to the 280th Engineers, Company A. Fred was in the second wave assault on Europe and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. Fred was a founder and partner of Mayfair Infants Wear, Inc. in New York. No one who knew Fred, his intelligence and generous nature, will forget him. He is survived by his wife Sally, four children: Adrienne, Robin, Joyce and Ezra, and four grandchildren. Fred, we love you.

SUSSER--Phyllis L. (August, 24, 1938 - September 30, 2013) The Board of Directors and Staff of Birch Family Services, Inc. are saddened by the passing of our Founding Director, Phyllis L. Susser. Phyllis was a visionary, a pioneer, and a leader for social change for the disenfranchised, using her considerable intelligence and energy to advocate for those with severe developmental disabilities and social and behavioral challenges, helping them to live their lives as fully and independently as possible. Inspired by her teacher and mentor, Herbert G. Birch, M.D., she began the Herbert G. Birch School for Exceptional Children in 1975 with 28 students and 11 staff members, and she built that program into an agency that now operates educational, residential, adult day and other programs in 23 different sites throughout New York City, serving more than 1,300 people annually. (Our flagship school was re-named the Phyllis L. Susser School for Exceptional Children in April 2006.) Phyllis also was never afraid to serve the socially ostracized. Even when it was not widely accepted, Phyllis opened the doors of Birch's early childhood centers and residences to infants, toddlers and preschoolers affected by HIV/AIDS. She established one of the first camp programs for families living with HIV, staffed almost entirely by volunteers. She was relentless and selfless in her pursuits, and always persevered until she successfully accomplished her mission. No one worked harder or cared more deeply about the people she served. Without Phyllis's inspiration, vision, and determination, Birch Family Services, Inc. would not exist. The Board and Staff honor her memory and pledge to keep her legacy alive. We extend our deepest condolences to her daughter, Kim Susser and her husband, Jordan Cohen, grandsons Charlie and Ethan Cohen, her sister, Sherry Katz, nephew, Andrew Stern, and her family. She will be dearly missed. Robin E. Keller, Esq. Chairman Gerald F. Maurer, Ph.D., President, CEO

SOLOMON--Shirley Blacher. 1921-2013. Daughter of Charles and Bernardine Blacher, wife of the late Dr. M.D. Solomon, sister of Dr. Richard Blacher, mother of Robert and Carol. A Camp Reena girl until the end of her days.

SANDERS--Joyce Schechter, formerly of Ardsley, NY, passed away at her home in Sleepy Hollow, NY on October 1, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband of 42 years, Dr. Arnold R. Sanders, and her parents, Dr. Solomon P. Schechter and Elsie R. Schechter. Joyce is survived by her children, Bill Sanders of Santa Monica, CA, Rory Sanders Ehrlich of New York and Gina Sanders Newhouse of New York, and her brother, Rabbi Philip Schechter of Stamford, CT. Also surviving are her grandchildren, Aaron, Ardsley and Duncan Sanders of Santa Monica, and Daniel and Jason Ehrlich, and Robert and Kate Newhouse of New York. Born in the Bronx, Joyce received her BA from Syracuse University and her Masters in Education from Columbia University. She was a teacher, and later a hospital administrator, serving in various executive positions including Director of Volunteer Services at Beth Abraham Hospital. Throughout her life, Joyce was also a published freelance writer and poet. A graveside funeral will be held today at 11:00am at Ferncliff Cemetery, 280 Secor Road in Hartsdale, NY. Services by Frank E Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave New York, NY.

RUSSELL--Mildred K. Of New Canaan, CT, passed away peacefully on September 28. The loving wife of the late William T. Russell, she is survived by Catherine Ann, Margaret-Angele, and William Thomas Russell, Jr., daughter-in-law Holly Russell, and grandchildren Liam, Aram, and Maggie. She was passionate about politics, literature, and issues that affected children, and volunteered as the Director of the Youth Employment Service and the Career Resource Center at New Canaan High School for 25 years. A memorial service will be held Thursday, October 3, at 1pm at the First Presbyterian Church, 178 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Amagansett Free Library, Amagansett, NY, would be greatly appreciated.

PENNOYER--Victoria. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum mourn the death of Victoria Pennoyer, wife of Trustee Robert M. Pennoyer and mother of Trustee Peter Pennoyer. Vicky was a valued, longtime Fellow and a person of abundant kindness and quiet grace. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, Pres. William M. Griswold, Dir.

PENNOYER--Victoria Parsons, died peacefully at home surrounded by her family on September 30, 2013, at the age of 85. She was the beloved wife of Robert M. Pennoyer, her husband of 65 years. The two met when she was eighteen after he returned from the Pacific at the end of World War II. When he wrote to invite her to a performance of Oscar Wilde's Lady Windermere's Fan she replied: "Pleasure was my first sensation. Let us hope the evening does not lead us into any serious indiscretion. Your more than willing, Victoria." She was the adored mother of Christy Pennoyer, Russell Pennoyer, Tracy Pennoyer and Peter Pennoyer, mother-in-law of Helen Pennoyer, John Auchincloss and Katie Ridder, and grandmother of: Kate, Frances and Molly Greathead; Gordon, Robbie and his wife Polly, and Margaret Pennoyer; Emily and James Auchincloss; and Jane, Tony and Gigi Pennoyer. She is also survived by her much-loved sister Margaret Hendon Parker and by numerous nieces and nephews. Amazingly creative, her poetry and paintings expressed her love for her family, the beauty of nature, the city, and Central Park. Her imagination and humor, warmth, and capacity for love gave strength and inspiration to her children and grandchildren, and to her countless friends and admirers, and were a lifelong source of happiness to her husband Bobby. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, October 12 at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th Street, New York, N.Y. 10022, or Poets House, 10 River Terrace, New York, N.Y. 10282.

NICOLAU--Siobhan. It is with unbound sadness, but also appreciation for a life exceedingly well-lived, that we mourn the passing of Siobhan Nicolau, who with her husband, George Nicolau, was a cherished friend of Human Rights First, with an unwavering belief in the primacy of human rights.

McGRATH--David "Dave", passed away peacefully with his wife Marge at his side on Thursday, September 26 in Palm City, Florida at the age of 86. Dave grew up in Englewood, New Jersey; served in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific; and graduated from Princeton University with honors. Dave had a successful 39-year career at McGraw Hill Publishing Company, rising through the ranks from salesman to Senior Vice President in the Construction Information Group. He was one of the first American business magazine publishers to enter the People's Republic of China, establishing a joint venture with the Chinese in 1979 that helped open the door for trade between China and the American construction industry. As a young man, Dave met and married the love of his life, Marjorie Lovett. They are the parents of five children, Anne McGrath of Pacific Grove, CA, Patty McGrath Morris of Tesuque, NM, Laura Hardin of Chatham, NJ, Kate Morris of Andover, MA and David McGrath IV of Short Hills, NJ. Dave is survived by his wife, children, three sons-in-law, and nine grandchildren. Dave was a resident of Palm City, Florida and maintained a home in Short Hills, NJ. He was a member at the Short Hills Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, Harbour Ridge Yacht & Country Club and the Snowmass Club in Colorado. A celebration of Dave's life will be held on Saturday, October 5 at 10am at St. Rose of Lima Church in Short Hills, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Princeton University Class of '48 or memorybridge.org. Services are under the direction of the Forest Hills Funeral Homes Palm City Chapel. An online registry is available at: foresthillspalmcityflorida.com.

GUBERMAN--Robert, 73, of Long Beach and Bovina, NY passed away on October 1, 2013. He was married to the love of his life, Ilene, for 47 years, with whom he traveled the world. He is survived by his wife, son Jeffrey and daughter-in-law Phara, who he loved with the warmth and enormity of his heart. Bob was a longtime Senior Executive in the retail industry, where he most notably held the trademark for "Year 2000." The funeral will be held at 2pm on October 2nd at Beth David in Elmont.

GOLDFEIER--Moritz. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of Moritz Goldfeier who with his wife Angie, was a Yeshiva University Guardian. A devoted supporter of Yeshiva University and its Holocaust Studies Program, he was respected in the diamond industry and was a jewel of a man admired for his integrity and creativity. Mr. Goldfeier was a survivor of the Shoah who believed that Jewish education was the single most important antidote to the preservation of a proud Jewish identity to perpetuate our heritage. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Angie and his dedicated children: Harry and (Evelyn) Goldfeier and Marilyn Rosen and their grandchildren and great grandchildren and entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

GOLDFARB--Roy, of Boca Raton, FL passed away on September 28. He is survived by his loving wife Bobbie, two daughters Lori Certilman and Joanne Fried; four grandchildren, Jennifer and Brandon Fried, Aly and Jason Certilman. Also will be missed by his adored son-in-law Bob Fried and his faithful caregiver Kedner. Shiva will be held at Joanne Fried's home Wednesday and Thursday 1-4pm and 6-9pm.

GERST--Paul H.,M.D., of Tenafly, NJ passed away on September 29, 2013 at the age of eighty-six (86). Dr. Gerst graduated from Columbia College in 1948 and received his M.D. degree from The College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University in 1952. He completed training in General Surgery and in Cardiothoracic Surgery at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center joining the attending staff in 1962. In 1964, he was appointed Department Chairman of Surgery and Surgical Residency Program Director at the Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center, and Professor of Surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, a position he held until his retirement in 2003. He had a distinguished career as Surgeon and Educator, and in 2003, he received the Parker J. Palmer Award from the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education for outstanding direction of The Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center Surgical Residency Training program. During the Korean War, he served as a Medical Officer with the U.S. Army in Korea. Dr. Gerst is survived by three sons: Steven, a physician and healthcare investment banker in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, Andrew, an attorney in Washington, D.C., and Jeffrey, of Tenafly, New Jersey; and a granddaughter, Chantal, of Charlotte, North Carolina. His wife, Dr. Elizabeth C. Gerst, a former Assistant Dean at the College of Physicians and Surgeons died in 1994. Services will be held on Friday October 4, 2013 at 11:30am at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive Tenafly, NJ 07670. Internment at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, New Jersey.

FREDERICK--William C.,MD, 85 years, of Staten Island, NY, died at home surrounded by his loving family on September 27, 2013. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Joan (nee Hasson), the love of his life, his sister Lois McCutcheon of Swickley, PA, his devoted children and their spouses, Gail and Tim Donovan, Donna and Tom Kendris, Lynda and Chris Meehan, William Frederick, Megan and Larry Altavilla, Douglas and Melissa Frederick and his beloved grandchildren Kathryn and Timothy Donovan, Amanda and Thomas Kendris, Laura Kendris and her husband John Tully, Christopher, Emily and Molly Meehan, Erin Anne Frederick, Matthew and Andrew Salzano, Vivienne and Colin Frederick. A brilliant surgeon, teacher and compassionate physician, Dr. Frederick was the first to specialize in vascular surgery and established the first four year accredited surgical training program on Staten Island during his 30 years associated with the former St. Vincent's Medical Center. He was a man of many interests including golf, reading, gardening and a great crossword puzzle. Most importantly, Bill loved spending time with his family and friends. His greatest gift and legacy was his genuine respect for all humanity. The Funeral Mass will be held at St. Ann's RC Church Wednesday, at 11am.

FRANK--Charlotte Lorraine (nee Fox), of Hewlett, NY and Palm Beach, FL died on September 29 at the age of 89 after a long illness. Beautiful and beloved wife of Morton Frank, she cared for him devotedly until his death in 2006. Loving mother to Peter, Jeffrey, and Jonathan; wonderful mother-in-law to Carol; adoring grandmother of Dara and David. She is survived by her siblings Ada Herring and Julius Fox. A generous aunt to Rochelle Woldoff, Jordan Fox, Kenneth Fox, Judith Rudin, JoAnn Rifkind, Cindy Cossin, and the late Sandy Herring and Barry Hilsenroth. A great-aunt to Melissa, Eric, Elisha, Benjamin, Becky, Lianna, Randi, Robert, Samantha Jo, Paul and Debbie. Charlotte was a tireless volunteer benefit organizer for the United Jewish Appeal and the National Foundation for Ileitis and Colitis, now CCFA. Known for her organizational skills and exquisite taste, she was always eager to help her immediate and extended family in their projects to make their homes lovely and inviting. Loyal and thoughtful to a wide circle of friends, she shared fully in their joys and sorrows. "She walked in grace." Services will be held on Wednesday, October 2nd at 12:15pm at Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, 11520 U.S. 441, Boynton Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society or the Alzheimers Association. Shiva will be held following the service at 3100 South Ocean Blvd., Apt. 407 S, Palm Beach, FL. until 8pm.

FLYTHE--Starkey Flythe Jr, 78, writer, poet, past editor of the Saturday Evening Post, died September 13, 2013 in Augusta, GA. He published in Best American Short Stories, O Henry Prize volumes, and won an Iowa Short Fiction award. His poems, collected in three volumes, appeared in magazines including The New Yorker.

FLEISCHER--Shirley. American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev is deeply saddened by the passing of Shirley Fleischer. Together with her late husband William, Shirley has been an ardent supporter of Ben-Gurion University and its desert research for many years. We extend our sincerest condolences to the Fleischer family and all who mourn her loss. Lloyd Goldman, President Lite Sabin, New York Regional Board Chair Doron Krakow, Executive Vice President Kevin Leopold, Executive Director Northeast

CALICK--Gladys (formerly Gladys Green) age 95. Loving wife to Paul (deceased 2001), loving sister of Harold Green (deceased), loving mother to Dedee and Stephen Lovell and Terry Roberts, grandmother to David and Lisa Roberts, Jamie Roberts and Mark Swirsky, Barry Lovell and Ellen Reinheimer, Wendy Lovell-Smith and Colin Smith, and Hope Lovell Newman and Joshua Newman and 14 great-grandchildren. Gladys was beautiful, gracious, and charming and believed that life was supposed to be fun. She managed to find humor, joy, and gratitude in almost every situation, even up to her last moments. She will be sorely missed by those closest to her, and all who knew her. Private services will be held in New Jersey on October, 2, 2013. The family requests that any donations be made to Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America.

BURNS--Arnold I.,former Deputy Attorney General of the United States in the second Reagan administration, died October 1. He was 83. The cause was heart failure and complications from Parkinson's disease. Mr. Burns is survived by his wife of 62 years Felice, his son Doug Burns and his wife Joanne; his daughter Linda and John Crump; and his four grandchildren, Brendan, Scott, Leah and Katie. He is also survived by his sisters Dr. Ruth Cowan and Norma Salem. Mr. Burns, who started a law firm with one other lawyer in 1960, grew that firm to over 120 lawyers. He then left New York after being named Associate Attorney General in 1985, number three at Department of Justice. After confirmation and the nomination of then Deputy Attorney General D. Lowell Jenson to serve as a United States District Judge in California, Mr. Burns was named and then confirmed by the Senate as Deputy Attorney General. Arnold Burns was born in 1930 in Brooklyn, NY. After graduating from Union College and the Cornell Law School, he served in the Army Judge Advocate General for four years before beginning law practice in New York City. As a JAG lawyer, he handled military appeals from courts martial. Mr. Burns also served as national chairman of the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and was a tireless advocate for our nations youth. Many, many colleagues considered him a great mentor, for which he was eternally proud. He also joked how being an Eagle Scout was one of his proudest accomplishments. The funeral will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street on Thursday, October 3 at 12:45pm. Visitation will be at 11:45am before the funeral.

BROOKS--Norma. We mourn the passing of our dear Norma Brooks, widow of Harry Brooks. Her 96 years epitomized the adage Live Long and Live Well, as a loving, devoted inspiration to her ten great-grandchildren, five grandchildren, son Barry (Gail), (predeceased by daughter Judith Lawsky) sisters, nieces, nephews. She fervently supported Sunrise Florida Jewish Center, was active in National Hadassah and was past President of Sunrise Hadassah. Her ceaseless energy and thoughtfulness were reflected in her readiness to always participate in family celebrations, near and far, wearing her high heels and favored finery. Funeral services Friday at 1:30pm Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ, burial at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus.

BLYTH--Jeffrey. March 20, 1926 - September 21, 2013. Jeffrey Blyth traveled the world for many years as a foreign correspondent for The London Daily Mail. For most of the time he was based in New York. Major stories he covered included the assassination of President Kennedy in Dallas, (and the subsequent shooting of Lee Harvey Oswald in the basement of the Dallas Police headquarters), the killing of Robert Kennedy in Los Angeles, Chappaquiddick, and Castro's takeover of Cuba. Before that he covered Grace Kelly's wedding, the Suez Crisis, the Hungarian Revolution and the building of the Berlin Wall. His travels took him all over the world. In fact there were only two major countries he never visited: Australia and New Zealand. The reason, as he once explained to the Australian ambassador, was because neither country had experienced a revolution. But he did cover stories in virtually every country in South America, Europe, Africa and Asia--including Vietnam. He accompanied President Eisenhower to his "peace trips" to the Middle East and Asia. Blyth, born in 1926 in South Shields, started in journalism at the age of 16 as a "cub reporter" on the Shields Gazette. His salary, seven shillings a week. Later he worked in the Newcastle office of the Northern Echo. During WWII he was a soldier journalist, working for the British Army newspaper Union Jack in Italy. After the war he joined the now defunct News Chronicle, and then was appointed shipping correspondent for the Daily Mail in Southampton. It was there he scored his first big scoop--discovering the car in which the famous runaway spies Burgess and MacLean had fled London and then abandoned in the Southampton docks. It was the first clue to how the renegades had left Britain. Years later he discovered when he met Guy Burgess in Moscow that had even been with them in the bar of the ship in which they fled Britain without knowing it. His overseas years began when he was appointed the Daily Mail's European roving correspondent, based in Paris. He scooped the world with an exclusive interview with Prince Rainier just before his wedding to Grace Kelly. In 1957 he was sent to New York where he was the Chief US correspondent for almost 15 years. After the Mail he worked as a New York correspondent for the BBC and the South African Broadcasting Company, filing daily radio reports. At the same time he set up a company in New York, called Interpress, filing regular weekly reports on show business, media and travel for various British publications including Press Gazette for which he wrote a popular weekly column. He was one of the early members of the Overseas Press Club and a past president of the Foreign Press Association. He leaves his wife Myrna, his sons, Jonathan and Graham, and two grandchildren. He was a great journalist, an admired colleague and a much loved husband and father. Memorial service November 2nd at 3pm at the House of the Redeemer, 7 East 95th Street.

BYRNE--Patrick. In loving memory of your birth and life. You live in our hearts forever. BMCC and KJEBI

WEIDINGER--Hugh John III, 72, of Wakefield, Rhode Island, Oyster Bay, NY, died on Sunday, September 29, 2013, in Wakefield, RI. Calling hours will be held Friday, October 4, 2013 from 4-7pm at Avery-Storti Funeral Home, 88 Columbia Street, Wakefield, RI, (401) 783-7271. A Requiem Eucharist will be held at 10am on Saturday, October 5, 2013, at Saint Peter's-by-the-Sea, 72 Central Street, Narragansett, RI. A memorial reception will be held on Long Island on Wednesday, October 9th from 5-8pm at The Creek Club, 1 Horse Hollow Ct., Locust Valley, NY 11560 (516) 676-1405. For full obituary and condolences: averystortifuneralhome.com.

SPRINGER--June Reimer, of New York City, died peacefully on September 27, 2013 in Chico, CA at the age of 85. Born in 1928 in Hackensack, NJ to Alice and Rudolph Reimer, she grew up in Bogota NJ. June became a professional singer at 18, appearing in several musicals on Broadway (including "Kiss Me Kate" for which she recalled auditioning before Cole Porter; Sigmund Romberg's "My Romance;" and "Three Wishes For Jamie," among others); and on national tours including Romberg's "The Student Prince", in which she starred as the Princess. In the 1950s, under the stage name Monica Lane, June joined crooner Cass Franklin as a popular singing duo playing New York nightclubs such as The Latin Quarter, pioneer television variety shows such as The Colgate Comedy Hour, and Catskills resorts (Monica's publicity pin-up became the source material for Roy Lichtenstein's famous "Girl With Ball," in NYC's MoMA). In 1953, June married John Springer, whose career as a film and theater public relations agent became legend. With John, she enjoyed the glamour of the New York and international entertainment, arts and journalism worlds, but she was far more devoted to family: children Gary, Alicia, and Cynthia; grandchildren Nicholas and Olivia Springer, Zachary Gilman, and Anthony and Zora Thomas; and her sister Marilyn and family. Warm, funny, beautiful, and generous, June was beloved by loyal friends and family. A Memorial will be held later in October in New York City at the Players Club.

SCHWARTZ--Lucille. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Lucille Schwartz. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

RUSSELL--Mildred K. Of New Canaan, CT, passed away peacefully on September 28. The loving wife of the late William T. Russell, she is survived by Catherine Ann, Margaret-Angele, and William Thomas Russell, Jr., daughter-in-law Holly Russell, and grandchildren Liam, Aram, and Maggie. She was passionate about politics, literature, and issues that affected children, and volunteered as the Director of the Youth Employment Service and the Career Resource Center at New Canaan High School for 25 years. A memorial service will be held Thursday, October 3, at 1pm at the First Presbyterian Church, 178 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Amagansett Free Library, Amagansett, NY, would be greatly appreciated.

PENNOYER--Victoria. With deep sadness we mourn the passing of Victoria Pennoyer, beloved wife and sustaining partner of Robert Pennoyer, an enduring friend of Human Rights First and an unswerving advocate for the extension of human rights and human dignity everywhere. Elisa Massimino, President & CEO, Human Rights First

MIDDLETON--Jean Cousins, August 1, 1922 - September 20, 2013. Lived a joyful life, passed away peacefully at home in Los Angeles. Beloved wife, loving mother of Shoshanna Tallant and Tom Javits, grandmother of five, great-grandmother of six. We remember her young at heart, dancing, devoted to family, friends and her work as a social worker.

MATHIAS--Alvin. It is with profound sadness we mourn the passing of our dearest friend, Alvin Mathias, a man of deep humility, imagination, warmth and generosity. Alvin had an unbounded capacity to love, especially his cherished wife, Leslie, and his beloved children and grandchildren. He was an inspiration and guiding force to all who knew him. Alvin, you rewarded us, your friends, with love, humor and fierce loyalty. Our friendship was one of sincere admiration and devotion that cannot be broken. You were a lifelong source of happiness and love that will remain with us forever. Joyce & Richard Marion & Steve Nuny Valerie & Butch Stuie & Marcella Lori & David Amy & Shelly

LITTLE--Susan ("Suki"), nee Richards. Born: January 17, 1931; Educated at the Chapin School and Briarcliff College; Married William Riegel June 9, 1953, Divorced 1967; Married Robert ("Bob") Little November 14, 1969; Died September 30, 2013 after a long illness. Survived by her children: William Riegel Jr., Guy Riegel, Katherine Riegel and Margaret Riegel; brothers: Peter Richards and Archibald Richards; 10 grandchildren. Donations to Alzheimer's Foundation of America at: www.alzfdn.org/index.htm. Services will be held at the First Congregational Church in Litchfield, CT. 21 Torrington Rd. Litchfield, CT (860) 567-8705 on October 5th at 11am. Suki had a marvelous sense of humor, loved to laugh and could sing like an angel. Her forte was cooking and a delight it was for all who graced her table. She was kind beyond words and will be sorely missed by all who knew her.

LAWNER--Ethel G.,MD, 91, of Westfield, NJ, died September 27, 2013, at home. Born in Brooklyn, NY, she resided in Jersey City for over 50 years before moving to Westfield. Dr. Lawner, graduated from University of North Carolina and New York Medical College, and was an internist and specialist in endocrinology, with a private practice in Jersey City for 60 years. Dr. Lawner also served as the Acting Chief of Endocrinology at Christ Hospital, before she retired in 2007. Earlier, she served as Medical Director for the Job Corps Program in Jersey City. She was a founding member and first president of Citizens Committee to Save JFK Boulevard, later known as Citizens Committee of Hudson County. In 2008 Dr. Lawner received the Jersey City Legend Award. Surviving are daughter Sydne Marshall (Chazanow Sommer), sons-in-law Elliot Sommer and Thomas Koontz, and grandchildren Matthew and Abby Chazanow. Dr. Lawner was pre-deceased by her husband, Irving Marshall, MD, and daughters Nina Marshall Koontz and Madeline Marshall. Services were held on September 29, 2013 at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ, with services by Menorah Chapels at Millburn. Donations in Dr. Lawner's memory may be made to Vitas Hospice or American Diabetes Association.

GOLD--Jeffrey Seth. It is with great sorrow that we mourn the passing of Jeffrey Seth Gold, son of Theodore David and Debra (Fridovich), brother of William (Nili), uncle of Doria and Avitai (Jocelyn), and great-uncle of Elijah and Tali. In 1969, Jeff founded Community Tax Aid in New York, for which he received an award from Mayor Beame. For two years, Jeff served on the IRS Commissioner's Advisory Group. Jeff will be remembered as a dear family member, a loyal friend with a superior intellect, and as a true advocate for marginalized groups culminating in his efforts at the forefront of the anti-smoking movement. A gifted writer and editor, avid reader, accomplished hiker, baseball fan and traveler, Jeff will always be honored by those how knew him. Funeral service will be held at 9:30am on Friday, October 4th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, located at 630 Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan.

GILBERT--Evelyn, passed away peacefully with her daughters Roni Gilbert and Lona Newman by her side on October 1st in New York City. She was one of the best and smartest moms in the world and was always there for her family. Evelyn is survived by her daughters and grandson Alan Newman. Her wonderful style, joy of life, and passion for classical music was with her throughout her life. A Memorial Service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York City on Sunday, October 6th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers Contributions may be sent to Chamber Music Associates, c/o Ann Loeb, 91 Central Park West, NY, NY 10023.

FRIEDMAN--Arnold D.,86, died October 1, 2013 peacefully at home after a courageous fight with cancer. Born in the Bronx to Louis and Jane Friedman, he obtained his BS in accounting from NYU. He was a veteran of WWII and the Korean War. He married Barbara Silverstein in 1951 and remained devotedly married until her death in 1999. He was a devoted father, grandfather and friend. He was a trusted financial advisor and accountant to Jack Dreyfus and Adelaide de Menil. He earned his private pilot's license at age 79 and skied until he was 84 years of age. He is survived by his children and their spouses; Jeffrey and Rhonda, Bruce and Isabelle, Stuart and Mitha, his beloved grandchildren Jenna, Nicholas, Stacie and Hannah, his companion Arlene and his brother Elliot. Memorial contributions may be made to Manhattan Hematology Oncology Research Foundation, 157 East 32 Street, New York, NY 10016.

FEITELL--Lawrence K. of New York City died October 1, 2013 (age 83), surrounded by friends and family. Born and raised in Brooklyn, a graduate of Brooklyn College and Columbia Law School, he served in the army, taught at Columbia, and began his legal career as an Asst. District Attorney in Manhattan under Frank S. Hogan. He clerked in the Appellate Division, 1st Dept., under Judge Aron Steuer before entering private practice as a defense attorney. In 1984, he was the first attorney to introduce computer reenactment evidence at trial, an innovative and groundbreaking use of technology in the courtroom. He practiced criminal defense in the Southern and Eastern District courts, joined in his practice by his son, the attorney Bennett Feitell, by whom he is survived along with his loving wife, Myrna Feitell (nee Rosenberg), and his daughter, the writer Merrill Feitell. He was known throughout his career as an Appeals Man, and he fought tenaciously until the end. Funeral services will be held at Riverside in Manhattan on Friday October 4, at 11:15am.

CALICK--Gladys. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Gladys Calick, mother-in-law of JTS Trustee Stephen J. Lovell, mother of Dedee Lovell and Terry Roberts, grandmother of 10, and great-grandmother of 14. Mrs. Calick was a warm and generous woman who shared her love of Judaism and legacy of humor with all who knew her, most especially her dynamic family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

CALICK--Gladys. The Board of Directors and Membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Gladys Calick. Our deepest sympathies are extended to the bereaved family. Jeffrey Weingarten, Acting President

BURNS--Arnold I. The Board of Directors of BioTime, Inc. mourns the loss of our former Director and dear friend. We always admired his wise counsel. We extend our deepest and sincere condolences to his family and to his many friends and colleagues. Michael D. West, Chief Executive Officer, Alfred D. Kingsley, Chairman of the Board

BURNS Arnold I. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. Arnold Burns, a great friend of Boys & Girls Clubs, and staunch advocate for America's children. He actively served on the Board for 31 years, including two as Chairman. His longtime leadership of the Government Relations Committee led to our dynamic relationship with the Department of Justice, resulting in hundreds of millions of dollars in support for local Clubs. He was a recipient of the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award, BGCA's most highly coveted honor. Arnie's support for the BGCA cause was tireless, and his eloquence and creativity at the podium was legendary all spurred by a deep, heartfelt compassion for the kids who most need and benefit from Boys & Girls Clubs. Our thoughts and prayers are with his beloved Felice and the entire Burns family. Arnie was a giant a champion a true friend of young people in need. He was genuinely one of a kind and we will miss him greatly. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Ron Gidwitz, Chairman James Clark, President

BROOKS--Norma. We mourn the passing of our dear Norma Brooks, widow of Harry Brooks. Her 96 years epitomized the adage Live Long and Live Well, as a loving, devoted inspiration to her ten great-grandchildren, five grandchildren, son Barry (Gail), (predeceased by daughter Judith Lawsky) sisters, nieces, nephews. She fervently supported Sunrise Florida Jewish Center, was active in National Hadassah and was past President of Sunrise Hadassah. Her ceaseless energy and thoughtfulness were reflected in her readiness to always participate in family celebrations, near and far, wearing her high heels and favored finery. Funeral services Friday at 1:30pm Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ, burial at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus.

BROCHSTEIN--Harry R. 10/4/1913 - 12/4/2009 On the anniversary of the 100th year of his birth we celebrate with affection this remarkable man. We love him. We miss him. He was our dad, step-dad, grandpa, great-grandpa and my wonderful husband.

WENDT--Rosemary, born in Vernon, Texas in 1939, daughter of the beloved Frank and Mary Lou Wendt, and adoring sister of Charles Wendt, passed away in her home in NYC on July 18, 2013 after a long illness. She will long be quoted by her many good friends, especially her Mary McCarthy group; and sorely missed for her sage advice, quick wit, Texas-style visits, and generosity. A private memorial service will be held October 8 in her home.

WEIDINGER--Hugh John III, 72, of Wakefield, Rhode Island, Oyster Bay, NY, died on Sunday, September 29, 2013, in Wakefield, RI. Calling hours will be held Friday, October 4, 2013 from 4-7pm at Avery-Storti Funeral Home, 88 Columbia Street, Wakefield, RI, (401) 783-7271. A Requiem Eucharist will be held at 10am on Saturday, October 5, 2013, at Saint Peter's-by-the-Sea, 72 Central Street, Narragansett, RI. SUFIAN--Harris. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Helene K. Gray, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor

SUFIAN--Harris. We will miss your laugh, your wit and your friendship. You always had a wonderful way of making sense of things, while throwing in that small piece of humor or cynicism, whether on the ski mountain, at weekend breakfasts or at a quiet dinner without the dogs (but with the Weiners). Our deepest condolences to dear Barbara and to Andrew, Ethan and Nicole. The Kasner Family

STEIN--Michael, 71, suddenly of septicemia. Distinguished US Trade attorney and sailor by way of New Haven, CT, Swarthmore, D.C. and Shady Side, MD. Beloved by his wife Eileen and his sister Laura. His many devoted fans will sorely miss their go-to person for wise counsel, sharp insight, incisive humor and unfailing support.

SPRINGER--June Reimer, of New York City, died peacefully on September 27, 2013 in Chico, CA at the age of 85. Born in 1928 in Hackensack, NJ to Alice and Rudolph Reimer, she grew up in Bogota NJ. June became a professional singer at 18, appearing in several musicals on Broadway (including "Kiss Me Kate" for which she recalled auditioning before Cole Porter; Sigmund Romberg's "My Romance;" and "Three Wishes For Jamie," among others); and on national tours including Romberg's "The Student Prince", in which she starred as the Princess. In the 1950s, under the stage name Monica Lane, June joined crooner Cass Franklin as a popular singing duo playing New York nightclubs such as The Latin Quarter, pioneer television variety shows such as The Colgate Comedy Hour, and Catskills resorts (Monica's publicity pin-up became the source material for Roy Lichtenstein's famous "Girl With Ball," in NYC's MoMA). In 1953, June married John Springer, whose career as a film and theater public relations agent became legend. With John, she enjoyed the glamour of the New York and international entertainment, arts and journalism worlds, but she was far more devoted to family: children Gary, Alicia, and Cynthia; grandchildren Nicholas and Olivia Springer, Zachary Gilman, and Anthony and Zora Thomas; and her sister Marilyn and family. Warm, funny, beautiful, and generous, June was beloved by loyal friends and family. A Memorial will be held later in October in New York City at the Players Club.

ORSHAN--Joseph, of Roslyn Heights, NY, October 3, 2013, age 92, former Chairman of Mikasa. Beloved husband of Judith, father of Janet (Barry), Peter (Patti), Andrew (Charlotte), brother of David (Nina), the late Marty (Miriam) and Seymour. Grandfather of Eden, Reuben, Renee. We will miss his special presence and enormous friendly personality.

NEMETH--Dr. Abraham. JBI International (the Jewish Braille Institute) deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Abraham Nemeth who was associated with JBI for more than 60 years. Dr. Nemeth was a Trustee of JBI and a long time and devoted supporter. Dr. Nemeth, who was born blind, was a brilliant mathematician and the creator of the Nemeth Braille Code for Mathematics and Scientific Notation. He was also a Hebraist and Jewish scholar who assisted JBI in publishing the Braille Hebrew Bible and other major liturgical texts in Braille for all Jewish denominations. The last and perhaps longest project he undertook for JBI was the compilation in Braille of The Complete Artscroll Siddur. His was a unique contribution to Jewish life and to the blind community and he will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Nemeth family. May his memory serve as a blessing. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman of the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President & CEO Israel A. Taub, Vice President & CFO

MATHIAS--Alvin. It is with profound sadness we mourn the passing of our dearest friend, Alvin Mathias, a man of deep humility, imagination, warmth and generosity. Alvin had an unbounded capacity to love, especially his cherished wife, Leslie, and his beloved children and grandchildren. He was an inspiration and guiding force to all who knew him. Alvin, you rewarded us, your friends, with love, humor and fierce loyalty. Our friendship was one of sincere admiration and devotion that cannot be broken. You were a lifelong source of happiness and love that will remain with us forever. Joyce & Richard Marion & Steve Nuny Valerie & Butch Stuie & Marcella Lori & David Amy & Shelly

LITTLE--Susan ("Suki"), nee Richards. Born: January 17, 1931; Educated at the Chapin School and Briarcliff College; Married William Riegel June 9, 1953, Divorced 1967; Married Robert ("Bob") Little November 14, 1969; Died September 30, 2013 after a long illness. Survived by her children: William Riegel Jr., Guy Riegel, Katherine Riegel and Margaret Riegel; brothers: Peter Richards and Archibald Richards; 10 grandchildren. Donations to Alzheimer's Foundation of America at: www.alzfdn.org/index.htm. Services will be held at the First Congregational Church in Litchfield, CT. 21 Torrington Rd. Litchfield, CT (860) 567-8705 on October 5th at 11am. Suki had a marvelous sense of humor, loved to laugh and could sing like an angel. Her forte was cooking and a delight it was for all who graced her table. She was kind beyond words and will be sorely missed by all who knew her.

KAUFMAN--Paul P.,passed away on September 18, 2013 in Florida. He was the husband of the late Marguery, father of Andrew (Corinne) and grandfather to Kate Gibbons (David), Jamie Watkis, Lisa Walsh (Brian) and great grandchildren, Paige, Anaya, Brooke and Caden. A WWII Army Airforce Veteran, POW, and Textile executive for M. Lowenstein. He was treasured by all. Contributions may be made to Planting Fields Foundation, P.O. Box 660, Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

KAPLOVE--Jay L.,86, of Tenafly, NJ. Beloved husband of Lila (nee Ozaroff) for 63 years. Devoted father of Kenneth (Debra), James and Jules (Sharon). Cherished grandfather of Charly, Jacqueline, Alizah, Jessica, Zachary, Jillian and Caroline. Loving son of the late Julius Henry and Mary (nee Hubsch). Brother of the late Robert. A Penn Wharton graduate, Executive Vice President of Presidential Life Insurance Co., JD, LLM, and author of the Jewish National Fund Stamp Catalogue, his greatest accomplishment was his love and devotion to his wife, children and grandchildren. Funeral Sunday, October 6, 2013 at 1:30pm at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of gifts or flowers, donations may be made to the Jewish National Fund or Temple Sinai of Bergen County.
HUGHEY--Janet E.,age 83, on September 2. Mother of four, grandmother of four, friend of countless many. We miss your loving embrace, mischievous smile, and passion for New York.

GOLD--Jeffrey Seth. It is with great sorrow that we mourn the passing of Jeffrey Seth Gold, son of Theodore David and Debra (Fridovich), brother of William (Nili), uncle of Doria and Avitai (Jocelyn), and great-uncle of Elijah and Tali. In 1969, Jeff founded Community Tax Aid in New York, for which he received an award from Mayor Beame. For two years, Jeff served on the IRS Commissioner's Advisory Group. Jeff will be remembered as a dear family member, a loyal friend with a superior intellect, and as a true advocate for marginalized groups culminating in his efforts at the forefront of the anti-smoking movement. A gifted writer and editor, avid reader, accomplished hiker, baseball fan and traveler, Jeff will always be honored by those who knew him. Funeral service will be held at 9:30am on Friday, October 4th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, located at 630 Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan.

GELBSTEIN--Arnold. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed member. Fox of Wayland, MA and the late Deborah M. Fox and Patricia A. Fox. Also survived by four granddaughters, 11 nieces and nice nephews. Husband of the late Sally Ingersoll Fox. Bryant Funeral Home of Wayland, MA. For online condolences please visit johncbryantfuneralhome.com.

EDELSTON--Martin. Our treasured friend and wise advisor for four decades. To his devoted wife Rita, and to the family of which he was so justly proud, we extend our deepest condolences. Marty's Legacy of Good Deeds endures. Rabbi Jonathan D. Levine The Prayer Book Press of Media Judaica

EDELSTON--Martin, 84, of Greenwich, CT, passed away peacefully on October 2, 2013. He was born in Newark, NJ and raised his family in Short Hills, NJ before moving to Greenwich in 1994. Marty, who started his career as an advertising salesman, became a pioneer in the direct marketing and publishing industries when he launched his company, Boardroom Inc., and the flagship Boardroom Reports newsletter in 1972, as well as subsequent newsletters, including "Bottom Line/Personal" and "Bottom Line/Health," and numerous books. He was a philanthropist, a provocateur, a caring man of action who helped millions of individuals, both directly and through the invaluable advice published these past 40 years in the company's newsletters and books. Marty is survived by his wife of 58 years, Rita, their three children, Sam Edelston, Sarah Hiner and Marjory Abrams and their spouses, and nine grandchildren. The funeral will be held at Temple Sholom in Greenwich, CT on Friday, October 4 at noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Jewish Family Service of Greenwich. www.jfsgreenwich.org or the nonprofit educational foundation Marketing Edge, www.marketingedge.org

CLANCY--Thomas L.,Jr. Schulman Lobel Wolfson Zand Abruzzo Katzen & Blackman LLP extend their deepest condolences to the family of Thomas L. Clancy, Jr. Tom was a wonderful person and will be missed by many.

BURNS--Arnold. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the loss of Arnold Burns, a longtime ADL Honorary National Commissioner. A distinguished attorney and principled public servant, he was committed to justice and equality, the essence of our mission. He will be fondly remembered for his intellect, good humor, and wit. Barry Curtiss-Lusher, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

BURNS Arnold I. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. Arnold Burns, a great friend of Boys & Girls Clubs, and staunch advocate for America's children. He actively served on the Board for 31 years, including two as Chairman. His longtime leadership of the Government Relations Committee led to our dynamic relationship with the Department of Justice, resulting in hundreds of millions of dollars in support for local Clubs. He was a recipient of the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award, BGCA's most highly coveted honor. Arnie's support for the BGCA cause was tireless, and his eloquence and creativity at the podium was legendary all spurred by a deep, heartfelt compassion for the kids who most need and benefit from Boys & Girls Clubs. Our thoughts and prayers are with his beloved Felice and the entire Burns family. Arnie was a giant a champion a true friend of young people in need. He was genuinely one of a kind and we will miss him greatly. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Ron Gidwitz, Chairman James Clark, President

BURNS--Arnold I.,former Deputy Attorney General of the United States in the second Reagan administration, died October 1. He was 83. The cause was heart failure and complications from Parkinson's disease. Mr. Burns is survived by his wife of 62 years Felice, his son Doug Burns and his wife Joanne; his daughter Linda and John Crump; and his four grandchildren, Brendan, Scott, Leah and Katie. He is also survived by his sisters Dr. Ruth Cowan and Norma Salem. Mr. Burns, who started the law firm of Burns and Lesser in 1960 with his colleague and friend, Stanley Lesser, grew that firm to over 120 lawyers. He then left New York after being named Associate Attorney General in 1985, number three at Department of Justice. After confirmation and the nomination of then Deputy Attorney General D. Lowell Jenson to serve as a United States District Judge in California, Mr. Burns was named and then confirmed by the Senate as Deputy Attorney General. Arnold Burns was born in 1930 in Brooklyn, NY. After graduating from Union College and the Cornell Law School, he served in the Army Judge Advocate General for four years before beginning law practice in New York City. As a JAG lawyer, he handled military appeals from courts martial. Mr. Burns also served as national chairman of the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and was a tireless advocate for our nations' youth. He also served as Chairman of the Board of Union College and of the International Centre for Missing and Exploited Children, and also served on the Boards of Freedoms Foundation of Valley Forge, Biotime, and Diopysis, and was an active member of the Lawyers Division of the Anti-Defamation League.

BARNES--Grace L. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of our beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, Grace L. Barnes, on September 30, 2013. She died as she lived surrounded by the love and admiration of her family. Her 87 years were a testament to her unwavering devotion to family, friends and community. Her amazing heart and endless love will be missed. Viewing Sunday October 6, 2013 from 2-5 and 7-9pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, NY 10023; Funeral services, Monday, October 7, 2013, 10am at Christ & St. Stephen's Church, NYC.

BARTHELL--Otto L. Happy 100th birthday, Daddy! We miss you very much. Love your children.

TOGUT--Stanley. Devoted husband of Roslyn for 65 years, loving father of Albert, Susan and Joan (Kalmans). Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Parker, Michael and Zachary. Brother of late Lawrence. Lived a full and good life filled with sweetness and love for 87 years. Funeral will be at noon on Monday, October 7 at Riverside-North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza in Great Neck, Long Island.

SCHEINBERG--Sidney. Beloved father of Sari Scheinberg Alange and Ronald Scheinberg, grandfather of Aurora and Gabriel Alange and Melissa, Carly and Danielle Scheinberg and father-in-law of Stacy Scheinberg and Sverker Alange. Sidney was a WWII hero, having been awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross (and other commendations) for his service as a lead navigator of the 8th Air Force. He was a loving husband to Eleanor (z'l), a wonderful father, grandfather and father-in-law and a successful businessman as Chairman of DeLuxe Fashions. Funeral services on October 6, 2013, 9am at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, 90th St. Donations in honor of Sidney's memory can be made to the Ramaz School, 125 East 85th St., NY, NY 10028 (attn: K Rochlin).

MORFOGEN--Elaine, lifelong New York resident, died October 2, 2013 at her home in Manhattan at the age of 83. Born December 11, 1929, she was the devoted daughter of Diamond and Sam Morfogen of New York and Anavriti, Lakonias, Greece. Miss Morfogen was a graduate of Parsons School of Design and taught figure drawing and illustration in Parsons. She is known for lush, layered oil paintings, pastels, drawings and watercolors, portraits of children, landscapes and flowers. Her illustrations appeared in Vogue, McCalls, Town & Country, Seventeen, Ladies Home Journal and Interview, and numerous books. She was featured in American Artist for her unique methods as a noted painter and illustrator. Her paintings also served as images for the award-winning short film "A Texas Romance, 1909." She is survived by her sister Vivienne Brauman and brother George Morfogen and nieces Leslie Brauman and Amanda Brauman King. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave (81st) Monday, October 7th at 9:30am. Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery.

LEWIS--Roberta,The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our member, Roberta Lewis. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Arthur, and family. Jack Irushalmi, President
LEWIS--Roberta, on October 3, 2013. Beloved wife of Arthur. Loving mother of Alison and Mitchell Sisun and the late John. Cherished grandmother of Dean.

KAPLOVE--Jay L.,86, of Tenafly, NJ. Beloved husband of Lila (nee Ozaroff) for 63 years. Devoted father of Kenneth (Debra), James and Jules (Sharon). Cherished grandfather of Charly, Jacqueline, Alizah, Jessica, Zachary, Jillian and Caroline. Loving son of the late Julius Henry and Mary (nee Hubsch). Brother of the late Robert. A Penn Wharton graduate, Executive Vice President of Presidential Life Insurance Co., JD, LLM, and author of the Jewish National Fund Stamp Catalogue, his greatest accomplishment was his love and devotion to his wife, children and grandchildren. Funeral Sunday, October 6, 2013 at 1:30pm at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of gifts or flowers, donations may be made to the Jewish National Fund or Temple Sinai of Bergen County.
