“The Paradise,” beginning Sunday night on PBS, centers on a 19th-century country girl who takes a job in a department store in northern England.
In the first week of the Obama administration’s health care enrollment period, consumers had questions on insuring dependent children over 26 years old, immigrants and pre-existing conditions.
The New York Film Festival continues to have some juicy fare, with one foot in the American commercial mainstream, and another in the realm of international art cinema.
Nora Chipaumire explores the notion of the black primitive in “rite riot.”
“House of Versace,” a Lifetime film based on Deborah Ball’s book of the same title, takes a look at the fashion dynasty built by Gianni Versace and continued after his death by his sister, Donatella.
“Grace Unplugged” takes its title character to Los Angeles for a career in the music industry and, ultimately, some life lessons from the Bible.
“A Rite,” a new dance-theater work keyed to the centenary of “The Rite of Spring,” was performed by Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane and SITI at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Michele Rosewoman’s set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola promoted her new album with New Yor-Uba.
Fusion, the new network that is a joint venture of Disney and Univision, named a chief, and Telemundo said its president, Emilio Romano, was stepping down.
Deborah Voigt, who withdrew last month from the Washington National Opera’s season-opening production of “Tristan und Isolde,” talks about that decision and her future singing choices.
The Mets announced that pitcher Matt Harvey would have Tommy John surgery on his pitching elbow, ending his attempts to avoid it.
By making an official offer, the Yankees expect to learn within a few days whether a deal is likely to be reached to extend Joe Girardi’s contract as manager.
After a power loss upended commutes for tens of thousands of riders, the New Haven line plans to return to normal operations in time for the Monday morning rush, transit officials said.
Gerrit Cole, 23, allowed two hits in six innings to the Cardinals’ potent lineup, sending the division series to Pittsburgh tied, 1-1.
After finishing the 2012-13 season low on the depth chart, Brad Richards looked good on the power play in the Rangers’ season opener and played left wing on the top line.
Alan Gilbert paired Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony with Mark-Anthony Turnage’s “Frieze,” written last year, at the New York Philharmonic on Thursday.
A growing number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East are crossing the ocean for Europe, and many never make it.
Senators argue that the move is nothing but a naked power grab by the government and Prime Minister Enda Kenny, masquerading as a cost-saving exercise.
The violence unleashed bubbling religious tensions in the wake of the terrorist attack last month on a shopping mall in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital.
The expulsion vote against Silvio Berlusconi represents his second setback of the week, after his failed attempt to bring down the country’s fragile coalition government.
Three episodes in the drama have proved popular, helped further by delayed viewing. “Lucky 7” on ABC was the first new show to be sidelined.
The contract extension means that the late-night host will be on the air well past the Jay Leno era on NBC.
While Representative Steve King’s constituents are beginning to question his tactics and his focus on the health law, they support his core commitment to cutting the size of government.
The mob killing, prompted by the discovery of mutilated body of a boy, is the latest blow to Madagascar’s struggle to emerge from turmoil.
Relatives and associates gave differing accounts of the mental state and history of Miriam Carey, who was killed after trying to drive into the White House complex.
FIFA’s president, Sepp Blatter, announced on Friday that a committee would examine a possible schedule change for the 2022 World Cup in Qatar and report back next year.
Among the countries in the European Union, whether or not members of the euro zone, all but Germany now have more adult unemployed workers than at the end of 2007.
Speaking to a civic group, mayoral candidate Bill de Blasio delivered his most detailed blueprint yet for how he would change New York.
Governors across the United States are contemplating the use of state funds to keep closed parks and programs operating until the deadlock in Washington is broken.
Carnegie Hall and its stagehands have settled the yearlong contract dispute that led to the cancellation of Carnegie’s opening-night concert.
Four days into the crisis, Congress appeared no closer to a resolution, and Speaker John A. Boehner urged President Obama to negotiate over his health care law.
The change of plans undercut President Obama’s “pivot” to Asia, and this week China’s leader, Xi Jinping, seized the opening in some of the nations Mr. Obama would have visited.
As expected, the N.B.A. on Friday barred Nets Coach Jason Kidd for two games after he pleaded guilty in July to a drunken-driving charge.
Because going from a tax-deferred I.R.A. to a tax-free Roth has huge implications, the government gives people a chance to change their minds.
Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, hopes to influence coming negotiations over what he described as a “comprehensive international struggle.”
General Giap, whose victory at Dien Bien Phu forced France from Vietnam, later waged a long battle with the United States military that eventually sapped America’s political will to fight.
Stocks were slightly higher as a partial shutdown of the federal government went into a fourth day on Friday, but the major indexes lost overall this week.
A year off to pursue learning outside of academics is increasingly common for new high school graduates, but it can cost as much as a year’s college tuition.
A defiant Alex Rodriguez alleged that Major League Baseball bought the cooperation of a Biogenesis witness and that the Yankees’ medical team was negligent.
The authorities did not give any indication of how much money might have been involved in any manipulation.
Japan’s nuclear watchdog agency summoned the Tokyo Electric Power Company to explain the repeated accidents and spills that have plagued the Fukushima nuclear plant since its meltdown in 2011.
Choppy waters around the island of Lampedusa hampered a search by the Italian Coast Guard divers for the hundreds of migrants still missing.
The social-networking service said in its stock filing that more than three-quarters of its recent users are outside the United States.
Representatives of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative bloc in Germany began a series of talks aimed at sounding out each side’s willingness to compromise.
Dozens of Syrians who fled their country’s conflict had occupied a ferry terminal in the northern port of Calais, demanding to reach Britain.
The pope made a pilgrimage to the Italian town of Assisi on the feast day of St. Francis, retracing the holy man’s footsteps and stressing the church’s commitment to care for the sick and the poor.
Samsung Electronics probably benefited from memory chip sales, analysts said, while HTC said it would lose about $101 million after its flagship smartphone failed to catch on.
RUBIN--Cynthia. 5/15/50-10/07/2010 In loving memory of my twin sister; never to be forgotten. Corinne and Family
JACOBS--Melvin. 8/26/26 - 10/06/93. Your deeds and accomplishments are still remembered by all who were privileged to know you. We miss you.Love Roz and Peggy

WILLIAMS--Mary Butler, 86, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, died Monday, September 30, 2013 in Montpelier, VT. Fieldston School 1943; Vassar College 1947. Past president, Scarsdale Women's Club; past president, Westchester Vassar Club. Wife of the late Dr. M. Henry Williams Jr. Mother of Stuart (wife Sarah) of Montpelier, Patricia (husband Joseph Garofalo) of Colchester, VT; Marshall (wife Marguerite Gousie) of Woonsocket, RI; Frances of Bonnieville, KY, and Richard of Barre, VT. Seven grandchildren and one great-grand-child. Full obituary at Legacy.com.

WILKIE--Margot. The family of Margot L.M. Wilkie invites you to a celebration of her life on Wednesday, October 9, 2013, at 5:30 in The Cathedral of St. John the Divine at 112th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NY.

WHALING--Suzanne Kelly. Suzanne "Suzy" Kelly Whaling, born on September 9, 1940 and died on September 27, 2013 after a hard-fought and courageous battle with depression. Suzy was a rare woman. She was a vibrant wife, mother, grandmother and friend whose limitless enthusiasm, infinite energy, and genuine interest in others was a truly extraordinary gift to all who knew her. She was 100% engaged in anything and everything that mattered to everyone she loved. She made every single person she knew whether for a few minutes or for a lifetime feel like they mattered. For Suzy, they genuinely did, as she sincerely wanted happiness and good fortune for all in her orbit. The ultimate fan and supporter, she never missed a chance to cheer on her children, and later her grandchildren. She created homes that were the active center of her children and their friends' lives. Her door was always opened, her refrigerator always stocked, and there always was room for another to join the dinner table. Suzy was fun, deeply loyal, and always positive. She was competitive and relentlessly curious. Suzy was a knock-out, both inside and out. But most important of all, Suzy had fierce and boundless love for her family and many friends. It was matched only by theirs for her. She is survived by Tony, her husband of 47 years; her children Collins (Sam) Baker, Sally, and Mark (Carolyn) Whaling, and her five grandchildren: Will and Jake Baker, Caden, Lilly and Beau Whaling, her beloved Reilly and pre-deceased by her son Tyler. In honor of Suzy's life, donations may be made to the Tyler Whaling Colgate University Scholarship Fund. "She will make the face of heaven shine so fine that all the world will be in love with night." William Shakespeare

VEAL--Charlotte Kelly, 83, former PR Director for all Hearst Magazines died in Manhattan September 14, 2013. Over a career spanning 50 years, Ms. Veal was an influential public relations, media, and advertising executive for top executives and their clients. She began as a secretary for Foote Cone & Belding in Los Angeles where she met Helen Gurley Brown; the two remained loyal friends their entire lives. Producer David O Selznick brought her to NYC. Later she held major PR positions with Ladies' Home Journal, Woman's Day, Esquire, NBC-TV, Benton & Bowles, D'Arcy and McCann ad agencies. Her philanthropic interest included a three-year job directing Public Information for Odyssey House. Ms. Veal was active in the Women's Forum, AWNY, and board member of New York Women in Communications, presenter of The Matrix Awards which she received for PR in 1983. Charlotte Kelly was born in Manhattan Beach, CA in 1929. Her first marriage to Page Thompson, Sr. ended in divorce. In 1984 she married C. Speed Veal, advertising VP at Prudential Insurance, who died in 1996. Ms. Veal is survived by many lifelong friends. Private memorial will be held at 6:30pm, November 7, 2013 at St. Peter's Church. Contact rml@grimblelaw.com for information. Donations in her memory can be made to VNSNY Hospice Residence, c/o Hospice Development Care. 1250 Broadway, 7th floor, NYC 10001.

TOGUT--Stanley. Devoted husband of Roslyn for 65 years, loving father of Albert, Susan and Joan (Kalmans). Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Parker, Michael and Zachary. Brother of late Lawrence. Lived a full and good life filled with sweetness and love for 87 years. Funeral will be at noon on Monday, October 7 at Riverside-North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza in Great Neck, Long Island.

TAWIL--Fred Ezra, on September 26, at 89, of Brooklyn, NY, Hemlock Farms, PA, and Herzliyah, Israel. Much loved father and grandfather, Fred was very well informed and widely read in many subjects. Firm in his ideas, he was always open to those of others. He invited debate without rancor and civil discourse with all. Fred served in the US Infantry and went to the University of Connecticut under the ASTP program and was later assigned to the 280th Engineers, Company A. Fred was in the second wave assault on Europe and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. Fred was a founder and partner of Mayfair Infants Wear, Inc. in New York. No one who knew Fred, his intelligence and generous nature, will forget him. He is survived by his wife Sally, four children: Adrienne, Robin, Joyce and Ezra, and four grandchildren. Fred, we love you.

SZABO--Dr. Gustav. Dr. Gustav Szabo passed away peacefully in his sleep at his residence in Tudor City Place, NYC, Tuesday evening October 2nd. Beloved father, he is survived by his three children, Pia and Thomas from NYC and Paul from Mamaroneck, NY. Born in Budapest Hungary on April 4th, 1921, he became the youngest individual at 18 years old, to have a seat on the Budapest Stock exchange when his father passed. After graduating the Business School at the University of Budapest, Gustav arrived at Ellis Island in February 1949 on Valentines Day. Speaking four languages fluently, he attended Columbia University where he received his Phd in Economics and lived at International House where he formed many of his life long friendships. As the founder of Progress Unlimited Inc. and Live Leads Corporation, this allowed him to travel the world and visit over 20 countries. He was also an interpreter for the U.S. State Department and introduced invited Hungarian groups to the country he loved. Full of life and love, he was always happy skiing or swimming, playing tennis or bridge, reading and traveling or just talking with old friends and family being sure to always end with a funny story or anecdote. The memorial service will be held on Monday, October 7th at 12:00pm at St. Stephens Church 414 East 82nd Street NYC 10028. 212-861-8500 www.ssh-nyc.org. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to your local boy scout troop on Gustav's behalf.

STEIN--Michael, 71, suddenly of septicemia. Distinguished US Trade attorney and sailor by way of New Haven, CT, Swarthmore, D.C. and Shady Side, MD. Beloved by his wife Eileen and his sister Laura. His many devoted fans will sorely miss their go-to person for wise counsel, sharp insight, incisive humor and unfailing support.

SPAROZIC--Joyce Dendievel, age 92, fashion designer, of Port Washington, on October 2, 2013. Beloved wife of Jean. Loving mother of Jill Morrison, Suzy and Wendy Dirkes. Adored grandmother of Jonathan and Ryan. Dear sister of Margaret Baer. Caring sister-in-law of William T. Allen. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington, Sunday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday at 10:30am at St. Peter of Alcantara RC Church. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

SLOAN--Don, M.D.,died September 30, age 84, of MSA of the Cerebellum. Retired from OB/GYN at Lenox Hill Hospital. Survived by his wife, Elaine, children Allison, Meredith and Elliot Sloan, step-son Peter Graham Wood, three grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. He had great passion for life. "Remember Rachel Corrie".

SCHWIMMER--Leonard, 90, died in Boca Raton, FL on September 24th. Beloved husband to his dearly departed wife Ruth for 58 years and father of Danae, Allyson, Claudia, proud and loving grandfather of Zoe, Rachel, Dara and Logan. Devoted brother to Jim. Grew up in the Bronx, long-time resident of Great Neck, NY, chemical engineering graduate of NYU. Veteran of WWII (lieutenant commander U.S. Navy.) Owner of Chieftain Automotive. Scrupulously honest in business, lover of European history, travel, chocolate babka, bridge, and veritable fount of knowledge. Irreplaceable and lovingly remembered always. Farewell salute! Goodbye Mr. Chips! Donations may be made to PBS Foundation (In memory of Leonard Schwimmer).

SCHEINBERG--Sidney. Beloved father of Sari Scheinberg Alange and Ronald Scheinberg, grandfather of Aurora and Gabriel Alange and Melissa, Carly and Danielle Scheinberg and father-in-law of Stacy Scheinberg and Sverker Alange. Sidney was a WWII hero, having been awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross (and other commendations) for his service as a lead navigator of the 8th Air Force. He was a loving husband to Eleanor (z'l), a wonderful father, grandfather and father-in-law and a successful businessman as Chairman of DeLuxe Fashions. Funeral services on October 6, 2013, 9am at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, 90th St. Donations in honor of Sidney's memory can be made to the Ramaz School, 125 East 85th St., NY, NY 10028 (attn: K Rochlin).

SAPADIN--Eugene, of Burlington, VT, age 73, on September 19. A graduate of Forest Hills High School, Middlebury College, Harvard University and the Claremont Graduate School in California, Gene was a popular professor of philosophy for 39 years at Johnson State College in Vermont and a dedicated researcher and lecturer at Wolfson College, Oxford University. He was friend, scholar, teacher, writer, uncle, brother and beloved curmudgeon. He leaves a huge Gene-shaped hole in the universe. A private memorial will be held in NYC on October 6 and a celebration of his life at Johnson State College on October 25.

SAAR--Bobbie, 92, died on September 28, 2013. Bobbie was wise, compassionate, generous and curious. She was a chef and baker extraordinaire, and an accomplished jewelry maker and seamstress. Her great talent was working one-on-one with children who had learning disabilities or hearing loss. Her first pupil was her own daughter, about whom she wrote a book, The Birth of Language (as Barbara Trace, with coauthor Shulamith Kastein). One student said that Bobbie taught her what words were. Decades later, as Bobbie struggled with dementia, that student became her art therapist. Bobbie was married for 63 years to Joe Saar, a psychotherapist, who died in 2008. They lived in White Plains and traveled the world together. They are survived by their sons David and Robert; daughter Carol; grandchildren Steven, Karen, Leslie, Brian and Eric; and a great-granddaughter, Gillian.

ROSENSTOCK--Stanley C. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the passing of our beloved brother, brother-in-law and uncle. Stanley was the patriarch of our family. A man of quiet strength and brilliant mind. Our love and devotion to Phyllis, his wife of 64 years, his five children, spouses, and nine grandchildren. We will miss you always. Sherry, Herb and family.

RIDGWAY--Emily Parsons, of Short Hills, NJ and Fishers Island, NY died peacefully on October 1st, two months before her 103rd birthday. Her husband William C. Ridgway, Jr. predeceased her, as did her sister, Lucille Parsons Balcom, and her brother, Joseph Lester Parsons, Jr. She is survived by her four children William C. Ridgway, III (Carol), Charles P. Ridgway (Julianne), Emily R. Crisp (Peter), and Sara R. McLean (Locke); eleven grandchildren, five step-grandchildren and 17 great-grandchildren and her step-sister, Harriet Wells Bailey. Emily was a dedicated volunteer, serving as President of the Short Hills Garden Club and going on to serve as a Vice-President of the Garden Club of America; as a Trustee of Miss Porter's School; as a Regent of Kenmore and as a member of The Auxiliary of Overlook Hospital. She was an Overlook Foundation Trustee from 1988-1994. In 2002 she received the Hospital's Lifetime Achievement Award for Community Service. She was a lifetime member of twenty-two philanthropic organizations. Following her husband's death in 1986, she pursued her long suppressed dream to be on stage by performing in a number of Paper Mill Playhouse productions. Emily was an avid collector of art and artifacts and travelled extensively including two trips around the world in her later years. Horticulture, particularly orchids, was her passion. She treasured her flower and vegetable garden at Fishers Island and tended it with loving care each summer while boasting she never bought a single vegetable during the season. Emily also held strong political views which she had no hesitation in expressing, sometimes to the consternation of her friends and family. Her exemplary life will be an inspiration to her family and all those who were privileged to know her. A celebration of her life will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Overlook Foundation (Box 220 Summit, NJ 07902) or The Island Health Project (Box 344, Fishers Island, NY 06390) would be appreciated.

RICE--Benjamin Manson, Jr.,of New York City, died September 19th at home at the age of 83. Ben grew up in Peterborough, NH and graduated from Milton Academy in 1948, Princeton in 1952 and the Harvard Business School in 1956. Ben served as an Army First Lieutenant followed by many years as a financial analyst. He was a member of the Union Club of New York City, traveled extensively, and was an accomplished photographer. Ben was a frequent volunteer and mentor for those in need. Ben is survived by his wife Joan Ross Rice of New York City and sister Judith Rice Millon of Washington, DC. Ben leaves behind sons Benjamin, John and Christopher, and four grandchildren. Donations may be made to The Salvation Army or the ASPCA.

PERKS--Harry Mark, on September 29, 2013. Loving husband of the late Gladys, father of Mark, Chris, Matthew and Clark. Executive Director of the Pennsylvania Convention Center, Streets Commissioner of Philadelphia, President of Day & Zimmermann, Deputy Superintendent of Schools of Philadelphia, and owner of Perks Reutter Associates. Described by the Daily News as "the man behind practically everything good" in Philadelphia. Memorial service followed by a luncheon will be Saturday, October 26, at 11am, at Central Baptist Church, 37 South Jackson St., Woodbury, NJ 08096. www.harrymperks.com

PENNOYER--Victoria Parsons, died peacefully at home surrounded by her family on September 30, 2013, at the age of 85. She was the beloved wife of Robert M. Pennoyer, her husband of 65 years. The two met when she was eighteen after he returned from the Pacific at the end of World War II. When he wrote to invite her to a performance of Oscar Wilde's Lady Windermere's Fan she replied: "Pleasure was my first sensation. Let us hope the evening does not lead us into any serious indiscretion. Your more than willing, Victoria." She was the adored mother of Christy Pennoyer, Russell Pennoyer, Tracy Pennoyer and Peter Pennoyer, mother-in-law of Helen Pennoyer, John Auchincloss and Katie Ridder, and grandmother of: Kate, Frances and Molly Greathead; Gordon, Robbie and his wife Polly, and Margaret Pennoyer; Emily and James Auchincloss; and Jane, Tony and Gigi Pennoyer. She is also survived by her much-loved sister Margaret Hendon Parker and by numerous nieces and nephews. Amazingly creative, her poetry and paintings expressed her love for her family, the beauty of nature, the city, and Central Park. Her imagination and humor, warmth, and capacity for love gave strength and inspiration to her children and grandchildren, and to her countless friends and admirers, and were a lifelong source of happiness to her husband Bobby. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, October 12 at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th Street, New York, N.Y. 10022, or Poets House, 10 River Terrace, New York, N.Y. 10282.

PAGANO--Frank, 93, died peacefully on September 30. Beloved husband of the late Helen (Laitin) Pagano. Loving father to step-daughters Julie Laitin and Laurie Bergner, devoted grandfather to Joel and Elizabeth Bergner, cherished uncle to Bruce Pagano. We (and all his ballroom partners) will miss his wonderful humor, kindness, patience and support. He was a plant manager at Con Ed for 48 years.

ORSHAN--Joseph, of Roslyn Heights, NY, October 3, 2013, age 92, former Chairman of Mikasa. Beloved husband of Judith, father of Janet (Barry), Peter (Patti), Andrew (Charlotte), brother of David (Nina), the late Marty (Miriam) and Seymour. Grandfather of Eden, Reuben, Renee. We will miss his special presence and enormous friendly personality.

MORFOGEN--Elaine, lifelong New York resident, died October 2, 2013 at her home in Manhattan at the age of 83. Born December 11, 1929, she was the devoted daughter of Diamond and Sam Morfogen of New York and Anavriti, Lakonias, Greece. Miss Morfogen was a graduate of Parsons School of Design and taught figure drawing and illustration in Parsons. She is known for lush, layered oil paintings, pastels, drawings and watercolors, portraits of children, landscapes and flowers. Her illustrations appeared in Vogue, McCalls, Town & Country, Seventeen, Ladies Home Journal and Interview, and numerous books. She was featured in American Artist for her unique methods as a noted painter and illustrator. Her paintings also served as images for the award-winning short film "A Texas Romance, 1909." She is survived by her sister Vivienne Brauman and brother George Morfogen and nieces Leslie Brauman and Amanda Brauman King. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave (81st) Monday, October 7th at 9:30am. Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery.

L'ESPERANCE--Laura Ann. Laura Ann L'Esperance died in her home on September 22, 2013. She was 49 years old. Born in New York City, she was a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis A. L'Esperance, Jr. of New York City, Water Mill, NY and Palm Beach, FL. She attended The Convent of the Sacred Heart, and graduated from St. Paul's School, Tulane University, and the Gemological Institute of America. At age 12 she was Tri-State figure skating champion and won several competitions in the Northeast. She trained at Sky Rink in New York and in Sun Valley, Idaho with Peter Dunfield. In addition to skating, Laura was an accomplished equestrian, and enjoyed open water scuba diving. She was a volunteer at the New York Junior League and made her debut there. Laura, a gemologist, worked with several jewelers, including Buzz Baumgold Fine Jewelry, Harry Winston and Kaufmann de Suisse. The funeral took place on Thursday, September 26 at The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, followed by a private burial at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Cemetery in Southampton, NY. Laura is survived by her parents, her brother, Francis A. L'Esperance III, her sister, Linda L'Esperance Lartigau, and her daughter, Winston Aylesworth Rossetter. Memorial donations may be made to the Southampton Fresh Air Home, 36 Barkers Island Road, Southampton, NY 11968. (www.sfah.org)

KURZ--Jeffery W.,88, speech and drama professor, died September 27, Leonia, NJ; Cleveland born, Kurz was in the Coast Guard in WWII, later became a Quaker committed to peace and a draft counselor during Vietnam. Graduate of Stanford (BA) and Columbia (PhD) he taught at CCNY and Baruch College. Poet, playwright, actor, director, active with Leonia Players' Guild, Kurz is survived by wife of 63 years Janis (Grimes); children Nancy Wood (Tim), Jeffery W. Kurz, Jr., David L. Kurz; many loving kin. Service is Noon, October 27, Friends Quaker Meeting House, Ridgewood, NJ.

KRIEDMAN--Warren, M.D. passed away unexpectedly on August 19, 2013. He was born in New York, the son of the late Shirley and Herbert Kriedman. He was a respected psychiatrist, well loved by his patients. He enjoyed his family and will be greatly missed by them. He is survived by his daughter Casey, son-in-law Edward, grandson George, and his sister Barbara, her husband Ernest, and his niece and nephew, as well as his cat, Molly. Services have already been held. Donations in his name can be made to the Secaucus Animal Shelter.

KAUFMAN--Paul P.,passed away on September 18, 2013 in Florida. He was the husband of the late Marguery, father of Andrew (Corinne) and grandfather to Kate Gibbons (David), Jamie Watkis, Lisa Walsh (Brian) and great grandchildren, Paige, Anaya, Brooke and Caden. A WWII Army Airforce Veteran, POW, and Textile executive for M. Lowenstein. He was treasured by all. Contributions may be made to Planting Fields Foundation, P.O. Box 660, Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

HOTCHKISS--Ann G.,90, passed away September 28 in Wilmington, DE. Wife of the late Horace (2005). Beloved mother of Lucinda Hotchkiss-Diel (Ronald Diel) and Benjamin. Memorial service at Chandler Funeral Home, Wilmington, DE October 19 at 2pm.

HOLLEY--Irving Brinton, Jr.,Distinguished Professor Emeritus of History at Duke University and Major General, United States Air Force (ret.), died August 12, 2013, in Durham, NC, aged 94. For further information: irvingbholley.blogspot.com

HARTOCOLLIS--Dr. Peter, psychoanalyst, former director of the C.F. Menninger Memorial Hospital and founder of the Hellenic Psychoanalytical Society, died September 24, in Philadelphia. Dr. Hartocollis was at the Menninger clinic in Topeka, KS, a magnet for therapists from around the world, from 1957 to 1980. He returned to his native Greece as chairman and professor of psychiatry at the University of Patras and founded the contemporary Greek psychoanalytic movement. A frequent traveler to Mount Athos, confidant of monks and expert in mysticism, he wrote 13 books, including a series of novels rooted in his youth in Mani during the German occupation and civil war. He is survived by his wife, Calliope, of Athens and Philadelphia, children, Anemona, Lina and Thomas, and six grandchildren. As he wrote in his book, "Time and Timelessness," one more summer in Greece has become one less.

HARLEY--Catherine E. Chi Chi (Catherine E.) of New York City, of breast cancer, October 2, peacefully at home with husband John Ryan by her side. Chi Chi loved her native Brooklyn and celebrated life in her love of cooking, gardening, animals and the arts. A strongly independent woman whose radiance was felt by all the many lives she touched. While thoughtful and kind, she was armed with a sharp sense of humor and did not suffer fools. She freely expressed her opinions, taking action in the causes she believed in. Her trademark smile in good times and bad will endure in the hearts of her loving family and friends. Funeral services, Monday, October 7 at 12 noon Riverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11210. Donations to dedicate a Magnolia Tree in tribute to Chi Chi can be made online to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden (http://www.bbg.org/support).

HALPERT--Edward R.,Died September 29 in New York City of complications of Parkinson's Disease. He was 80 years old. Gracious, competent, sensible, generous and kind, Ed had a long and notably happy life, enriched by his extraordinary gift for friendship and by his devotion to his wife and to their children and grandchildren, sources of enormous pride and joy to him. An avid sailor, he grew up in Kings Point, learning to sail when he was seven years old and spending much time as a teenager sailing and racing on Long Island Sound. After earning a BA from Bates College and MBA from the Harvard Business School, he served for three years as an officer in the US Army Finance Corps and embarked on a career that culminated in founding, with his colleague Ira Sahlman, a chain of retail fabric stores and a highly successful textile converting business, the Tussah Company. He retired in 1992 to be able to spend more time travelling during school vacations with his wife, Evy, then Head of the Brearley School, and to pursue a vast array of shared interests and experiences among them tennis and sailing with family and friends, theater, opera, ballet, museum-going and chamber music (he began studying the cello in his late twenties and attained a modest level of competence which enabled him to enjoy playing slow movements of Mozart and Beethoven trios and quartets with far more accomplished amateurs). He was a Fellow for Life of the Metropolitan Museum (thanks to a gift his family made to the Costume Institute in memory of his father, the US manufacturer for Jacques Fath), and early in his career he was President of the Wiltwyck School for Boys, a residential treatment center for troubled, delinquent, court-referred teenagers. He later served on the Board of the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (now renamed the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation) and on the Board of Prep for Prep, an academic program which prepares minority students for admission to independent schools. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Evelyn J. Halpert, their two sons, James J. Halpert of Washington, DC and David C. Halpert of Singapore, and four grandsons, Sam, Daniel, Rustam and Ramsey, all of whom miss him terribly. A celebration in his memory will be held at the Century Association, 7 West 43rd St, at 5:30pm on Thursday, October 17. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the International Rescue Committee.

HALPERT--Edward, The Brearley School deeply mourns the passing of Edward R. Halpert, husband of Evelyn J. Halpert '52, Head of the School from 1975 to 1997. Jane Foley Fried, Head of School The Brearley School

GLICK--Gertrude Bluminson, died in San Francisco at the age of 103 on October 3, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband Dr. Bernard Glick. She is survived by her son, Ira Glick, four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. She was a devoted sister, wife and mother.

FIORENTINO--Imero, passed away peacefully at home after a long illness on October 1. He is survived by his loving wife Angela, daughter Rev. Linda Crabbs, son-in-law Kenneth Crabbs and grandson Christian. A Visitation will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St., NYC from 6-9pm on Sunday, October 6th; a funeral Mass will be held at 10:30am on Monday, October 7th at St. Malachy's Church, 239 W. 49th St., NYC.

EIGARD--Russ, 59, died recently at his Honk Lake cottage, upstate New York. Russ was born in Oakland, CA, graduated from the University of California at Berkeley and attended New York University after moving to New York in 1980. An outstanding editor and marketing executive, he was a long-time employee of PaineWebber's research and asset management divisions. Predeceased by his partner, Charles Goggans and his parents, Russ is survived by a sister, Kerry Mello, and his brother, Bill Eigard. He is also survived by a large circle of loving friends who found enormous pleasure in sharing long conversations, unending laughter and his passionate, and sometimes passing commitments. A memorial will be celebrated November 3 in New York City. Contact margo.alexander1@gmail.com for details.

DeMERS--Danielle G.,68, on August 26, 2013. Daughter of Janice and Joe DeMers. Artist, educator and entrepreneur, Danielle will be remembered fondly by the many people whose lives she touched and changed.

DEL DUCA--Peter A.,(Mr. Downtown) on October 4, 2013 of Plandome. Executive Vice President of Cushman & Wakefield for many years. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Denise Zenaldin, Evelyn McKeon, Helen Johnson, Laura Walls, Janice Hyland, Therese Hept. Cherished grandfather of 13 and brother of Donald Del Duca and Louise Franza. Visitation will be held at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Monday and Tuesday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10am, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset with interment to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

COOK--Karen Strauss. 61, passed away peacefully at home in New York on October 2, 2013. She was born on April 7, 1952 in Yonkers, New York to Anthony J. Strauss and Marion Hanney Strauss. Karen earned a Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy, magna cum laude, from Wheaton College in 1974. She received an MBA in 1979 from New York University, which she attended at night while working full-time at Goldman Sachs. Karen's career in the securities and investment business spanned more than 30 years, most recently as Chief Investment Officer of Steinhardt Management Company. From 1975 until 1988, she was a trader in the Equities Division at Goldman Sachs & Co. Karen was the first woman hired in Equities and the third female finance professional at the firm. From 1995 to 2008, Karen worked at Steinhardt Partners where she served as Chief Investment Officer and managed a hedge fund of funds. Karen was actively involved in various charitable organizations, serving on the boards of the International Rescue Committee, The LiveStrong Foundation and Wheaton College where she chaired the Investment Committees. She was also a board member of The Initiative to Educate Afghan Women. As an early female professional on Wall Street, Karen was influential in developing policies to address working mothers and other family needs issues at Goldman Sachs. After leaving Goldman Sachs, she co-founded AlternaTrak, an executive placement firm for female finance professionals seeking part-time employment while caring for their families. Through 100 Women In Hedge Funds, where she has been named to receive its 2013 Leadership Award, Karen mentored many professional women. Karen was married to Everett R. Cook II for 33 years with whom she raised her two sons Everett Cook III and Conor Cook of New York City. Karen was happiest while working in her garden, playing tennis or golf with friends, or traveling with her family. In 2008, Karen was diagnosed with progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), a rare neurodegenerative disease. The Cook family would like to express their most sincere gratitude to all the friends and caregivers who supported Karen through her illness. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial donations be made to the CurePSP Foundation in memory of Karen Cook at: http://www.psp.org/donate/ A memorial service will be held at 11am on Monday, October 7, 2013 at St. James Church at 865 Madison Avenue in New York.

COHN--Jeffrey A.,beloved son of Pearl and the late Herbert; dear brother of Dr. Robert (Sylvia) and cherished uncle of Benjamin and Zachary. Services Sunday, 11:30am at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY.

CLEM--Gordon H. We are deeply saddened to announce that Gordon Clem, former Headmaster of Saint Thomas Choir School, died on Sunday, September 29, after a lengthy illness. Gordon H. Clem (1931-2013) joined the Choir School faculty in 1955 as an athletic coach and then as a teacher in math and science. In 1963 he became Senior Master and assistant to the Headmaster. In 1967 he was appointed Headmaster by Dr. Morris (X Rector from 1954 to 1972), who recruited Mr. Clem to the Choir School in the first instance. Gordon was distinguished as a math teacher, and as Headmaster he brought good order, academic excellence, efficient administration, and, it is right to say, renown, to Saint Thomas Choir School. In 1985, together with Father John Andrew (XI Rector 1972-1996), the Wardens and Vestry, and architect Harold Buttrick, Mr. Clem played a key role in planning and executing the move of the Choir School from West 55th Street to its present location to a new building designed and built for the purpose on West 58th Street; the move was accomplished in 1987. The new building was named "Gordon Clem House;" Mr. Clem's name is carved on the cornerstone. Mr. Clem retired as Headmaster in 1995. There will be a memorial service for Mr. Clem on Sunday, October 13 at 4pm at Saint Thomas Church, 5th Ave. and 53rd Street. Rector Wardens Vestry Headmaster Saint Thomas Church and Choir School

BERKOWITZ--Edwin J.,of New York, NY passed away on September 17, 2013. He was the beloved son of Shirley B. Rosen and sister of Marilyn Littlefoot. He received a BA degree at SUNY New Paltz, a JD degree from New York University School of Law and an MBA from New York University Stern School of Business. He was a long time Business Consultant with Randa Accessories. He will be missed by many friends and colleagues who loved him, and to whom he was a very special person. He was known for his intelligence, being the best at what he did and for his humanity. He was a supporter of many animal rescue and welfare charities.

BEACH--Arthur T. Arthur died peacefully at home on October 3rd at the age of 92. He was born on December 2, 1920 in Brooklyn and lived his entire life in Huntington. Artie graduated from Stony Brook Prep School and Lafayette College, class of 1942, with a degree in mechanical engineering. He played football for the Leopards and was a member of Phi Delta Theta. He served as an artillery officer in the Pacific Theatre from 1942-1946 in WWII. He was Chairman of the Board of Beach Russ Company, Abbe Engineering, and a member of the American Vacuum Society. Artie held several patents in vacuum engineering. He was also a long-time member of Huntington Country Club where he excelled at tennis and paddle tennis. With his sons earning three national championship trophies, Artie was a lifelong lacrosse fan. He had a magnetic personality and keen sense of humor. Artie had a wonderful life full of family fun, good times and great friends. He is survived by five children and their in-laws: Rick and Cade of Maplewood, NJ; Betsy and Monk of Rye, NY; Liz of Cold Spring Harbor, NY; Cyndy and Mark of Pasadena, MD; Todd of Huntington, NY; Peter and Lisa of Huntington, NY; fourteen grandchildren and two great- grandchildren. He is predeceased by his beautiful wife of 60 years, Kiki, and his beloved son, CA. Contributions may be made in Artie's memory to the US Lacrosse Foundation, 113 West University Parkway, Baltimore, MD 21210. A memorial service will be held at the Old First Church in Huntington, NY on Thursday, October 17th at 11am.

BARNES--Grace L. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of our beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, Grace L. Barnes, on September 30, 2013. She died as she lived surrounded by the love and admiration of her family. Her 87 years were a testament to her unwavering devotion to family, friends and community. Her amazing heart and endless love will be missed. Viewing Sunday October 6, 2013 from 2-5 and 7-9pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, NY 10023; Funeral services, Monday, October 7, 2013, 10am at Christ & St. Stephen's Church, NYC.
ARENSTEIN--Renee. My confidant, my friend, rest easy, I'll miss you and our calls. Gloria S. Boris

ADELSON--Claire,Dearest Sister to Shirley. Devoted Aunt to Ronnie and Andrew, Nancy, Barbara, Amanda and Emily. Will always remember our many holiday dinners, celebrations and good times together. We will miss you forever. The Moss and Segal families

WILEY--Marcia D.,of New York City, died September 8 at age 95 after a brief illness. She was born on February 17, 1918 in Hempstead, NY and spent her childhood with three brothers in Revere, MA and Bronxsville, NY. She graduated from Connecticut College in 1941. A true member of "the greatest generation," she served during WWII with the Office of Strategic Services as a transcriptionist. In 1946 she began a lifelong career at Yachting Magazine, rising from an entry-level position to Executive Editor at the time of her retirement in 1988. During her time at Yachting she traveled the world extensively as a journalist and sailor and crewed on several boats competing in the New York to Bermuda regatta. Following retirement, like Grandma Moses, she became an avid painter and beloved figure at the Students' Art League. Her travels continued and took her above the Arctic Circle twice, to Antarctica, the Galapagos Islands, Europe, Scandinavia, Egypt and heli-hiking in British Columbia at age 88. She was an active member of the New York Yacht Club and served on the membership committee for many years. Her active mind, keen interest in art and politics, generosity, loyalty, independence and kindness were in evidence until the end and appreciated by all who knew her. Pre-deceased by her three accomplished brothers, she is survived and deeply missed by two nephews and two nieces and their families, all residing in New Hampshire.

TOGUT--Stanley. Devoted husband of Roslyn for 65 years, loving father of Albert, Susan and Joan (Kalmans). Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Parker, Michael and Zachary. Brother of late Lawrence. Lived a full and good life filled with sweetness and love for 87 years. Funeral will be at noon on Monday, October 7 at Riverside-North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza in Great Neck, Long Island.

SULLIVAN--Gloria Elizabeth Ann. The St. John's University family mourns the passing of Gloria Elizabeth Ann Sullivan, dear friend, model of grace and compassion, and, together with her beloved husband, trustee emeritus and first lay chair of the University's Board of Trustees, Eugene Sullivan '42C, '73HON, extraordinarily generous benefactor. Gloria lived the mission of this University in her many works of charity for the poor and the sick; for more than half a century she gave of her time, her love, and her energy to the Church and her Long Island neighbors, especially through her volunteer work at St. Francis Hospital. St. John's gave tribute to her dedication to others by presenting her with the St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Medal and the President's Medal. We shall remember her selflessness and compassion always. Our thoughts and prayers go to her husband, Gene, their children and grandchildren at this time of sorrow. Peter P. D'Angelo, Chair, Board of Trustees Reverend Joseph L. Levesque, President

SKURKA--Joseph, beloved husband of Maxine, loving father of Jordana, adoring grandfather of Kaylie, died on October 5th at the age of 77. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, 1:00pm Tuesday, October 8th.

SIMMONS--Christopher. Christopher DeWitt Simmons, of Alexandria, Virginia and Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts died on October 3, 2013, in his sleep. He is survived by his wife, Laura McIntosh Simmons, children Tucker McIntosh Simmons and Charlotte Bleecker Simmons, all of Alexandria, Virginia; his father, Richard DeLacey Simmons, former President of the Washington Post Company, also of Alexandria; his sister Robin Simmons Turner (Eric), niece Merrill and nephews Brooks and Griffin of Arlington, Virginia. Born on April 19, 1963, in Huntington, New York, Christopher was the son of Richard and the late Mary Bleecker Simmons. A gifted athlete, at Deerfield Academy, in Deerfield, Massachusetts, he was a member of the school's football and lacrosse teams. Christopher attended Duke University and received his Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in fine arts and art history from Tufts University. He also held a degree with a concentration in painting and drawing from the School of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, receiving its highest artistic prize, The Boit Award, in his first year. Christopher was an inveterate traveler, visiting all seven of the world's continents. He was one of the first Americans to travel to China after Nixon's historic visit and to Vietnam in 1994. An accomplished artist, his travels were reflected in his art. Christopher's signature mixed media technique merged photography and painting, documenting the monochromatic landscape of Antarctica as poetically as the Soviet Pacific fleet in Vladivostok and the desert refuge of WWII American planes in Arizona. Galleries in Washington, DC, Los Angeles, New Jersey and New York City showed his work. Christopher was intimately involved in his children's lives much to their benefit. He was active in their sporting activities; including coaching his daughter's youth lacrosse team and expanding his son's winning club swim team. Christopher devoted a significant effort to fundraising for Saint Stephens and St. Agnes School, Alexandria, Virginia and Washington DC's St. John's College High School. He was a member of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Belle Haven Country Club, Farmington Country Club and the Mill Reef Club. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, October 8, at 1pm, at the historic St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Virginia. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that Christopher be memorialized with contributions to the American Heart Association and the Lung Cancer Alliance.

SCHECHTMAN--Laurette. Laurette Baumann Schechtman passed away peacefully at her home in Princeton, NJ on October 5, 2013 at the age of 92 surrounded by her loving family. Born December 17th, 1920 daughter of Martin and Anne Schurman. She had unwavering devotion to her family, friends and community. Laurette was a long time resident of Freeport and Bayshore Long Island. She attended Pratt Institute and graduated from Hofstra University. Laurette was an accomplished artist and her mezzo soprano voice delighted audiences, friends and family. Her pure voice was only exceeded by her intrinsic elegance and beauty. She was pre-deceased by her first husband, Lester Baumann. She is survived by her husband Dr. Seymour Schechtman, sister Roberta Bucovetsky of Toronto, children Florence Kahn and Jeffrey Baumann, son-in-law Dr. Steven Kahn, daughter-in-law Nancy Baumann, grandson-in-law, Mitchel Sonies, granddaughter-in-law, Nnenna Lynch Kahn, grandchildren Jonathon, Caroline, Maxwell, Justin. and great-grandchildren Ava, Ellis and Margo. She will be forever missed and will live in the memories of all who knew and loved her. Funeral services will be held at the Jewish Center, 435 Nassau St. Princeton, New Jersey, October 8, 12noon. Interment will be at Mt Ararat Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to The Jewish Center Life and Legacy Endowment.

OCHS--Daniel, 85, died peacefully October 4. Born Cologne, Germany. Bronx High School of Science, City College, Phi Beta Kappa. Chief, Radiotherapy Bronx-Lebanon Hospital. Survived by loving wife Arlene Spark, siblings Eva, Michael, children Jordan, Jennifer, Susan, Danielle.

LANIER--Sidney. His strong belief in the participation of Art in religious worship led to his co-founding The American Place Theatre, a mission of St. Clements Episcopal Church, at that time moribund. He engendered peace and inspired all of us who knew him. Let us now praise Sidney Lanier! Wynn Handman Artistic Director and Co-Founder, The American Place Theatre
KAPLAN-RUBIN--Harriet. Beloved wife of Ivan Rubin, adored mother of Keith (Alice) and Seth (Miriam) Kaplan. Honored teacher and mentor.

HARLEY--Catherine E. Chi Chi (Catherine E.) of New York City, of breast cancer, October 2, peacefully at home with husband John Ryan by her side. Chi Chi loved her native Brooklyn and celebrated life in her love of cooking, gardening, animals and the arts. A strongly independent woman whose radiance was felt by all the many lives she touched. While thoughtful and kind, she was armed with a sharp sense of humor and did not suffer fools. She freely expressed her opinions, taking action in the causes she believed in. Her trademark smile in good times and bad will endure in the hearts of her loving family and friends. Funeral services, Monday, October 7 at 12 noon Riverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11210. Donations to dedicate a Magnolia Tree in tribute to Chi Chi can be made online to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden (http://www.bbg.org/support).

HALPERT--Edward R.,Died September 29 in New York City of complications of Parkinson's Disease. He was 80 years old. Gracious, competent, sensible, generous and kind, Ed had a long and notably happy life, enriched by his extraordinary gift for friendship and by his devotion to his wife and to their children and grandchildren, sources of enormous pride and joy to him. An avid sailor, he grew up in Kings Point, learning to sail when he was seven years old and spending much time as a teenager sailing and racing on Long Island Sound. After earning a BA from Bates College and MBA from the Harvard Business School, he served for three years as an officer in the US Army Finance Corps and embarked on a career that culminated in founding, with his colleague Ira Sahlman, a chain of retail fabric stores and a highly successful textile converting business, the Tussah Company. He retired in 1992 to be able to spend more time travelling during school vacations with his wife, Evy, then Head of the Brearley School, and to pursue a vast array of shared interests and experiences among them tennis and sailing with family and friends, theater, opera, ballet, museum-going and chamber music (he began studying the cello in his late twenties and attained a modest level of competence which enabled him to enjoy playing slow movements of Mozart and Beethoven trios and quartets with far more accomplished amateurs). He was a Fellow for Life of the Metropolitan Museum (thanks to a gift his family made to the Costume Institute in memory of his father, the US manufacturer for Jacques Fath), and early in his career he was President of the Wiltwyck School for Boys, a residential treatment center for troubled, delinquent, court-referred teenagers. He later served on the Board of the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (now renamed the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation) and on the Board of Prep for Prep, an academic program which prepares minority students for admission to independent schools. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Evelyn J. Halpert, their two sons, James J. Halpert of Washington, DC and David C. Halpert of Singapore, and four grandsons, Sam, Daniel, Rustam and Ramsey, all of whom miss him terribly. A celebration in his memory will be held at the Century Association, 7 West 43rd St, at 5:30pm on Thursday, October 17. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the International Rescue Committee.

COOK--Karen Strauss. Wall Street pioneer Karen Strauss Cook passed away peacefully at her home in New York on Wednesday morning, October 2, 2013. She was 61. Karen was born April 7, 1952 in Yonkers, New York to Anthony J. Strauss and Marion Hanney Strauss. Karen earned her Bachelor of Arts degree in Philosophy, magna cum laude, from Wheaton College in 1974. She received an MBA in 1979 from New York University, which she attended at night while working full-time at Goldman Sachs & Co. Karen's career in securities and investments spanned more than three decades. From 1975 until 1988, she worked as a trader in the Equities Division at Goldman Sachs & Co. Karen was the first woman hired in that division and the third female finance professional at Goldman Sachs. Beginning in 1995, Karen served as Chief Investment Officer at Steinhardt Partners where she managed their fund of funds. She retired in 2008. At Goldman Sachs, Karen was influential in developing new policies that would address family issues for working mothers. She also co-founded AlternaTrak, an executive placement firm for female finance professionals who sought part-time employment while caring for their families. Karen mentored countless young women through the 100 Women In Hedge Funds organization, from which she will receive the 2013 Leadership Award. Karen was actively involved in charitable organizations, serving on a number of Boards. She chaired the Investment Committees at the International Rescue Committee, The LiveStrong Foundation and Wheaton College. She was also a Board Member of The Initiative to Educate Afghan Women. Karen was happily married to Everett R. Cook II for 33 years with whom she raised her two sons, Everett R. Cook III and Conor W. Cook, both of New York City. Karen most enjoyed spending time with her family in Millbrook, working in her garden, playing tennis and golf with friends, and adventuring abroad. In 2008, Karen was diagnosed with progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), a rare neurodegenerative disease. The Cook family would like to express their most sincere gratitude to all their friends and caregivers who supported Karen through her illness. Your gifts, thoughts, prayers, and time have been so deeply appreciated. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the CurePSP Foundation in memory of Karen Cook at: http://www.psp.org/donate/ A memorial service will be held at 11am on Monday, October 7, 2013 at St. James Church at 865 Madison Avenue in New York.

WEBER--Felicia Penzell, co-founder of the Doris and Alex Weber Jewish Community High School, passed away peacefully early Monday morning surrounded by her family and friends. The cause was multiple infections following a serious car crash. She will be remembered as a lifelong community activist, with great personal warmth and charm. Felicia was born on January 13th, 1947 in Brooklyn, NY to Joseph and Helen Penzell. She studied at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem and received a Masters in Education from Northeastern University, after graduating from Wheaton College with a major in English Literature. Moving to Atlanta in 1976 with her husband and two year-old daughter, she co-founded the organization Mothers to Mothers - a support network for first-time mothers living far away from family. In the early 90s, along with others, Felicia responded to the need for an interdenominational Jewish high school in Atlanta and worked tirelessly to help launch the Weber School. She remained committed to the success of the school and its growing body of students and graduates. Felicia is survived by her husband, Joe Weber; her children and their spouses: Molly Rubin (Zach), Jacob Weber (Amy), and Rachel Weber (Ephraim Pelcovits); and five grandchildren: Yael, Akiva, Rosa, Alexander and Lev. An online guestbook is available at (edressler.com). In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Weber School, 6751 Roswell Rd., Atlanta, GA 30328, www.weberschool.org. Services will be 11:00am Wednesday, October 9, 2013 at The Weber School with Rabbi Ephraim Pelcovits officiating. Burial will follow at Crest Lawn Memorial Park. Arrangements by Dressler's Jewish Funeral Care, 770-451-4999.

SIMMONS--Christopher. Christopher DeWitt Simmons, of Alexandria, Virginia and Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts died on October 3, 2013, in his sleep. He is survived by his wife, Laura McIntosh Simmons, children Tucker McIntosh Simmons and Charlotte Bleecker Simmons, all of Alexandria, Virginia; his father, Richard DeLacey Simmons, former President of the Washington Post Company, also of Alexandria; his sister Robin Simmons Turner (Eric), niece Merrill and nephews Brooks and Griffin of Arlington, Virginia. Born on April 19, 1963, in Huntington, New York, Christopher was the son of Richard and the late Mary Bleecker Simmons. A gifted athlete, at Deerfield Academy, in Deerfield, Massachusetts, he was a member of the school's football and lacrosse teams. Christopher attended Duke University and received his Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in fine arts and art history from Tufts University. He also held a degree with a concentration in painting and drawing from the School of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, receiving its highest artistic prize, The Boit Award, in his first year. Christopher was an inveterate traveler, visiting all seven of the world's continents. He was one of the first Americans to travel to China after Nixon's historic visit and to Vietnam in 1994. An accomplished artist, his travels were reflected in his art. Christopher's signature mixed media technique merged photography and painting, documenting the monochromatic landscape of Antarctica as poetically as the Soviet Pacific fleet in Vladivostok and the desert refuge of WWII American planes in Arizona. Galleries in Washington, DC, Los Angeles, New Jersey and New York City showed his work. Christopher was intimately involved in his children's lives much to their benefit. He was active in their sporting activities; including coaching his daughter's youth lacrosse team and expanding his son's winning club swim team. Christopher devoted a significant effort to fundraising for Saint Stephens and St. Agnes School, Alexandria, Virginia and Washington DC's St. John's College High School. He was a member of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Belle Haven Country Club, Farmington Country Club and the Mill Reef Club. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, October 8, at 1pm, at the historic St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Virginia. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that Christopher be memorialized with contributions to the American Heart Association and the Lung Cancer Alliance.

SCHWARTZ--Selma, 96, died October 5, 2013. Predeceased by her husband of 67 years, Samuel. Survived by her daughter Judge Terry Jane Ruderman (Jerold), granddaughter Jill Sandford (Rocco Totino) and great-grandson Tommy.

PARLAMIS--Michael Frank, 73, passed peacefully on October 6, 2013 of complications from pulmonary fibrosis. He is survived by Marguerite, his wife of 47 years, his children Franklin, Christine and Alexander, and ten grandchildren. Michael graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University. A Professional Engineer and expert on the New York City building code, Michael presided over the family's restaurant contracting business, expanding it into restaurant ownership, notably Axia Taverna. A man of boundless charity, he was a leader in his own community and a bridge to other communities. Michael was honored, like his father, as an Archon of the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople. He received the Ellis Island Medal of Honor, celebrating immigrant achievement, and was a member of Leadership 100, stewards of the Greek Orthodox Church. Michael served for years as trustee and benefactor of the Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly, NJ (353 East Clinton Ave), where visitation will be held on Thursday, October 10 from 2-4pm and from 7-9pm. Funeral service at the Cathedral on Friday, October 11 at 11am. Interment Brookside Cemetery, Englewood NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Alexia Foundation for World Peace (www.alexiafoundation.org) or the Frank Parlamis Hellenic Senior Center of St. Demetrios (84-35 152 St, Jamaica, NY 11432). Services by the Barrett Funeral Home of Tenafly www.barrettfuneralhome.net.

PAPPI--Ann M.,79, of Wareham, MA, formerly of New York City, on October 3, 2013. Her social work career, lively intellect, caring spirit, and appreciation of life enriched the lives of many. Guestbook: www.ccgfuneralhome.com.

O'CONNOR--Rita A.,92, (Wrocklage) on October 6th. She was predeceased by her devoted husband John F. Loving mother of Brian, Robert (Ann), Kathleen, Margaret (Jose), and John Justin. Cherished grandmother of nine, great-grandmother of three. Aunt to many nieces and nephews. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm, Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Bronxville on Thursday, October 10 at 10am. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

LOWENBERG--Beatrice, passed away on October 5, 2013 at the age of 98, peacefully in her home. She spent most of those years dancing in the sunlight, with optimism and infectious laugh that will long be remembered by anyone who knew her. She was married to her childhood sweetheart for 78 years and taught us all by example of what love was about. Her family was her life's work and she exceeded all expectations of what a daughter, a wife, a mother, a grandmother and great-grandmother should be. She never stopped thanking God for blessing her with an extraordinary life. And we, her family, will never stop thanking God for the gift she was to all of us. She is survived by her husband, Sidney, her two sons, Andrew and Marc, her grandchildren, Adam, Jaimi, Tara and Terrence and her seven great-grandchildren Morgan, Kaley, Travis, Mia, Reese, Graydon and Dylan. We all celebrate her life and the gift of love she gave us. Services will be held on Tuesday October 8 at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Ave.

LENOBLE--Renee Kalb, 80, deeply loved wife of Paul, boundlessly loving mother of Peter and Alizabeth, adoring grandma of Max Antonio; predeceased by Everett and Marilyn, died peacefully October 6. Her overflowing love and kindness, and unrelenting advocacy for social justice, was larger than life. Funeral services, Tuesday, October 8 at 12noon at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY 11797. Donations may be sent to: sepamujer.org, hrc.org or wnet.org. we carry your heart with us (we carry it in our hearts).

LEE--Betty Neuwirth. Weill Cornell Medical College mourns the passing of its longtime donor, Betty Neuwirth Lee, whose committed generosity supported generations of researchers. Betty's unique spirit is captured in the Betty Neuwirth Lee and Chilly Professorship in Stem Cell Research, which is named for her and her beloved dog. We will miss her humor, elegance and warm spirit. Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College Dr. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., Co-Chairman, Board of Overseers

LEE--Betty Neuwirth, on October 4, 2013. Daughter of the late Charles and Lillian Neuwirth. Mother of Lawrence and Robert Lee. Grandmother of Jason and Courtney Lee. A loving and loyal companion, Valentina Burdier and lifelong friend Ina Bell. Most important her angel girl Chilly, the love, the joy and the light of her life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Chilly Lee Scholarship in honor of Lewis Berman, DVM C/O Office of Alumni Affairs & Development, S2002 Schurman Hall, College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853-6401. OR to the Betty Neuwirth Lee Trust Weill Cornell Medical College, Attn: Pat Gutter, 1300 York Ave, New York, NY 10021. Services were held on October 7, 2013 at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave New York, NY.

LANIER--Sidney. His strong belief in the participation of Art in religious worship led to his co-founding The American Place Theatre, a mission of St. Clements Episcopal Church, at that time moribund. He engendered peace and inspired all of us who knew him. Let us now praise Sidney Lanier! Wynn Handman Artistic Director and Co-Founder, The American Place Theatre
KAPLAN-RUBIN--Harriet. Beloved wife of Ivan Rubin, adored mother of Keith (Alice) and Seth (Miriam) Kaplan. Honored teacher and mentor.

HIRSCHBERG--Stephen E. M.D.,age 66, died at home on October 7, 2013, 7++ months after diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. He was born in Brooklyn on June 13, 1947, to Morris Joel Hirschberg and Ann Lillian Hirschberg (Cohen), and grew up in Great Neck where he made lifelong friends. Steve took his BA from the University of Pennsylvania in three years, graduating Phi Beta Kappa, and his MD from NYU School of Medicine. He served as a physician in the United States Navy 1974-1976, and then moved to Westchester, where he practiced internal medicine in Yonkers until his final illness. He cared deeply and personally about his patients and was proud of providing excellent medical care. Steve was the founding chair of two Amnesty International groups, the longtime president of the Knollwood Neighborhood Civic Association, an avid outdoor photographer, a lover of puzzles, a student of the classical guitar, a fine letterpress printer, and an all-around good guy. He leaves his wife and best friend, Arlene R. Popkin, his children David, Daniel (Elizabeth Austin) and Laura, his sister Barbara Lituchy (Richard), his cousin Judy Berlin (Martin) and many cherished friends. Services will be held at Scarsdale Synagogue Temples Tremont and Emanuel, 2 Ogden Road, Scarsdale, at 10:15am, Thursday, October 10. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Doctors Without Borders.

GUETTEL--Henry. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Henry Guettel, a friend to all, a consummate man of the theater, and a true believer. We send our condolences and love to Mary, Adam, Alec and the entire family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director

GUETTEL--Henry. The Board and Staff of The New 42nd Street and The New Victory Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Founding Board Member dear, sweet, gentle Henry Guettel. Hank served on our Board since we were founded 23 years ago. We will forever miss him and his enlightened encouragement, constant support and remarkably darling nature. We send our love and deepest condolences to dear Mary, Matthew, Adam and Alexander. The New 42nd Street Fiona Howe Rudin, Chairman Cora Cahan, President

GUETTEL--Henry. We will miss our friend Henry Guettel. His wise counsel, his astute assessment of people, his sense of humor and his artistic sensibilities were appreciated and always valuable. As a member of the larger Rodgers family, he was very much a part of us. Condolences to Mary and all the members of his extended family. Ted Chapin and everyone at Rodgers & Hammerstein

GUETTEL--Henry. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of our dear friend, Henry Guettel. Along with his wife, Mary Rodgers Guettel, chairman emeritus of Juilliard, Hank participated actively in many programs over the years. His intellect, quick wit, and knowledge of the performing arts world enriched all that we addressed at the school. We send our deepest sympathy to Mary, their family, and his many friends. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President Kenneth S. Davidson, Trustee
GUETTEL--Henry. A wonderful friend, a beautiful man inside and out. We will miss you, Hank. Our deepest condolences to Mary, Adam, Alec, Tod, Kim, Nina and family. Nicole and Paul Harman
ELLIS--Ray. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Ray Ellis, and send condolences to his family.

FAULKNER--Joan Hills, of Larchmont, NY, beloved wife of the late Walter T. Faulkner, died October 2, 2013. The daughter of George S. Hills and Alice Shaw Hills, Mrs. Faulkner was born May 6, 1932 in New York, NY, and grew up in New Rochelle. She attended Thornton-Donovan Primary School and Rye Country Day School and graduated from Wheaton College in 1953. She married Walter in 1956, and their marriage lasted 55 years until his death in 2011. Soon after marrying, Joan and Walter moved to Larchmont where they raised four children. She was very active in the community, serving as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Larchmont Public Library, President of the Hommocks PTA, President of the Larchmont-Mamaroneck P-T Council, President of the Junior League of Larchmont, and in many other capacities. During her ten years as Library Chairman, she oversaw a number of significant initiatives, including the major expansion and upgrade of the Library's facilities that was completed in 1995. Her warmth, generosity, friendship and community service will be greatly missed by family and friends. She is survived by sons John of New York, NY, Andy of New York, NY, and George of Pleasantville, NY; daughter Susan of Portland, OR; and eight grandchildren: Stephen, Brian, Elizabeth, Patrick, Anna, Lucy, Henry and Lily. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, October 9th at 11:00am at Larchmont Avenue Church. Visiting hours are Tuesday, October 8th from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Larchmont Public Library, 121 Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY 10538, or the Cancer Support Team of Westchester, 2900 Westchester Ave., Purchase, NY, 10577.

TREMBLAY--Maryann E. (Sylvester) October 9, 1930-July 13, 2011. In our hearts, and grateful for unconditional love and support, always. "If you are what you should be, you will set the whole world on fire!'-St. C. of Siena All of us.

ZIMMERMAN--Jerome, 92, passed away peacefully on September 28, 2013 in Palm Beach, FL. A native of Atlanta, GA, he graduated from Emory University. He served in the United States Army, infantry division, from 1943-1945 in the European campaign. He was a business man and entrepreneur in the building product industry in Atlanta until his retirement in 1995. He is survived by his wife, Harriet, sister Annette Easton, children Layne, Ellen Kaufman, Scott (Elana), stepchildren, Claire Marx (Cornelius), Robert Altschuler, Nancy O'Leary (Mark) and thirteen grandchildren. A private memorial service was held in Florida followed by a funeral service in Aspen, Colorado which was attended by a military honor guard. Jerome was a man of character and compassion and a generous supporter of Jewish causes. May his memory be a blessing. Donations in his memory may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, MorseLife of West Palm Beach and Shearith Israel, Atlanta.

YOSEF--Ovadia Rabbi. The Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS), an affiliate of Yeshiva University, joins in mourning the passing of the world renowned Sephardic Torah Sage, Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, z'tl, who served as The Rishon Letzion, the Sephardic Chief Rabbi of the State of Israel and founder of the Council of Sephardic Torah Sages (SHAS). His unsurpassed encyclopedic erudition in Talmudic and Jewish Legal Studies earned him, in 1970, the Israel Prize for Rabbinical Literature. He honored our institution by his three visits to provide Talmudic and Halakhic lectures to our entire study body and Sephardic lay leaders of the Sephardic Council of Overseers and remained to teach our students for one week. He lectured at Yeshiva University in 1974 on Talmudic Discourse Outside Israel, in 1975 he was invited to receive an honorary degree and was unable to attend, but later in November 1975 he received the Mordechai Ben David Award at a RIETS Ceremony and in May 1991 he taught classes and delivered lectures at RIETS and YU for an entire week. He was received on his visits by the revered Professor of Talmud and Jewish Philosophy, Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik, z'l and the then President of Yeshiva University and RIETS, Rabbi Dr. Samuel Belkin, z'l, his successor as President, Rabbi Dr. Norman Lamm, the Dean of RIETS, Rabbi Zevulun Charlop, and a Co-founder of YU's Sephardic Studies Programs and the Jacob E. Safra Institute of Sephardic Studies, Rabbi Dr. Herbert C. Dobrinsky, Vice President for University Affairs who accompanied him on his inaugural visit to the West Coast. The faculty and students of RIETS and the University's Sephardic Council of Overseers will ever recall his warm friendship for our institution which he respected for its commitment to bona fide Torah scholarship and the preservation of the Sephardic heritage for its more than 300 undergraduate and 100 graduate Sephardic students through courses, educational programs for the laity and the manner in which students learn to be immersed in Torah and be respectful of each other's traditions and participate in Torah and general studies, Sephardim together with their Ashkenazi brethren. Sincere condolences are extended to the ten children of Rabbi Yosef and his beloved wife, and to their many grandchildren and great grandchildren. Min Hashamayim Tenuhamu. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President David Eshaghian Chairman, Sephardic Council of Overseers
WALKER--Greta, age 85, passed away on July 20, 2013 after a long illness. Grandmother of Einar, mother-in-law of Charlotte, mother of David, who will miss and think of her everyday.

SWING--John Temple, former Executive Vice President and Acting President of the Council on Foreign Relations and President Emeritus of the Foreign Policy Association, died peacefully on October 4 surrounded by his family. John was born in 1929 to Raymond Gram Swing, an influential print and broadcast journalist, and Betty Gram Swing, a noted suffragist. He graduated cum laude from Harvard College in 1950 and from Yale Law School in 1953. After practicing law in Salisbury, Connecticut, and serving on the town's Board of Selectmen, John joined the Council on Foreign Relations in 1963 and helped to modernize that organization. He was a close colleague of Elliot Richardson in the negotiation of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, and he remained a prominent advocate for the treaty, founding the Rule of Law Committee for the Oceans, a primary source of information for treaty supporters. He also was active with the Non-Profit Coordinating Committee of New York, the Northcote Parkinson Fund, the Century Association, and the Board of Trustees of the Putney School in Putney, Vermont. John is survived by his wife, Devereux L.P. Swing; a son, the artist Johnny Swing, his wife, Pamela, and their children, Alva and Eli, of Brookline, Vermont; a daughter, Jenny Swing of Rockland, Maine, her former husband, Kirby Wilton, and their children, Katelin and Kelty; and a stepdaughter, Susan Kumar, her husband Parameswaran, and their son, Nikita. John was predeceased by a brother, Peter Gram Swing, and a sister, Sally Swing Shelley. His first marriage, to Janet Adams Swing, ended in divorce. John loved music and sang and played various instruments. An avid sailor, he also enjoyed cooking and travel. Donations in his memory may be made to the Rule of Law Committee for the Oceans (202-470-2543) and the Foreign Policy Association. A memorial service is planned for Friday, November 8.

SABER--Lester E.,age 91, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away October 7, 2013. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, father-in-law, uncle, friend, scholar. Proud WWII veteran.

PARLAMIS--Michael Frank, 73, passed peacefully on October 6, 2013 of complications from pulmonary fibrosis. He is survived by Marguerite, his wife of 47 years, his children Franklin, Christine and Alexander, and ten grandchildren. Michael graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University. A Professional Engineer and expert on the New York City building code, Michael presided over the family's restaurant contracting business, expanding it into restaurant ownership, notably Axia Taverna. A man of boundless charity, he was a leader in his own community and a bridge to other communities. Michael was honored, like his father, as an Archon of the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople. He received the Ellis Island Medal of Honor, celebrating immigrant achievement, and was a member of Leadership 100, stewards of the Greek Orthodox Church. Michael served for years as trustee and benefactor of the Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly, NJ (353 East Clinton Ave), where visitation will be held on Thursday, October 10 from 2-4pm and from 7-9pm. Funeral service at the Cathedral on Friday, October 11 at 11am. Interment Brookside Cemetery, Englewood NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Alexia Foundation for World Peace (www.alexiafoundation.org) or the Frank Parlamis Hellenic Senior Center of St. Demetrios (84-35 152 St, Jamaica, NY 11432). Services by the Barrett Funeral Home of Tenafly www.barrettfuneralhome.net.

KATZ--Molly Kanner, died at her home on October 6, 2013. She was a cherished member of her community and an incredible source of love and support to all her knew her. Molly was privileged to have been loved by two fine men, Max Kanner and Alexander Katz. Her loss is deeply mourned by her children, Carol and Chuck, and step-daughter, Laura; grandchildren: Monica, Chloe, Jordan and Maxx; her much adored brother Bob, sister-in-law Anne, as well as her nephew Seth and his family.
