JACOB--Constance D.,on Tuesday, October 8, 2013, in New York City, after a long illness. She was born 85 years ago in New Haven to Julius Dorfman and Mildred (Levine) Dorfman. Connie graduated from Radcliffe College, Harvard University, where she met Edwin J. Jacob, her husband of 65 years. Elegant and intelligent, she raised her family and ran her household with style. Among her many enjoyments were the ballet, the theater, literature and travel. Her work as financial aid counselor at Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts allowed numerous young artists to go to college. She is survived by her devoted husband Ed, her daughters Louise Jacob, Beth Jacob and Ellen Jacob, her son-in-law Kirk Cheyfitz, twelve grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Services Wednesday, October 9, at 11:30am at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts or the New York City Ballet.

GUETTEL--Henry. Mary, A dear, gentle man; most importantly, He adored you, As do I. Alice H.
GUETTEL--Henry. A wonderful friend, a beautiful man inside and out. We will miss you, Hank. Our deepest condolences to Mary, Adam, Alec, Tod, Kim, Nina and family. Nicole and Paul Harman

GUETTEL--Henry. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of our dear friend, Henry Guettel. FORSYTHE--James R.,on October 4, 2013. Beloved husband of Denise Quarles Forsythe. Mr. Forsythe was retired from the position of Executive Vice President for Essence Magazine in 2001. He headed the circulation and direct marketing departments. Visitation Thursday, October 10, 2013 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., 2 to 5pm and 7-9pm. Services Friday 11:30am. FEINSILVER--Denise. Denise "Denny" Feinsilver, lost her seven year battle with cancer at the age of 66 on Sunday, October 6, 2013. She is survived by her husband Paul, daughter Corey, son Zachary, grandson Dylan, mom Betty, and brother, Scott. Denny's children and grandson were the pride and joy of her life. Born in St. Louis, Missouri, she received her undergraduate degree from the University of Maryland and her M.S. from Barry College. She and her husband Paul, co-founder of FMSbonds, Inc., met in Maryland. They married a year after graduation and settled in Florida, where they resided for more than 40 years. Although family meant everything to Denny, she always made time for "giving back" and worked tirelessly to comfort those in need. She was active in The Greater Miami Jewish Federation and a founder of the Museum of Contemporary Art but her true passion, even before contracting breast cancer, was supporting cancer research at The University of Miami Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center. Denny was a founding member of "Friends for Sylvester" and sat on the Sylvester Board of Governors, as well as co-chairing the Board of the Founder's Society. Her proudest achievement, which will become her legacy, was the creation of "Coupons for a Cure," a program that facilitated donations to Sylvester in honor of a person or event. This overwhelmingly successful program raises a significant amount of money annually to combat cancer, and will do so well into the future. Denny was an inspiration to all who knew her. Right up until the end, other cancer patients continually looked to Denny for support, marveling at her unceasing optimism and positive mental attitude. Denny died peacefully at home, surrounded by her loving family. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, October 9, at 11:30am, at Temple Beth Sholom, 4144 Chase Avenue, in Miami Beach, Florida. For those who are unable to attend, the service may be viewed online at www.tbsmb.org. Click on "Worship" and "Watch Services Online." If you wish to make a donation in Denny's memory, please direct it to The University of Miami Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center at 305-243-9088.

CONNOR--Mary Therese, was born on October 10, 1953, in Glenside, PA. She grew up surrounded by her loving brothers and sisters Jimmy, Joanne, Alice, and Jerry. She attended St. Luke's Grammar School, Bishop McDevitt High School, Trinity College in Washington D.C., and earned her MBA at Columbia University Business School. She had an illustrious career at Morgan Stanley as an investment banker, where over the course of 17 years, she earned the respect and admiration of her colleagues and competitors. However, she will be remembered most for her devotion as a wife to Mark Gallagher, and mother to her four children Alex, Catherine, Carolyn, and Laura. Whether she was walking her dog in Central Park, doting on her many nieces and nephews, bodysurfing in Ocean City, NJ, or traveling the world, her passion for life brought joy to all those around her. She will be deeply missed. The viewing will be held at The Frank Campbell Funeral Home (1076 Madison Ave), on October 10, from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Church (980 Park Ave), on Friday, October 11, at 11:30am. Cremation is private.

CHEREAU--Patrice. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of the great director of theater, film, and opera, Patrice Chereau. He permanently changed the face of staged opera with his legendary 1976 Ring Cycle in Bayreuth, influencing an entire generation of stage directors who followed. STACEY--Maria Dolores (Lola), died on Tuesday, October 8, in New York City of congestive heart failure. She was 84 years old. Originally from Quito, Ecuador, she was the eldest of five children. Lola studied International Law and Political Science, and worked for a time in the Executive Branch of the Ecuatorian government. She moved to the United States in 1960 and dedicated herself to numerous non-profit educational endeavors in Washington, D.C., Boston, and New York City. Her wisdom, warmth, and capacity for friendship are reflected in the many lives she touched over the years, many of whom still count her as a close friend today. Funeral services are being made by Frank Campbell Funeral Home. The wake will take place on Thursday, October 10, from noon until 9:00 pm at Alderton House, 117 East 70th Street. The Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St. Vincent Ferrer Church on Friday, October 11 at 10am. All are welcome to attend. Donations in her memory may be made to Rosemoor Foundation, a non-profit organization benefiting women of all ages.
WALKER--Greta, age 85, passed away on July 20, 2013 after a long illness. Grandmother of Einar, mother-in-law of Charlotte, mother of David, who will miss and think of her everyday.

REAM--Frank C.,Jr., 59 of Berlin, PA and New York City, died October 9, 2013 at Somerset Hospital. Rev. Frank Demmy officiating. Interment Berlin I.O.O.F. Cemetery. Condolences may be given at DeanerFuneralsAndCrematio ns.com

O'CONNOR--Raymond V.,of Forest Hills, NY, on October 8, 2013. Loving husband of the late Rita O'Connor (nee McCarthy). Devoted and caring father of Raymond (Paula), Eileen Hodgdon (Timothy) Cathleen Vaccari (Michael), Nancy O'Connor and Marita Agresta (Anthony). Proud grandfather of Brendan, Claire and Ryan. Reposing Fox Funeral Home 98-07 Ascan Ave. (corner Metropolitan) Forest Hills, NY Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Our Lady of Mercy Church 70-01 Kessel St., Forest Hills, Saturday, October 12th at 10:30am Interment Calvary Cemetery.

MINEI--Rhoda Fagen. In loving memory of Rhoda Fagen Minei, 86, wife and muse of Italian artist Franco Minei, mother of Cynthia Fagen and Lesley Fagen, daughters of the late William Elliott Fagen, and grandmother to Roman William Fagen, six months. She and our wonderful dad remained good friends throughout. She was an amazing woman who led a life full of adventure. Mother even took us along on a freighter across to Europe when we were eight and seven. She was an editor at Viva magazine, Bob Guccione's adult woman's magazine. She helped start the South Street Seaport magazine and loved working in Fine Art Advertising at the New York Times. Mother raised her girls in Manhattan, using Rome, Italy as her base to travel the world with Franco. Mother died on October 2, peacefully, at home, with her family and her English Pointer, Dashiell, at her side. We adored Mother and we miss her terribly. A private memorial service will be held at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers a donation can be made to the charity of your choice.

MEYERS--John Thomas, 79, of New York City passed away on October 6, 2013. Beloved father of John and Larry, cherished grandfather of John, William, Ciana, Orla, and Liam and loving brother to Ann, William, Dolores, Elsie, Ed, Joe, and Patricia. Decorated Korean War Marine (featured in 2012 The New York Times for his service with Sgt. Reckless) and long-time Inwood resident, John is remembered most for his empathy, love for the Great American Songbook, bone rattling humor, and fondness for a cold beer. Reposing at Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway at 214 St. NYC, Friday, October 11 from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Good Shepherd R.C. Church, Saturday at 9am.

LOOMIS--Robert Lockwood, aged 87, died peacefully on September 29 in Saranac Lake, NY, with his children Tim and 'Lia, at his side. He is also survived by brothers Worth and Harvey Loomis, and sister Sarah Campbell, grandchildren Miranda and Harvey Runyon, eight nieces and nephews, and eight grand nieces and nephews.

KLEIN--Amelia (nee Deutsch), 89, of La Jolla, CA, formerly of New York City, whose 57 year marriage to her late husband, Judah, was a symphony of love. The world is a better place because of her life.

GUETTEL--Henry. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts deeply mourn the passing of Henry Guettel, former Executive Director of Theater Development Fund and former Director, Music Theater of Lincoln Center. For Henry and his wife Mary, nee Rodgers, daughter of composer Richard Rodgers, musical theater was both their work and their life. Henry produced workshop productions of musicals at the Forum Theater, now the Mitzi Newhouse at Lincoln Center Theater, and Mary is a Lincoln Center Director Emerita, former Chair of Juilliard and Lincoln Center Board Executive Committee member. Our heartfelt sympathies go to Mary, to their two sons Adam and Alec, and to their family and many friends. Katherine Farley, Chair Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

CREED--Anne Mundell, a Washington native who dedicated her adult life to supporting Catholic education and Catholic charities in New York, died peacefully on Sunday in Northwest Washington. She was 85. A Memorial Mass will be offered for the repose of the soul of Anne Creed at Immaculate Conception Catholic Church at 8th and N Street NW on Saturday, October 12 at 10am. Interment private. In lieu of flowers please make donations in Anne's name to Catholic Big Sisters and Big Brothers.

CONNOR--Mary Therese, was born on October 10, 1953 to James Connor and Alice McGoldrick Connor in Abington, PA. She grew up in Glenside surrounded by her loving brothers and sisters Jimmy, Joanne, Alice Denise, and Jerry. She attended St. Luke's Grammar School, Bishop McDevitt High School, Trinity College in Washington D.C. and earned her MBA at Columbia University Business School. She had an illustrious career at Morgan Stanley, where over the course of 17 years, she earned the respect and admiration of her colleagues and competitors. However, she will be remembered most for her devotion to her family, as a loving wife to Mark Gallagher, an adoring mother to her four children Alex, Catherine, Carolyn, and Laura, and a caring daughter to her mother and father. Whether she was walking her dog in Central Park, doting on her many nieces and nephews, bodysurfing in Ocean City, NJ, or traveling the world, her passion for life brought joy to all those around her. She will be deeply missed. The viewing will be held at The Frank Campbell Funeral Home (1076 Madison Avenue), on October 10, from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Church (980 Park Avenue), on Friday, October 11, at 11:30am. Cremation is private. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106; www.mskcc.org.

Bedford--Mary Lee. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the sudden loss of Mary Lee Bedford, longtime executive assistant to deans and a pillar of the Law School community. Over nearly three decades, Mary Lee assisted four deans and numerous associate deans, worked with the faculty and staff, and assisted countless students with her unfailingly calming presence. She was an exemplar of professional skill and dedication, with her upcoming retirement more than well-earned. Before joining Brooklyn Law School in 1985, she served as secretary to senior management at Touche Ross & Co., the firm that would later became Deloitte. Earlier in her career, she was an elementary school teacher at various parochial schools in Brooklyn and Long Island, as well as at the Barnard School for Girls. She was a graduate of St. Francis College. We will never forget her kindness, keen intellect, ready laugh, and strength of character. We extend our deepest condolences to her daughter Amy, a 2002 Brooklyn Law School graduate, her son Peter, her beloved grandchildren, and her many friends. Stuart Subotnick '68, Chairman of the Board Nicholas W. Allard, Dean

THOMAS--Carrie M. Born: September 10, 1913, Passed: October 3, 2013. She lived surrounded by the love and admiration of all who knew her. Miss Carrie's 100 years were full and engaged with the unwavering devotion of her friends and to her beloved Harlem community of over 80 years. Her life was full of firsts: most notably, first African American woman to work for Robert Moses. She was a champion and friend to politicians and artists of the Harlem Renaissance; credited with finding individuals both interested and qualified in the new jobs opening to Blacks in New York City in the 1940s; advocate for Harlem Hospital Center and the Renaissance Healthcare Network; and an early supporter of Black American civic organizations. As the consummate lady, we celebrate her life.

For 30 years, John helped guide the growth and success of NPCC. His devotion to NPCC and to the non-profit sector was unmatched and will be deeply missed. John E. Craig, Jr., Chairman Michael E. Clark, President

SHANLEY--Kevin, passed away peacefully at home in Gladstone, NJ on Tuesday, October 8, 2013. He was the CFO of Atlantic Health. His life will be celebrated at a Mass of Christian Burial at St. Mary's Abbey Church at Delbarton School in Morristown, NJ on Tuesday, October 15 at 10:30am. He is survived by his beloved wife, Maudie and his daughters, Alison Johnson and her husband, Peder (Johnny); Katy Scott and her husband, Dan; Eliza Sutte and her husband, Matt and Julie Ryan and her husband, John. He leaves his much loved grandchildren, Eleanor and Samuel Johnson; Kellen and Lachlan Sutte. RAUSNITZ--William. February 5, 1917 to October 4, 2013. Committed family man and fighter for social justice.

KNIPE--Peter Rolin, 75, died October 7, 2013 in Glendale, CA while visiting family. A longtime Princeton resident, he had lived in Skillman and Sea Girt in recent years. Born in New Haven, CT, he was the youngest son of James L. Knipe and Danielle Rolin Knipe. While he grew up in Princeton, NJ, he attended Princeton Country Day School. Later he would go onto to attend Andover, Yale University, and Yale Law School. Peter began his law career with a clerkship for a Federal Judge in Oregon. Peter's practice areas included business negotiations, entertainment law, administrative law and estate planning. Through these experiences, he was able to negotiate commercial, investment, film and book deals. He represented public boards of education, and did trial and appellate work. He also worked with local charities and had a role in the creation and operation of Children's Medical Relief International, while also working on projects to assist minority businesses. He was the author of two articles published in The Times of Trenton entitled "Vietnam: A Personal Journey," April 23, 1995 and "Change and Constancy in the Vietnam of Today," April 30, 1995. He also published, "Truth, Beauty and the IRS-Attorney Beware," 3NJL415, February 28, 1994 and co-authored, "Attorney Beware: Fair is Fair-Sometimes," May-June 1994 Issue of New Jersey Lawyer, the magazine. He is survived by his wife Nancy of Skillman, NJ; two sons, Peter of Bordentown, NJ, and Daniel of Fair Haven, NJ; a brother, James of San Bernardino, CA; and four grandchildren. Celebrations of his life will be held at a viewing on Sunday, October 13th from 2-5pm at the O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Route 35, Wall NJ, followed by a Funeral Mass on Monday, October 14th at 9:30am at St. Mark's Catholic Church in Sea Girt, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent in honor of Peter R. Knipe to the Foundation Fighting Blindness, (formerly the RP Foundation). For more information or to send condolences, visit: www.obrienfuneralhome.com.

HECHT--Lenore, 87, passed away peacefully at her home on October 9th 2013. She is survived by her daughters, Gina Freis (Jeffrey) and Barbara Hurlbutt (DanieI), four grandchildren, Stacey. Michelle, Bryan and Julie and five great-grandchildren. She was extremely charitable and many organizations benefited from her generosity. Lenore was a veracious reader, a lover of old movies and enjoyed doing crosswords with her nephew, playing Scrabble with her daughter and Skyping with her great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Friday at 9:30am, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Memorial Donations may be made to Thirteen/WNET New York, 825 8th Avenue Fl 14, New York, NY 10019-7435

KLEIN--Amelia (nee Deutsch), 89, of La Jolla, CA, formerly of New York City, whose 57 year marriage to her late husband, Judah, was a symphony of love. Devoted mother to Leonard, Janet and "Taffy," beloved grandmother to Jeffrey, and sister to Alvin. Her life was dedicated to her family and a multitude of long and cherished friends. The world is a better place because of her life.

EIGARD--Russ, 59, died recently at his Honk Lake cottage, upstate New York. Russ was born in Oakland, CA, graduated from the University of California at Berkeley and attended New York University after moving to New York in 1980. An outstanding editor and marketing executive, he was a long-time employee of PaineWebber's research and asset management divisions. Predeceased by his partner, Charles Goggans and his parents, Russ is survived by a sister, Kerry Mello, and his brother, Bill Eigard. He is also survived by a large circle of loving friends who found enormous pleasure in sharing long conversations, unending laughter and his passionate, and sometimes passing commitments. A memorial will be celebrated November 3 in New York City. Contact margo.alexander1@gmail.com for details.

CREED--Anne Mundell. The Board of Directors of The Catholic Big Sisters and Big Brothers notes with sorrow the death of our dear friend, past Board President, long standing board member, and generous supporter, Anne Mundell Creed. We will miss her delightful humor and caring guidance. Our thoughts and prayers are with her family.

COOK--Karen Strauss. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the passing of our colleague Karen Cook. As a member of the IRC Overseers since 2008, Karen made significant contributions to our work on behalf of the world's uprooted people. We are grateful for her service as chair of our Investment Committee and for the counsel and wisdom she provided to us. We will miss her, and we extend our heartfelt sympathies to her husband, Everett R. Cook II, and her sons, Everett R. Cook III and Conor W. Cook. International Rescue Committee Sarah O'Hagan and Thomas Schick, Co-Chairs of the Board; Glenda Burkhart and Scott Pelley, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers; David Miliband, President

CARTER--Louise Cahill, of Washington, DC, died October 9, 2013. Mrs. Carter was the youngest of five children of James Augustine Cahill, M.D., and Florence McKinney Cahill, of Washington, D.C. Her father was Chief of Surgery at Georgetown University Hospital and Professor of Surgery at Georgetown University Medical School. The Cahill Medal for excellence in surgery is awarded every year to a student at Georgetown University Medical School. Mrs. Carter was educated by the nuns at the Convent of the Sacred Heart and graduated from Stone Ridge School in Bethesda, MD. She graduated from American University with a Bachelor's degree and also studied at Georgetown. In 1962 she married Warwick Montgomery Carter. Mrs. Carter lived her entire life in Washington. She spent many Summers in Watch Hill, Rhode Island, and Winters in Palm Beach, Florida. Mrs. Carter was a lifelong Francophile. She studied and spoke French and travelled to France at various times throughout her life. Her favorite place was a small village in Provence known as Ansouis. Mrs. Carter was an avid opera buff and was a long-standing member of the Board of Trustees of The Washington Opera. Mrs. Carter was a member of the Chevy Chase Club as well as the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach. She was also a former member of the Sulgrave Club in Washington and of the Colony Club in New York. Her greatest passion was her family. She was a devoted wife to her husband, Warwick, who suffered from Parkinson's disease for 20 years and died in 2006. She will be remembered as a woman with a keen wit, a great sense of humor and "joie de vivre." Louise Carter was survived by her three children: Warwick Montgomery Carter, Jr., Raymond Prescott Cahill Carter, and Louise Lee Carroll Carter and four grandchildren. A funeral mass will be offered at Immaculate Conception Catholic Church at 1315 8th Street, NW (at 8th and N Streets) in Washington, D.C. 20001, on Tuesday, October 15, 2013, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Louise's memory to Immaculate Conception.

BROWN--Shelley. It is with great sadness that we mark the passing of our beloved friend and office manager. We will miss Shelley's incredible kindness and devotion. We extend our sympathy to her family. Franklin, Weinrib, Rudell & Vassallo

BERMEL--Albert D. 5 October 2013. Playwright, critic, translator, professor emeritus of theater and film at CUNY Graduate Center and Lehman College, beloved husband, brother, father and grandfather. A memorial will be held later this year.

BRITON--Celine Walker, long-time resident of New York City, died on October 9, 2013 in Manhattan. Born in Kansas City, MO, to Joan and Lewis Briton, Celine was engaged in the antiques and interior design business for most of her professional life. With her mother, Celine traveled to France summer after summer, purchasing fine antiques for their clientele across the United States. Always positive, ever the lady, she lived her life with grace and spirituality. We will miss her sorely. Bon Voyage to our beloved friend, whose wisdom and love enriched all those who crossed her path.

BERMAN--Jules. Jules Berman, died peacefully October 5 at his home in Silver Spring, Maryland. Born September 11, 1910 in Chicago, raised in Rochester, NY, he had a long and distinguished career at the U.S. Department of Health Education and Welfare where he played a key role in the initial creation and launch of Medicare and Medicaid and the early revisions and expansion of Social Security. Jules often represented HEW at Congressional hearings and briefings during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. He had a second rewarding career at the University of Maryland as Emeritus Associate Professor in its School of Social Work and Community Planning. Jules was beloved as much for his warmth and compassionate interest in those around him as for his intelligence and his range of interests. Jules was the devoted husband of the late Susan Berman and is survived by his children, Robert of St. Petersburg Florida, Elinore Shafer of Fairfield Connecticut and Jeremy of New York City as well as seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Jules' kindness to others was returned to him and his family wishes to thank the especially caring staff and residents at Bedford Court in Silver Springs where he lived for nearly ten years and the resourceful team of caregivers who assisted him in his final days.

Bedford--Mary Lee. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the sudden loss of Mary Lee Bedford, longtime executive assistant to deans and a pillar of the Law School community. Over nearly three decades, Mary Lee assisted four deans and numerous associate deans, worked with the faculty and staff, and assisted countless students with her unfailingly calming presence. She was an exemplar of professional skill and dedication, with her upcoming retirement more than well-earned. Before joining Brooklyn Law School in 1985, she served as secretary to senior management at Touche Ross & Co., the firm that would later became Deloitte. Earlier in her career, she was an elementary school teacher at various parochial schools in Brooklyn and Long Island, as well as at the Barnard School for Girls. She was a graduate of St. Francis College. We will never forget her kindness, keen intellect, ready laugh, and strength of character. We extend our deepest condolences to her daughter Amy, a 2002 Brooklyn Law School graduate, her son Peter, her beloved grandchildren, and her many friends. Stuart Subotnick '68, Chairman of the Board Nicholas W. Allard, Dean

BERMAN--Jules. Jules Berman, died peacefully October 5 at his home in Silver Spring, Maryland. Born September 11, 1910 in Chicago, raised in Rochester, NY, he had a long and distinguished career at the U.S. Department of Health Education and Welfare where he played a key role in the initial creation and launch of Medicare and Medicaid and the early revisions and expansion of Social Security. Jules often represented HEW at Congressional hearings and briefings during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. He had a second rewarding career at the University of Maryland as Emeritus Associate Professor in its School of Social Work and Community Planning. Jules was beloved as much for his warmth and compassionate interest in those around him as for his intelligence and his range of interests. Jules was the devoted husband of the late Susan Berman and is survived by his children, Robert of St. Petersburg Florida, Elinore Shafer of Fairfield Connecticut and Jeremy of New York City as well as seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Jules' kindness to others was returned to him and his family wishes to thank the especially caring staff and residents at Bedford Court in Silver Springs where he lived for nearly ten years and the resourceful team of caregivers who assisted him in his final days.

WIEN--Stephen S.,age 76, passed away peacefully on Saturday, October 12th at NYU Medical Center in New York City. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY; Mr. Wien resided in Alpine, NJ for the last 29 years and also Boca Raton, FL; for the last 20 years. Mr. Wien was the owner of Wien Securities Corp formerly M.S. Wien and Co. for 56 years retiring in 2006. He was a member of the Montammy Golf Club in Alpine, the Broken Sound Club and Broken Sound Old Course in Florida, and many other clubs and organizations. He was best known as Big Daddy and otherwise known as Santa Claus. He is survived by his loving wife Edith of 52 years, two sons Larry and his wife Julie of Norwood, NJ, Brett and his significant other Kerri Baron of Greenwich, CT, his daughter Nicole Naidrich and her husband Joseph of Tenafly, NJ, his sister Sondra Goldring of Boca Raton, FL, and his six grandchildren Jake, Alex, Ryan, Tyler, Emma, and James. Funeral services will be held today at 2pm, Gutterman-Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park St. Hackensack, NJ 07601. Interment will follow Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. Donations in Mr. Wien's name may be made to St. Jude's Children's Hospital or the Melanoma Research Foundation, 411 K Steet, NW Suite 800, Washington, DC 20005.
WALDMAN--Shelley Brown. A wonderful mother, colleague and friend. We will miss you. John and Lynne Vassallo

THOMAS--Carrie M. Born: September 10, 1913, Passed: October 3, 2013. She lived surrounded by the love and admiration of all who knew her. Miss Carrie's 100 years were full and engaged with the unwavering devotion of her friends and to her beloved Harlem community of over 80 years. Her life was full of firsts: most notably, first African American woman to work for Robert Moses. She was a champion and friend to politicians and artists of the Harlem Renaissance; credited with finding individuals both interested and qualified in the new jobs opening to Blacks in New York City in the 1940s; advocate for Harlem Hospital Center and the Renaissance Healthcare Network; and an early supporter of Black American civic organizations. As the consummate lady, we celebrate her life.

SWING--John Temple. The Council on Foreign Relations (CFR) mourns the passing of John Temple Swing, former CFR executive vice president and president pro tempore, 1985-1986. During his 38 years on CFR's staff, John helped guide the institution through transformative changes that made it possible for CFR to be the valued and respected resource that it is today. The staff and board of CFR offer heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Devereux, and his entire family. Carla A. Hills, Co-Chair Robert E. Rubin, Co-Chair Richard N. Haass, President

SPONG--Paul. Ballet pianist extraordinaire Paul Spong died peacefully on October 4th. Born in 1932, Paul was a graduate of the University of Minnesota. From 1962 to 1984, he was Music Director for Brooklyn College's Dance Department. Later he worked at the Joffrey Ballet School, Ballet Academy East, Dance Space, the Dance/Impulses Theater of Margaret Beals and the Aspen Music Festival. Paul was the pianist for two recorded albums with ballet instructor David Howard. Paul is survived by his brother, John Spong of Pompton Plains, New Jersey, and three generations of nieces and nephews. Memorial service: 2pm, October 14 at Trinity Cemetery Chapel, 770 Riverside Drive. A celebration of Paul's life will be held in 2014. Donations can be made to: Manhattan School of Music or Amnesty International.

SPIELBERG--Frank E.,91, passed away at home, Sunday October 6, 2013. Born in Vertugeni, Russia Frank lived in Summit, NJ since 1979, as well as in Mexico, Holland, Kansas, California and New York. He earned a Bachelor of Science Degree from USC and was the President of Hoerbiger Products USA and served as President and member of the Board of Directors of Worthington Pumps, Mexico City. He was a member and past President of the Mexican Engineering Society. Frank also enjoyed being a longtime member of the Fairmount Country Club in Chatham. Frank is survived by his beloved wife of 58 years Gilda (Carmel); his loving children Gordon Spielberg and wife Georgina (California), Genevieve Spielberg-Frey and husband Armin Frey (Summit, NJ), his sister Bertha Herrmann, and four cherished grandchildren: Spencer, Justin, Katie and Carter. A devoted husband, father and grandfather, Frank was a loving, brilliant, and generous gentleman who will be missed immeasurably. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 24, 2013. In lieu of flowers, donations in Frank's memory can be made to Genevieve Spielberg on behalf of the Justin Frey Special Needs Trust. (ippolitofuneralhomes.com)

SOBEL--Ruth Lee, age 85, passed away peacefully on October 9, 2013 in Albuquerque, NM. She was born July 3, 1928 to Joseph and Helen (Kneibert) Weinblatt in New York City. Ruth is survived by daughters, Marianne Reuter Smith, Suzanne Reuter, and Joanne Reuter and husband, Ross Becker; grandchildren, Seth Becker, Matthew J.W. Smith and wife, Sandra, Rebecca Smith Stern and husband, Jonathan; great-grandson, Benjamin Stern; and many dear nephews, cousins and friends. She is preceded in death by her parents and brother Alan Weinblatt. Throughout her life, Ruth shared her love of art, music, opera, ballet, literature, archaeology and all things beautiful with her children and grandchildren. More than anything, she loved her daughters and grandchildren. Ruth loved to paint, sketch and wrote poetry. A self-described "city mouse," she lived almost all her life in her beloved New York City where she retired as Director of Telecommunications from Lenox Hill Hospital. As a young mother, she was a winner in the Mrs. New York State beauty pageant. A private Memorial Service will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, www.alz.org, P.O. Box 96011, Washington, DC 20090-6011. To view information or leave a condolence, please visit www.danielsfuneral.com

SIDES--Randolph W. age 58, passed away on Monday, September 23, 2013 in New York City. Beloved husband of Tracey Sides. Randy worked many years in the finance industry, both in the United States and overseas. He was a well respected member of the West Village community in Manhattan and he was a friend to many. Randy was an amazing man who lived life to the fullest. He will live on in our hearts forever. He will be sadly missed by his wife Tracey, his son John, his sister Sylvia, his dogs Mickey, Butch and Dolce and by his many friends, both human and canine.
SAFRAN--Nora, 79, at home in Charlottesville on May 30th. Accomplished artist known for Zen raku pottery. New York service October 27 at 3:00pm. Please RSVP to: safranestate@gmail.com

REETZ--Gay Edwards. Gay Edwards Reetz, of Bronxville on October 10, 2013. Fifty-six years ago, Gay Reetz packed up four children, a St. Bernard and moved to Bronxville. Soon there were six, a large porch and a Volkswagen bus. A graduate of Elmira College, after raising her six, she earned a Master's Degree from Manhattanville College, going on to teach in the Scarsdale Public Schools for over 30 years. Hundreds of children were touched by "The Gay Reetz Way". A lifelong volunteer, she served her church, her village and her country on countless committees, councils and boards, a preceptor to her children and family at large. The lamp she lit still burns in the five children, 10 grandchildren, nieces, nephews, cousins and village she loved. "For God alone my soul waits in silence, from him comes my salvation." A Memorial Service will be held at The Reformed Church of Bronxville on Tuesday, October 15, 2013 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Reformed Church of Bronxville or Jansen Hospice and Palliative Care.

PAGANO--Frank, 93, died peacefully on September 30. Beloved husband of the late Helen (Laitin) Pagano. Loving father to step-daughters Julie Laitin and Laurie Bergner, devoted grandfather to Joel and Elizabeth Bergner, cherished uncle to Bruce Pagano. We (and all his ballroom partners) will miss his wonderful humor, kindness, patience and support. He was a plant manager at Con Ed for 48 years.

O'DONOGHUE--William Sean, 69, retired I.R.S. auditor, died peacefully of cancer on October 3, 2013. He was raised in Bedford, NY and became a life-long resident of NYC. He graduated from St. Paul's School, Concord, NH and Princeton University, then served in Viet Nam as First Lieutenant TC, US Army. A memorial service will be held in the future. www.WarnerAndWozniak.com

MEYER--Melissa Saltman, beloved wife of Eugene Bradley Meyer, died October 2, 2013, at her home in Lincoln, Massachusetts at the age of 70. Born July 2, 1943, she was the daughter of the late Elias B. and Alice Saltman, of Newark, New Jersey. She graduated from Weequahic High School in Newark, in 1961, and received a B.A. from Bennington College in 1965. As a young woman, she was a serious student of the ballet, and maintained her interest in classical music and dance throughout her life, serving for a time on the board of the American Ballet Theatre in New York. She was Chairman of the board of Family Service of Greater Boston for 12 years, served on the board of Bennington College, and chaired the board of the DeCordova Museum and Sculpture Park in Lincoln for 12 years. She was a co-advisor with her husband for a family foundation in the New York Community Trust. A self-taught master cook, she could improvise delicious dishes and specialized in desserts, running a small catering company for a time. She raised three sons, one of whom is a professional cook and teacher of cooking. She was the beloved matriarch of a growing family, who mourn her passing. Both through her charitable work and by personal example she instilled in her children a passion for self-improvement and for helping others. Melissa and her family spent many summers in Maine, both in Blue Hill and on Hog Island in Penobscot Bay. Her interest in the arts extended to chamber music, and she served on the board of Kneisel Hall Chamber Music School and Festival for a number of years. She is survived by her husband; her son Nicholas David Meyer, of New York City and his wife Michelle; her son Jacob Eugene Meyer of Chatham, New York and his wife Rosamond; her son Nathaniel Saltman Meyer, of Brookline, Massachusetts and his wife Erin; her sister Susanna Brooks of New York City; her brother David Saltman, of Miami, Florida and his wife Pemmy; and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on November 9, 2013, at 2:00pm at the First Parish, Lincoln. Burial services will be private. Further information at www.concordfuneral.com.

MATSIL--Helen. December 29, 1925, died August 13, 2013. Beloved husband of Albert Matsil. Devoted mother of Marjorie, Wanda, Robyn and Michael Matsil. Graduate of Brooklyn College. Support ovarian cancer research and screening.

MANVILLE--Hiram Edward III May 21, 1932 September 29, 2013, of Lyme - Old Lyme, CT and Sarasota, FL, passed away peacefully at the age of 81 surrounded with family at Yale New Haven Hospital. He is survived by his beloved wife of 43 years, Nancy Manville, his son, Hiram Edward Manville IV, his adopted daughters, Nancy McMahon and Donna Islieb, his step children, David J. Tiffany, Jennifer Tiffany and Andrea Tiffany, and his sisters, Ethel Woolverton, Mia de Laire, and Deming Pratt Holleran. Ed was born in Mt. Kisco, NY, son of Ethel Schniewind Pratt and Hiram Edward Manville Jr. He was heir of the Founder and the President of the Johns-Manville Corporation, an insulation and building material giant of the American Industrial Age. Ed began his formal education as a boarding student at the age of nine, attending the Eaglebrook School in Deerfield, MA, followed by St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, and Brown University in Providence, RI. He excelled in athletics, particularly ice hockey, and was an Olympic hopeful for the 1952 US Olympic ice hockey team. He served two years in the US Navy, and during that time was a code decipherer for the NSA. His technical and creative genius made way to woodworking, building, real estate development, and providing laser alignment precision equipment for power plants in the Northeast. He had a passion and talent for music and sang four part Barbershop Harmony nearly his entire life. Dixieland, in particular Wild Bill Davidson, were music favorites, and he was a sports fan of the Giants and the Bruins. Known and loved by family and friends for his sharp wit, unusual dry humor, and warm affectionate nature, he leaves behind a three generations that affectionately called him "Popeye", and will miss him dearly. Donations in his honor may be given to: The Manville School at: jbcc.harvard.edu/manville or Harmony Foundation International at: HF@harmonyfoundation.org

LOUGHLIN--Caroline Keller. An award-winning volunteer for historical landscape preservation, died at her home in Cambridge, Massachusetts on October 7, 2013. She was 72. Mrs. Loughlin was born in New Orleans, and graduated from Cornell University in 1961 with a degree in mathematics. In 1962, she married her Cornell classmate Philip H. Loughlin III, and the couple settled in St. Louis in 1965. Mrs. Loughlin volunteered for twenty-eight years at the St. Louis Zoo worked on two mayoral master plan committees for Forest Park, the premier public park in St. Louis, and was a founding member and president of the support group Forest Park Forever. She was coauthor of Forest Park, a definitive history of the park. In 1992, she received the Hiram W. Leffingwell Award for having benefited Forest Park. Mrs. Loughlin was a member of the board for the National Association for Olmsted Parks, and received the group's first Caroline Loughlin Volunteer Service Award. She also was on the board of the Emerald Necklace Conservancy, supporting a chain of parks designed by Frederick Law Olmstead. View, the magazine of The Library of American Landscape History, described her as "among the country's most active stewards of the (Olmsted) firm's landscape history," and named her its 2012 Preservation Hero. After moving to Boston in 1999, Mrs. Loughlin volunteered her time at Cambridge's historic Mount Auburn Cemetery, and became a trustee of the cemetery in 2010. Mrs. Loughlin was predeceased by her brother, Charles Keller III. She is survived by a sister, Mary K. Zervigon, her husband, Philip H. Loughlin III, two sons, Philip H. Loughlin IV (Ellie M. Loughlin) and Thomas K. Loughlin, and two grandchildren, Christopher R. Loughlin and Katherine E. Loughlin. Mrs. Loughlin was inunrned at Mount Auburn Cemetery. A memorial service will be held at Mount Auburn Cemetery on Sunday, October 27 at 11:30am. Donations may be sent to the National Association of Olmstead Parks or to the Friends of Mount Auburn Cemetery.

KRAMER--Calvin, D.D.S.,husband of Lenore, on October 8, 2013. We honor him at our website: http://obits.dignitymemori al.com/dignity-memorial/ obituary.aspx?n=Dr.+ Calvin-Kramer&lc=1224& pid=167463847&mid= 5693753&locale=en--US

He served as an officer in the U.S. Navy and was buried with military honors. Online guestbook: www.plfryandson.com.
KIRSHENBAUM--Stuart. We mourn our esteemed member's passing and send heartfelt sympathy to his family. Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre

KIRSHENBAUM--Stuart M.,passed away October 10 at the age of 60. He leaves behind his beloved wife Meryl, daughters Ally, Lizzie and Zoe, parents Harry and Lillian and sister Shelly and brother Stan, greiving father-in-law Edward, brothers-in-law and nieces and nephews. He loved the Yankees, Giants and Rangers. He loved and practiced labor law, but most of all, he loved his family. He will be missed. Donations to Multiple Sclerosis Society in his memory will be appreciated.

KEHRL--Howard Harmon. Former General Motors Vice Chairman, age 90, passed away peacefully on October 1, 2013 at his home in Rancho Palos Verdes, California. Born February 2, 1923 in Detroit, he was raised by his mother Martha, who had emigrated from Germany. The Great Depression was a very challenging time for the family. Fortunately, Howard was an excellent student and earned a scholarship to Wayne State University. At Wayne State, he met the love of his life, Mary Katherine Maloney. Howard and Mary were happily married for 67 years and raised four children. An affinity for cars and all things mechanical distinguished Howard from an early age. He enjoyed fast cars in his teens and supported himself in school by selling cars he rebuilt. His career at General Motors began in the Research Laboratories in 1948. Positions at Cadillac, Chevrolet and Oldsmobile eventually led to his appointment as Chief Engineer and then General Manager of Oldsmobile. Later, he became Executive Vice President in charge of the General Motors technical and planning staffs and responsible for the company's international operations, before assuming the Vice Chairman post from 1981 to 1986. Howard was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in recognition of his contributions to automotive science and engineering. Howard left Wayne State to enlist in the Navy during World War II. Commissioned an Ensign after completing the Naval Officers Training Program, he taught engineering courses in the Notre Dame Midshipmen's School. He earned engineering degrees from Illinois Institute of Technology (Bachelors) and the University of Notre Dame (Masters). Later, General Motors sponsored him as a Sloan Fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he achieved his Master's degree in industrial management. Boards on which Howard served included the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, General Motors, the GM Cancer Research Foundation (where he served as Vice Chairman), Target Corporation (lead outside director), and the United Negro College Fund (Chairman of the Board). Howard and his wife Mary created an endowed scholarship fund at Wayne State for undergraduate science and engineering students, and have been active supporters of Bravo, a theatre support group, and other charitable organizations. Many of Howard's happiest times involved his family and the outdoors. His favorite places included Michigan's Walloon Lake; the mountains of Colorado and the Pacific Coast in California. Memorable vacations included cross country treks in the family car. He is fondly remembered for his use of the principles of torque and other engineering concepts in teaching his family to ski. Another vehicle for sharing his love of the outdoors was what his grandchildren called Camp Grandpa Bud (a family nickname), time alone with their grandfather including wilderness camping adventures. Howard and Mary particularly loved the grandeur of the mountains, and spent their early retirement years in Aspen, Colorado before settling in California. Howard is survived by his wife Mary; his children Dr. John Kehrl (Dr. Claudia Cicala), Dr. Howard Kehrl (Pamela Moore), David Kehrl (Alida) and Kathy Blenko (David); his grandchildren Tom, Brian, Jason, Ryan, Laura, Jenny, Peter and Matthew and six great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by two sisters, Dorothy and Judy. The memorial service will be held at Wayfarer's Chapel in Rancho Palos Verdes, California at 5:30pm on Sunday, October 13, 2013. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Wayne State University (c/o Wayne State University Fund Office, 5475 Woodward Avenue, Detroit, MI 48202).

HOUGHTON--William Pringle, 97, of Canandaigua, died September 15. For six decades he promoted land conservation, architectural preservation, and respect for fine craftsmanship. Born Plainfield, NJ, 1916, he worked as an automotive engineer in Rochester, where he met his wife, Marie Burgert (deceased 1987), to whom he remained devoted for 53 years. In 1948 they lovingly restored an abandoned Greek revival house on 110 acres near Canandaigua, opened Old Place Antiques, then restored numerous additional 19th-century homes. Bill was among the first locally to place his land in a conservation easement, preserving its natural beauty and inspiring others. Predeceased by wife Marie and sister Hess Engelking. Survived by daughter Charlotte, son-in-law Gilbert Friedman, dear friend and partner in adventure, Patti Simmons, nieces, nephew (and spouses) Elizabeth Mueller, Mary Motte Hall, David Barnes, Peter and Connie Engelking, and their children Bill, Joe, Sarah and John Teitler, Tim and Andrew Hall, Josh and Emily Engelking. Beloved by family, friends, and neighbors; we will miss him deeply.

HENTZEN--Robert K. Robert K. "Bob" Hentzen, president and co-founder of Christian Foundation for Children and Aging (CFCA), the largest charitable organization in Kansas, died on Tuesday in Guatemala. He was 77. Hentzen, his siblings and a family friend started CFCA, an international sponsorship organization, in his basement in 1981. They began their adventure with a Christmas card list and a calling to serve the poor. Today, CFCA works in 21 developing countries around the world and is one of the 200 largest nonprofits in the United States. It serves more than 300,000 children and aging people and their families. More than $1 billion in direct aid has been distributed to benefit families in CFCA programs. "Bob walked right into the hearts of people in poverty all over the world," said CFCA CEO Paco Wertin. "He built bridges across divides." In 1996, Hentzen set out on foot from CFCA headquarters in Kansas City, KS., and walked to Guatemala as an act of solidarity with the poor. It was in Guatemala that he and his wife, Cristina, settled. "He fell in love with the poor through personal encounters," said CFCA Global Strategy Director Paul Pearce. "He could never be the same after that." In 2009, Hentzen embarked on his second walk, an even bigger challenge. He walked more than 8,000 miles from Guatemala to Chile through 12 countries. Thousands of families and supporters joined him during the 18-month trek. "Society has told them all along that they are not capable," Hentzen said during the walk, in a reference to families living in poverty. "We are here to tell them they are quite capable. 'You are not alone. We are walking with you.' " Hentzen died unexpectedly October 8, 2013, of natural causes. He was the last surviving member of CFCA's five founders. But the mission and work of CFCA will continue. Bob is survived by his wife, Cristina, six children, 11 grandchildren, seven sponsored children, many nieces and nephews and an international circle of friends that numbers in the hundreds of thousands. Hentzen will be laid to rest in San Lucas Toliman, Guatemala, on Saturday, October 12, 2013. A memorial Mass will be held later in the church where Hentzen grew up in Kansas City, MO. Memorials may be made by sponsoring a child or donating to the CFCA Scholarship fund at hopeforafamily.org

GINLEY--Thomas H.,MD, on October 8, 2013 of Bryn Mawr, Nantucket and Round Hill, Jamaica. Beloved husband of Emma. Devoted father of Deborah Lewis and Vanessa Noel; also survived by his grandson George Lewis, VI. Relatives and friends are invited to attend his Viewing Monday after 10:00am in the Church of St. John Vianney, Gladwyne followed by a Funeral Mass at 11:00am. Interment private. FARINET--Gene, on October. 10, 2013. Cherished husband of Judy, beloved father of Scott (Mary Ann), Michele (Jared), John, Madeleine, and Jennifer and loving grandfather of Coco and Dylan. Gene was an extraordinary journalist at NBC News for over 40 years. He treasured his family and his memory will be celebrated by all who knew him. Donations in his memory may be made to The Committee to Protect Journalists.

DOERFLER--Ronald J. Ronald J. Doerfler, Hearst Corporation director, trustee and senior vice president, finance and administration, died Friday, October 11, in Brick, N.J. after a brief hospitalization. He was 72. Doerfler, whose career at Hearst Corporation spanned 15 years, had responsibility for Hearst's finance and accounting activities, and also oversaw Hearst's New York real estate holdings. He was elected to Hearst's Board of Directors in June 2002 and was a testamentary trustee under the will of William Randolph Hearst since 2008. Doerfler represented Hearst on the board of directors of A+E Networks during virtually his entire tenure at Hearst. "The passing of Ron Doerfler is not only a loss to Hearst, but to associates across the media community," said Steven R. Swartz, president & CEO of Hearst Corporation. "He was an outstanding executive, providing our management team with valuable strategic and transactional guidance throughout his career. He will be greatly missed." "Ron was a part of Hearst for more than 15 years and our partner before that in his roles at Cap Cities, ABC and Disney," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., executive vice chairman, Hearst Corporation. "His financial expertise stretched across nearly every line of business Hearst is engaged in, and he was an integral part of Hearst's major transactions since 1998, including: the Pulitzer broadcasting group acquisition, creation of Hearst Television, the A+E Networks and Lifetime merger, the Mark Burnett partnership and the addition of Lagardere's magazine titles. Most importantly though, Ron was a close friend. Those of us in the Hearst family who had the privilege to work with Ron will miss him greatly." Doerfler joined Hearst as vice president and chief financial officer in 1998 and was elected senior vice president in March 2000. Prior to Hearst, he was senior vice president and chief financial officer at ABC, Inc., and at its predecessor Capital Cities/ABC. Doerfler joined Capital Cities Communications in 1969 as assistant controller and was appointed treasurer in 1977, and senior vice president and chief financial officer in 1980. He played a major role in Capital Cities' acquisition of ABC, Inc., in 1986 and again in the 1996 Capital Cities/ABC merger with The Walt Disney Company. Doerfler began his business career in 1960 in public accounting and in 1966, he joined International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation as a senior financial analyst. He was a former chairman of the board of the Broadcast Cable Financial Management Association and a member of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. Doerfler sat on the board of trustees of Fairleigh Dickinson University, his alma mater, and the Museum of the Moving Image, and served on the board of directors of the Arts & Business Council. In 2007, he was awarded Fairleigh Dickinson's Charter Day Award, which honors individuals who have distinguished themselves as outstanding leaders in their professions and their communities. Doerfler was a member of the board of directors for Lazard, the financial advisory and asset management firm, from 2006 to 2011. He was also instrumental in the planning and construction of Hearst Corporation's award-winning Hearst Tower, which opened in 2006. Doerfler, born in Jersey City, N.J., graduated from Fairleigh Dickinson University with a degree in accounting and became a CPA in 1967. He received an MBA, magna cum laude, from Fairleigh Dickinson in 1972. He is survived by his wife, Krystyna, daughter Stephanie and granddaughter Alexandra Casteele. Funeral services are private. A memorial service, to be announced at a later date, will be held in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Fairleigh Dickinson University and the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York. With Appreciation, Hearst Corporation Board of Directors William R. Hearst III, Chairman of the Board Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Executive Vice Chairman Steven R. Swartz, President & Chief Executive Officer

CREED--Anne Mundell. The Board of Directors of The Catholic Big Sisters and Big Brothers notes with sorrow the death of our dear friend, past Board President, long standing board member, and generous supporter, Anne Mundell Creed. We will miss her delightful humor and caring guidance. Our thoughts and prayers are with her family.

CARTER--Louise Cahill, of Washington, DC, died October 9, 2013. Mrs. Carter was the youngest of five children of James Augustine Cahill, M.D., and Florence McKinney Cahill, of Washington, D.C. Her father was Chief of Surgery at Georgetown University Hospital and Professor of Surgery at Georgetown University Medical School. The Cahill Medal for excellence in surgery is awarded every year to a student at Georgetown University Medical School. Mrs. Carter was educated by the nuns at the Convent of the Sacred Heart and graduated from Stone Ridge School in Bethesda, MD. She graduated from American University with a Bachelor's degree and also studied at Georgetown. In 1962 she married Warwick Montgomery Carter. Mrs. Carter lived her entire life in Washington. She spent many Summers in Watch Hill, Rhode Island, and Winters in Palm Beach, Florida. Mrs. Carter was a lifelong Francophile. She studied and spoke French and travelled to France at various times throughout her life. Her favorite place was a small village in Provence known as Ansouis. Mrs. Carter was an avid opera buff and was a long-standing member of the Board of Trustees of The Washington Opera. Mrs. Carter was a member of the Chevy Chase Club as well as the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach. She was also a former member of the Sulgrave Club in Washington and of the Colony Club in New York. Her greatest passion was her family. She was a devoted wife to her husband, Warwick, who suffered from Parkinson's disease for 20 years and died in 2006. She will be remembered as a woman with a keen wit, a great sense of humor and "joie de vivre." Louise Carter was survived by her three children: Warwick Montgomery Carter, Jr., Raymond Prescott Cahill Carter, and Louise Lee Carroll Carter and four grandchildren. A funeral mass will be offered at Immaculate Conception Catholic Church at 1315 8th Street, NW (at 8th and N Streets) in Washington, D.C. 20001, on Tuesday, October 15, 2013, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Louise's memory to Immaculate Conception.
CARPENTER--Scott. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Scott Carpenter, and send condolences to his family.
BURKE--Mack. 98, worked at The New York Times and Time. Retired in San Diego. Wife Patricia died 2005. Children: Sheila Page and Paul@globe1234.com
BLACK--Charles A.A. A dear friend to many on both sides of the Atlantic, died suddenly in London on October 9th. He will be sorely missed.

BERNS--Philip A.,died on October 5th at his home in Henderson, NV. He was 80. The longtime head of the San Francisco Field Office of the United .States Department of Justices Admiralty and Aviation section, Berns, a Staten Island native, worked for the Department for 44 years and was the lead attorney on some of the agency's most high-profile cases of recent decades, including the Exxon Valdez and Argo Merchant. Berns knew that a good piece of fish was a gift from the oceans he loved and the very best flavor in a shank of beef was found in the marrow. He loved Broadway musicals, a good Chinese restaurant and Fred Astaire albums "You could hear him sing AND dance." When asked in his final days whether he was comfortable, Berns paused for a three count and cited one of his favorite lines: "I make a living." He is survived by his wife, Jane; sons, David, Peter and Jay; daughters-in-law Debbie and Deann; and grandchildren Asia, Brittney and Ty.

BERMEL--Albert D. 5 October 2013. Playwright, critic, translator, professor emeritus of theater and film at CUNY Graduate Center and Lehman College, beloved husband, brother, father and grandfather. A memorial will be held later this year.

ANNAN--Marilyn Agnes, passed away on Thursday, October 10, in her beloved, "beautiful" Bronx. She was born on August 27, 1933, in Brooklyn, NY. She was a loving and dedicated daughter of Frances Annan, until Frances' death in June of 1984. Marilyn is survived by her goddaughter Dea Perez (nee Connick); Dea's husband Dominique; their daughter Gemma; many "nieces" and "nephews;" and countless friends that loved her dearly. Marilyn was pre-deceased by her closest friend of 40+ years, Mary H. Connick, and Mary's husband, Brendan (Joseph) Connick. Marilyn, a longtime librarian at The New York Times, retired in 2001. A wake will be held at Williams Funeral Home, at 5628 Broadway (at West 232nd Street), in the Bronx, on Monday, October 14, from 2pm to 5pm, and 7pm to 9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held at 10:45am, at Our Lady of Refuge Church, 290 E 196th Street, Bronx, on Tuesday, October 15.

HALPERT--Edward R. The Memorial Service for Edward R. Halpert will be held at 5:30pm on Thursday, October 17 at THE BREARLEY SCHOOL, 610 EAST 83rd STREET, New York City - not, as originally announced, at the Century Association.

WOLFE--Jane Baker, 73, of Pequannock Township, NJ, formerly of Staten Island, NY, passed away on October 11, 2013. Jane was the daughter of the former Staten Island Borough President, the late Edward G. and his wife, Jesse P. Baker. She was the wife of Peter J. Wolfe. Jane is survived by her children, Peter and his wife Joy, Edward and his wife Laurie, Kevin and his wife Heather, and Megan. She was also blessed with nine grandchildren. A Funeral Mass will be held 11am Tuesday, October 15 at Holy Spirit Church, Pequannock, NJ. Visiting hours will be 3-7pm Monday at the M. John Scanlan Funeral Home, Pompton Plains, NJ.

WIEN--Stephen. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Edie and the entire family. Frederic Krieger, President
WIEN--Stephen, dear friend, loving, caring, kind. He was very loved and will live in our hearts forever. Joanne and Sid, Denise, Jolie and Gary
Snell--Michael, August 3, 1950-September 30, 2013. NYC resident, Army veteran and film score aficionado whose passion for movie music enriched the lives of others.

RICHTER--Arleen.The family of Arleen Richter mourn her passing on October 12, 2013. Arleen was a spectacular wife, a wonderful mother and a remarkable and loving grandmother. She leaves a legacy of love and teaching to her children Scott and Lori, Jonathan and Deborah, Lisa and Jeff. The loss to her friends is profound. Her mark on her grandchildren will carry on forever in the lives of Spencer and Matthew Hagler; Zachary, Gabriella and Adam Richter; Sloan, Scott and Jamie Richter. Her husband Martin senses a deep and profound loss. His love for her will continue forever. Services Monday at 12pm at Star of David Memorial Chapels in West Babylon. Interment is at Wellwood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please consider contributions to NYU Lagone Medical Center for The Study and Treatment of Pain at 240 E. 38th St NY, NY 10016 (212) 201-1004 Att: Dr. John Delfino. For more info go to www.jewish-funeral-home.com

REETZ--Gay Edwards. Gay Edwards Reetz, of Bronxville on October 10, 2013. Fifty-six years ago, Gay Reetz packed up four children, a St. Bernard and moved to Bronxville. Soon there were six, a large porch and a Volkswagen bus. A graduate of Elmira College, after raising her six, she earned a Master's Degree from Manhattanville College, going on to teach in the Scarsdale Public Schools for over 30 years. Hundreds of children were touched by "The Gay Reetz Way". A lifelong volunteer, she served her church, her village and her country on countless committees, councils and boards, a preceptor to her children and family at large. The lamp she lit still burns in the five children, 10 grandchildren, nieces, nephews, cousins and village she loved. "For God alone my soul waits in silence, from him comes my salvation." A Memorial Service will be held at The Reformed Church of Bronxville on Tuesday, October 15, 2013 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Reformed Church of Bronxville or Jansen Hospice and Palliative Care.

MATSIL--Helen. December 29, 1925, died August 13, 2013. Beloved wife of Albert Matsil. Devoted mother of Marjorie, Wanda, Robyn and Michael Matsil. Graduate of Brooklyn College. Support ovarian cancer research and screening.

MONTEVERDE--John W.,(Monte), on October 11, 2013. 31-year-veteran, FDNY, assigned to Engine 22 in Manhattan for 30 years, and most recently assigned to Engine 159 on Staten Island. Beloved partner of Nelly Sciascia. Devoted father to Alexis, William and Johnny. Beloved son of Delma A. Monteverde. Adored brother of Celeste Rovello. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 E 62nd St, Thursday 11am. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

LIPPS--Roslyn M.,June 10, 1925-October 12, 2013. An outstanding figure in publicity, advertising and theater. Colleague of Earl Blackwell at his Celebrity Service, founder of Lippservice, member of the Outer Critics Circle. She leaves many loving friends. Funeral Tuesday, October 15, at 11:30am at the "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

KOPF--Irving, on October 11, 2013. Taught 'Far Eastern Affairs' at Central Connecticut State University; Associate Professor of Geography, Emeritus. Served in Cambodia with the Foreign Service. Veteran of the Korean War. World traveler with a strong appreciation of many cultures. Beloved brother and uncle, he will be greatly missed. Services at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, NJ on Tuesday, October 15, 2013, at 10am.

HOUGHTON--William Pringle, 97, of Canandaigua, died September 15. For six decades he promoted land conservation, architectural preservation, and respect for fine craftsmanship. Born Plainfield, NJ, 1916, he worked as an automotive engineer in Rochester, where he met his wife, Marie Burgert (deceased 1987), to whom he remained devoted for 53 years. In 1948 they lovingly restored an abandoned Greek revival house on 110 acres near Canandaigua, opened Old Place Antiques, then restored numerous additional 19th-century homes. Bill was among the first locally to place his land in a conservation easement, preserving its natural beauty and inspiring others. Predeceased by wife Marie and sister Hess Engelking. Survived by daughter Charlotte, son-in-law Gilbert Friedman, dear friend and partner in adventure, Patti Simmons, nieces, nephew (and spouses) Elizabeth Mueller, Mary Motte Hall, David Barnes, Peter and Connie Engelking, and their children Bill, Joe, Sarah and John Teitler, Tim and Andrew Hall, Josh and Emily Engelking. Beloved by family, friends, and neighbors; we will miss him deeply.

HIJUELOS--Oscar,The first Latino author to win the Pulitzer Prize in Literature for his 1990 novel 'The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,' has died on October 12th at the age of 62. Hijuelos was known for his experimentation with form and voice in all his works and leaves behind a rich collection of novels, a young adult novel and a memoir. Born in New York to Cuban immigrant parents, his work was influenced by their experiences. While he received critical praise for his early work, it was the second novel that catapulted him onto bestseller lists and earned him international acclaim. He is survived by his wife, Lori Marie Carlson, his brother Jose Hijuelos and nephew Matthew Hijuelos. A private service will be held this week at Riverside Memorial Chapel and a public memorial will be planned in the future.

HECHT--Lenore. The entire community of Beth Israel Medical Center, a member of the Mount Sinai Health System, acknowledges with sadness the passing of our dear friend and generous benefactress Lenore Hecht, who served with great distinction as a member of our Board of Trustees for many years. Lenore continued the charitable work of her beloved parents, former Beth Israel Trustees Jack and Belle Linsky, forging her own legacy of support. Her philanthropy enhanced many of the hospital's programs, most notably through the naming of the Thomas Killip, MD, Division of Cardiology. She will always be remembered for her compassion and desire to help provide our patients with the highest quality of care in a safe, healing environment. To her daughters, Gina Freis and Barbara Hurlbutt, her family and all her loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Kenneth L. Davis, MD President and CEO Mount Sinai Health System Harris M. Nagler, MD President. Beth Israel Steven R. Bergmann, MD, PHDVice Chairman, Department of Medicine and Chief, The Thomas Killip, MD, Division of Cardiology

Devoted brother of the late Rabbi Arthur Chiel, Annette Arlan, and brother-in-law of the late Malka Levine and Bernard Eisenberg. Dear brother-in-law of Kinneret Chiel, Phyllis Eisenberg and Rabbi Murray Levine. Loving uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Remembrances may be made to Temple Emanuel, Newton, MA, Combined Jewish Philanthropies, Boston, MA, Maimonides School, Brookline, MA, Fuchs Mizrachi School Cleveland, OH or Congregation Shaarei Tefillah, Newton, MA. Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA.
BLACK--Charles A.A. A dear friend to many on both sides of the Atlantic, died suddenly in London on October 9th. He will be sorely missed.

ANNAN--Marilyn Agnes, passed away on Thursday, October 10, in her beloved, "beautiful" Bronx. She was born on August 27, 1933, in Brooklyn, NY. She was a loving and dedicated daughter of Frances Annan, until Frances' death in June of 1984. Marilyn is survived by her goddaughter Dea Perez (nee Connick); Dea's husband Dominique; their daughter Gemma; many "nieces" and "nephews;" and countless friends that loved her dearly. Marilyn was pre-deceased by her closest friend of 40+ years, Mary H. Connick, and Mary's husband, Brendan (Joseph) Connick. Marilyn, a longtime librarian at The New York Times, retired in 2001. YUAN--Shuen, 77, Professor of mathematics in algebra, man of sublime virtue who was immersed in both Chinese and Western culture and philosophy. A connoisseur of all fine wine, food, music, art, literature, museums and gardens, he died at 77, in his home at Williamsville. Forever resting with his beloved parents at Serenity, Forest Lawn, Buffalo, NY.

WOLFE--Jane Baker, 73, of Pequannock Township, NJ, formerly of Staten Island, NY, passed away on October 11, 2013. Jane was the daughter of the former Staten Island Borough President, the late Edward G. and his wife, Jesse P. Baker. She was the wife of Peter J. Wolfe. Jane is survived by her children, Peter and his wife Joy, Edward and his wife Laurie, Kevin and his wife Heather, and Megan. She was also blessed with nine grandchildren. A Funeral Mass will be held 11am Tuesday, October 15 at Holy Spirit Church, Pequannock, NJ. Visiting hours will be 3-7pm Monday at the M. John Scanlan Funeral Home, Pompton Plains, NJ.

WEISMAN--Leon, of Jericho, NY on October 13, 2013. Leon is survived by wife Sylvia, son Steven Weisman, daughter Marlene Weisman-Abadi, and their families. Thank you to caregiver, Diana. Services at Gutterman's, Woodbury, LI on Tuesday, October 15, at 1pm.

ROTHSCHILD--Lieslotte, (Lilo) (nee Braun) born in Frankfurt, Germany, and formerly of Riverdale, NY and Fort Lee, NJ passed away on October 13, 2013 in Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 91. She is survived by Fred, her devoted and loving husband of 67 years, her beloved sons Stephen and Peter (Laura), adoring grandchildren Lara (Bryan), Alexander and Jennifer, and cherished great-granddaughter Emily. Private services will be held graveside. The family will receive visitors from 5pm to 9pm on October 15 at The Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Lilo's memory to UJA-Federation of New York. (www.ujafedny.org)

RITCHIE--Celia Ann. February 17, 1934 October 3, 2013. Celia Ann Ritchie succumbed to pneumonia at Allen Memorial Hospital. Ritchie served as a Foreign Student Advisor at Columbia and NYU. She was also an artist, whose watercolors and collages were exhibited nationally. She will be missed by family and friends. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Interment at Lakeview Cemetery in Burlington, VT.

RICHTER--Arleen.The family of Arleen Richter mourn her passing on October 12, 2013. Arleen was a spectacular wife, a wonderful mother and a remarkable and loving grandmother. She leaves a legacy of love and teaching to her children Scott and Lori, Jonathan and Deborah, Lisa and Jeff. The loss to her friends is profound. Her mark on her grandchildren will carry on forever in the lives of Spencer and Matthew Hagler; Zachary, Gabriella and Adam Richter; Sloan, Scott and Jamie Richter. Her husband Martin senses a deep and profound loss. His love for her will continue forever. Services Monday at 12pm at Star of David Memorial Chapels in West Babylon. Interment is at Wellwood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please consider contributions to NYU Lagone Medical Center for The Study and Treatment of Pain at 240 E. 38th St NY, NY 10016 (212) 201-1004 Att: Dr. John Delfino. For more info go to www.jewish-funeral-home.com

REED--Carole, 74, of Port Jefferson, died October 12, 2013. Dearest friend of Kathleen Martin, devoted mother of Kenneth F. Mac Alpin and James J. Reed, cherished grandmother of Smaika "Danielle" Qaddas and Kenneth E. Mac Alpin and great- grandmother of Malaika Qaddas, loving sister to Wallis Reed, Loretta Reed, Roseanne Reed Motti, and Patricia Reed Meehan, and beloved aunt and grand aunt to many nieces and nephews. Carole graduated from Bishop McDonald High School and received a BA in English from Queens College, an MS in Library Studies from CWPost, and an MA in Liberal Studies from Stony Brook University. Carole taught in the Port Jefferson and Comsewogue School Districts for 30 years. After her retirement, Carole taught poetry at Stony Brook University, moved to Manhattan, taught literature at The New School, and enjoyed going to museums, the I opera, theatre, and everything NYC had to offer. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Friends may call at the Bryant Funeral Home, 411 Old Town Road, Setauket, NY. Visiting hours Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30am at the St. James Church in Setauket, NY. Interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the Good Shepherd Hospice, 245 Old Country Road, Melville, NY 11747.

PORDY--Ruth G.,on October 13, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Leon Pordy. Devoted mother of Dr. William Todd, Dr. Robert Craig, and Melissa Jane, loving mother-in-law of Richard Lefkowitz and Dr. Cathryn Devons. Adored grandmother of Rachel, Jessica and Matthew Pordy and dear sister of Marion Halpern, the late Marvin Gansberg and sister-in-law of John Halpern and Wendy Gansberg. Our mother was a beautiful, brilliant woman who fought valiantly and has left the world a bit dimmer. Wishing her love, peace and eternal rest. Service Tuesday, October 15, 2013, 11:00am at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87 St., NY, NY. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to: Dorot, 171 W. 85 St., NY, NY 10024, www.dorotusa.org.

O'NEIL--Celeste Cheatham, passed away at her residence in North Palm Beach, Florida, on October 13, 2013 as a result of head injuries sustained from a fall in April. Celeste was born November 29, 1935 in Augusta, Georgia, and later moved to New York City but never forgot her southern roots. She was the daughter of Owen Robertson Cheatham, the founder of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, and Celeste Wickliffe Cheatham. Celeste attended The Madeira School in McLean, Virginia, and later attended the Spence School, Finch College, and Columbia University in New York City. Celeste ("Wiki" to her southern kin) was widely known for her kind and generous spirit. Her warmth and sense of humor made everyone feel comfortable and welcome. Throughout her life, she did more for others than for herself, a trait that was visible until the end. She had many life-long friends, and even those whom she met for a short time felt as though they had known her forever. Celeste was an active supporter of the arts and education, both personally and through The Owen Cheatham Foundation, of which she was the Chairman of the Board. She had been a board member and trustee of Choate Rosemary Hall, Martha Graham Dance Company, The Museum of Broadcasting, Musica Sacra (New York), and other philanthropic organizations. She is survived by her husband, Stephen E. O'Neil of New York City; her sons, Kenneth Robertson Kennerly (and wife Kelly) of Jupiter, Florida, and Owen Cheatham Kennerly (and wife Sarina) of San Francisco; five grandchildren (Carly, Charlie, Ava, Eero, and Rae), seven step-children, and eighteen step-grandchildren. She was pre-deceased by her other son, Charles Wickliffe Kennerly, whom she has now joined in Heaven. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, October 15th at 2pm at the Lost Tree Chapel, 11149 Turtle Beach Road, North Palm Beach, Fl. An additional service and burial will occur on Friday, October 18, 2013 at The New Concord Presbyterian Church in Concord, Virginia, where she will be laid to rest with other family members. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 53000 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407 or to The Lost Tree Village Charitable Foundation, 11520 Lost Tree Way, North Palm Beach, Fl 33408.

MENOWITZ--Harold, of Bal Harbour, Florida, passed away peacefully on October 13. Beloved husband of Lila Pollock Menowitz, devoted father of Fred and Sue Menowitz and Carol Penn, grandfather of Marc and Elle Menowitz, Laurence and Jill Penn, Todd and Pam Menowitz, Jonathan and Lisa Penn, Valerie Penn, Jonathan and Lisa Hamburger, and Gregory and Edith Penn. Great- grandfather of 13. His first wife, Sophie Lefrak Menowitz, predeceased him in June 1979. Son of Carl and Florence Menowitz, he was born in New York on November 10, 1913. At the age of 17, he started, what became the largest manufacturing company of round belting used for sewing machines throughout the world, availing himself of the New York Public Library to learn the trade. As founder of the Menowitz organization in 1956, and subsequently its chairman emeritus, Harold became a real estate developer and investor building numerous multi-family and commercial properties in Brooklyn and Queens during the 1950's, 60's, and 70's. Settling in the Miami, Florida area in 1973, he became a prominent Miami area philanthropist. Especially devoted to numerous medical organizations, including Mt. Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach where he was a Founder, and funded the Breast Cancer Clinic of Mt. Sinai Hospital, which is regarded as the best such facility in the state of Florida, helped establish the new pediatric outpatient building at John's Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore, MD, and having previously been an Associate Trustee at North Shore Hospital/LIJ where he started the Outpatient Transportation Service, providing free transportation for outpatients needing transportation to and from the hospital. Harold was a longtime donor of his time and money for over sixty years to the Anti-Defamation League. Charming, intelligent and a spell binding conversationalist, he will be greatly missed by all who knew him. A private service will be held graveside at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, Long Island, on Wednesday, October 16. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations in his honor be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY Hospice Care, in appreciation of the wonderful work that they do.

MARTON--Michael. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Michael Marton, z'l, a longtime supporter of the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, the university's Holocaust Studies Program, the Jacob and Dreizel Glueck Center for Jewish Study, the Yeshiva University High Schools and the YU Museum. A Holocaust survivor who together with his first wife Sarah Marton, of blessed memory and his wife Lillian, was a YU Guardian. He was deeply admired by all who knew him for his kindness, warm personality, ever present smile and dedication to Jewish education and to Jewish observance. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Lillian Marton, his children Robert Marton and Elaine Marton-Diller, grandchildren and great grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

MARTON--Michael. The SAR community is deeply saddened by the passing of Michael Marton, a longtime Trustee and generous benefactor of the school. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Lillian and his children, Robert Marton and Elaine Marton-Diller. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C.
