EPHRON--Erwin. Influential media consultant and father of modern media planning passed away peacefully on October 13, 2013. He was 79 years old. Born in New York, he received a BA from Swarthmore College and an MBA in Economics from New York University. Ephron was a top media executive at several advertising agencies, including his own, Ephron, Raboy & Tsao, before becoming a partner in media consultancy with Ephron Papazian & Ephron. He is survived by his wife Elaine, daughters Susan Ephron and husband Randy Daniels, and Rachel Ephron Barenholtz and husband Brett Barenholtz, son John Ephron and wife Joan Olson, and grandchildren, Sydney, Jacob, Jeremy, and Sam.

DOERFLER--Ronald J. Ronald J. Doerfler, Hearst Corporation director, trustee and senior vice president, finance and administration, died Friday, October 11, in Brick, N.J. after a brief hospitalization. He was 72. Doerfler, whose career at Hearst Corporation spanned 15 years, had responsibility for Hearst's finance and accounting activities, and also oversaw Hearst's New York real estate holdings. He was elected to Hearst's Board of Directors in June 2002 and was a testamentary trustee under the will of William Randolph Hearst since 2008. Doerfler represented Hearst on the board of directors of A+E Networks during virtually his entire tenure at Hearst. "The passing of Ron Doerfler is not only a loss to Hearst, but to associates across the media community," said Steven R. Swartz, president & CEO of Hearst Corporation. "He was an outstanding executive, providing our management team with valuable strategic and transactional guidance throughout his career. He will be greatly missed." "Ron was a part of Hearst for more than 15 years and our partner before that in his roles at Cap Cities, ABC and Disney," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., executive vice chairman, Hearst Corporation. "His financial expertise stretched across nearly every line of business Hearst is engaged in, and he was an integral part of Hearst's major transactions since 1998, including: the Pulitzer broadcasting group acquisition, creation of Hearst Television, the A+E Networks and Lifetime merger, the Mark Burnett partnership and the addition of Lagardere's magazine titles. Most importantly though, Ron was a close friend. Those of us in the Hearst family who had the privilege to work with Ron will miss him greatly." Doerfler joined Hearst as vice president and chief financial officer in 1998 and was elected senior vice president in March 2000. Prior to Hearst, he was senior vice president and chief financial officer at ABC, Inc., and at its predecessor Capital Cities/ABC. Doerfler joined Capital Cities Communications in 1969 as assistant controller and was appointed treasurer in 1977, and senior vice president and chief financial officer in 1980. He played a major role in Capital Cities' acquisition of ABC, Inc., in 1986 and again in the 1996 Capital Cities/ABC merger with The Walt Disney Company. Doerfler began his business career in 1960 in public accounting and in 1966, he joined International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation as a senior financial analyst. He was a former chairman of the board of the Broadcast Cable Financial Management Association and a member of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. Doerfler sat on the board of trustees of Fairleigh Dickinson University, his alma mater, and the Museum of the Moving Image, and served on the board of directors of the Arts & Business Council. In 2007, he was awarded Fairleigh Dickinson's Charter Day Award, which honors individuals who have distinguished themselves as outstanding leaders in their professions and their communities. Doerfler was a member of the board of directors for Lazard, the financial advisory and asset management firm, from 2006 to 2011. He was also instrumental in the planning and construction of Hearst Corporation's award-winning Hearst Tower, which opened in 2006. Doerfler, born in Jersey City, N.J., graduated from Fairleigh Dickinson University with a degree in accounting and became a CPA in 1967. He received an MBA, magna cum laude, from Fairleigh Dickinson in 1972. He is survived by his wife, Krystyna, daughter Stephanie and granddaughter Alexandra Casteele. Funeral services are private. A memorial service, to be announced at a later date, will be held in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Fairleigh Dickinson University and the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York. With Appreciation, Hearst Corporation Board of Directors William R. Hearst III, Chairman of the Board Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Executive Vice Chairman Steven R. Swartz, President & Chief Executive Officer

URVATER--Ronald. Passed away after a sudden illness October 14, 2013. Beloved husband of Eve, devoted father of Arielle and Jessie, adored brother of Michele, son of the late Philip and Judith of Antwerp, Belgium. TIMMONS--James. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James Timmons, associated with The New York Times from April 20, 1936 until retiring on February 1, 1983.

STEIN--Linda Lasker, BA, MPH. July 10, 1943-October 12, 2013. Born in New Haven, CT, she lived her early years in Brooklyn and later in Manhattan and Queens. She was a founding partner of Brownlee Dolan Stein Association, a pioneer of employee assistance programs in the late 70's. Subsequently Linda worked with Career Mentors before moving to Newbury Vermont where she worked as a mediator. Returning in recent years to New York City, she volunteered helping new immigrants with naturalization exams, with adult English language learners in conversational English, and in elementary school reading programs. She encouraged and mentored many young people in pursuit of college degrees and careers. Linda is survived by nieces Nisa Zap and Stacey Lasker. She will be remembered by all who knew and loved her as a wise, thoughtful, kind, and generous soul.

She is survived by Fred, her devoted and loving husband of 67 years, her beloved sons Stephen and Peter (Laura), adoring grandchildren Lara (Bryan), Alexander and Jennifer, and cherished great-granddaughter Emily. ROTHSCHILD--Lilo. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Lilo Rothschild. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband Fred and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

REED--Carole. The Board of Directors and management of Hampshire House acknowledge with sadness the passing of our neighbor, Carole Reed. We were fortunate to share her literary expertise with our building's book club. Our heartfelt condolences to her family.

REED--Carole, 74, of Port Jefferson, died October 12, 2013. Dearest friend of Kathleen Martin, devoted mother of Kenneth F. Mac Alpin and James J. Reed, cherished grandmother of Smaika "Danielle" Qaddas and Kenneth E. Mac Alpin and great- grandmother of Malaika Qaddas, loving sister to Wallis Reed, Loretta Reed, Roseanne Reed Motti, and Patricia Reed Meehan, and beloved aunt and grand aunt to many nieces and nephews. Carole graduated from Bishop McDonald High School and received a BA in English from Queens College, an MS in Library Studies from CWPost, and an MA in Liberal Studies from Stony Brook University. Carole taught in the Port Jefferson and Comsewogue School Districts for 30 years. After her retirement, Carole taught poetry at Stony Brook University, moved to Manhattan, taught literature at The New School, and enjoyed going to museums, the I opera, theatre, and everything NYC had to offer. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Friends may call at the Bryant Funeral Home, 411 Old Town Road, Setauket, NY. Visiting hours Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30am at the St. James Church in Setauket, NY. Interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the Good Shepherd Hospice, 245 Old Country Road, Melville, NY 11747.

NARDOZA--Kathleen F. (nee Shinnick) on October 13, 2013. Beloved wife of Peter. Devoted mother of Carol Wheeler (Thomas), Mary Ellen, Jean and the late Peter and Michael. Loving sister of Anne Schinnick. Cherished grandmother of Brian, Anne, Colin and Marielle. Reposing at The Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28 Street NYC on Wednesday 4-8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Immaculate Conception Church 414 East 14 Street NYC at 10am. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

MONTE--James K. Prodigious painter, curator at the Whitney Museum of American Art & the L.A. County Museum of Art, writer and critic, raconteur par excellence, he left this life on October 12, 2013. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him, especially his spouse, Aileen Pare. Memorial service to be announced.
MENOWITZ--Harold. Our heartfelt condolences to Fred Menowitz, a member of our Board of Directors, on the loss of his father and to the entire family. Medallion Financial Corp.

MACKLIN--Julia, of Brooklyn, NY on October 13th, 2013, age 50. Beloved daughter of Suzanne and the late Edward R. Loving sister of Bruce, Janet (Peter Malchow) and David (Leigh Ann). Dear aunt of Katie and Clayton. Visitation at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas, Glen Cove, Wednesday, 4-7pm. Interment Private. Donations may be made to the Bailey Arboretum (baileyarboretum.org).

KRAINES--Evelyn (nee Korn), 93, daughter of Aaron and Lillian (nee Axelrod), died October 13, 2013 from natural causes. Accountant to multiple organizations and hospital volunteer. Family always came first. She wanted the best for her children, grandchildren, husband and parents. Loving and devoted mother and grandmother, wife of the late Sidney, sister of the late Irene Sacks. She leaves her sons, Jeffrey and Merrill, daughters-in-law Linda and Jeane, and grandchildren, Benjamin Kirkland, Daniel, Morganne and Michael. Contributions in her memory may be made to the William P. Goldman & Brothers Foundation, 47 Irving St., Arlington, MA 02476.

KERMISH--Julie, on October 12, 2013 at age 87. Loving mother of Nicole Kermish and her husband Alan Ani. Cherished grandmother of Lauren Skidmore and Eileen Ani. Devoted friend to many. Artist, Teacher, Traveler and Creative Free Spirit. Services Thursday, 2:30pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. www.riversidenassaunorth chapels.com
HIJUELOS--Oscar. Brilliant writer, adoring husband, unique individual, beloved friend. Carol Fein & Jeffrey Hoffeld
HIJUELOS--Oscar. We will miss the wit, warmth and humanity that was Oscar. Our condolences and love to Lori. Allen and Irene Brill

GORDON--Paula Hughes, 68, died October 11 from breast cancer at her home on Cape Cod, surrounded by family. Born in Bridgeport CT, she received her R.N. from St. Luke's Hospital School of Nursing in New York City and a B.S. from St. Joseph's College. An exceptional nurse, she was on the first liver transplant team at the University of Colorado School of Medicine. In New York, Paula served as president of the St. Luke's Roosevelt Auxiliary, and a member of the Vestry of the Church of the Heavenly Rest. Later in life, she realized her dream as a school nurse at the Nightingale-Bamford School. She and Philip, her husband of 46 years, retired to Cape Cod where they had spent more than 30 happy summers. She was a funny, generous and special friend to many, and a completely devoted mother and wife. Paula will be deeply missed and remembered for her strength, grace, and wry sense of humor and for being "cheerfully non-compliant." In addition to Philip, she is survived by daughters Amanda and Margaret, granddaughter Ramona and mother Dorothy. A visitation will be held at the Chapman Cole and Gleason Funeral Home 74 Algonquin Ave. (Rte 151) Mashpee, MA on Saturday October 19, 2013 from 11am to 1pm followed by a 1pm memorial service. A memorial service will be held at a later date in New York City at the Church of the Heavenly Rest. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Paula H. Gordon Memorial Fund at Nightingale Bamford School 20 E. 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128. For online guestbook and direction please visit www.ccgfuneralhome.com

FENNEBRESQUE--Frances (Fritzi) Campbell, of Locust Valley, NY, beloved wife of the late John D. Fennebresque, died October 14, 2013. The daughter of Samuel G. Campbell and Virginia Clark Campbell was born September 13, 1920 in Charleston, West Virginia. She married John in 1944 and their marriage lasted 27 years until his death in 1971. Shortly after marrying they moved to the North Shore of Long Island where they raised their two sons. Fritzi was very active in the community and in the lives of her children and grandchildren. She was an avid bridge player who viewed the game as a means by which to enjoy the company of the many friends she so dearly loved. Her greatest joy was her family, and they were always her first priority. Fritzi is survived by her devoted sons Tudor (Frances) and Kim, her brothers Samuel and Clark Campbell, her sister Louise Wilcox, her grandchildren John (Jolee), Amy Burleson (Baker), Frances Hankins (John), Quincy, Billy (Kinsey), Jack (Christie) and Maddie and seven great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY at 11:00am, October 18. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Grenville Baker Boys and Girls Club, 135 Forest Avenue, Locust Valley, NY 11560.

EPSTEIN--Lila Closter, born January 15, 1921 died on October 11, 2013 in Carlsbad, CA. Previously a long-time resident of Belle Harbor, New York; Lila was previously deceased by her husband Joseph B. Epstein. She was the beloved mother of Sydele Golston, Lawrence and Nina Epstein, and the late Harvey Epstein. Devoted grandmother to Maggie Golston, Isabel Blumberg, Amy Gadsden, John Golston, and Brian Epstein, and devoted great-grandmother of nine. Funeral services Friday, October 18, 2013 at Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel. The family extends its gratitude to Julietta Walker for her devotion to Lila and Joseph.

EPHRON--Erwin. Influential media consultant and father of modern media planning passed away peacefully on October 13, 2013. He was 79 years old. Born in New York, he received a BA from Swarthmore College and an MBA in Economics from New York University. Ephron was a top media executive at several advertising agencies, including his own, Ephron, Raboy & Tsao, before becoming a partner in media consultancy with Ephron Papazian & Ephron. He is survived by his wife Elaine, daughters Susan Ephron and husband Randy Daniels, and Rachel Ephron Barenholtz and husband Brett Barenholtz, son John Ephron and wife Joan Olson, and grandchildren, Sydney, Jacob, Jeremy, and Sam.

EICHEL--Seymour, 83. Loving son of Julius and Ester Halperin Eichel. Born in Brooklyn, NY on June 13, 1930, died on October 13, 2013 in Bridgewater, NJ. Associated with what is now New Jersey City University from 1969 to 1994. Awarded Emeritus status two years later. A graveside service was held at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, Long Island, NY on October 16, 2013. The Eichel family papers are to be found in the Swarthmore College Peace Collection, Swarthmore, PA.

DOERFLER--Ronald. Lazard mourns the passing of Ron Doerfler, who served on our board of directors from 2006 to 2011. We greatly benefited from his wise counsel and insights based on a lifetime of experience. Our thoughts are with his wife and family.

DOERFLER--Ronald J. The Kenilworth Apartments family mourns the passing of our friend, neighbor and wise counselor Ronald Doerfler. Ronald served on our Board of Directors, now Chaired by his beloved wife Krys, with wisdom and kindness. We will greatly miss his caring, concern and warmth and extend our heartfelt condolences to Krys and the entire Doerfler family. The Board, Tenants and Staff of the Kenilworth Apartments

DOERFLER--Ronald J. The Board of Trustees of the Museum of the Moving Image are heartbroken at the loss of esteemed and beloved Vice Chairman, Ronald J. Doerfler. Herbert S. Schlosser, Chairman Carl Goodman, Executive Director

ASCH--Sylvia H.,of Locust Valley, NY formerly of Wailuku, Maui on October 12th, 2013 age 93. Extraordinary homemaker, gardener and baker. Beloved wife of the late Roy D. for over 64 years. Loving mother of Jonathan, Barbara and the late Carolyn. Dear sister of Alma Mae and the late Katherine. Proud grandmother of Christopher, Michael, Charlotte and Katherine. Special great-grandmother of Sydney and Olivia. Interment service at Locust Valley, Saturday 12:30pm. Services by Dodge-Thomas.

PETRAKIS--Evangeline "Vangie" passed away October 27th, 2012. A Memorial Service is to be held on Sunday, October 20th at the Greek Orthodox Metropolitan Cathedral of St. John the Theologian, 353 East Clinton Avenue, Tenafly, NJ at 10:30am. For more information: vourgareli@aol.com.

WELLS--Phyllis S. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death on Sunday, October 13, of Phyllis S. Wells, beloved mother of our partner and friend, Theodore V. Wells, Jr. We express our deepest sympathies to Ted, Nina and all other members of the family.

URVATER--Ronald. Passed away after a sudden illness October 14, 2013. Beloved husband of Eve, devoted father of Arielle and Jessie, adored brother of Michele, son of the late Philip and Judith of Antwerp, Belgium. A renaissance man loved by family, friends and all who knew him. Always caring, thoughtful, insightful and generous; a man of integrity and faith. Funeral at Park Avenue Synagogue, Wednesday 11am.

SWING--John Temple, The Board of Directors and staff of the Foreign Policy Association mourn the passing of our President Emeritus and Director, John Temple Swing. During his presidency, John introduced innovative programs, extended FPA's national outreach, and strengthened dialogue across the country on global issues. We are grateful for his keen insights into international law and world affairs. To Devi and his children Johnny, Jenny, and Susan and their families, FPA extends its deepest condolences.

SHELLEY--Helen Patricia. Entered into eternal life October 15, 2013. Beloved daughter of the late Thomas J. and Helen P. Shelley. Devoted sister of Mary A. Shelley and Msgr. Thomas J. Shelley. Wake at Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave. (exit 28N SS Pkwy), Wantagh, NY, October 18, 2-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of St. Brigid, 75 Post Avenue, Westbury, NY, October 19, at 11am. Interment to follow in the adjacent Cemetery of the Holy Rood. www.osheafuneral.com
RATTNER--Sol. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sol Rattner, associated with The New York Times from September 1, 1967 until retiring on January 6, 1997.

MANDRAKOS--Judith, 75, of Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late Leo Mandrakos. Sister of Elizabeth Attebery; aunt of Alexandra Gulden, Carolyn Laing, Elizabeth Mead and Michael Attebery; step-mother of Lisa Purdy and Mark Mandrakos; and grand-aunt of seven. Board member of New York's Professional Children's School. Funeral will be Friday morning, October 18. Details available at Oyster Bay Funeral Home, www.oysterbayfuneral home.com. Contributions may be sent to City Harvest of New York City or the Professional Children's School, for the purpose of tuition assistance.

KLEINER--David M. We will miss your smile and your feistiness, and we will learn from your courage and will to live through adversity. We will miss you and love you forever and ever. Ken, Chris and Danielle

KLEINER--David M.,46, died peacefully at his home in Florida on October 14, 2013. Loving son of Julie and Michael Sanjenis and Darlene Kleiner and the late Samuel Kleiner. Beloved brother of Kenneth, Christopher, Danielle, Jeremy and Benjamin.

HURST--Stanley D. The family of Stanley D. Hurst DDS mourn his passing on October 13, 2013. Stanley was a loving husband, an adored father, and a wonderful grandfather. He leaves a legacy of love, wisdom, and optimism to his wife of 54 years Marcia, his children Wendy and Richard Levine, Lori and Victor Bushell, and Terry and Bill Sanders. The profound mark he left on his grandchildren Jordan, Alexandra, Joshua, Abigail, Hannah, Austin, Taylor, and Brooke will last forever. Please consider donations to Englewood Hospital and Medical Center Dialysis Unit in his memory.

HIJUELOS--Oscar. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Oscar Hijuelos, Pulitzer Prize-winning author and alumnus of The City College of New York, BA '75, MA '76. The son of Cuban immigrants who raised their family in West Harlem, Mr. Hijuelos was inspired to succeed at CUNY colleges, first taking classes at Bronx Community College, where a literature professor's positive feedback kindled an interest in writing. Mr. Hijuelos entered City College through the then-new SEEK program. Delivering CCNY's President's Lecture last December, entitled "Coming Home to City College," Mr. Hijuelos credited CUNY for giving him the educational opportunities that nurtured his life as a writer. His outstanding achievements are an inspiration to us all. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife, Lori Ann Carlson, family and friends. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson CUNY Board of Trustees William P. Kelly, Interim Chancellor

GORDON--Paula Hughes, 68, died October 11 from breast cancer at her home on Cape Cod, surrounded by family. Born in Bridgeport CT, she received her R.N. from St. Luke's Hospital School of Nursing in New York City and a B.S. from St. Joseph's College. An exceptional nurse, she was on the first liver transplant team at the University of Colorado School of Medicine. In New York, Paula served as president of the St. Luke's Roosevelt Auxiliary, and a member of the Vestry of the Church of the Heavenly Rest. Later in life, she realized her dream as a school nurse at the Nightingale-Bamford School. She and Philip, her husband of 46 years, retired to Cape Cod where they had spent more than 30 happy summers. She was a funny, generous and special friend to many, and a completely devoted mother and wife. Paula will be deeply missed and remembered for her strength, grace, and wry sense of humor and for being "cheerfully non-compliant." In addition to Philip, she is survived by daughters Amanda and Margaret, granddaughter Ramona and mother Dorothy. A visitation will be held at the Chapman Cole and Gleason Funeral Home 74 Algonquin Ave. (Rte 151) Mashpee, MA on Saturday October 19, 2013 from 11am to 1pm followed by a 1pm memorial service. A memorial service will be held at a later date in New York City at the Church of the Heavenly Rest. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Paula H. Gordon Memorial Fund at Nightingale Bamford School 20 E. 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128. For online guestbook and direction please visit www.ccgfuneralhome.com

FIELDS--David Ian. Beloved father of Steven and Michael, beloved son of Helene Fields, and son of the late Eugene Fields, devoted brother to Cathy and Jacqueline, wonderful uncle and greatest friend with the most amazing sense of humor lived a loving and caring life and passed away peacefully after battling a chronic illness. He will be deeply missed by all. In lieu of flowers, please send all donations to the American Liver Foundation, or The American Kidney Foundation.

FENNEBRESQUE--Frances (Fritzi) Campbell, of Locust Valley, NY, beloved wife of the late John D. Fennebresque, died October 14, 2013. The daughter of Samuel G. Campbell and Virginia Clark Campbell was born September 13, 1920 in Charleston, West Virginia. She married John in 1944 and their marriage lasted 27 years until his death in 1971. Shortly after marrying they moved to the North Shore of Long Island where they raised their two sons. Fritzi was very active in the community and in the lives of her children and grandchildren. She was an avid bridge player who viewed the game as a means by which to enjoy the company of the many friends she so dearly loved. Her greatest joy was her family, and they were always her first priority. Fritzi is survived by her devoted sons Tudor (Frances) and Kim, her brothers Samuel and Clark Campbell, her sister Louise Wilcox, her grandchildren John (Jolee), Amy Burleson (Baker), Frances Hankins (John), Quincy, Billy (Kinsey), Jack (Christie) and Maddie and seven great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY at 11:00am, October 18. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Grenville Baker Boys and Girls Club, 135 Forest Avenue, Locust Valley, NY 11560.

EPSTEIN--Lila Closter, born January 15, 1921 died on October 11, 2013 in Carlsbad, CA. Previously a long-time resident of Belle Harbor, New York; Lila was previously deceased by her husband Joseph B. Epstein. She was the beloved mother of Sydele Golston, Lawrence and Nina Epstein, and the late Harvey Epstein. Devoted grandmother to Maggie Golston, Isabel Blumberg, Amy Gadsden, John Golston, and Brian Epstein, and devoted great-grandmother of nine. Funeral services Friday, October 18, 2013 at Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel. The family extends its gratitude to Julietta Walker for her devotion to Lila and Joseph.

DOERFLER--Ronald J. The Kenilworth Apartments family mourns the passing of our friend, neighbor and wise counselor Ronald Doerfler. Ronald served on our Board of Directors, now Chaired by his beloved wife Krys, with wisdom and kindness. We will greatly miss his caring, concern and warmth and extend our heartfelt condolences to Krys and the entire Doerfler family. The Board, Tenants and Staff of the Kenilworth Apartments

DOERFLER--Ronald J. A+E Networks mourns the passing of Ronald J. Doerfler, Hearst Corporation director, trustee and senior vice president, finance and administration, and an esteemed and respected member of our Board of Directors. He was a wise advisor, partner and friend. His contributions to our success were many and his mark on our company will be felt for years to come. He will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to Krys and the entire Doerfler family. The Management Team and Staff of A+E Networks

BONNELL--Stewart A.,on September 15, 2013. Beloved husband of Harriet Edelman Bonnell, devoted father of Darren, John and Julia Bonnell, adoring grandfather of Aiden, Jake, Cate, Jessica and Max Bonnell. Dedicated and generous friend to many. Stu was predeceased by his father and mother, Arthur and Marion, and his sister, Karen MacWilliam. Surviving siblings are Allan Bonnell and Ellouise Bellevue. Stu was born in Halifax, Nova Scotia and grew up in Newfoundland, Canada. He spent most of his professional life as an executive with Avon Products, Inc., and was based in Montreal, London and New York City over a successful thirty-three year career. His colleagues remember him as a true leader and gentleman. Stu adored his home on the hill and was so proud of his family. We are missing his loving heart, beautiful calm voice, generous spirit and mischievous sense of humor. Rest in peace, dearest Stu -- we love you forever and ever: "He was alone. He was unheeded, happy and near to the wild heart of life. He was alone and young and willful and wild-hearted, alone amidst a waste of wild air and brackish waters and the sea-harvest of shells and tangle and veiled grey sunlight." (James Joyce) Donations in Stu's honor may be made to the Gaylordsville Volunteer Fire Department, Gaylordsville, CT.

BIRNBAUM--Grace, of Great Neck, NY and formerly of Longboat Key, FL. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry A. Birnbaum. Devoted mother of Jan and Stephen Sophir and Dr. Morris and Barbara Birnbaum. Cherished grandmother of Rebecca, Eric, Harry and Julia. Great-grandmother of five. A classy lady with wit and humor. We will miss you. Services private.

WAGMAN--Della. Best friends forever. Your beauty, kindness and love of life will never be forgotten. The impact your courage made on all who love you will carry forward in our hearts forever. The Bendett, Konigsberg & Schwartz families

SHELLEY--Helen Patricia. Entered into eternal life October 15, 2013. Beloved daughter of the late Thomas J. and Helen P. Shelley. Devoted sister of Mary A. Shelley and Msgr. Thomas J. Shelley. SANDS--Herman. Bloomingdale Aging in Place mourns a devoted founding board member. Sympathies to Phyllis Sperling with whom we share this loss.

POSNER--Phyllis, (nee Katcher), on October 15, 2013. Beloved wife of the late David Posner, step-mother to Debra DeCosta and step-grandmother to Christine, Robert and Raymond. Cherished aunt to Anita Katcher Beeber. Loving aunt to many nieces, nephews, great-nieces, great-nephews, great-great nieces and great-great nephews. She will be sorely missed. Services Sunday, 10am at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. O'NEIL--Celeste Cheatham. Musica Sacra NY's Board notes with sadness the passing of our dear friend and former board colleague. She served with a generous heart, wisdom, and deep appreciation for music. We are grateful for her time in our midst.

KAMBHU--Tirachai, of Ka'a'awa, Hawai'i, on October 13, 2013. A graduate of Phillips Academy, Andover, Harvard College, and the Harvard Graduate School of Design, Chai taught in the Faculty of Architecture at Chulalongkorn University in Bangkok in the 1970s. He relocated to Washington, DC in the early 1980s with his wife, Kanitta Meesook, an economist at the IMF, and they retired to Hawai'i in 2006. Highly creative and blessed with a wonderful sense of humor, Chai will be greatly missed by a large circle of family and friends. He is survived by his wife and by his beloved son Chayapat.

HAGGERTY--Anne, of NYC and Locust Valley, LI on October 15th, 2013, age 59. Beloved daughter and sister. Visitation at Doge-Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove Saturday and Sunday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. She leaves knowing our love for her husband Richard and her children Adam and Tracy will keep us close forever. The Gilberts, Arlene & Larry, Eric, Assunta, and Jay

BIRNBAUM--Grace, of Great Neck, NY and formerly of Longboat Key, FL. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry A. Birnbaum. Devoted mother of Jan and Stephen Sophir and Dr. Morris and Barbara Birnbaum. Cherished grandmother of Rebecca, Eric, Harry and Julia. Great-grandmother of five. A classy lady with wit and humor. We will miss you. Services private.

WELLS--Phyllis S. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death on Sunday, October 13, of Phyllis S. Wells, beloved mother of our partner and friend, Theodore V. Wells, Jr. We express our deepest sympathies to Ted, Nina and all other members of the family.

WASHBURN--A. Lawrence Jr.,77, of Dorset, VT, retired New York lawyer, on October 13. Funeral Mass at St. Paul's, Manchester Center, Vt., Monday, October 21 at 11am. Calling hours, Sunday, October 20, 2-5pm at Brewster Funeral Home, Manchester. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to the Community Food Cupboard (P.O. Box 864, Manchester Ctr., Vt. 05255) would be welcome.

VINSON--Bernard L.,94, of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, passed away on Sunday, October 13, 2013. Pioneer in temporary office-homecare- industrial services in New York Metropolitan area. Founder of Tempo and Long Island business leader. US Navy Lieutenant Commander, WWII. Proud University of Michigan graduate. Pre-deceased by Gloria, wife and business partner. Father of Marsha (Marvin) and Edward (Linda). Grandfather of David, Robert, Eve, Sydney, and Sara. Remembrances may be made to: University of Michigan Library Attn: Mari Vaydik, 8076 Hatcher Graduate Library, 913 University Avenue, Ann Arbor, MI 48109.

SCHAEFER--Franklyn S. 92, Sands Point, NY. A glorious lifetime ending on October 11. Son of Beatrice and Benjamin Schaefer, adored husband for 62 years of Rosalind (Massar), loving father of Diane and Aram Ampagoumian, Philip Schaefer and Wendy (Weintraub), cherished grandfather of Alyssa and Gregory Schaefer. Deceased brother Stephen always in his heart, devoted uncle to Brenda Schaefer and Mark Thompson and children George and Gwen. Purdue University graduate, after four years of WW II Air Corps service, entered the family business, McPhilben Lighting Company. His vision and creativity was contagious, as he worked with designers, creating cast aluminum molds revolutionizing the industry. At 49, McPhilben was sold to Emerson Electric Company, Inc. His early retirement gave him time to explore many avenues including fishing, gardening, the outdoors, collecting Boehm porcelain birds, could fix anything, and like his mother enjoyed baking. He was an avid dog fancier, and with his wife, founded Wellspring Kennels, breeding and successfully showing German Shepherds. A generous and modest person needing little for himself, getting pleasure in giving, loyal to his family, friends, and employees. At a later date, the family will celebrate his life with a memorial at his home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Francis Hospital Roslyn, NY, the ASPCA, or the charity of your choice.

SHAPIRO--Milton, on October 17, 2013. Beloved husband of Bonnie. Loving father of Steven and the late Amy. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Laura, Marissa and Jillian. Devoted brother of the late Jack Shapiro. A veteran of World War II who enlisted in the Army Air Corps. at age 17. He was the President and Founder of David Geller Associates, Inc. for many years and will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Services Sunday, October 20th, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Contributions in his memory may be made to New York Presbyterian Hospital in honor of Dr. Martin Post.
SAFRAN--Nora, 79, at home in Charlottesville on May 30th. Accomplished artist known for Zen raku pottery. New York service October 27 at 3:00pm. Please RSVP to: safranestate@gmail.com

ROGERS--Paul. Dear husband of Birgit, loving father of Monica and son-in-law Jeff Rothstein, adoring grandfather of Jeremy and Ethan. Born January 17, 1921 in Vienna, Austria and died at his home in Great Neck, NY. His warmth and love will be with us forever. Services Sunday, 10am at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

POSNER--Phyllis, (nee Katcher), on October 15, 2013. Beloved wife of the late David Posner, step-mother to Debra DeCosta and step-grandmother to Christine, Robert and Raymond. Cherished aunt to Anita Katcher Beeber. Loving aunt to many nieces, nephews, great-nieces, great-nephews, great-great nieces and great-great nephews. She will be sorely missed. Services Sunday, 10am at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in Phyllis's memory can be made to Congregation Adas Emunno, 254 Broad Avenue, Leonia, NJ 07605 or the Visiting Nurse Association of Englewood Hospice, 75 Demarest Ave., Englewood, NJ 07631. Shiva Monday 11am-8pm, at Phyllis' Home, 805 Waterford Towers, 190 River Rd., Englewood, NJ.

NYDORF--Elsie. Acclaimed artist and educator Elsie Nydorf, 93, of Port Washington, NY, died October 6, 2013. She illustrated for J.B. Tarcher in New York, then Hecht's in Washington, D.C., and, during WWII, the Office of Strategic Services in the China-Burma-India Theater. She was awarded the Watrous Gold Medal in Sculpture from the National Academy of Design in 1977.

LIGHTER--Jeremiah B.,born Philadelphia, March 23, 1921, son of Julius and Sema Tabachnick Lighter, passed away peacefully on October 10, 2013 in Manhattan. A gifted artist, he signed his art "Lighter" or "Umy", an affectionate family name. His career as print director, art director, book designer and illustrator spanned from 1945 to 2008. He taught design at School of Visual Arts, Parsons School of Design and Queens College. He was an active hiker, bicyclist, chess player and kite flyer. He built and sailed model boats in Central Park. Gladys Spielberg, his beloved wife of over forty years, pre-deceased him. He is survived by a niece, Marina Bokelman, and nephews Jon and Andrew Bokelman.

LEVY--Peter A. Peter's colleagues at Harmony Capital Management mourn his passing. Peter, Ron and Bob were partners for over thirty years, first at Goldman Sachs, then at Sage Capital Management and Harmony Capital Management where Peter was one of the founding partners. Peter was the ideal partner who brought his intellectual strengths and investment experience to every decision but always in a spirit of consensus and true harmony. He was a marvelous teacher who loved working with younger colleagues who gained so much from their association with Peter. Peter seemed to know everyone in the investment business and earned his reputation not only as a great investor but as someone whom others sought out for advice and counsel. Our personal association with Peter has been one of the great joys of our lives. He helped make our business feel more like a family and our memory of his friendship will be with us forever. Our heartfelt condolences go to Peter's loving wife, Nadine, his children, Dominique, Dany, Kate, Vanessa and Gus, his grandchildren, Sebastian and Henry his wife's stepchildren, Sharon and Oren, and his sister, Betty Hess. Robert Friedman, Ronald Tauber, Anne Farrell, Joanne Giordano

LEVY--Peter Alexander, 77, formerly of New York, passed away in Palm Beach on October 18th. The son of the late Gus and Janet Levy, Peter was born in New York City on May 18th, 1936. He graduated from The St. Mark's School in 1955 and continued on to receive his Bachelors of Science from The Wharton School. After graduation, Peter worked on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange until 1982, primarily as a floor broker for Goldman Sachs where he was a partner. He later founded two very successful funds, Sage Capital in 1994 and Harmony Capital in 2008. He enjoyed tennis, skiing, windsurfing, cooking, music, dancing, movies, great food and folk art. An understated, wise man with a true love of life, he took pleasure in every aspect of life great and small. He had a huge heart, generous spirit and loved his family and friends dearly. He is survived by his wife Nadine, his sister Betty Hess, his five children, Dominique, Dany, Vanessa, Kate, and Gus, his grandchildren Sebastian and Henry and his wife's stepchildren Sharon and Oren. Memorial contributions to Sari Asher Center, 1411 N. Flagler Drive, suite 8900B, West Palm Beach, FL 33401 of the Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, 33407 or the charity of your choice. The family wishes to thank The Hospice and The Florida Cancer Institute at The Good Samaritan Medical Center in West Palm Beach. A celebration of his life will be held in New York at date and time to be announced.

DORF--Annette, of Cedarhurst, NY. Beloved wife of Stanley Dorf. Devoted mother of Laura Dorf Queller and Michael Dorf. Loving grandmother of Sarah, Philip and Julia Queller and of Meena and Amelia Colbdorf. Dedicated teacher. Funeral services, noon, Sunday at Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel.

BISGEIER--Howard. NCJW NY Section mourns the passing of Howard Bisgeier, beloved husband of our esteemed Board Member and Management Council co-chair, Shirley Bisgeier. We appreciated Howie's support for Shirley's many NCJW activities, and offer our heartfelt sympathy to Shirley, Bonnie, Sam, Craig, Karen, Eli and the entire family. Paula Moss and Karol Todrys, Co-Presidents Joan Shapiro Green, Executive Director

DAVIDOFF--Esther, on October 16, 2013. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Barbara Weintraub, Joanne and Dan Free, Larry and Lisa Davidoff, Lisa and the late Howard Davidoff. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Allison, Amanda, Melanie, Jesse, Owen, Gabrie, Benjamin, Hannah and Michael. Great- grandmother of Rachel and Seth. Services 12 Noon Sunday at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. www.riversidenassaunorth chapels.com

BISGEIER--Howard. October 18, 2013. Beloved husband of Shirley, devoted father of Craig (Karen) and Bonnie (Sam Lunetta). Cherished grandfather of Eli, loving brother of Millicent Bauer. He will also be especially missed by his nieces and nephews. Services Sunday, October 20, 2013 at 1:45pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to National Council of Jewish Women, New York Section.

BEGUN--Sam. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Jewish Home Lifecare are deeply saddened by the passing of Sam Begun, a dear friend and benefactor to Jewish Home Lifecare. Mr. Begun was truly devoted to the residents and clients at Jewish Home and many lives have been enriched as a result of his friendship. Mr. Begun will be greatly missed by his Jewish Home family. Elizabeth Grayer, Chairman of the Board, Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President/CEO
BEGUN--Samuel, on October 18, 2013 at age 101. Valued client and, much more important, a unique and terrific person and a dear friend. Steven J. Wohl

BACKNER--Sally, 82, of Glendale, New York, passed on October 17, 2013 after a long struggle with a respiratory illness. Sally was a clinical social worker and psychotherapist with a B.A. from Antioch College, a C.S.W. from Adelphi University and a certificate in individual psychotherapy from Smith College. Sally had a great sense of humor and loved driving, music and animals, especially her dogs. Proud grandmother of Claire and Sam, beloved mother of Amie, Tom and daughter in law Erika. Sally made a big difference in the lives of all who knew her, including her patients, friends and family members, especially her husband of fifty years, Burton L. Backner. Donations in Sally's honor to Grace Lutheran Church at 103-15 Union Turnpike Forest Hills, NY 11375 or Doctors Without Borders USA at P.O. Box 5030 Hagerstown, MD 21741-5030 will be appreciated.

THOMSON--Edward "Paul." Born August 4, 1958 in Paisley, Scotland to Catherine and Edward Thomson, Paul passed away peacefully on October 10, 2013 with his wife, Robin, at his side in the comfort of their home in Manhattan. In early life his family emigrated to Hamilton, Ontario where he made life-long friends. He held a PhD in philosophy from Princeton University, an M.A. from Dalhousie University in Halifax, NS and a B.A. in Liberal Arts from St. John's College, Annapolis, MD, where he met and married Robin. Paul was a tenured professor at John Carroll University in Cleveland, OH and subsequently, a founding faculty member of Columbia Secondary School in New York City. He loved teaching students of all ages. In keeping with his St. John's education, Paul was a proponent of the Socratic method of dialectic learning. He was the author of many articles and critical reviews, primarily in the area of philosophy of science, and several books, including two volumes of Philosophy for Teens. Paul and Robin were fortunate to have traveled extensively throughout their 33 years of marriage and enjoyed experiencing so much of the world together and often with friends. He was an avid scuba diver, photographer and road biker. Paul is survived by Robin, dear relatives in Ontario, loving friends and countless students. He will be sorely missed, but ever so fondly remembered by us all. Details of favored charities and life celebrations to be held in New York, Cleveland and Toronto will be provide on Legacy.com.

SLAFF--Dr. Bertram, died at home in Manhattan on October 11th at the age of 91. Dr. Slaff was affiliated with the Child-Adolescent Division of Mt. Sinai's Department of Psychiatry as an associate clinical professor. In 1958, he co-founded the New York Society for Adolescent Psychiatry, was a past president of the American Society for Adolescent Psychiatry, and held leadership roles in other local and international organizations. He will be remembered for his mentorship of young psychiatrists, his careful listening, and his deep respect for his patients. Dr. Slaff was born in Passaic, NJ, graduated cum laude from Harvard College, and received his MD at the Long Island College of Medicine. He also had a passion for literature, and was a first reader for novelist and dear friend, the late Coleman Dowell. Bert was the beloved brother of the late Estelle Schneider, and is survived by his nephew, Stephen Schneider, and his niece, Dr. Louise Schneider.

SHAPIRO--Milton, on October 17, 2013. Beloved husband of Bonnie. Loving father of Steven and the late Amy. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Laura, Marissa and Jillian. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Contributions in his memory may be made to New York Presbyterian Hospital in honor of Dr. Martin Post.

SCHWEBEL--Milton, a psychologist at the forefront of postwar educational reform and peace psychology, died October 3 in Tucson, Ariz. He was 99. For over a half century Professor Schwebel examined how the public school as an institution shaped expectations about children's capacity to learn. His best-known book, "Who Can Be Educated?," was published in 1968, when much of the country was resisting court-ordered school desegregation and believed integration would erode school quality. His most recent book, "Remaking America's Three School Systems: Now Separate and Unequal," published in the aftermath of No Child Left Behind, examines how United States schools continue to shortchange children, especially disadvantaged youth. Schwebel also co-edited, with Jane Raph, the influential book, "Piaget in the Classroom." Schwebel was among the pioneer researchers to investigate children's anxiety about nuclear war. He spearheaded efforts to create the American Psychological Association's "Society for the Study of Peace, Conflict, and Violence: Peace Psychology" and was the founding editor of the association's journal Peace and Conflict. Throughout his career, the cause of education, social justice, and peace were linked. He argued in his first academic article, published in 1940, that to be strong, a nation needed more than a powerful army; it needed to provide youth with opportunities for education and economic security. Schwebel came of age during the Great Depression. He entered Union College at age 16, majoring in Philosophy. He earned an MA in Human Development and American Civilization from SUNY-Albany. After his marriage to Bernice Davison, he served as a cottage parent at the Hebrew Orphan Asylum and worked for the National Youth Administration. He served in the European Theater during World War II. After earning his Ph.D. from Columbia, he taught at several institutions, including New York University and Rutgers University's Graduate School of Education (Dean). He is survived by a son, Robert; two sisters, Tobie Kessler and Leah Gaies; four grandchildren: David, Sara, Frank, Henry; and two great-grandchildren. He is predeceased by his wife Bernice, son Andrew, and siblings Walter Schwebel and Rosalind Kaufman.

SCHEIMER--Louis "Lou" (October 19, 1928 - October 17, 2013) Los Angeles, CA - Louis Scheimer, the renowned and much loved animation pioneer has died at his home at age 84, just two days shy of his 85th birthday, from Parkinson's Disease. Lou is survived by his beloved daughter Erika Scheimer and his son Lane Scheimer. At his side over these final days were Erika, who worked with her father for decades at Filmation, the company founded by Lou, Norm Prescott, and Hal Sutherland in the early sixties. Also on hand throughout Lou's final days were his devoted daughter-in-law, Amy Rosenberg, and sundry close friends, former employees and relations. Lou's wife Jay Scheimer, had passed in 2009. Lou often said that Jay was truly the woman behind the man, and she was greatly instrumental in making Filmation a reality. He often said that he could never have survived the early years without Jay's support. They were a most colorful couple; back in the day, some referred to them as the "George and Gracie" of the animation crowd. Lou graduated from Carnegie-Tech in 1952, married in 1953 and moved to Los Angeles in 1955 to work in the animation industry. In 1962, Filmation Studios was created and became one of the world's premiere animation houses. During this early period, the studio produced TV commercials and documentaries. In 1965, the studio unveiled its first Saturday morning series, "Superman", a solid hit which ran for three years on CBS. Soon to follow were a string of shows, including the arrival of "Aquaman", "Batman" and the phenomenally rated "Archies" show. Lou was widely credited with starting Saturday morning cartoons. From the "Archies" cartoons came the number one hit song "Sugar, Sugar", which has been re-recorded through the years some 29 times and counting! It was also the number two song of the 1960's, second only to the Beatles' "I Want to Hold Your Hand". A number one song from a cartoon? This was the first animated show to include original songs with each episode. This was one of many "firsts" achieved throughout the life of Filmation. The praise from critics and viewers alike was even more enthusiastic for Filmation's proudest animation achievement, "Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids". In its twelve year run, "Fat Albert" was acclaimed by parents, educators and children everywhere. It received countless honors, including a number of Emmy nominations and the prestigious Peabody Award. It was the show that Lou was most proud of. From then on, he made it his life's mission to produce children's shows that not only were entertaining, but also contained pro-social values and messages. After "Fat Albert" aired in the early seventies, Filmation had truly come into its own as a giant in the field of animation. Shows broadcast on CBS, NBC and ABC in that time period include "Groovie Ghoulies", "The Brady Kids", "Mission Magic", "Jerry Lewis", the "Fabulous Funnies", "Mighty Mouse and Heckle and Jeckle", "Tom and Jerry", "Space Sentinels", "Lassie", and "Gilligans Island". Subsequently, Lou ventured into live-action shows with such hits as "Shazam-Isis Hour", the original "Ghostbusters", "Ark II", "Space Academy" and "Jason of Star Command". In addition, Filmation made a triumphant foray into theatrical feature production with "Journey Back to Oz" in 1973. That year also marked the first of many prime time specials, including "Oliver Twist", "Treasure Island", "Fat Albert" and "A Snow White Christmas". In 1981, Filmation unveiled "Blackstarr", a sword and sorcery fantasy that rocketed to the top of the Saturday morning ratings. This was not surprising considering Filmation's acknowledged leadership in producing quality animated adventure shows. Beginning with "Fantastic Voyage" and "Journey to the Center of the Earth" in 1967, the studio went on to produce the now classic, Emmy award winning animated "Star Trek" series, as well as animated versions of "Tarzan", "Zorro", "The Lone Ranger" and "Flash Gordon." In 1983, Lou created the marketplace for first-run syndication of animated shows. Filmation took on its most ambitious project to date: the "He-Man and the Masters of the Universe" series. Over the years Filmation produced 130 "He-Man" episodes directly for syndication. Once again, Lou made positive messages a hallmark of the show. The results: another winner, both in domestic ratings and in unprecedented international sales in thirty countries in the first year alone. Two years later, in 1985, Filmation brought He-Man's twin sister "She-Ra, Princess of Power" to the syndicated world. Lou always felt that little girls were underserved in the world of super heroes. He made it a cause to change that with She-Ra. It too was a huge success at home and abroad. After Filmation closed, the now legendary Lou Scheimer had grown to be one of the most loved men in the animation industry. He became known for trying to keep animation in the US, and he fought hard to do so. Additionally, it was of great importance to him that Filmation train the next generation of animators in America. Many of Lou's former employees can, to this day, be found working at Disney, DreamWorks, Pixar and more. Indeed, many will tell you that it was Lou who gave them their start in the business. Lou's legacy of shows saw a whole new life in recent years, as DVD collections of his many shows began to proliferate in the 1990's. The fact that a new generation of kids would be able to watch his Filmation shows gave Lou endless joy. Hundreds of fan mail letters and emails just keep on coming. Google the guy and read all about it. It is a great American rags-to-riches story you will much enjoy. In lieu of flowers, Lou and his family kindly request that donations to Parkinson's research be made in his honor.

SCHAEFER--Franklyn S. 92, Sands Point, NY. A glorious lifetime ending on October 11. Son of Beatrice and Benjamin Schaefer, adored husband for 62 years of Rosalind (Massar), loving father of Diane and Aram Ampagoumian, Philip Schaefer and Wendy (Weintraub), cherished grandfather of Alyssa and Gregory Schaefer. Deceased brother Stephen always in his heart, devoted uncle to Brenda Schaefer and Mark Thompson and children George and Gwen. Purdue University graduate, after four years of WW II Air Corps service, entered the family business, McPhilben Lighting Company. His vision and creativity was contagious, as he worked with designers, creating cast aluminum molds revolutionizing the industry. At 49, McPhilben was sold to Emerson Electric Company, Inc. His early retirement gave him time to explore many avenues including fishing, gardening, the outdoors, collecting Boehm porcelain birds, could fix anything, and like his mother enjoyed baking. He was an avid dog fancier, and with his wife, founded Wellspring Kennels, breeding and successfully showing German Shepherds. A generous and modest person needing little for himself, getting pleasure in giving, loyal to his family, friends, and employees. At a later date, the family will celebrate his life with a memorial at his home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Francis Hospital Roslyn, NY, the ASPCA, or the charity of your choice.

LIGHTER--Jeremiah B.,born Philadelphia, March 23, 1921, son of Julius and Sema Tabachnick Lighter, passed away peacefully on October 10, 2013 in Manhattan. A gifted artist, he signed his art "Lighter" or "Umy", an affectionate family name. His career as print director, art director, book designer and illustrator spanned from 1945 to 2008. He taught design at School of Visual Arts, Parsons School of Design and Queens College. He was an active hiker, bicyclist, chess player and kite flyer. He built and sailed model boats in Central Park. Gladys Spielberg, his beloved wife of over forty years, pre-deceased him. He is survived by a niece, Marina Bokelman, and nephews Jon and Andrew Bokelman.

LEVY--Peter A. Peter's colleagues at Harmony Capital Management mourn his passing. Peter, Ron and Bob were partners for over thirty years, first at Goldman Sachs, then at Sage Capital Management and Harmony Capital Management where Peter was one of the founding partners. Peter was the ideal partner who brought his intellectual strengths and investment experience to every decision but always in a spirit of consensus and true harmony. He was a marvelous teacher who loved working with younger colleagues who gained so much from their association with Peter. Peter seemed to know everyone in the investment business and earned his reputation not only as a great investor but as someone whom others sought out for advice and counsel. Our personal association with Peter has been one of the great joys of our lives. He helped make our business feel more like a family and our memory of his friendship will be with us forever. Our heartfelt condolences go to Peter's loving wife, Nadine, his children, Dominique, Dany, Kate, Vanessa and Gus, his grandchildren, Sebastian and Henry his wife's stepchildren, Sharon and Oren, and his sister, Betty Hess. Robert Friedman, Ronald Tauber, Anne Farrell, Joanne Giordano
LEVY--Peter A. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Nadine's husband. He was our friend and cheerleader. We will miss him. Abbi, Connie, Nancy

LEVY--Peter Alexander, 77, formerly of New York, passed away in Palm Beach on October 18th. The son of the late Gus and Janet Levy, Peter was born in New York City on May 18th, 1936. He graduated from The St. Mark's School in 1955 and continued on to receive his Bachelors of Science from The Wharton School. After graduation, Peter worked on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange until 1982, primarily as a floor broker for Goldman Sachs where he was a partner. He later founded two very successful funds, Sage Capital in 1994 and Harmony Capital in 2008. He enjoyed tennis, skiing, windsurfing, cooking, music, dancing, movies, great food and folk art. An understated, wise man with a true love of life, he took pleasure in every aspect of life great and small. He had a huge heart, generous spirit and loved his family and friends dearly. He is survived by his wife Nadine, his sister Betty Hess, his five children, Dominique, Dany, Vanessa, Kate, and Gus, his grandchildren Sebastian and Henry and his wife's stepchildren Sharon and Oren. Memorial contributions to Sari Asher Center, 1411 N. Flagler Drive, suite 8900B, West Palm Beach, FL 33401 of the Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, 33407 or the charity of your choice. The family wishes to thank The Hospice and The Florida Cancer Institute at The Good Samaritan Medical Center in West Palm Beach. A celebration of his life will be held in New York at date and time to be announced.

LARRY--Anthony E. February 1, 1910 - October 15, 2013, Notre Dame, IN - formerly of Manhasset, NY. Former President of Crockett & Buss and "Man of the Year" in the carpet industry. Condolences visit: www.McGannHay.com

LARRY--Anthony, E.,was born in San Giovanni Enfiori, Italy. After his parents, Salvatore Loria and Chiara Gerard, immigrated to the United States in 1911, he grew up in West Virginia. After making his way to New York at age fifteen, dancing in Vaudeville, he turned the $10 he started with into a successful life. He met and married his beloved, Josephine Ross, served in the Army Air Corps, completed High School, studied accounting at City College and began a long career with Crockett and Buss, a leading carpet distributor in Manhattan. Anthony eventually became President of C & B and was selected as "Man of the Year" in the carpet industry. There are few who met him that weren't touched by his humor, kindness, optimism and fortitude, especially those left to tell his story and carry his spirit: his daughter, Nancy (Henry) Mascotte; his grandson, Carl Schoeneman of Rancho Mirage, CA; his granddaughter, Sara (Gerald) Clark of Maui, HI and his great-granddaughter, Chiarra Clark of Maui, (among many others). To see the entire obit or to express condolences please visit: www.McGannHay.com

KENNEDY--Barbara Jane, of New York City, widow of Irish Ambassador Eamonn L. Kennedy, died peacefully October 11 after a bitter battle with Alzheimer's Disease. She was 77. Born in Manhattan, Mrs. Kennedy was a graduate of Mount Holyoke College and had a masters degree in international relations from Harvard University. She met her future husband at the United Nations and served with him at Ireland's embassies in Lagos, Bonn, Paris, New York, London and Rome. Mrs. Kennedy's father was William Black, the Russian immigrant who founded New York's "Chock Full 'o Nuts" coffee and restaurant chain, and the Parkinson's Disease Foundation. Her mother was Lillian Mandl Schwarz, former business manager at Chock. She is survived by two children, Helen and Mark, both journalists. She requested no services. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Alzheimer's Association or the Southold Animal Shelter.

LAREN--Kuno, 1924-2013 (nee Boris Kuum), died peacefully at home after a short illness. He was born in Tallin, Estonia during the first short period of Estonian independence. His childhood and young adulthood included early triumphs as a child violin prodigy who became a successful jazz musician throughout Estonia, Finland and Sweden. His escapes from the German army and the Russians during World War II, his help from the Swedish government, and his successful efforts to attain college and university degrees (Park College in Missouri and New York University in New York City) on scholarships are well-known to his family and friends. These led to a lifelong career in finance. He successfully earned one of the first Certified Financial Analyst diplomas, and quickly rose to important positions in New York City firms such as Shearson Hammill, Jessup and Lamont, and MacDonnell and Company, and Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia. In the mid 1960's he started his own firm as a venture capitalist who helped found and finance many small companies which grew into successful public companies. He is survived by his loving wife of over 62 years, Mary, and by his four children: Inga, Guy, Philip and Anders, as well as his 15 grandchildren. We are grateful for the inestimable help during Kuno's illness from Cara Laren, Anders' beloved wife. May Kuno's memory remain alive in our hearts forever.

KARANAS--Arthur, MD, 79, died peacefully at Roosevelt Hospital on October 17, 2013. A native New Yorker, Arthur was a practicing hematologist/oncologist at Roosevelt Hospital from 1964-2003. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Albert Attia Educational Fund, Dev. Office, SLRH, 555 West 57th Street, New York, NY 10102-0109, or the Kastorian Society of Whitestone, New York. Visitation and funeral service information available at www.chaspeternagel.com.

JAFFE--A Jane, died in Port Washington, NY, at the age of 89 on October 15, 2013 of colon cancer. Born as Anne Jane Sylvestre in Berlin, NH, Jane, as she was known, attended the University of New Hampshire and Columbia Presbyterian School of Nursing. She received her BS in nursing in 1947. Most of her married life was spent in Tenafly, NJ. She was predeceased by her husband of 57 years, Dr. Ernst R. Jaffe. She is remembered lovingly by her son, Richard S. Jaffe, his wife, Geraldine Jaffe, her daughter, Stephanie A. Green, her husband, Stephen J. Green, and her four grandchildren, Courtland and Caroline Jaffe, and Andrew and Christopher Green. Memorial Donations may be made to the American Red Cross or the Ernst R. Jaffe Scholarship Fund at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

HENRY--Dorothy Verne Johnson, a longtime resident of Greenwich, CT and Edgartown, MA passed away on October 9th. She was 83 years old. Mrs. Henry was born on June 15th, 1930, to Howard Deering Johnson and his wife, Dorothy. Her father was the founder of the restaurant chain Howard Johnson's, recognized as the largest restaurant chain in the world throughout the 1960's and 1970's. Mr. Johnson started the business with single soda fountain in 1925. Mrs. Henry was educated at the Dana Hall School in Wellesley, MA before continuing on to Briarcliffe Junior College and the New York School of Interior Design. Mrs. Henry's greatest passion was her family. Her two sons, William and Joshua were her greatest sources of pride and devotion. Throughout her life she served on many boards and committees, including the Boys and Girls Club of Greenwich and the board of Tabor Academy. She also served as the director of the Howard Johnson Foundation for many years. She loved to socialize, and was a hostess without equal. She will be remembered as a woman who held her door open for friends and family, as she delighted in bringing people together. She enjoyed memberships of the Jupiter Island Club, the Field Club of Greenwich, the Colony Club of New York City, and perhaps her favorite, the Edgartown Yacht Club, where she organized dances and was formerly the head of senior entertainment and a member of the House Committee. Mrs. Henry was an avid traveler throughout her life, visiting countless countries while delighting in taking her growing family of children and grandchildren with her. Though a resident of Greenwich, CT, she shared a deep love for Martha's Vineyard, where she summered for over fifty years. She was a lover of culture, rare antiques, and beautiful interiors, with her taste greatly influenced by her travels and studies. Her attention to detail, gracious hospitality and devotion to style will be her legacy for many years to come. Mrs. Henry was deeply beloved and is survived by her brother, Howard Brennan Johnson and his family, her two sons, William and Joshua, her daughters-in-law, Olivia and Christine, her six grandchildren and one great-grandchild, though many more thought of "Dottie" as family as well. A private graveside service for family was held in Milton, MA in the last week. A memorial gathering is scheduled for next summer in Edgartown, MA. In lieu of flowers, Mrs. Henry had wished for donations to be made in her memory to the Boys and Girls Club of the donor's choice. She was a true force of nature and the very definition of what a matriarch should be. She will be terribly missed.

GOLDSTEIN--Carl S. Lichtenberg & Co. mourns the passing of Carl Goldstein, our Vice Chairman, friend and colleague of 40 years. His business skill and leadership are surpassed only by the warmth of his friendship and the generosity of his heart. Our deepest sympathy to Lynn, Scott, Wendy and the entire Goldstein family.

GOLDBERG--Philip, DDS, passed away October 13, 2013 at age 98. Predeceased by all siblings; May, Jack, Allen and Jeanette. Graduate of Townsend Harris, CCNY, Columbia University, NYU Dental. Veteran, Army Captain European Theater. Practiced family dentistry on the Upper East Side for many decades. Survived by his devoted loving wife, Ruth, many nieces and nephews and their families. He will always be lovingly remembered for his kindness, extraordinary humor and keen wit.

GILBERT--Janet. It is with deep sadness we mourn the loss of Janet Gilbert, our beloved sister-in-law and aunt. We will remember her always for her incredible courage and will to live through her many years of difficult times. She leaves knowing our love for her husband Richard and her children Adam and Tracy will keep us close forever. The Gilberts, Arlene & Larry, Eric, Assunta, and Jay

GERSHENBERG--Dr. Irving, September 29, 1932 to September 25, 2013, passed peacefully with family and friends at home in Berkeley, CA. He and older brother Bernard Gerson (deceased) were born to Russian emigrants, Harry and Fanny (nee Freide Wenetick) Gershenberg in the Bronx, New York. Dr. Gershenberg graduated from the CCNY and earned a PhD in economics from University of California, Berkeley. Teaching posts included University of Connecticut, Uganda, Kenya, Jamaica, and Bulgaria. Dr. Gershenberg retired as Professor Emeritus in 2000 from University of Massachusetts, Boston. His scholarly work focused on development economics with numerous published papers. He is survived by his beloved wife Linnea Hansen Gershenberg, children, Aaron Gershenberg, Lia Humphrey, Sarah Pritchard and eight grandchildren. His family and friends from around the world fondly remember Irving as a cross between Socrates and Dennis the Menace, questioning and intensely curious, but also funny, lovable, and a little mischievous. He liked to point out he was only 20 years old, which was true in a double sense: he was a leap-year baby, and he retained a youthful outlook throughout life. Irving celebrated life and social justice, giving freely to others near and far. To honor Irving's memory, please consider a donation to his favorite charity, Doctors Without Borders.

FIELD--Albert E.,Jr., of Huntington, NY, died at the age of 86 on October 10, 2013. He attended Adelphi Univ and Univ of Penn Dental School, and served in the USN during WWII. He practiced dentistry in Manhasset and Huntington, and was known for his generosity to all. Active in his community, his passion was sailboat racing. Over the years he belonged to Port Washington, Centerport and New York Yacht Clubs, serving race committee at NYYC while living in Rhode Island. Survived by his beloved wife of 64 years, Iris Stafford Field, son Todd Field, daughter Bonnie Field Crowley, and cherished grandchildren Elsbeth Field Dowd, Donald Crowley, Meaghan Crowley and Gareth Field. Memorial service to be held at St. John's Episcopal Church Cold Spring Harbor, Sunday, October 27 at 2pm.

FERRIS--Barton P.,Jr. died October 17, 2013 at age 73 after a long illness due to complications from ataxia. Bart was a graduate of Northfield Mt. Hermon, Princeton University class of 1962 and Columbia Business School. Over the course of his long career as an investment banker, Bart worked for Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc., E.F. Hutton & Co. Inc. and Advest, Inc. He served on several boards of directors, including Ronson Corp., DSLT Inc., and Graham Magnetics. Bart attributed his lifelong interest in athletics and academics to his experience at Northfield Mt. Hermon. He lived the school's philosophy of "the head, the hand, the heart" and devoted significant time fundraising for the school. At Princeton he was captain of the wrestling team while pursuing a thesis in complex mathematical theory. Memberships included The Manhattan Rugby Club, Tiger Inn, Twilight Park Association and the Union Club. Bart was a devoted family man. He is survived by his wife Susan, daughter Juliana, son Jeffrey and his wife Laurie, son Nathaniel and his wife Patricia, brother Warren, many nieces and nephews, and his two loving granddaughters Sally and Annabelle. Bart was sustained throughout his long illness by the devotion of his wonderful friends to whom our family is ever grateful. A service is planned in Twilight Park in Haines Falls, NY in June.

EDELSON--Edward E.,a former science editor of The New York Daily News and an author on science and other topics, died at home Thursday, October 17th in Manhattan. He was 81. Mr. Edelson's journalism career spanned more than 50 years and his awards for newspaper and magazine writing, included The American Heart Association's Blakeslee Award, American Medical Association's Certificate of Commendation, The American Cancer Society's Media Award, and the New York Newspaper Front Page Award among several others. Born on September 10th, 1932 in Astoria, Queens, he was the son of Saul Edelson, a restaurateur, and Sarah Edelson, who emigrated from Eastern Europe in the early 1900's. Educated in New York City's public schools, Mr. Edelson graduated from Stuyvesant High School, New York University in 1953. He served in the US Army during the Korean War from 1953-1954 at Fort Ord, California, receiving an honorable discharge and having been awarded The National Defense Service Medal. From 1963-1964, Mr. Edelson was a participant in the Sloan Rockefeller Advanced Science Writing Program at the Columbia School of Journalism. He joined The New York World-Telegram and Sun as a science editor in 1962 and continued as a science writer and editor when the World Telegram merged with two other newspapers in 1966 to form the short lived World Journal Tribune. When the World Journal Tribune ceased publication in 1967, Mr. Edelson worked as a free-lance writer and was published by Smithsonian, Popular Mechanics, Popular Science, Medical World News, Harper's Bazaar, McCall's, and Woman's Day, among others. Mr. Edelson was appointed science editor at The New York Daily News in 1971, writing feature articles and breaking news stories on every aspect of science, technology and medicine. From 1979-1980 he was the president of the National Association of Science Writers. He left the Daily News in 1991, and continued to write, authoring several books and freelancing for Newsday, Healthscout.com, and many other publications. He wrote for, and was on the staff of, the internet news service Health Day until the time of his death. His books include: 'Parent's Guide to Science', 'Poisons in the Air', 'Healers in Uniform', 'Help for Your Headache', 'Great Monsters of the Movies', 'Funnymen of the Movies', 'Great Movie Spectaculars', 'Great Kids of the Movies', 'The Book of Prophesy', 'Nutrition and the Brain', 'Drugs and the Brain', 'Sports Medicine', 'Sleep', 'Aging', 'Chemical Principles (with Drs. Robert Boikess and Kenneth Breslauer)', 'Francis Crick & James Watson And the Building Blocks of Life', and 'Gregor Mendel And the Roots of Genetics'. He is survived by his wife Phyllis, whom he married in 1957; sons, Noah and Daniel, a daughter, Anne, a brother, Gilbert, a granddaughter, Hannah, and a grandson, Henry.

DORF--Annette, of Cedarhurst, NY. Beloved wife of Stanley Dorf. Devoted mother of Laura Dorf Queller and Michael Dorf. Loving grandmother of Sarah, Philip and Julia Queller and of Meena and Amelia Colbdorf. Dedicated teacher. Funeral services, noon, Sunday at Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel.
DANIELS--Patricia Seaman, 92, Oakland, CA, born in New York City. Descendent of John Adams. Tropical Medicine Technology at New York Hospital, WAVE WWII. Married to James Daniels.
COHEN--Sue Ann, on October 17, 2013. A resident of East Atlantic Beach, NY. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Loving mother of Jody and Jaime (Lynn). Cherished grandmother of Zachary.

CALLAGHAN--William, Chairman of Sterling Possessions/Thistle & Bee, died on Wednesday, October 9, 2013 in New York after a brief illness. He was 70 years old. Born in the Bronx, Bill graduated from Fordham Prep and Fordham University and received his Master's of Business degree from New York University. In 1987, Bill co-founded Sterling Possessions/ Thistle & Bee, a fine sterling silver jewelry, giftware and clothing manufacturing concern with offices in New York, Florence, Hong Kong and Bangkok. Bill took great pride in Thistle & Bee, the firm's signature silver brand, and the extensive private label business through Sterling Possessions, LLC. Bill leaves behind his many relatives, business associates and cherished, long-time friends. He also leaves his nephew, William Castagna and his business partner of 26 years, Richard Castagna. A Memorial Reception will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Thursday, October 24th from 6pm8:30pm, with a Prayer Service at 7:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Children's Aid Society of New York.

CAIRO--Leon, age 94, passed away peacefully on October 15, 2013. Loving husband of the late Ida Cairo, kind and loving father of Mitchell (Ellen) and Henry (Rochelle Golub) Cairo. The family will receive visitors at their home on October 21st from 6:30pm to 9:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Pediatric Cancer Research Foundation, P.O. Box 1092, White Plains, NY 10602 or www.pcrf-kids.org.

BOARDMAN--Constance M.,67, beloved friend and muse to so many, on September 23rd following a two-year illness. She was predeceased by her parents, Fon W. Boardman Jr. and Dorothea Reber Boardman, and her aunt Constance "Donna" Reber. She is survived by an uncle, Ralfe D. Reber of Wichita, KS, and a cousin, R.D. Reber of London. Connie retired from Gilbert & Co., a consulting firm where she served as Office Manager for 30 years following graduation from Fordham University. She earlier was graduated from Northfield School (MA) and attended Lake Forest College (IL). A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 26th at 11:00am at Christ & St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th St., NY, NY 10023. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East 70th Street, 5th Floor, NY, NY 10021, or to Christ & St. Stephen's Church for its Pre-School Scholarship Aid program or its Friends of Music program.

BLACKBURN--Douglas A.,75, of West Cornwall, CT and New York, NY died October 9, 2013. He received his bachelor's degree from Yale and his MBA from Rutgers and was a longtime employee of the accounting firm Arthur Young, now Ernst and Young. He was the Chief Financial Officer of the Henry Street Settlement House in New York City. Douglas is survived by his beloved wife and best friend, Wendy Weinberg, by his five children: Wendy Ward, Douglas Blackburn, Christopher Blackburn, Jonathan Blackburn and Kathryn Guidone and twelve grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, friends may wish to make a donation to The Little Guild of Saint Francis, 285 Sharon-Goshen Trnpke, West Cornwall, CT 06796. For an extended obit, please visit: www.kennyfuneralhomes.com

BISGEIER--Howard. October 18, 2013. Beloved husband of Shirley, devoted father of Craig (Karen) and Bonnie (Sam Lunetta). Cherished grandfather of Eli, loving brother of Millicent Bauer. He will also be especially missed by his nieces and nephews. Services Sunday, October 20, 2013 at 1:45pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to National Council of Jewish Women, New York Section.

BARR--Elinor, nee Goldstein, born July 24, 1931, died on October 13, 2013. A life long activist for peace and social justice. The wife of the late Sherman Barr and the late John Bown, mother of Rachel, Danny and David, grandmother of Nathaniel and Isaiah and daughter of Ben and Minnie Goldstein. Born in Brooklyn, Ellie taught at Kingsborough Community College and Beach Brook Nursery and volunteered at GMHC. A Memorial Service will be held with date and location to be announced.

BACKNER--Sally, 82, of Glendale, NY, passed on October 17, 2013 after a long struggle with a respiratory illness. Sally was a clinical social worker and psychotherapist with a B.A. from Antioch College, a C.S.W. from Adelphi University and a certificate in individual psychotherapy from Smith College. Sally had a great sense of humor and loved driving, music and animals, especially her dogs. Proud grandmother of Claire and Sam, beloved mother of Amie, Tom and daughter in law Erika and loving sister of Nancy Skavish. Sally made a big difference in the lives of all who knew her, including her patients, friends and family members, especially her husband of fifty years, Burton L. Backner. Donations in Sally's honor to Grace Lutheran Church at 103-15 Union Turnpike, Forest Hills, NY 11375 or Doctors Without Borders USA at P.O. Box 5030, Hagerstown, MD 21741-5030 will be appreciated.
ARLEN--Lenee. Lenore Aldort-Koechl- Coatrieux, 81, on October 3, 2013, in Berkeley, California.
