MELLO--Judy Hendren (Schwamm) . July 14, 1943 - October 21, 2003 It is ten years and I think of you and miss you every day. All who knew you continue to be guided by your words- those by which you so optimistically and courageously lived: "EVERY DAY IS A BEAUTIFUL DAY. IT IS ONLY THE WEATHER THAT CHANGES Except perhaps for this day of October 21st on which we are so sadly reminded that your wonderful, loving and joyous presence is no longer with us. Jay.

WILLINGHAM--Raymond, 76, passed away peacefully in his home on October 14th, 2013. Services will be held Saturday, November 2nd, 2013 at 3pm, at Church of The Ascension, 5th Ave. and 10th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Voices of Ascension, 12 W. 11th St., New York, NY 10011.

SOKOLOW--Moe, "Martin" died peacefully on October 8, 2013, in Delray Beach, FL while watching the film Gravity with friends. The son of Irving and Minne, he was born June 27, 1926 and grew up in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx. A WWII veteran, Martin spent his professional career as an accountant working for some of NYC's largest real estate firms. For over 15 years, Martin served as "a most loving listener" to at risk children at Hammock Pointe Elementary, wrote the school's guidance counselor. "He was a true gift to our children... he was a grandpa to some, a friend to others and just a man that cared beyond words for each of our little 'listenees'. Martin's beloved wife Beverly died in 2009. His two sons Richard and Michael, his daughter-in-law Sharon, and his granddaughter Violet, survive him. The family requests that donations in Martin's memory be made to the Listen to the Children program: mhapbc.org/ListentoChildren.

SMITH--Susan Joan. Died October 12, in Los Angeles, 71, extraordinarily respected theatre/film/TV talent agent/manager of Los Angeles and Santa Barbara and formerly New York City. Susan had her own agency her entire 44-year career and her clients received more Oscars, Tony's, Emmy's and Golden Globes than any other independent talent representative. She was famous for her taste and for launching and maintaining numerous distinguished careers. Susan was also widely recognized for qualities increasingly rare in her industry--total honesty and an unwavering devotion to talent over profit. Survived by brother Roger Smith, sister-in-law Terry Steiner and beloved niece Daisy, and her loving companion Myke Zykoff. But it is the amazing roster of friends, colleagues and--most of all--her beloved clients who are her true survivors. This week the lights of the Shubert theatres will be dimmed in Susan's honor, a rare but fitting tribute to a talent representative who loved actors. Memorial services in New York City and Los Angeles to be announced.

SHASHA--Alfred Aboud, died on October 19, 2013, in New York. He was born in Baghdad, Iraq, emigrated to Manchester, England in 1936, where he lived for two years. The next year he attended the London School of Economics. He immigrated to New York in 1939 and graduated from the Wharton School in 1942. He was honorably discharged from the US Army in 1946. He was awarded two bronze stars for the Philippine Liberation, the Good Conduct Medal, the Asiatic Pacific Campaign Medal, and the Bronze star for the American Campaign. Mr. Shasha began importing wool to the US in 1939 and was involved in the worldwide textile industry throughout his career for 65 years. Alfred is survived by his wife of 69 years, Hanina Zilkha Shasha, his sister Rae, his brothers Frank and Jim, his children Carol, Robert, and Dennis, and grandchildren Jeff, Ariana, Nick, Cloe, Tyler, Jordan, David and Caroline. Additionally he is survived by his brothers-in-law, Ezra and Selim Zilkha. He is survived by numerous nephews and nieces and their offspring. A philanthropist to many schools which his grandchildren attended along with the UJA, American Jewish Committee, Kol Ami Synagogue, the Babylonian Jewry Heritage Center, International Sephardic Education Foundation, American Sephardi Federation, and the mid-Westchester YMHA and Jewish Museum in NYC. He had a lifelong commitment to peace and education. His philosophy of life was that the fun is in the doing! The funeral will take place on October 21st at 10am at Riverside Chapel at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue in NYC.

SCHUMAN--Richard R. (Rick) a longtime Florida resident, died suddenly on Wednesday, October 16, 2013, from complications of diabetes. He was the youngest son of Henry Schuman and Rose Garbarsky, both deceased. He was a devoted brother to the late Robert A. Schuman, and to Dr. Donald L. Schuman, his surviving brother. He was a beloved uncle to his nephews, Philip and Russell, and niece, Elaine, and is mourned by his many relatives and friends. He is survived by his devoted wife of many years, Nanci.

ROSENBERG--Daniel J.,December 15, 1962 - October 4, 2013, Wuxi, China. A gifted educator, he inspired students in Atlanta, San Francisco, Hanoi and Wuxi. He is mourned by his family and wife, Karen White.

ROSEFF--Dr. Lionel S.,It is with overwhelming sadness that we mourn the loss of Dr. Lionel Roseff, who was born December 2, 1932 and passed away on October 19, 2013. Beloved, respected, and selfless doctor to generations of patients, loving husband to Barbara, cherished father and father-in-law to Lisa and Bruce Shalett and Tracy and Saul Kattan, adored grandfather to Zachary and Matthew Shalett and Alex and Andrew Kattan, devoted son-in-law, caring brother to Sylvia Swerdel, Henrietta Lederman, and the late Renee Appelbaum, and very generous, special, and dear friend to many. Passionate and dedicated in helping others, being a doctor was truly his calling, like his father before him. A graduate of NYU The Heights and Chicago Medical School at the top of his class, he was a distinguished member of The Beth Israel Medical Center community for over 50 years, loved by all who knew and worked with him. As an OB/GYN, he had an impact on so many lives, and helped bring life into the world. He will be profoundly missed. Our family is grateful for what he stood for and the wonderful example he set, and takes comfort, amidst the suddenness and shock of his death, in knowing that he will be remembered with love and admiration by his many patients, colleagues in the medical community, and friends. Funeral services will be Tuesday, October 22nd, at 11:15am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City.

O'BRIEN--Rev. Robert E.,S.J., on October 19, 2013. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY on Tuesday, 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass in the Fordham University Church on Wednesday at 11am. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. For information, contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors (718)654-0500.

LEVY--Peter A. Peter's colleagues at Harmony Capital Management mourn his passing. Peter, Ron and Bob were partners for over thirty years, first at Goldman Sachs, then at Sage Capital Management and Harmony Capital Management where Peter was one of the founding partners. Peter was the ideal partner who brought his intellectual strengths and investment experience to every decision but always in a spirit of consensus and true harmony. He was a marvelous teacher who loved working with younger colleagues who gained so much from their association with Peter. Peter seemed to know everyone in the investment business and earned his reputation not only as a great investor but as someone whom others sought out for advice and counsel. Our personal association with Peter has been one of the great joys of our lives. He helped make our business feel more like a family and our memory of his friendship will be with us forever. Our heartfelt condolences go to Peter's loving wife, Nadine, his children, Dominique, Dany, Kate, Vanessa and Gus, his grandchildren, Sebastian and Henry his wife's stepchildren, Sharon and Oren, and his sister, Betty Hess. Robert Friedman, Ronald Tauber, Anne Farrell, Joanne Giordano

LEVY--Peter Alexander, 77, formerly of New York, passed away in Palm Beach on October 18th. The son of the late Gus and Janet Levy, Peter was born in New York City on May 18th, 1936. He graduated from The St. Mark's School in 1955 and continued on to receive his Bachelors of Science from The Wharton School. After graduation, Peter worked on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange until 1982, primarily as a floor broker for Goldman Sachs where he was a partner. He later founded two very successful funds, Sage Capital in 1994 and Harmony Capital in 2008. He enjoyed tennis, skiing, windsurfing, cooking, music, dancing, movies, great food and folk art. An understated, wise man with a true love of life, he took pleasure in every aspect of life great and small. He had a huge heart, generous spirit and loved his family and friends dearly. He is survived by his wife Nadine, his sister Betty Hess, his five children, Dominique, Dany, Vanessa, Kate, and Gus, his grandchildren Sebastian and Henry and his wife's stepchildren Sharon and Oren. Memorial contributions to Sari Asher Center, 1411 N. Flagler Drive, suite 8900B, West Palm Beach, FL 33401 of the Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, 33407 or the charity of your choice. The family wishes to thank The Hospice and The Florida Cancer Institute at The Good Samaritan Medical Center in West Palm Beach. A celebration of his life will be held in New York at date and time to be announced.

KENNEDY--Barbara Jane, of New York City, widow of Irish Ambassador Eamonn L. Kennedy, died peacefully October 11 after a bitter battle with Alzheimer's Disease. She was 77. Born in Manhattan, Mrs. Kennedy was a graduate of Mount Holyoke College and had a masters degree in international relations from Harvard University. She met her future husband at the United Nations and served with him at Ireland's embassies in Lagos, Bonn, Paris, New York, London and Rome. Mrs. Kennedy's father was William Black, the Russian immigrant who founded New York's "Chock Full 'o Nuts" coffee and restaurant chain, and the Parkinson's Disease Foundation. Her mother was Lillian Mandl Schwarz, former business manager at Chock. She is survived by two children, Helen and Mark, both journalists. She requested no services. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Alzheimer's Association or the Southold Animal Shelter.

GOLDSTEIN--Philip, 90. Lover and chronicler of life, devoted husband of Helen for 65 years. Survivor of Normandy Beach. Obtained BA in Film at 63. He was notorious for his love of Hitchcock. A builder of Jewish Life in Concordia, New Jersey. Survived by his loving children, Sharyn and Rick, Joan and Warren, Brenda and Ken and brother Arnold. Cherished grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of 15. His legacy lives on.
GOLDSTEIN--Carl. My dear friend, we shared so many joyous times. My family and I will miss you terribly.

GOLDSTEIN--Carl. You were a great friend, a mentor, and like a second father to us. From a chance meeting in the basement of O'Neil's Department Store in 1960, we have shared a lifetime of happy memories. The Lichtenberg Family

GOLDSTEIN--Carl S. Lichtenberg & Co. mourns the passing of Carl Goldstein, our Vice Chairman, friend and colleague of 40 years. His business skill and leadership are surpassed only by the warmth of his friendship and the generosity of his heart. Our deepest sympathy to Lynn, Scott, Wendy and the entire Goldstein family.

FERRIS--Barton P.,Jr. died October 17, 2013 at age 73 after a long illness due to complications from ataxia. Bart was a graduate of Northfield Mt. Hermon, Princeton University class of 1962 and Columbia Business School. Over the course of his long career as an investment banker, Bart worked for Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc., E.F. Hutton & Co. Inc. and Advest, Inc. He served on several boards of directors, including Ronson Corp., DSLT Inc., and Graham Magnetics. Bart attributed his lifelong interest in athletics and academics to his experience at Northfield Mt. Hermon. He lived the school's philosophy of "the head, the hand, the heart" and devoted significant time fundraising for the school. At Princeton he was captain of the wrestling team while pursuing a thesis in complex mathematical theory. Memberships included The Manhattan Rugby Club, Tiger Inn, Twilight Park Association and the Union Club. Bart was a devoted family man. He is survived by his wife Susan, daughter Juliana, son Jeffrey and his wife Laurie, son Nathaniel and his wife Patricia, brother Warren, many nieces and nephews, and his two loving granddaughters Sally and Annabelle. Bart was sustained throughout his long illness by the devotion of his wonderful friends to whom our family is ever grateful. A service is planned in Twilight Park in Haines Falls, NY in June.

EDELMAN--Ruth. Ruth Edelman, deputy chairman of DJE Holdings, parent company of her late husband's eponymous global public relations firm, Edelman, and recognized mental health advocate, died peacefully at the University of Chicago Medical Center. Mrs. Edelman was 84 years old. She was married to Daniel J. Edelman for 59 years prior to his death this past January. Mrs. Edelman is survived by her three children Richard and Renee of New York City and John of Chicago; as well as three granddaughters Margot, Victoria and Amanda Edelman, all of New York City. Throughout her life, Mrs. Edelman was a great supporter of numerous health organizations and nonprofits. She helped to significantly further the goals of the National Depressive and Manic-Depressive Association through her visibility as a patient advocate and philanthropist. In 1994, Mrs. Edelman became the first individual outside of the medical community to receive the National Depressive and Manic-Depressive Association's Jan Fawcett Humanitarian Award, which recognizes outstanding contributions to the understanding of depressive illness, commitment to research and sincere devotion to those suffering from depression. She was also an advocate for the Save the Children Foundation, Chicago Project for Violence Prevention and Committee for Economic Growth of Israel. In addition, Mrs. Edelman was active in Chicago's fine arts community, having raised funds for the Lyric Opera Company and the Chicago Art Institute. She worked for former US Senator Charles Percy, helping him organize community events for more than a decade. She would later become the special events chair for the state of Illinois under Governor Jim Thompson. However, Mrs. Edelman is best known as a driving force behind her late husband's success. "Ruth was a part of Edelman from day one," said Richard Edelman. "My parents created our business and established our culture. My mother had the poise and grace of a sought-after hostess, with the wit and wisdom of a savvy businesswoman. She charmed many a guest into becoming a client." Ruth Edelman was born Ruth Rozumoff in Racine, Wisconsin in 1929. After graduating from the University of Wisconsin-Madison as an economics major, she moved to Chicago where she met her future husband on a blind date. "I liked him," said Mrs. Edelman, as quoted in Edelman and the Rise of Public Relations by Franz Wisner. "I liked him because he was smart, refined, a gentleman and hardworking. I wanted him (for my husband) from the first day." From her marriage to Dan in 1953 until his death earlier this year, Mrs. Edelman nurtured her family as tirelessly as she helped support his company. With Dan often on the road, she oversaw the children's education with exacting standards of excellence. "It's something that we looked forward to, that our children would live a better life if they got better grades. And they did," she said. In addition to her children and granddaughters, Mrs. Edelman is survived by her sister Rosalie Aronin, 86 years old, and her daughters-in-law, Roz Edelman and Susie Krohn. Shiva will be held at the at Casino Club in Chicago and the memorial service will be held at the Temple Sinai in Chicago. The funeral service will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to either Leukemia Research at the University of Chicago Medical Center: University of Chicago Gift and Record Services, Ruth Edelman Memorial, 1427 East 60th Street, Suite 120, Chicago, IL 60637 or online at: https://www.kintera.org/site/c.phLWJ6PFKmG/b.6079897/k.8CE3/Make--A--Gift/apps/ka/sd/donorcustom.asp (specify "Ruth Edelman Leukemia Memorial"), or the National Depressive and Manic-Depressive Association: 730 N. Franklin Street, Suite 501Chicago, IL 60610-7204 or via phone 312-642-0049.

WYNN--Thomas Francis, III. On January 6, 1944, Thomas Francis Wynn III was born in St. Petersburg, Florida to Thomas and Catherine Wynn. Tom was the eldest of four children and he is survived by his brothers Jack and Bob and sister Kathy. Tom was raised in Fairlawn, New Jersey. His lifetime love for baseball started early with neighborhood games. And just like his idol Willie Mays, Tom "The Jet" played center field. Mr. Wynn was a graduate of Fordham University and Fordham Law School. He subsequently enlisted in the U.S. Army, served as Battalion Prosecutor and rose to the rank of Captain. In 1970 as Tom prepared to leave his station in Germany for the war in Vietnam, he received news that his wife of only one year, Linda Evelyn Gerbasi, had died following childbirth. Mr. Wynn was granted honorable discharge and he returned to the United States to find a job and care for his newborn twin girls Laura and Michele. Tom has always said that he was lucky enough to love two women in his life. On February 23, 1974, Ursula Claudina Loor married widower Tom Wynn; she adopted Tom's twin daughters and she gave birth to Thomas Loor Wynn IV and Ursula Mary Wynn. Ursula was the center of Tom's life for nearly 39 years of marriage whether on the dance floor or in the garden they were always together. On October 15, 2012 Ursula was called to the Kingdom of Heaven. Tom is survived by his children Thomas, Ursula and Laura. Michele predeceased both Tom and Ursula. Mr. Wynn is also survived by many friends and family members including his loving daughter-in-law Lysset Wynn and James Decker; and grandchildren Matthew, Thomas, Hank, Tammy and Luke. In 1970, Mr. Wynn joined the NASD Arbitration and Mediation Department (now part of FINRA) and most recently served as the Associate Director of Neutral Training and Development. Throughout his 34-year career, Mr. Wynn served in virtually every area of this department and, at various times, supervised the California, New York and Florida Offices. He was a frequent speaker at NASD and other seminars and developed training programs for Chairpersons. Tom was especially proud of his newsletter The Neutral Corner to which served as the Editor-in-Chief from its inception in 1995 until his retirement in 2004. With great humility, Tom described his role at the NASD as one that seemed to be "created just for him." At his core, Mr. Wynn was principled, fair and transparent; and his life's work, therefore, was an expression of himself. On Saturday, October 19, 2013, the Lord granted Tom entrance to the Kingdom of Heaven. Following cremation, we will celebrate Tom's life during a Memorial Mass on Friday, October 25, 2013 at 10:00am in St. Ann's Catholic Church located in Nyack, New York. Finally we ask that in lieu of flowers, donations can be made in the memory of Thomas Francis Wynn III to the Joe Raso Hospice Residence at 415 Buena Vista Road, New City, New York, 10956.

ROSEFF--Dr. Lionel S.,It is with overwhelming sadness that we mourn the loss of Dr. Lionel Roseff, who was born December 2, 1932 and passed away on October 19, 2013. Beloved, respected, and selfless doctor to generations of patients, loving husband to Barbara, cherished father and father-in-law to Lisa and Bruce Shalett and Tracy and Saul Kattan, adored grandfather to Zachary and Matthew Shalett and Alex and Andrew Kattan, devoted son-in-law, caring brother to Sylvia Swerdel, Henrietta Lederman, and the late Renee Appelbaum, and very generous, special, and dear friend to many. Passionate and dedicated in helping others, being a doctor was truly his calling, like his father before him. A graduate of NYU The Heights and Chicago Medical School at the top of his class, he was a distinguished member of The Beth Israel Medical Center community for over 50 years, loved by all who knew and worked with him. As an OB/GYN, he had an impact on so many lives, and helped bring life into the world. He will be profoundly missed. Our family is grateful for what he stood for and the wonderful example he set, and takes comfort, amidst the suddenness and shock of his death, in knowing that he will be remembered with love and admiration by his many patients, colleagues in the medical community, and friends. Funeral services will be Tuesday, October 22nd, at 11:15am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City.

LEVY--Peter A. The Board of Directors and staff of Selfhelp Community Services are saddened by the loss of our dear friend, Peter A. Levy, husband of former long-standing and dedicated Board member, Nadine Netter Levy. Peter was a devoted and generous supporter of Selfhelp's programs and services. LEVY--Peter A. It is with great sadness that the Board and Staff of Creative Alternatives of New York mark the passing of Peter A. Levy. Peter was a generous and thoughtful supporter of CANY, which was founded thirty years ago by his mother, Janet Levy. Peter's devotion to his mother's memory, and his loyalty to her vision of integrating mental health treatment with the creative arts, was an inspiration to all at Creative Alternatives of New York. Peter had a gentle soul and a focused vision that enabled him to carry forward his mother's work. Our hearts go out to his wife, Nadine, his beloved children and grandchildren and to his sister, Betty Hess.

GOLDSTEIN--Carl. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved friend and member, Friar Carl Goldstein. A Friar since January 1999, Carl Goldstein was a man of integrity and immense kindness. For the past 14 years our club has been blessed with the omnipresent spirit of Carl Goldstein. His goodwill and best wishes, along with his sage wisdom and tireless hard work, made the Friars Club all the better for having him as a member. In his role as House Committee Chairman, Governor of the Friars Club, Vice President of the Friars Foundation and Chairman of its Adopt a Scholar program; there has never been a more committed Friar than was he. We, along with his Friends at the United States Military Academy at West Point, as well as the entire textile industry shall miss him dearly. His memory and contribution will linger for many years to come. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Goldstein family for their loss. We are proud to have had him as a member. Friars Foundation Chairman: Ambassador Joseph Zappala, Vice Chairman Myron "Mike" Shevell Friars Club Abbot: Jerry Lewis, Dean Freddie Roman

DICKSTEIN--Paul. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of member Paul Dickstein, beloved husband of Robin Dickstein. Father of Isabel, Anthony, and Veronica Dickstein. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Lief D. Rosenblatt, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi

DICKSTEIN--Paul, was the quintessential New Yorker. He was born (1942) and raised in the Bronx by parents Kate and Ben Dickstein, who cultivated integrity, valued social justice, and instilled respect for public service. He graduated from James Monroe High School, Columbia University and New York University Law School. He concluded seventeen years serving the City of New York with a stint as the City's Budget Director from 1985 through 1989 under Mayor Ed Koch. His succeeding years were devoted to improving managed healthcare. In collaboration with the Greater New York Hospital Association he founded HealthFirst, a provider owned managed care company, and stayed on as President and CEO, managing fifteen years of rapid growth. In recent years, Paul had an independent healthcare consulting business, maintained a keen interest in local and national politics, listened to experimental rock, was an avid reader and exerciser, and a reluctant walker of the new family dog. He died on Monday, October 21, 2013, in the company of family who loved him in the City he loved. Paul is survived by his wife, Robin Gitman Dickstein, children Isabel, Anthony and Veronica Dickstein, sisters Linda Dienst and Diane Dickstein. Memorial Services will be private. Friends are invited to our home to share memories of Paul or just hang out: Tuesday, October 22 4pm to 9pm, Wednesday, October 23 11am to 2pm and 6pm to 9pm and Thursday, October 24 11am to 2pm and 5pm to 9pm. Donations in Paul's name may be made to the Westchester Jewish Community Services POINT Program or the Ethical Culture Fieldston School.

DAVIDOFF--Esther. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Esther Davidoff. She leaves behind a tradition of exceptional philanthropy and care for the Jewish community. We extend our condolences to Esther's beloved husband, Robert; her children, Barbara Weintraub, Joanne and Dan Free, Larry and Lisa Davidoff, and Lisa Davidoff, widow of the late Howard Davidoff; her grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

CRECELIUS--Ruth H.,on October 20, 2013, in her 92nd year. Beloved mother of Kathryn and Carolyn (Filippelli). Devoted mother-in-law of Andy and Jim. Cherished nanny of Amanda and James. Always in our hearts.

A memorial service celebrating her life will be held at Malcolm X and Dr. Betty Shabazz Cultural Center, 3940 Broadway, NYC on October 26 at 2pm. Carol was preceded in death by her parents Martha and William Bateman, two brothers Walter and John Bateman, and her son Ladji Blank. She is survived by her two children Ravi and Radha Blank, their father Roger Blank, two brothers William and Charles Bateman, two grandsons Naseem and Qadir Blank, and a host of loving family and friends.

WYNN--Thomas Francis, III. On January 6, 1944, Thomas Francis Wynn III was born in St. Petersburg, Florida to Thomas and Catherine Wynn. Tom was the eldest of four children and he is survived by his brothers Jack and Bob and sister Kathy. Tom was raised in Fairlawn, New Jersey. His lifetime love for baseball started early with neighborhood games. And just like his idol Willie Mays, Tom "The Jet" played center field. Mr. Wynn was a graduate of Fordham University and Fordham Law School. He subsequently enlisted in the U.S. Army, served as Battalion Prosecutor and rose to the rank of Captain. In 1970 as Tom prepared to leave his station in Germany for the war in Vietnam, he received news that his wife of only one year, Linda Evelyn Gerbasi, had died following childbirth. Mr. Wynn was granted honorable discharge and he returned to the United States to find a job and care for his newborn twin girls Laura and Michele. Tom has always said that he was lucky enough to love two women in his life. On February 23, 1974, Ursula Claudina Loor married widower Tom Wynn; she adopted Tom's twin daughters and she gave birth to Thomas Loor Wynn IV and Ursula Mary Wynn. Ursula was the center of Tom's life for nearly 39 years of marriage whether on the dance floor or in the garden they were always together. On October 15, 2012 Ursula was called to the Kingdom of Heaven. Tom is survived by his children Thomas, Ursula and Laura. Michele predeceased both Tom and Ursula. Mr. Wynn is also survived by many friends and family members including his loving daughter-in-law Lysset Wynn and James Decker; and grandchildren Matthew, Thomas, Hank, Tammy and Luke. In 1970, Mr. Wynn joined the NASD Arbitration and Mediation Department (now part of FINRA) and most recently served as the Associate Director of Neutral Training and Development. Throughout his 34-year career, Mr. Wynn served in virtually every area of this department and, at various times, supervised the California, New York and Florida Offices. He was a frequent speaker at NASD and other seminars and developed training programs for Chairpersons. Tom was especially proud of his newsletter The Neutral Corner to which served as the Editor-in-Chief from its inception in 1995 until his retirement in 2004. With great humility, Tom described his role at the NASD as one that seemed to be "created just for him." At his core, Mr. Wynn was principled, fair and transparent; and his life's work, therefore, was an expression of himself. On Saturday, October 19, 2013, the Lord granted Tom entrance to the Kingdom of Heaven. Following cremation, we will celebrate Tom's life during a Memorial Mass on Friday, October 25, 2013 at 10:00am in St. Ann's Catholic Church located in Nyack, New York. Finally we ask that in lieu of flowers, donations can be made in the memory of Thomas Francis Wynn III to the Joe Raso Hospice Residence at 415 Buena Vista Road, New City, New York, 10956.

WHERRY--Grace Elizabeth, died October 22, daughter of the late Martha Herzig and Francis T. Maloney, United States Senator from Connecticut. Attended Trinity College and Yale School of Music. Retired age 85. Personal assistant to playwright S.N. Behrman. Over 45 years at Harold Matson and Curtis Brown literary agencies. Survived by daughter, Liza (John) and Toby (Sarah) and three cherished grandsons: Jesse, Robbie, and Charlie. Interment private, Middlebury, VT beside former husband Toby Wherry. ULLMAN--Joel S.,on October 21, 2013. Adored and adoring husband of Mari, devoted father of Brian (Sam) and Andrew (Kelsey); beloved stepfather of Carolyn and Ellen (Adam) and proud Poppy of Justin, Ben, Maddie, Grace, Hope, Jared and Natalie. Joel was a contractor, pilot, Asian art dealer, computer educator, toolbox guru, late-blooming poet and wonderful friend. Memorial service to be announced.

She leaves behind daughters, Nina Trevens and Melissa DiGenova; son-in-law, Andy Bryant; daughter-in-law, Lynn DiGenova and five grandchildren: Ceanna, Michael, Sky, Anthony and Jared. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to TADA!, 15 West 28th St, New York, NY, 10001.

Joins his beloved wife (Joyce) who passed away in 2005. Service on Wednesday, October 23 at 12pm at Weinstein Funeral Home: 1652 Central Park Avenue. Yonkers, NY 10710.

SHERESKY--Norman. The Officers and Fellows of the New York Chapter of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers mourn the passing of our former President, friend, colleague and mentor, Norman Sheresky. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Michael Stutman, President
SHERESKY--Norman. Most cherished uncle of Rusty Unger and great-uncle of Amanda Guinzburg, who will treasure his wonderful memory always.

SHERESKY--Norman M.,on October 19, 2013. Beloved husband of Elaine Lewis, adored father of Brooke and godfather of Cezara Russu. Son of the late Harry and Rose; brother of the late Richard, Kenneth and Jacqueline. Cherished uncle and treasured friend. Eminent attorney and author; Founder and President elect, American College of Family Trial Lawyers, former President New York Chapter American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers. SHASHA--Alfred, the Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club, note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Alfred Shasha, and extend sincere condolences to his family. Alan Fischer, President

SELTZER--Bertha (Bailey), died on October 21, 2013, joining her beloved husband Sidney in heaven. Devoted mother to Dan, Linda (Stephen Breskin), Elaine (Peter Muff) and Alan. Adored grandmother to Nicole (Jeremy), Big Mike and Little Mike. Loved and cherished by many dear relatives and friends. She will be missed.

SELKAITIS--Walter J. October 15, 1915 - October 18, 2013, died at home in Bedminster, New Jersey, following a brief illness on Friday, October 18, in the company of family and God. Blessed with a sharp mind, he lived to be 98 years strong! Walter was a humble, intelligent, undemanding and dignified man who loved his family, the Catholic Church, automobiles of any kind and the New York Yankees. Born in the Bronx, New York, Walter worked for the IRT System as a clerk and photographer before entering the New York City Police Department in 1943. Within the NYPD, he rose to the rank of Gold Shield Detective in the Photography Unit of the Homicide Division of the 48th Precinct, before retiring in 1969. He went on to work in the authorizations department of American Express for 10 years post retirement. He was predeceased by his wife, Irene Kovacs Selkaitis, in 1966, and we know she greeted him in heaven last week. He is survived by his four children James Selkaitis, Joan Selkaitis, Karen Stanhope and Susan Hart, and his only grandchild, Caroline Hart, for whom he held a special place in his heart. He considered his daughter-in-law, Betty Selkaitis, and son-in-law, Bradford Hart, to be his own children, loving them with equal care. He left us with many words of wisdom as he departed this earth, and we hope we can live up to his high standards and strong beliefs as well as he did. The extended Selkaitis family would like to thank the many hospice and health care professionals who helped Walter and our family throughout his final days. Walter requested that in lieu of flowers, donations could be directed to the food pantry at The Church of St. Vincent de Paul Parish, 250 Bebout Avenue, Stirling, NJ 07980 or stvdparish@aol.com.

ROSEFF--Lionel. The Board of Directors and Membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Lionel Roseff. Our deepest sympathies are extended to the bereaved family. Jeffrey Weingarten, Acting President

QUIRK--John G.,60, of Kent, CT on October 19 surrounded by his loving family. Pop will be remembered as an inspiring educator, steadfast friend, dedicated father and devoted husband. He touched everyone he met with his humor and sincerity.

POST--Herman, died October 19, Glastonbury, CT. Survived by Robin, Ernest and Laura Post, Amy Wiseman, spouses and nine grandchildren. Predeceased by Blanche. Founded Robins Industries Corp. Service 1pm October 26, Glastonbury Funeral Home.

He was a Distinguished Lecturer of Public Administration at Medgar Evers College, CUNY. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife, Maria, children and grandchildren Benno Schmidt Chairman, Board of Trustees William P. Kelly Interim Chancellor

ORTIZ--George, aged 86, died at home in Geneva, Switzerland, on October 8th after a long illness. Dearly loved and sorely missed by his spouse Catherine, his children Georges, Oliver, Nicolas, Graziella and all his grandchildren. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, November 16th at 2pm at the Church of Collonge-Bellerive, 113, Route d'Hermance, Geneva CH-1245, Switzerland.

MORAN--Juliette M. Born in New York City June 12, 1917. Died peacefully October 20. A chemist by training, she was one of the first women to become a top executive in a Fortune 500 corporation without benefit of a family connection. Educated in the excellent New York public schools of her youth, Miss. Moran graduated with a B.S. in Chemistry from New College, Columbia University in 1939 and earned a Master's Degree in Chemistry at NYU in 1948. She joined General Aniline & Film Corp., later GAF, in 1943, working her way up the ranks until her retirement as Vice Chairman and Director in 1982. She also served as President of GAF Broadcasting Company (WNCN-FM), the company's classical music station. She was a director of the New York State Science and Technology Foundation and of the American Symphony Orchestra, and was a member of the Committee of Judges, New York State Science Fair. She received the 1972 Greater NY Advertising Award for Excellence in Communication, the 1977 NYU Graduate School of Arts and Sciences Award and the 1979 Catalyst Award for Distinguished Career and Achievement in Business. She loved science, poetry, music, fine wines, and conversations with her many devoted friends. Above all, she was a reader. She knew no better companion than a book. Miss. Moran is survived by her nieces, Nancy Granlund of Coeur d'Alene, ID and Jill Rivers of Poughkeepsie, NY. In keeping with her wishes, there will be no funeral or memorial service.
McGOVERN--Bridget M.,on October 17, 2013. Native New Yorker and life-long Manhattan resident. Beloved sister of Charles and the late Mary (Morgan). For information, www.walterbcooke.net

LIMA--Frank, poet, beloved husband and father, passed away on Monday, October 21st, at his home in Lido Beach. He is survived by his wife, Helen and children, Christophe and Matthew. You have reached the coast, Frank. We will miss you.

LEVY--Peter A. It is with great sadness that the Board and Staff of Creative Alternatives of New York mark the passing of Peter A. Levy. Peter was a generous and thoughtful supporter of CANY, which was founded thirty years ago by his mother, Janet Levy. Peter's devotion to his mother's memory, and his loyalty to her vision of integrating mental health treatment with the creative arts, was an inspiration to all at Creative Alternatives of New York. Peter had a gentle soul and a focused vision that enabled him to carry forward his mother's work. Our hearts go out to his wife, Nadine, his beloved children and grandchildren and to his sister, Betty Hess.

HANLEY--Joseph P.,on October 20, 2013 at age 85. He was born on October 16, 1928 in Manhattan. He started his career at Macy's and eventually ran the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. He was also head of the Public Relations for WCBS Radio, followed by Women's Wear Daily and Crains. He became the Vice President of the Los Angeles Times Newspaper Syndicate and then moved on to The News Corporation Syndicate under Rupert Murdoch. He is survived by his wife Marie Hanley. His son Christopher perished on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Memorial visitation at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Thursday from 3-6pm. Memorial Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral Lady's Chapel on Friday 11am.

GUARNIERI--Anna, of Brooklyn, NY, on October 22, 2013 in her 84th year. Beloved sister to Phyllis Piazza. Loving aunt to Vivian, Grace and Joan. Cherished great-aunt to Alessandra, Andrew, Gabriela, Peter and Allison. Former supervisor of the Brooklyn Navy Yard and The Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace. Anna was admired and loved by all. The family will receive friends Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Christopher T. Jordan Funeral Home, 302 Long Beach Rd., Island Park, NY. Funeral Mass Friday 9:45am. St Ignatius Martyr R.C. Church, Long Beach, NY. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers please make donations to mjhs.org Hospice and Palliative Care. www.jordanfh.com

A longtime friend and supporter of the college, he was a member of the Home Products Development Industry Advisory Council. He and his wife established the Lynn and Carl Goldstein Endowed Scholarship for FIT's Home Products Development majors, leaving a legacy for generations of students to come. Joyce F. Brown, FIT President The FIT Board of Trustees The FIT Foundation

GOLDSTEIN--Carl. The LeFrak Family mourns the loss of our dear friend Carl Goldstein. Carl's friendship meant so much to us and our beloved parents Sam and Ethel. He will be missed. Our deepest sympathy to his wife Lynn, his children Scott, Wendy and the entire Goldstein family.
GOLD--Jack, friend and confidant for decades. Sarcasm, wit, loyalty - a true triple crown. "Your forum friends" will miss you and lend our support to Jan and Lane.

DICKSTEIN--Paul. Maimonides Medical Center mourns the loss of our friend and colleague. Paul's public service and impact on healthcare will be long remembered, and his presence will be missed by all. We extend heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Robin Gitman, his three children and entire Dickstein family. Martin D. Payson Chair, Board of Trustees Pamela S. Brier President & CEO Maimonides Medical Center

DICKSTEIN--Paul. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the loss of our dear friend and colleague Paul Dickstein. Across a remarkable career in health care and government service, Paul was a true visionary with a superb ability to find creative solutions to complex problems. With unmatched skill and leadership, he took Healthfirst from a concept at GNYHA to one of the nation's leading provider-sponsored insurance companies. In 2013, GNYHA turned to Paul to work with hospitals and other stakeholders across New York State to facilitate the implementation of a statewide health information technology strategy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Robin, his children Anthony, Isabel, and Veronica, and his many friends and colleagues. James Kaskie, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President GNYHA

DICKSTEIN--Paul, was the quintessential New Yorker. He was born (1942) and raised in the Bronx by parents Kate and Ben Dickstein, who cultivated integrity, valued social justice, and instilled respect for public service. He graduated from James Monroe High School, Columbia University and New York University Law School. He concluded seventeen years serving the City of New York with a stint as the City's Budget Director from 1985 through 1989 under Mayor Ed Koch. His succeeding years were devoted to improving managed healthcare. In collaboration with the Greater New York Hospital Association he founded HealthFirst, a provider owned managed care company, and stayed on as President and CEO, managing fifteen years of rapid growth. In recent years, Paul had an independent healthcare consulting business, maintained a keen interest in local and national politics, listened to experimental rock, was an avid reader and exerciser, and a reluctant walker of the new family dog. He died on Monday, October 21, 2013, in the company of family who loved him in the City he loved. Paul is survived by his wife, Robin Gitman Dickstein, children Isabel, Anthony and Veronica Dickstein, sisters Linda Dienst and Diane Dickstein. Memorial Services will be private. Friends are invited to our home to share memories of Paul or just hang out: Tuesday, October 22 4pm to 9pm, Wednesday, October 23 11am to 2pm and 6pm to 9pm and Thursday, October 24 11am to 2pm and 5pm to 9pm. Donations in Paul's name may be made to the Westchester Jewish Community Services POINT Program or the Ethical Culture Fieldston School.

ZUCKER--Susan R.,72. Loving wife of David L. Hoffman and widow of her beloved Morris R. Zucker. Devoted (and exceptional!) mother of Dana Zucker and Lauren Zucker. Sister of Ken Robins. Loving mother-in-law of Brahm Cramer and David Shorrock. Adoring grandmother of Alex, Will, Evan, Marisa, Andrew and Eli. Dedicated step-mother and step-grandmother. Service noon Friday at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. at 65th, Street, NYC.

WYNN--Thomas Francis, III. On January 6, 1944, Thomas Francis Wynn III was born in St. Petersburg, Florida to Thomas and Catherine Wynn. Tom was the eldest of four children and he is survived by his brothers Jack and Bob and sister Kathy. Tom was raised in Fairlawn, New Jersey. His lifetime love for baseball started early with neighborhood games. And just like his idol Willie Mays, Tom "The Jet" played center field. Mr. Wynn was a graduate of Fordham University and Fordham Law School. He subsequently enlisted in the U.S. Army, served as Battalion Prosecutor and rose to the rank of Captain. In 1970 as Tom prepared to leave his station in Germany for the war in Vietnam, he received news that his wife of only one year, Linda Evelyn Gerbasi, had died following childbirth. Mr. Wynn was granted honorable discharge and he returned to the United States to find a job and care for his newborn twin girls Laura and Michele. Tom has always said that he was lucky enough to love two women in his life. On February 23, 1974, Ursula Claudina Loor married widower Tom Wynn; she adopted Tom's twin daughters and she gave birth to Thomas Loor Wynn IV and Ursula Mary Wynn. Ursula was the center of Tom's life for nearly 39 years of marriage whether on the dance floor or in the garden they were always together. On October 15, 2012 Ursula was called to the Kingdom of Heaven. Tom is survived by his children Thomas, Ursula and Laura. Michele predeceased both Tom and Ursula. Mr. Wynn is also survived by many friends and family members including his loving daughter-in-law Lysset Wynn and James Decker; and grandchildren Matthew, Thomas, Hank, Tammy and Luke. In 1970, Mr. Wynn joined the NASD Arbitration and Mediation Department (now part of FINRA) and most recently served as the Associate Director of Neutral Training and Development. Throughout his 34-year career, Mr. Wynn served in virtually every area of this department and, at various times, supervised the California, New York and Florida Offices. He was a frequent speaker at NASD and other seminars and developed training programs for Chairpersons. Tom was especially proud of his newsletter The Neutral Corner to which served as the Editor-in-Chief from its inception in 1995 until his retirement in 2004. With great humility, Tom described his role at the NASD as one that seemed to be "created just for him." At his core, Mr. Wynn was principled, fair and transparent; and his life's work, therefore, was an expression of himself. On Saturday, October 19, 2013, the Lord granted Tom entrance to the Kingdom of Heaven. Following cremation, we will celebrate Tom's life during a Memorial Mass on Friday, October 25, 2013 at 10:00am in St. Ann's Catholic Church located in Nyack, New York. Finally we ask that in lieu of flowers, donations can be made in the memory of Thomas Francis Wynn III to the Joe Raso Hospice Residence at 415 Buena Vista Road, New City, New York, 10956.

RATTNER--Sol, age 76 beloved husband and father died on October 12, 2013 at the Queen's Medical Center in Honolulu, Hawaii. Mr. Rattner was born October 1, 1937 in Brooklyn, New York. He moved with his family to Hawaii on October 31, 1999. Mr. Rattner was a retired Foreman from the New York Times with 28 years of service. Prior to joining the New York Times he was a Newpaper Man for the Hearld Tribune. He also worked a short time with World Journal Tribune before joining the New york Times in 1968. Mr. Rattner is survived by loving wife Lila Rattner and son Joseph Rattner. He was laid to rest on Thursday, October 17, 2013 in Abramham's Garden at Hawaiian Memorial Park Cemetery.

POST--Herman, died October 19, Glastonbury, CT. Survived by Robin, Ernest and Laura Post, Amy Wiseman, spouses and nine grandchildren. Predeceased by Blanche. Founded Robins Industries Corp. Service 1pm October 26, Glastonbury Funeral Home.

QUINN--Donald Thomas. November 11, 1928 - October 19, 2013. Born and raised in Oil City, PA, Don graduated from the US Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point in 1950. He was a well-known executive with Boise-Griffin Steamship Company from 1951 until 1969 when he relocated to Miami to operate the Luckenbach Steamship Company. Luckenbach was acquired by Lavino Shipping Company, where he remained until 1977. Later that year, after a move back to Boise-Griffin as president and CEO, he returned to Miami and founded Oceanic Steamship Companies. Don retired to Fort Lauderdale in 2004. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Frances Lucia, his three children and ten grandchildren.

MOZER--Robert J.,beloved husband of Patricia, devoted father of eight, treasured grandfather of 22 and cherished great-grandfather of six, died in his Manhasset, NY home on October 21, 2013. Viewing will take place at Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel located at 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY on Friday, October 25, 2013 from 2pm-5pm and from 7pm-9pm. MORAN--Juliette M. Born in New York City June 12, 1917. Died peacefully October 20. A chemist by training, she was one of the first women to become a top executive in a Fortune 500 corporation without benefit of a family connection. Educated in the excellent New York public schools of her youth, Miss. Moran graduated with a B.S. in Chemistry from New College, Columbia University in 1939 and earned a Master's Degree in Chemistry at NYU in 1948. She joined General Aniline & Film Corp., later GAF, in 1943, working her way up the ranks until her retirement as Vice Chairman and Director in 1982. She also served as President of GAF Broadcasting Company (WNCN-FM), the company's classical music station. She was a director of the New York State Science and Technology Foundation and of the American Symphony Orchestra, and was a member of the Committee of Judges, New York State Science Fair. She received the 1972 Greater NY Advertising Award for Excellence in Communication, the 1977 NYU Graduate School of Arts and Sciences Award and the 1979 Catalyst Award for Distinguished Career and Achievement in Business. She loved science, poetry, music, fine wines, and conversations with her many devoted friends. Above all, she was a reader. She knew no better companion than a book. Miss. Moran is survived by her nieces, Nancy Granlund of Coeur d'Alene, ID and Jill Rivers of Poughkeepsie, NY. In keeping with her wishes, there will be no funeral or memorial service.
McGOVERN--Bridget M.,on October 17, 2013. Native New Yorker and life-long Manhattan resident. Beloved sister of Charles and the late Mary (Morgan). For information, www.walterbcooke.net
LEICHMAN--Howard B. Athlete, scholar, teacher, husband, father, the one and only Howie. Sissy, Seym, Sam, Hugh, Jesse and Liz

KLEBANOFF--Steven. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Steven Klebanoff, and extend sincere condolences to his family. Alan Fischer, President

KLEBANOFF--Steven, age 76, passed away on October 21, 2013 after a brief illness. Steven was born in Philadelphia, the son of Betty and Benjamin Klebanoff and brother of the late Elaine Benson Kaufman. He was a resident of Rye Brook and, previously, Scarsdale, NY. A graduate of Ohio State University with an Engineering Degree, Steven was a well respected and successful businessman. He was a person who was both creative and strategic who thrived on the art of crafting a deal. As a result of his willingness to help others and his unbounded openness and curiosity, he had friends and associates from all walks of life. He had the exceptional ability to tell stories and jokes that matched whatever topic was being discussed. Motivated and always on the go, he enjoyed life to the fullest and somehow always managed to convince his wife, Joy, to join him on every adventure. As a longtime member of Beach Point Club, Steven treasured the many friendships he fostered and the precious family milestones celebrated there. He was a devoted husband and family man. He is survived by his wife, Joy; his son, Peter; his daughter, Jennifer; and his grandchildren, Grant, Abby, Emily and Blake, who were a special source of pride and enjoyment to him. His initiative, optimism and sense of humor enabled him to maintain a balanced life. Steven was a man with a big heart and a strong will. The unexpected passing of a man who was never at a loss for words has left us speechless. Donations in Steven's memory may be made to Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester's New Chapel Fund. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 27 at 2pm at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester in Rye, NY.

KERNER--Sidney, on October 21, 2013. Loving husband of Anna Bisso, wonderful father of Michael (Margery) and Susan (Stephen) and stepfather of Margaret (Donald) and Amy (David), beloved grandfather of Zach (Sarah), Jamie, Evan and Jessica and devoted brother of Ben (deceased) and Frances.

HOBEL--Philip Sherman, 92, of New York City and East Hampton, died peacefully at home on Wednesday, October 23, surrounded by loving family and caregivers. Founder and owner of The Cinema Guild, Hobel-Leiterman Productions and Document Associates, and producer and distributor of scores of award-winning television series, documentaries and features, notably "Tender Mercies," which was nominated for five Academy Awards, including Best Picture, and which won two. A Manhattan native, 1942 graduate of Columbia College, and proud U.S. Navy veteran, having served as a lieutenant in the Pacific theatre during WWII, he founded and operated the Cortland Furniture Company, a leading manufacturer and wholesaler of furniture, after the war and until 1970 when he entered the television and film business. Beloved husband of Mary-Ann (nee Hirsch) for 63 years, devoted father of Joseph (Marjorie), Michael (Michal), and Sara (Scott Mendel). Loving grandfather of Zachary and Samuel Hobel, Adam and Ethan Hobel, and Madeleine and Cleo Gordon. Dear son of Joseph and Celia Hobel (nee Goldberg) and loving brother of Bernice Hobel, who predeceased him. Philip will be deeply missed by his family and by his many friends and mentees. Services will be held graveside at Sharon Gardens, 273 Lakeview Ave, Valhalla, NY on Thursday, October 24 at 2:30pm. The family will receive visitors for Shiva and to celebrate Philip's life on Thursday and Friday from 5pm to 8pm at home in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Philip's memory to the Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer's Disease and the Aging Brain at Columbia University (https://giving.columbia.edu/ giveonline/?schoolstyle=523).

HEISLER--Leslye. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Leslye Heisler. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband, Jerome, and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

HANLEY--Joseph P.,on October 20, 2013 at age 85. He was born on October 16, 1928 in Manhattan. He started his career at Macy's and eventually ran the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. He was also head of the Public Relations for WCBS Radio, followed by Women's Wear Daily and Crains. He became the Vice President of the Los Angeles Times Newspaper Syndicate and then moved on to The News Corporation Syndicate under Rupert Murdoch. He is survived by his wife Marie Hanley. His son Christopher perished on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Memorial visitation at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Thursday from 3-6pm. Memorial Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral Lady's Chapel on Friday 11am.

GOODMAN--Walter Flato, A world-renowned breeder-owner-handler of Skye Terriers and an American Kennel Club judge died October 6 in Miami, FL at 91. An enthusiastic traveler who traversed the globe nine times, Goodman was also a patron of the arts and a Life Trustee of Villa Vizcaya. Born to Maurice and Adele Goodman on August 15, 1922 in Rye NY, Goodman followed his father's advice to "Live up to your name: "Good-man." After graduating from Rumsey Hall and the Hotchkiss School, Mr. Goodman attended Yale University ('44). He interrupted his studies in January 1943 to join the United States Army. By the end of WWII, Goodman was second in command of a U.S. P.O.W. camp on the outskirts of Antwerp, Belgium housing 1,700 German soldiers. Following the War, Mr. Goodman completed his bachelor's degree in International Relations at Yale and later earned a Masters in History at Columbia University. Although Goodman worked as a trust officer at the Bank of New York, an associate producer at NBC and at Mike Ellis Productions, his true life's work and passion was in the sport of purebred dogs. His mother Adele founded Glamoor Kennels in 1937 with Walter joining in soon after, and Glamoor Kennels became known as one of the top Skye Terrier kennels in the world, breeding American, Canadian, French and Italian champions. Goodman's dogs earned a record 300 Terrier Group Firsts and 99 Best-in-Shows including Westminster Kennel Club's, where he handled Ch. Glamoor Good News to a Best-in-Show in 1969. After retiring from the show ring in 1975 to become an AKC judge, Goodman judged dog shows worldwide for 36 years, including Best-In-Show at Westminster Kennel Club in 1994. As the Skye Terrier Club of America's delegate, Mr. Goodman was elected to the American Kennel Club Board of Directors in 1988 serving for an unprecedented 24 years to March 2012. Goodman was a long-standing member of Westminster Kennel Club, Westbury Kennel Club, The Kennel Club (UK), Morris & Essex Kennel Club, and Palm Beach Dog Fanciers. He was proudest of having served as President for 28 years at Montgomery County Kennel Club, the club that sponsors the largest, most celebrated all-terrier show in the world in Blue Bell, PA each October. Goodman's innumerable contributions to the world of purebred dogs included his being a founding member of the AKC Museum of the Dog and of the Canine Health Foundation. As a Member of the University of Pennsylvania's School of Veterinary Medicine Board of Overseers, he co-founded along with Robert A. Flanders the Walter Flato Goodman Center for Comparative Medical Genetics. Goodman's recent honors include the American Kennel Club's Lifetime Achievement Award in 2011 and his induction into the Anne Rogers Clark Hall of Fame at the Show Dogs of the Year Awards in 2013. A resident of Miami, FL since 1973, Walter is survived by his son Robert A. Flanders, five nieces and nephews, three great-nieces, his many close friends, and his beloved Norfolk Terrier, Gypsy. A memorial "Celebration of Life" will be held early next year. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Walter Flato Goodman Center for Comparative Medical Genetics, School of Veterinary Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, 3800 Spruce Street, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6008.

EHRENWORTH--Lionel (Lee) M.D.,born January 9, 1929, died October 20, 2013. Belleville High School, Class of '46, United States Marine Corps, 1946-48, Tulane University, Tulane University Medical School, 1955, died at home in Watchung, NJ after a long illness. Dr. Ehrenworth, of Elizabeth Medical Associates, Elizabeth, NJ. was a Board Certified internist and cardiologist with specialties in hematology and oncology until his retirement in 2003. He was affiliated with many New Jersey and New York health care facilities throughout his career. He is survived by his adored and cherished wife, Beth (Sapinkoff-Bass) and her family. He was a devoted and caring father to Douglas, Robert, Andrew and Richard, a doting grandfather to Jackson Nathanial and Matthew Petr, a beloved older brother to Jonathan and Susan (Addelston-Kunken), a warm hearted uncle to their children, a cherished friend and honored professional colleague to many. Funeral services will be held Friday, October 25th, 11am at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel in Livingston, NJ with interment to follow at B'nai Abraham Memorial Park in Union, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send your contributions to the Dr. Lee Ehrenworth Emergency Medical Care Vehicle Fund, c/o Watchung Rescue Squad, 10 Stirling Road, Watchung, NJ 07069.

DICKSTEIN--Paul. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the loss of our dear friend and colleague Paul Dickstein. Across a remarkable career in health care and government service, Paul was a true visionary with a superb ability to find creative solutions to complex problems. With unmatched skill and leadership, he took Healthfirst from a concept at GNYHA to one of the nation's leading provider-sponsored insurance companies. In 2013, GNYHA turned to Paul to work with hospitals and other stakeholders across New York State to facilitate the implementation of a statewide health information technology strategy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Robin, his children Anthony, Isabel, and Veronica, and his many friends and colleagues. James Kaskie, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President GNYHA

CROSBIE--William R.,of Tarrytown, NY. Retired judge; naturalist; community leader. "Wisdom and wit" describe him well. Born January, 27 1924; raised in Cuba and Southbridge, MA. Graduated Suffield Academy, Princeton University (1945); US Army captain WWII. MBA, NYU; JD, NY Law School; editor, Law Review. Led new business ventures Cuban-American Sugar Co. and Union Carbide Corp.; VP, Corporate Market Dev. Manufacturers Hanover (Chase). Tarrytown Village Trustee; Westchester County Legislator. Brigadier General, NY Guard Reserve. Predeceased Mary Ann Hazelton, wife; survived by six daughters, 15 grandchildren, three great-grandchildren.

DANSKER--Norman, passed away peacefully at home on October 22, 2013. Norman is remembered foremost as the devoted husband of 66 years to his cherished Gloria, loving father to Susan and Robert, brother-in-law to Doris, brother to Penny, father-in-law to Joseph, and grandfather to Jonathan and Matthew. We are proud of the role that this lifelong New Yorker played in shaping the skyline of the city he loved. We will miss him very much. Condolences and Shiva inquiries may be sent to ndfamilynyc@gmail.com.

COLFELT--Gail Schwenk, died of sudden complications in a valiant fight against Alzheimer's disease, Gladwyne, PA, October 22, 2013. She lived 72 years full of accomplishment and devotion. First-born daughter of Alfred Everett Schwenk of Scranton, PA, and of Iva Leona Campbell of Bunkie, LA, Gail Judith Schwenk was born during April 1941, in East Orange, NJ grew up in Hempstead, Long Island, and graduated in 1959 from Hempstead High School. She met her husband of 49 years, H. Todd Colfelt, in Carlisle, PA, and there graduated in Dickinson College's Class of 1963. Directly following her B.A., Gail S. Colfelt earned her M.Ed. in Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology from Penn State, and in 1964 began a 42-year career at The Montgomery County Intermediate Unit (MCIU), where she served as a special education clinician, then supervisor, teaching speech, hearing, vision and remediation to both public and non-public school students in over 160 different Pennsylvania schools. In 1989, while working full-time and raising a teenage son, she completed her Doctorate in Educational Administration at Temple University, where she wrote her dissertation: First Amendment Rights of Speech and Expression for Public School Teachers in the Classroom 1975-1987. For her achievements, Dr. Colfelt was awarded a lifetime membership in the Pennsylvania Speech-Language-Hearing Association (PSHA) on her retirement in 2006, and was saluted by The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA) for her "personal and professional dedication" and her 'wonderful example to those entering the field of communication sciences and disorders." In retirement, Gail enjoyed volunteer work in the tutoring program at Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, where she was a member, as well as election work at the polls. In her battle against Alzheimer's disease, Gail was proud to complete a clinical trial at the Penn Memory Center at HUP. Gail Schwenk Colfelt was a fun-loving and courageous woman who relished hard work but also loved family vacations in Nantucket and in Deer Isle, Maine. She is survived by her husband Todd, son Craig, son-in-law Michael Andrews, sister Janice Robbins, brother-in-law Dr. David Robbins, nieces Drs. Cindy and Karen Robbins (Andrew Knapp), and cousins Bill Carter (Judy), Nancy Bell (Kenny), Sandra Carter, and cousins in the Welton family, on the Schwenk side. Visitation services will begin at 11am, Friday, October 25, 2013 with Funeral Services at 12pm at Bringhurst Funeral Home at West Laurel Cemetery, 225 Belmont Ave, Bala Cynwyd, PA. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gail Colfelt's memory should be made to the Alzheimer's Association, alz.org. www.forever-care.com

BULL--Robert Jehu. The Drew University community is deeply saddened by the passing of Robert Jehu Bull of Madison, NJ., a retired Drew University professor of church history and archaeologist in the Middle East who died of West Nile disease at the age of 92. He was the devoted husband of Drew President Vivian Bull and father of two sons, Camper, a 1991 Drew alumnus, and Carlson. Kind, funny, and wise, he left an impressive legacy in both his fields. Dr. Bull, who was ordained in the United Methodist Church, came to Drew's Theological School in 1955 and began his archaeological work with the Drew-McCormick expedition to Tell Balata in Jordan the same year. He served as director of the Joint Expedition to Caesarea Maritima in Israel, the site of an ancient city, from 1971 until 1996. He inspired hundreds of students with his passion for archaeology and enthusiasm for the study of history, and we shall not forget him.

BRAGG, Edward H. Jr. of Greenwich, CT, passed away on October 21, 2013 at his home with his beloved wife and family by his side. He is survived by Margaret, his wife of 49 years, three sons, Philip, James, and Winston, his daughter-in-law, Jen and two grandchildren, Lily Elisabeth and Chase Edward. He was the only son of Edward and Hilda Bragg and was born in White Plains, NY on October 31, 1931. He was a graduate of Brunswick School, Princeton University, the Officer Candidate School at the United States Coast Guard Academy, and Harvard Business School. He served two years on the Coast Guard Search & Rescue duty in the Atlantic and one year as Commanding Officer of a LORAN station in the Pacific French Frigate Shoals on Tern Island, the smallest inhabited island in the world. He was a partner and managing director of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the investment counsel firm, with 35 years in the role of managing individual and institutional portfolios. His clients were domestic, European, and Middle Eastern. He was widely respected and admired in the investment counseling field and served as a highly regarded mentor to many of his colleagues at Scudder. He was a leader at Camp Dudley in Westport, NY and frequent visitor and supporter of Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, NY. He was a member of Round Hill Club, the Union Club, John's Island Club and Mill Reef Club. Present and past outside activities have included Board Membership in the "Save the Field" (Sabine Farm) program, "Return the Light" (Great Captains Island), American Bible Society, Naval War College Foundation, Historical Society of Greenwich, Greenwich Land Trust, Bruce Museum, Brunswick School, the Independent College Fund of New York and Indian River Land Trust. Memorial gifts may be made to Christ Church Greenwich or to the Bragg Memorial Academic Fund at the Naval War College Fdn., Cushing Road, Newport, RI 02841-1213. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT, on Saturday, November 9th at 11am.

Accomplished surgeon, medical pioneer, and connoisseur of French 18th century furniture. He was predeceased by his first wife Muriel Lederman Altchek. Graveside funeral at Mt. Hebron on Friday, 11:30am. Shiva to follow at the office of Dr. Altchek, 115 East 61st Street and also on Sunday 47pm.
