RUBENS--Charles III, Happy 57th Birthday! Gone but not forgotten, dearly loved and deeply missed. Your Dark Star shines brightly. Go in peace bro. Your Loving Brother (and family), Pete

ROSENFIELD--Zachary. Memorial service for noted hospital architect/planner Zachary Rosenfield will be held on Sunday, October 27 at 1pm at Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, 4450 Fieldston Road, Riverdale, NY. Please email: office@RYSEC.org of intention to attend.

VANDERMOLEN--Wilhelmina J.,died unexpectedly October 24, 2013. She was a respected member of the Corps of UN Civil Servants for many years and provided invaluable support for journalists covering the UN from the United States and abroad. She was hired by Matt Gordon (father of New York Times reporter Michael R. Gordon) who was the official in charge of the UN press section during several crisis times and in more placid periods. He used to say he recommended Ms. Vandermolen for the job because of her abundance of common sense. After her retirement she developed talents as a water colorist; her work was accepted for several exhibitions. She is deeply missed by her longtime partner Michael Littlejohns. In a tribute her trainer at NYHC, Nathan Palmer, called her "an inspiration" for all of the members of their aerobics class. Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home is handling services.

TURBEVILLE--Deborah. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our good friend, amazing artist and photographer Deborah Turbeville. It was a pleasure and an honor to work beside her. We will miss her terribly, but she leaves us with an extraordinary body of work that will forever remind us of her passion for life and her love of beauty. Deborah, we will miss you forever. Love, Marek, Donna, Barbara and the staff of Marek & Associates

SOLON--Joan. A generous spirit and committed friend, whose lust for life and adventure knew few bounds. Whether it was a friend in distress or a stranger in need, a formal charity or an individual act of kindness, Joan was always first to offer to help, enlist others, and give unselfishlessly of her time for the benefit of others. Wife, mother, grandmother and friend to many, we will miss her greatly but will remember always her blithe spirit, constant kindness and unlimited generosity. There are too few like her in the world. We love you Joannie. Judie, Ron and Bonnie

TANNER--Laurel N. Dr.,a renowned education expert who was awarded the 2007 Lifetime Achievement Award from the Curriculum Studies division of the American Educational Research Association, died on Sunday in Seattle, WA. She was 84. Dr. Tanner served as a Professor of Curriculum and Instruction and the Director of Urban Education at Temple University in Philadelphia, and also served as a professor at the University of Houston. Her 1978 book "Classroom Discipline" led to the development of the Discipline with Purpose program, a nationally acclaimed program currently taught in hundreds of schools. Dr. Tanner wrote and co-wrote numerous books and articles in the area of curriculum studies, including many with Dr. Daniel Tanner, with whom she was married for forty years and who continues to serve as a Professor Emeritus at the Rutgers University Graduate School of Education. She later married Dr. Kenneth Rehage, with whom she was married for 17 years before his death. Her sister Margo Reisman survives her, as do her niece Hope Sheffield and her nephews David, Carl and Andrew Reisman.

SCHILLING--Warner R.,died October 20, 2013, at age 88 at Englewood Hospital, Englewood, NJ. A long-time resident of Leonia, NJ, he grew up in the greater St. Louis area, served as a radio operator with the U.S. Army Air Forces, 194346, earned B.A., M.A., and Ph.D. degrees from Yale, and became an enthusiastic traveler on five continents. The James T. Shotwell Professor of International Relations Emeritus at Columbia University, he was director of the university's Institute of War and Peace Studies, 197686. For more than fifty years he guided several generations of students through the intricacies of American foreign policy, the causes of war, nuclear strategy, and the influence of technology on war and international relations. Beloved father of Jonathan and Frederick, father-in-law of Elaine, grandfather of Jeremy, uncle of Pauline and Alice, great-uncle of Gracie, Jimmy, and Billy. A memorial service at Columbia University will be announced. Donations may be made to the Pulmonary Rehabilitation Center at EHMC Foundation, 350 Engle Street, Englewood, N.J., 07631.

REILLY--Mary Jane, 84, in Lancaster, PA. Beloved mother of Eliza, Mary, and Sara and grandmother to Johanna, Sean, and Luke. Her elegance, wit, and grace will be sorely missed. Online condolences may be posted on our Web site: www.thegroffs.com. The Groffs Family Funeral & Cremation Services, Inc. 717-394-5300.

MAZER--Bill. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed honorary life member, Bill Mazer and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Barry N. Winograd, President Donald Capelin, Secretary

MAZER--Bill. It was a privilege to amplify Bill's voice on WVOX for the last eight years of his long, "amazin' " career. He was knowledgeable about everything and could talk with erudition on many subjects ... from DiMaggio and Henry Aaron to Mario Cuomo and Toots Shor ... also our Westchester neighbor of sainted memory, Robert Merrill. Mazer had a way with words which was unequaled in our tribe. And the State of Israel had no greater champion. Jimmy Cannon called Sports "the toys of a nation." Mazer ennobled those toys. William O'Shaughnessy WVOX

MANTEL--Marie F.,on October 21, 2013 at the age of 101. Marie was a US Navy Lieutenant during WWII. The first woman and layperson appointed the Director of Child Guidance Institute of Catholic Charities. Served on the Board of Directors at the Riverdale Mental Health and volunteered at St. Gabriel's Church. Dear sister of Margaret Mantel and the late Kathryn Moores and aunt of Susan Johnson, Lucinda McHale and the late Deborah Ostrum. Devoted friend of Marie McCarthy and Joselin Ynfante. Reposing Friday 2-4pm and 6-8pm at Riverdaleon-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10am at St. Gabriel's Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

LANDAU--Peter, 80, passed away in New York on October 23 after a long illness. The son of the late Edward and Charlotte Landau, he was a leader in financial journalism starting as a reporter for Newsweek after graduating from Duke and obtaining his master's degree in Economics from Columbia. In the early '70's he became editor for the influential magazine, Institutional Investor, where under his leadership over the next decade, the magazine received more than 40 awards for distinguished journalism including the National Magazine Award for Reporting, the first business magazine ever to receive this coveted award. An ardent golfer, he was the author (together with Shepherd Campbell) of "Presidential Lies", a history of the presidents who played golf. He was also the historian of the oldest golf club in America, St. Andrew's in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, where he created a golf library and wrote a history of the club, "St. Andrew's in the Gilded Age". He played year-round, using orange balls when snow covered the St. Andrew's course. He was a generous colleague, devoted friend and loving godfather.

KABAK--Norman M.,76 Died on October 23, 2013 in New Zealand. Proud father and grandfather, devoted husband, brother and uncle. Dedicated member of the Jewish Community from his origins in New York City to his final days in Wellington.

HUNTER--Helen Manning, professor emeritus of economics, and Mary Hale Chase professor emeritus of the social sciences at Bryn Mawr College, died Thursday October 17th at The Quadrangle in Haverford, Pennsylvania. She was 92 years old. Mrs. Hunter was the daughter of Frederick Johnson Manning, history professor at Swarthmore and Helen Taft Manning, history professor and dean at Bryn Mawr. Mrs. Hunter's grandfather, William Howard Taft, was the 27th President and the 10th Chief Justice of the United States. Helen Manning graduated from the Putney School and received her B.A. from Smith College in 1943. In 1945, she married Holland Hunter, professor of Economics at Haverford College. After obtaining her PhD from Radcliffe, Mrs. Hunter taught economics at Swarthmore and Bryn Mawr and directed summer programs at Haverford. Mrs. Hunter is survived by her husband Holland Hunter, her children Timothy Hunter, Christine Hunter, and Ann Hunter, eight grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held Saturday November 2nd at 11am at St. Mary's Church in Ardmore followed by interment at 2:30pm at the Haverford Friends Meeting. Instead of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

HOAGLUND--John C.,Long-time fashion designer, died October 6, 2013, natural causes. Loving son of Carl and Evelyn, and brother to twin Joan and sister Jeanette. Memorial service, Tuesday, October 29 at 2pm, Church of the Incarnation, East 35th St. and Madison Ave., Manhattan.

HERSHKOFF--Sylvia, age 91, died peacefully at home on October 24, 2013. She was predeceased in 1999 by her beloved husband Martin. She is cherished by her children, Kenneth and Helen, son-in-law Stephen, grandchildren Lauren, Joshua, and Benjamin, and great-grandchildren Jordana and Ronen. Services are Friday, October 25, 10am at I. J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

EDELMAN--Ruth. The Board and staff of The Children's Aid Society express our condolences and deepest sympathy to Board Trustee Richard Edelman on the passing of his mother. Ruth was a nurturing wife and mother and tireless supporter of numerous health and nonprofit organizations. A critical behind the scenes force at the world's largest PR firm, Ruth was the Edelman matriarch and her late husband's most influential partner. Our thoughts are with her family, friends and colleagues. Mark Edmiston, Board Chairman Richard Buery, President and CEO

DANSKER--Norman, passed away peacefully at home on October 22, 2013. Norman is remembered foremost as the devoted husband of 66 years to his cherished Gloria, loving father to Susan and Robert, brother-in-law to Doris, brother to Penny, father-in-law to Joseph, and grandfather to Jonathan and Matthew. We are proud of the role that this lifelong New Yorker played in shaping the skyline of the city he loved. We will miss him very much. Condolences and Shiva inquiries may be sent to ndfamilynyc@gmail.com.

ANTHONY--Aristotle, Ph.D. Telly died peacefully at the age of 84 on Tuesday, October 22, 2013. Dearly loved and adored by his wife and best friend, Sari; his son, David and wife Mariann Lemke, and his daughter Jessie Anthony Weinberg and husband Lee. He was the adored "Poppie" to Sam and Toby Anthony and Charlie Weinberg. He is also survived by his sister, Thalia Hanson. Telly was an exceptional and compassionate psychologist in private practice for more than 50 years. In his work with children, adolescents and adults, he believed strongly that dreams and the human spirit had an important role in emotional healing. In the 1960s, as Director of Psychological Services in Ridgewood, NJ, he promoted art, music and play therapy for young children. An avid cross country runner, tennis player, and sailor, he spent years sailing the waters of Cape Cod and Long Island. He earned his Ph.D. at Columbia, where he was elected to the national research society of Sigma Xi. A celebration of his life will be held at his home on Friday, November 8 from 4pm to 8pm. Donations in his memory may be made to St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Division of Geriatric and Palliative Medicine, 1000 Tenth Avenue, Suite 3A-02, New York, NY 10019. His warmth and humor will be greatly missed by his family and friends.

ANGRIST--Jack, 92, of Lake Worth, FL, died October 19. Beloved husband of the late Florence Angrist. Devoted father of Karen Nannis, husband Mark and Richard Angrist, M.D. Grandfather of Kimberly, Kerri, Andrew and Brett. Great-grandfather of Brooke. Mr. Angrist served with distinction on the NYPD and retired as Deputy Chief Inspector. Expressions of sympathy may be sent to Chabad of West Palm Beach, 2112 N. Jog Rd., Suite 101, West Palm Beach, FL 33411.

ALTCHEK--Victor, MD. Dr. Victor Altchek of Palm Beach, FL and Manhattan passed away on October 23 at age 94. Beloved husband of Thiya Lulinsky Altchek, adored father of Caren Pauley and Dr. Douglas Altchek and cherished grandfather of Rachel, Muriel and Sarah and great-grandchildren Milo, Maia and Abigail. Accomplished surgeon, medical pioneer, and connoisseur of French 18th century furniture. He was predeceased by his first wife Muriel Lederman Altchek. Graveside funeral at Mt. Hebron on Friday, 11:30am. Shiva to follow at the office of Dr. Altchek, 115 East 61st Street and also on Sunday 47pm.

TURBEVILLE--Deborah. We deeply regret the passing of our dear friend Deborah Turbeville. We greatly value our long association with her and the wonderful, original photography she left behind. Her work is much admired and she will be missed. Staley-Wise Gallery

TURBEVILLE--Deborah. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our good friend, amazing artist and photographer Deborah Turbeville. It was a pleasure and an honor to work beside her. Love, Marek, Donna, Barbara and the staff of Marek & Associates

STERN--Lawrence H.,The Board of Governors and Members of the Elberon Bathing Club mourn the passing of our long time Member and dear friend, Larry Stern on October 21st. Larry was a giant in the community and a legend in the trucking industry whose swimming prowess should not be overlooked. The vision of him donning his swim-racing cap and swimming 100 laps every summer for charity in the EBC pool is a memory we will always cherish. He loved his daily swim and he loved a good joke. Always a smile. Always a warm "Hello!" Always remembered as the extraordinary man that he was. Larry, you are already sorely missed by all of us who were privileged to know you. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Fred and Andrew, the entire Stern family and to Larry's dear friend Kathryn Gross. Robert Fagenson, President Douglas Schwartz, Secretary

SCHILLING--Warner R.,died October 20, 2013, at age 88 at Englewood Hospital, Englewood, NJ. A long-time resident of Leonia, NJ, he grew up in the greater St. Louis area, served as a radio operator with the U.S. Army Air Forces, 194346, earned B.A., M.A., and Ph.D. degrees from Yale, and became an enthusiastic traveler on five continents. The James T. Shotwell Professor of International Relations Emeritus at Columbia University, he was director of the university's Institute of War and Peace Studies, 197686. For more than fifty years he guided several generations of students through the intricacies of American foreign policy, the causes of war, nuclear strategy, and the influence of technology on war and international relations. Beloved father of Jonathan and Frederick, father-in-law of Elaine, grandfather of Jeremy, uncle of Pauline and Alice, great-uncle of Gracie, Jimmy, and Billy. A memorial service at Columbia University will be announced. Donations may be made to the Pulmonary Rehabilitation Center at EHMC Foundation, 350 Engle Street, Englewood, N.J., 07631.

SCALORA--Frank S. Dr.,Died peacefully on October 25. He was 86. Devoted brother to Sophie Colavito and the late Josephine Martino. Loving uncle to Rosalie Intravaia, Olimpia Gambacorta and Josephine Russo. He graduated Harvard University and received his Ph.D in mathematics from the University of Illinois. A former longtime employee of IBM, he taught at Fordham University. Author of Abstract Martingale Convergence Theorems, March 1, 1961. He was an honorary member of the American Mathematical Society. Reposing Sisto Funeral Home 3489 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx on Sunday 2pm-5pm & 7pm-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:30am at the Church of Saint Benedict. Interment Saint Raymond Cemetery.

MAYER--Edmund, on October 24, 2013. Beloved husband of Lidia. Devoted father of Lawrence Mayer and Michelle Tuchinsky. Dear brother of Cecile Gertel. Adored grandfather and uncle. Services: Sunday, 12 noon at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, Long Island.

CARO--Sir Anthony, OM, CBE, 1924-2013, British sculptor who pioneered the practice of liberating sculpture from the pedestal and pushing the limits of sculptural abstraction. His prolific career spanned more than six decades, during which he was widely renowned as Britain's most important sculptor. David Nash, Lucy Mitchell-Innes and the directors and staff of Mitchell-Innes & Nash gallery send their condolences to Sheila Girling, his wife of 64 years, his sons, Timothy and Paul Caro, and the staff of the Caro/Girling studio.

BLAIR--George "Banana", 98, After an illustrious career as an entrepreneur and world-class water ski champion George Blair died at home on October 17, 2013. He was born in Toledo, OH. He attended Miami University of Ohio where he was a member of the Delta Upsilon Fraternity. In 1939 George married Dorothy Spies. They raised four daughters in Shrewsbury, NJ. His great business success was Hospital Portrait Service, based in Red Bank, NJ which offered the first photo of newborn babies in hospitals. In 1973 he married his second wife, JoAnne White. He was a founder of Shrewsbury State Bank, which was acquired later by Valley National Bank. It was as a water skier that George gained global recognition. After mastering the sport he opened water ski schools in NJ, teaching thousands. A pioneer of the sport of barefoot skiing George won awards and established world records. Dressed in his signature yellow wet suit, he became known as "Banana George." He was named Man of the Year by the American Barefoot Ski Club four times. In 1991 he was inducted into the Water Ski Hall of Fame. He became an avid snowboarder at age 75 and was named Honorary Ambassador of Steamboat Springs, CO. He is survived by his devoted wife of 40 years, JoAnne Blair of NYC; four daughters Donna Blair of GA; Georgia Blair and Alan Lopez of NJ; Carrie Blair of VA; and Robin Blair of NJ. He has four grandsons and four great-grandchildren. Donations to the American Water Ski Education Foundation website, George Blair Memorial Page http://www.waterskihalloffame.com/donate.html or mail to ASWEF 1251 Holy Cow Rd, Polk City FL 33868.

LEVY--Peter A.,a Celebration of Peter's Life will be held at the Metropolitan Club (One East 60th) on Monday, November 4th from 05:30pm 08:00 pm with a short remembrance at 06:30pm. Jacket and tie is required for gentlemen.

ZUCKERT--Donald M. "Don" 79, died Monday, October 14. A resident of Jupiter, FL, he had homes in New York City and New Castle, NH. Mr. Zuckert was born on April 3, 1934, in New York, the son of Sidney and Doris Zuckert. His career in advertising began in 1960 at Ted Bates where he ultimately assumed the position of chairman and CEO. Mr. Zuckert, a graduate of Bowdoin College '56, received a law degree from New York University in 1959. He was chairman of the Board of Trustees of Bowdoin from 2002-2005. In honor of his support for arts education, Bowdoin's Museum of Art dedicated the Zuckert Seminar Room in 2010. Anyone who came in contact with Don found him to be a friend and mentor, generous with his time and resources. His creativity, sharp wit, infectious laugh, flair for the written word and sparkling green eyes will be remembered by all who knew him. Mr. Zuckert is survived by his wife Susan, sons, Andrew (Karen) and Timothy (Carol), grandchildren: Maxfield, Samuel, Carlyn, Sally Rose, Abigail, and brother, Owen. Memorial contributions may be made to the Donald M. Zuckert Visiting Professorship Fund, Bowdoin College, 4100 College Station, Brunswick, ME 04011.

ZUCKERT--Donald. A wonderful best friend, kind, thoughtful, a great guy who cared about everyone he met and touched, a lover of his family and of life, Art, Bowdoin, golf, travel, guacamole and above all his special love, Sue. Our condolences to his children and grandchildren. Don will be terribly missed and will live in our hearts forever. Carole and Dan

WORTMAN--Mel. The Greenberger, Lieberbaum and Popkin families mourn the passing of Mel Wortman, the legendary director of Camps Baco/Che-Na-Wah. Mel and Ruth created a magical place that has enriched the lives of three generations of our family. Along with hundreds of others, we will be forever grateful for a life well lived. The Greenbergers, The Lieberbaums, The Popkins

WORTMAN--Melvin S. Melvin's productive and fulfilling lifetime ended October 25, 2013 at age 89. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Bob, Jerry, and Anita. Cherished grandfather of Melissa, Allison and Michael. Devoted father-in-law to Laurie and Barbara. A born Educator, Mel's careers - first as a Teacher, then as an Assistant Principal, and later as Principal in the New York City School System spanned many decades. In addition, since 1950, Mel excelled as Head Counselor and later as Owner/Director of two outstanding Children's Camps in the Adirondack Mountains of New York State. The children at Camp Baco for Boys and Camp Che-na-wah for Girls on beautiful Balfour Lake adore "Melvin J" as they affectionally called him. He loved to participate Sports, led great Services and Campfires, told wonderful Stories, and performed an outstanding "Inka Dinka Doo". Mel served as President of the Association of Private Camps. He also was President of the Laurelton Bnai Brith. Mel and his wife Ruth have lived an active lifestyle, dividing their time in three Residences located in Manhattan, New York, Minerva, New York, and Palm Beach, Florida. They also have developed a passion for World Travel, and they journeyed to 65 countries. Most of the trips were Independent Travel Adventures - just the two of them together - side by side. Mel's smile, warmth, sense of humor, and caring will be greatly missed. Funeral Service 9:30am, Sunday, October 27, 2013, at "The Riverside", Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, New York City. Interment Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

WINNICK-Gladys, nee Kaplan, on October 20, 2013, in her 92nd year. Gladys was a great wife, wonderful mother, and loving grandmother. She will be missed and fondly remembered by her husband Jerry, sister Sylvia, her sons, Wayne and Walter and granddaughter Samantha, and grandson Steven as well as her niece Madeline and nephew Edward. She accomplished much and helped many during her long life. May she rest in peace.

VAUGHAN--William Nulty, 93, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and formerly of Greenwich, CT, passed away on October 22, 2013. Bill, also known as "Willy" was the son of William W. Vaughan and Alice M. Vaughan of Red Bank, NJ. He graduated from Lawrenceville in 1938 and Princeton in 1942. Mr. Vaughan was a sergeant in the US Army during WWII. He became a member of the NYSE in 1946 and worked there until he retired in 2005 at the age of 85. Mr. Vaughan is survived by his beloved daughter, Diane and his three grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife, Alice, in 2005. Funeral services were private.

WHERRY--Grace Elizabeth, died October 22, daughter of the late Martha Herzig and Francis T. Maloney, United States Senator from Connecticut. Attended Trinity College and Yale School of Music. VANDERMOLEN--Wilhelmina J.,died unexpectedly October 24, 2013. She was a respected member of the Corps of UN Civil Servants for many years and provided invaluable support for journalists covering the UN from the United States and abroad. She was hired by Matt Gordon (father of New York Times reporter Michael R. Gordon) who was the official in charge of the UN press section during several crisis times and in more placid periods. He used to say he recommended Ms. Vandermolen for the job because of her abundance of common sense. After her retirement she developed talents as a water colorist; her work was accepted for several exhibitions. She is deeply missed by her longtime partner Michael Littlejohns. In a tribute her trainer at NYHC, Nathan Palmer, called her "an inspiration" for all of the members of their aerobics class. Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home is handling services.

URBAN--Xenia N.,on October 15, 2013, in her 94th year. Beloved mother of Alix, Xenia and Jere; devoted Nana of Emma, Alex, Chris, Anna, and Cam; loving great-grandmother of Aurelia. In our hearts forever.

PARKER--Jack S.,19182013 Jack Steele Parker, retired vice chairman and executive officer of General Electric Company (1968-1980) died at his home in Carefree, Arizona. Born in Palo Alto, California July 6, 1918, he received his BSME from Stanford University in 1939. In 1970 he received an Honorary Doctor of Business Administration from Southeastern Massachusettes University, and an Honorary Doctor of Law from Clark University in 1972 and from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in 1986. Mr. Parker started his career in 1939 in the ship building industry and during World War II was in charge of constructing 37 Liberty Ships. He joined General Electric in 1950 where his first assignment was in Richland, Washington, as manager of the Separations Division. He later moved to the Aircraft Propulsion Division in Cincinnati. In 1956, he became vice president, followed by his election as director, vice chairman, and executive officer of the company in 1968. He has served as a director of many other corporations, including J.G. Boswell, BHP Utah Minerals International, The Continental Group, Pan American World Airways, Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, Sturm-Ruger & Company, TRW, Inc., UNIVEX and Whitehall Corporation. Mr. Parker is a member of the National Academy of Engineering (Einstein Award recipient), the President's Circle of the National Academy of Sciences and a fellow of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. He is a distinguished Overseer and past chairman of the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace having served as an Overseer over 40 years; Trustee Emeritus of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute; past chairman and Counselor for Life of the Conference Board; Life Trustee of the Heard Museum; Life Member, Past President and Sagamore Hill Award recipient of the Boone & Crockett Club; Life Member, Past President and Big Horse recipient of Conquistadors del Cielo; Old Guard member of The Bohemian Club; Chairman Emeritus Aircraft Industries Association and of the Wildlife Management Institute; Life Member Audubon Society, The Question Club and Trout Unlimited. He is a member of Beta Theta Pi, Lamba Sigma Chapter; Circumnavigators Club; Commercial Club and Commonwealth Club of Cincinnati; Council of Financial Aid to Education and the Camp Fire Club of America. He is a former Director of the Smithsonian Institution, the Monterey Bay Aquarium, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the National Association of Manufacturers and the American Enterprise Institute. He was a Trustee of St. Louis University and a distinguished achievement award recipient of the Wings Club. Throughout his life Jack Parker was an avid sportsman. He was an excellent shot having taken all five of the major African animals and on one occasion shot 299 straight clays in trap competition. He shot all the major North American mammals except a polar bear. His hunting included a tiger in India and ibex & Argali sheep in western Mongolia. For the last 30 years he shot grouse and pheasant in southern Scotland and northern England as well as ducks and pheasant at Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club where he has been a member for 53 years. His bird shooting also included trips to Spain and Argentina. He is an Endowment member of the National Rifle Association. Fishing was another sport Jack loved, especially fly fishing for Atlantic salmon on the Panoi River in northern Russia and the Moisie, the Restigouche and the Miramichi in Canada; as well as trout in Alaska and bonefish, permit and tarpon on the east coast of Mexico. He was also a great golfer having been a member of Augusta National Golf Club for some 50 years. On one occasion at Augusta he eagled the par five 13th twice in one day the first time from the Members tee and the second time from the Professional tee. He is also a member of the Blind Brook Club, Desert Forest Golf Club and the U.S. Seniors Golf Association. Elaine, his wife and Light of His Life' for over 60 years joined Jack on many of his safaris in Africa, fishing in Alaska and bird shooting at Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club. She predeceased him in 2005 and he is survived by their daughter, Kaaren Parker Gray of New York City and Connecticut. As Jack S. Parker was prone to say, I think we have done everything we came here to do.
MAZER--Bill. I grew up watching you, and then was fortunate to work with you. You were a mentor and a friend. Bruce Murray

MARLIN--Stanley, died October 20, 2013 in Laguna Woods, California at age 86. Interior Designer. Graduate of High School of Music and Art and Pratt Institute. Masters, Columbia University. 1970's to 1980's Administrator at Julia Richman High School and Director of Talent Unlimited High School. Survived by loving wife, Eileen, sister Lyda and spouse Robert Frielich, children Beth, David, Evan, their spouses George Lichter, Debra Marlin, Marian Marlin, and grandchildren Rachael, Hannah, Rebekah, Ciara, Ian, Joseph and spouse Bianca.

LIPSCHUTZ--Abraham. Abraham (Abbie) Lipschutz passed away at age 92 on October 21, 2013 surrounded by family and friends. Born in Holland, he was a fighter (WWII, Israel's War of Independence), writer, diamond merchant and Lebenskunstler. His memoir, "Child of the 20th Century" is available at www.jewishcurrents.org. Survivors include wife, Isabelle Ganz, sisters Miriam and Ruth, children Ronnie, Jonathan, Tamara, Gabrielle and Griffin (Debra), ten grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A celebration of his life will be held at Congregation Beth Israel in Houston on December 8, 2013, 3pm.

LONGLEY--Robert Fulton, 80, of Salisbury, CT and Nantucket, of a stroke on October 7. Born in Des Moines, IA, son of Rev. Harry S. and Agnes Longley. A 1955 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, he later served there as Dean of Men and Director of Alumni Relations. In 1967 he joined Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. in New York City and became a Senior Vice President and Director of Community Relations and Public Affairs. He retired in 1990 and founded The Salisbury Group, an executive search firm for not-for-profit organizations. He was a volunteer firefighter, private pilot, talented pianist, golfer, fisherman and photographer. Aside from family, his greatest love was Nantucket, where his grandparents began spending summers in the early 1900s. It is where he and his entire family have spent the happiest times of their lives. Survived by his wife of 56 years, the former Nancy Dempster; his children Anne, Amy, and Robert Longley and Jennifer Lynch; three grandchildren; his sister Lucinda Slate; and six nieces and nephews. Preceded in death by sister Nancy Agnew. A Memorial Service 11am November 1 at St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury. Interment next summer in Siasconset Union Chapel columbarium on Nantucket. Gifts appreciated to the 'Sconset Chapel, The 'Sconset Trust, or St. John's.

LINDAU--David Steuer, former managing partner of the New York law firm Holtzmann, Wise and Shepard; advisor to numerous charitable institutions; and moral compass for many, died at his home in Sleepy Hollow on Saturday. He was 87. Mr. Lindau was a labor lawyer who represented a broad range of clients including Allen & Company, the New York Daily News, and Syntex. He practiced law for more than 40 years. Mr. Lindau was born in New York, received a BA from Swarthmore College, and a law degree from Yale Law School. Mr. Lindau is survived by his three children Dan Lindau (Jane) and Maggie Nielsen, both of Chappaqua, and Peter Lindau (Stacy) of Chicago; a sister, Jackie Marlin of Washington, DC; and eight grandchildren. His marriage to Josie Grossman Lindau ended with her death in 2008. A fierce lifelong defender of equal rights, David Lindau served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services; on the Executive Board of the Legal Defense Fund of the N.A.A.C.P.; as President of the Board of Education of Hawthorne Cedar Knolls; and as member of and contributor to countless other human rights, justice, and arts-related causes. Equally passionate about his family, he counseled and guided his children and grandchildren to engage in pursuits that served the greater good. Perhaps the only views of his that wavered were those regarding New York sports teams. He went with the winners.

LEFCOURT--Florence. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and mentor, Florence Lefcourt, executive director of the NYSGE. She was the guiding force of our society and an invaluable partner during each of our years as president. Our heartfelt condolences to Marc and the entire Lefcourt family. Jerome H. Siegel M.D. Seth A. Cohen M.D. Franklin E. Kasmin M.D.

LEFCOURT--Florence. The New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy mourns the passing and celebrates the life of our dear friend, first executive director, and society matriarch Florence Lefcourt. For 40 years, Florence provided continuity and administrative leadership to the society as it grew from eight pioneers to the nation's largest regional gastrointestinal endoscopy society. She was tireless in directing her exceptional energies toward the education of young endoscopy trainees and more than any other non-physician, influenced the quality of endoscopy education and impacted the lives and practices of gastroenterologists in the greater New York area and around the country. She is much loved and will be long remembered.

LANDAU--Peter. Institutional Investor Magazine mourns the loss of its former distinguished editor Peter Landau, 80, who passed away in New York on October 23. During the 1970s and early 1980s his high standards and gifted skills in assigning and editing feature-length stories about personalities and drama of high finance and investing contributed to establishing the magazine as the leading publication in its field.

KAHN--Stanley, on October 25, 2013. Survived by his loving son Gary (Kristina), his dear brother Mike (Joan), his precious grandson Oskar, his adored nephew Doug and his ex-wife Maxine. For many years Stanley was an integral part of Croscill Home Furnishings. Services Sunday 10:30am at Sutton Place Synagogue 225 E. 51st St with interment at New Montefiore Cemetery. For more info, visit the Star of David Memorial Chapels website www.jewish-funeral-home.com

HOBEL--Philip Sherman, 92, of New York City and East Hampton, died peacefully at home on Wednesday, October 23, surrounded by loving family and caregivers. Founder and owner of The Cinema Guild, Hobel-Leiterman Productions and Document Associates, and producer and distributor of scores of award-winning television series, documentaries and features, notably "Tender Mercies," which was nominated for five Academy Awards, including Best Picture, and which won two. A Manhattan native, 1942 graduate of Columbia College, and proud U.S. Navy veteran, having served as a lieutenant in the Pacific theatre during WWII, he founded and operated the Cortland Furniture Company, a leading manufacturer and wholesaler of furniture, after the war and until 1970 when he entered the television and film business. Beloved husband of Mary-Ann (nee Hirsch) for 63 years, devoted father of Joseph (Marjorie), Michael (Michal), and Sara (Scott Mendel). Loving grandfather of Zachary and Samuel Hobel, Adam and Ethan Hobel, and Madeleine and Cleo Gordon. Dear son of Joseph and Celia Hobel (nee Goldberg) and loving brother of Bernice Hobel, who predeceased him. Philip will be deeply missed by his family and by his many friends and mentees. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Philip's memory to the Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer's Disease and the Aging Brain at Columbia University (https://giving.columbia.edu/ giveonline/?schoolstyle=523).

JAVER--Stanley. Beloved father, husband, grandfather, 81, died after a short battle with cancer. A one of a kind man who lived life on his own terms and to the fullest. Stan loved his family and was extremely charitable to all those in need. He was pre-deceased by his wife Renee and is survived by his sons Scott and Harry, grandsons Jason, Corey, Jack, daughter-in-law Elizabeth, Susan, and hundreds of friends. He will be forever loved and remembered.

GOODMAN--Walter Flato, A world-renowned breeder-owner-handler of Skye Terriers and an American Kennel Club judge died October 6 in Miami, FL at 91. An enthusiastic traveler who traversed the globe nine times, Goodman was also a patron of the arts and a Life Trustee of Villa Vizcaya. Born to Maurice and Adele Goodman on August 15, 1922 in Rye NY, Goodman followed his father's advice to "Live up to your name: "Good-man." After graduating from Rumsey Hall and the Hotchkiss School, Mr. Goodman attended Yale University ('44). He interrupted his studies in January 1943 to join the United States Army. By the end of WWII, Goodman was second in command of a U.S. P.O.W. camp on the outskirts of Antwerp, Belgium housing 1,700 German soldiers. Following the War, Mr. Goodman completed his bachelor's degree in International Relations at Yale and later earned a Masters in History at Columbia University. Although Goodman worked as a trust officer at the Bank of New York, an associate producer at NBC and at Mike Ellis Productions, his true life's work and passion was in the sport of purebred dogs. His mother Adele founded Glamoor Kennels in 1937 with Walter joining in soon after, and Glamoor Kennels became known as one of the top Skye Terrier kennels in the world, breeding American, Canadian, French and Italian champions. Goodman's dogs earned a record 300 Terrier Group Firsts and 99 Best-in-Shows including Westminster Kennel Club's, where he handled Ch. Glamoor Good News to a Best-in-Show in 1969. After retiring from the show ring in 1975 to become an AKC judge, Goodman judged dog shows worldwide for 36 years, including Best-In-Show at Westminster Kennel Club in 1994. As the Skye Terrier Club of America's delegate, Mr. Goodman was elected to the American Kennel Club Board of Directors in 1988 serving for an unprecedented 24 years to March 2012. Goodman was a long-standing member of Westminster Kennel Club, Westbury Kennel Club, The Kennel Club (UK), Morris & Essex Kennel Club, and Palm Beach Dog Fanciers. He was proudest of having served as President for 28 years at Montgomery County Kennel Club, the club that sponsors the largest, most celebrated all-terrier show in the world in Blue Bell, PA each October. Goodman's innumerable contributions to the world of purebred dogs included his being a founding member of the AKC Museum of the Dog and of the Canine Health Foundation. As a Member of the University of Pennsylvania's School of Veterinary Medicine Board of Overseers, he co-founded along with Robert A. Flanders the Walter Flato Goodman Center for Comparative Medical Genetics. Goodman's recent honors include the American Kennel Club's Lifetime Achievement Award in 2011 and his induction into the Anne Rogers Clark Hall of Fame at the Show Dogs of the Year Awards in 2013. A resident of Miami, FL since 1973, Walter is survived by his son Robert A. Flanders, five nieces and nephews, three great-nieces, his many close friends, and his beloved Norfolk Terrier, Gypsy. A memorial "Celebration of Life" will be held early next year. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Walter Flato Goodman Center for Comparative Medical Genetics, School of Veterinary Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, 3800 Spruce Street, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6008.

GILBERT--Lee, age 94, died peacefully at home on October 25th. Loving wife of the late Irving Gilbert, she is survived by her children Richard, Larry and Arlene and grandchildren Eric and Assunta, Adam, Tracy, and Jay. She will be remembered for making the best of all life dealt her and smiling through it all.

FOX--Mary Ellen, nee Dwyer, on October 8. Adored mother of six, loving grandmother of 12, dear sister of Kathleen and Bill. 1951 graduate of Manhattanville. Memorial Mass in Westhampton, NY to be announced.

FORSTEN--MICHELE I.,age 59, passed away on October 23. From Coney Island, Michele will be remembered by all who loved her for her work in communications and as a creative writer, singer, jokester, and loyal friend. She is survived by her spouse, Barbara, sister Marla, cousins Binky, Jeanie, Robin and Joan, and her many good friends.

DICKSTEIN--Paul. The Board of Directors and staff of Healthfirst mourn the loss of Paul Dickstein, our founding CEO. Built from the ground up in 1993, Healthfirst was a major managed care organization by the time Paul left in 2007. His originality, keen intellect and force of personality were essential to persuade otherwise unaffiliated healthcare organizations to work together to create one of the most successful provider-sponsored health plans in the country, a prototype for an insurance-based accountable care organization. He cared deeply about increasing access to decent health insurance, especially for underserved communities. He gave many people at Healthfirst their first careers and will be remembered with great admiration and affection. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Robin, his children Isabel, Anthony, and Veronica, and his sisters Linda and Diane. Donald Ashkenase, Chairman Pat Wang, President and CEO

DANTER--Ottillie, 94, of Westport, CT, October 25, 2013 at her home. Former owner of Prestige Theatre Parties. Survived by children Joan Frimmer, Lewis Bader and Edward Danter, eight grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren. Services Sunday, October 27, 2013 at 1:30pm from Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Rd. Westport.

CURRAN--Ann Miller, 82, of Missoula, MT, passed away October 17, 2013, following a battle with Lewy Body Dementia. She was born in Brooklyn, NY. Ann pre-deceased her sisters Judith (Childs) and Elizabeth (Dodge) son, David Loewenwarter (Maureen) of Missoula, MT; daughter Andrea Loewenwarter (Jim Gillespie) of Fairfax, VA; adopted daughters Andrea Curran, Tucson, AZ and Tracey Curran (Brian Herman) Minnetonka, MN. The family requests memorial contributions for the purpose of Lewy Body Dementia be sent to: Mayo Clinic, Dept. of Development, 4500 San Pablo Road, Jacksonville, FL 32224. Please note that the gift is in memory of Ann M. Curran and checks can be made out to Mayo Clinic. Her family thanks you.

CUMINGS-HOOD--Eleanor. died on October 14th at age 98. Born in Logansport, Indiana, she graduated from the University of Chicago, where she met and married Edgar C. Cumings. He died in 1988 after 50 years of marriage; in 1999 she married Eugene Hood and lived happily with him for five years until his passing. Loving mother of three sons, she also took great pride in her years as head of the Philosophy Library at Stanford University. Predeceased by her sons Robert and Richard, she is survived by her son Bruce Cumings.

CROSBIE--William R.,of Tarrytown, NY. Retired judge; naturalist; community leader. "Wisdom and wit" describe him well. Born January, 27 1924; raised in Cuba and Southbridge, MA. Graduated Suffield Academy, Princeton University (1945); US Army captain WWII. MBA, NYU; JD, NY Law School; editor, Law Review. Led new business ventures Cuban-American Sugar Co. and Union Carbide Corp.; VP, Corporate Market Dev. Manufacturers Hanover (Chase). Tarrytown Village Trustee; Westchester County Legislator. Brigadier General, NY Guard Reserve. Predeceased Mary Ann Hazelton, wife; survived by six daughters, 15 grandchildren, three great-grandchildren.

COX--Stanley E.,died October 20. Chairman Horizon Hotels Board Member Doral Arrowwood. Predeceased by wife Helen, survived by daughters Cindy (Mike), Diane (Bob) Donna (Joe), grandchildren Helen, Megan, Jason, current wife Francine. Service November 11, St. Patrick's Cathedral (Lady Chapel) 4pm.

CHALMERS--Douglas Alexander Stewart, MD of Basking Ridge, NJ and Greentown, PA passed away on May 30, 2013. His ashes were inurned at The Brick Presbyterian Church of New York City following a memorial service. Dr. Chalmers was born in Portland, OR on September 12, 1934 to Earl John Chalmers and Jennie Sherwood Chalmers. He grew up in Portland and graduated from Oregon State University in 1955. After a year of post-graduate study at Dartmouth College, he was commissioned into the United States Navy, where he served his country as a line officer with the Sixth Fleet. He then earned his MD degree, cum laude, at the University of Oregon Medical School, finishing second in his class. He completed his residency at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in New York. He then practiced orthopaedic surgery and sports medicine in Short Hills and Florham Park, NJ, serving on the staff of both St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, NJ and at Overlook Hospital in Summit, NJ. Dr. Chalmers was an avid tennis player and golfer, and a proud Republican. A gifted second tenor, he was a member of the University Glee Club of New York City for nearly 40 years. Dr. Chalmers is survived by his son Douglas Chalmers, Jr. of Johns Creek, GA, his daughter Cameron Chalmers Maguire of Atlanta, GA, and his son Christopher Chalmers of Millburn, NJ, all by his former wife Judith Chalmers Simpson of Summit, NJ; by seven grandchildren; by his sister Jacqueline Loomis of Jacksonville, FL; and by his longtime partner Frances G. Laserson of New York City and Quogue, NY and her daughters Tenley L. Chepiga and Galen G. Laserson. He was predeceased by his brother John Chalmers of San Francisco, CA. His family and friends will long remember Dr. Chalmers as a warm, sweet gentleman who loved to laugh and loved adventure. Donations in his memory may be made to the University Glee Club of New York City, 25 Point Road, Norwalk CT 06854.

CASSELL--Elisabeth. With sadness and a profound sense of loss, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records the death of our devoted member and generous benefactor Elisabeth Cassell in her home on October 18 at the age of 101. Born in Czechoslovakia, she was Miss Czechoslovakia in the early 1930's but the rise of Nazism forced her life in a new direction. One of seven children of Berta Rosenblum and Morris Gruenfeld, she and two sisters (now deceased) were the only family members to survive the Shoah. Her happiest years were those she shared with her beloved husband, Marvin, who was a pioneer in the liquor industry and the importer of Amaretto into the United States. A woman of strong moral convictions, Mrs. Cassell devoted herself to philanthropic causes and especially to Temple Emanu-El following Marvin's death in 1995. Interment was private. We wish her eternal peace. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President

BUCKNER--John Crawford, PhD. (age 55) of Weston, MA and Marstons Mills, MA, died unexpectedly of natural causes on September 29, 2013. Born in Boston, on October 3, 1957, Dr. Buckner was raised in Seattle, where he graduated from the Lakeside School. He went onto Stanford University, graduating with honors and distinction in Psychology. He subsequently received a PhD in Psychology from the University of Maryland followed by a research career in psychiatric epidemiology and prevention at the National Institutes of Mental Health, the National Center on Family Homelessness, and finally at the Harvard Children's Hospital Boston. Dr. Buckner published widely and lectured on the topics of community cohesion, the effects of homelessness and poverty on children, and on the concept of self-regulation in children. He took his work beyond his academic role by founding and running the non-profit organization, Community Resources Information, Inc., that operates the widely used website: www.massresources.org. The website provides information on resources that address basic needs of individuals and families. Outside his career, John was known as a superb athlete excelling in baseball in high school and college. He had become an outstanding golfer and was proud of winning the Willowbend Senior Club Championship in 2013. He climbed Mt. Kilimanjaro twice in his life, most recently in 2012 with his daughter Mila followed by a memorable safari with both Mila and his daughter, Kimberly. He enjoyed following current events and financial investments, his dogs, traveling, golfing, Cape Cod and keeping up with close friends. He was known for his generosity and kindness, his intellectual capacity, gentle manner and staying power. Above all, John was a loving and devoted family man who will be dearly missed. He is survived by his beloved wife, Dr. Elizabeth Cousins Buckner, his daughters Kimberly of New York and Mila of San Francisco, a brother, Dr. Frederick S. Buckner of Seattle, a sister, Catherine B. Hobbs of Corte Madera, CA, his mother, Ann S. Buckner of Seattle, and his father, Philip F. Buckner of Seattle and New York.

BRODER--Gloria Kurian, died in Marin County, CA on October 18, 2013. Born in 1927, she was raised in Detroit, MI. She received a BA from the University of Michigan and an MA in English and Creative Writing from Stanford University. She published stories in Harper's, Ploughshares, Bellevue Literary Review, Literary Imagination, and other literary magazines. Her story, "Elena, Unfaithful," was anthologized in Little Brown's "Great American Love Stories." She and her husband Bill Broder co-authored a novel, "Remember This Time." Her book of short stories, "Their Magician and Other Stories," was published in 2005. Gloria was known and loved for her remarkable ability to listen and respond to the humanity of others. Her survivors include her husband of 57 years, two children, a grandson, three sisters and many others who understood the unique beauty of her character. The family invites you to an open house at 68 Central Avenue, Sausalito, CA from 4pm to 7pm on Sunday, November 3, 2013. Food, drinks and parking assistance will be provided. No flowers please.

BRAGG, Edward H. Jr. of Greenwich, CT, passed away on October 21, 2013 at his home with his beloved wife and family by his side. He is survived by Margaret, his wife of 49 years, three sons, Philip, James, and Winston, his daughter-in-law, Jen and two grandchildren, Lily Elisabeth and Chase Edward. He was the only son of Edward and Hilda Bragg and was born in White Plains, NY on October 31, 1931. He was a graduate of Brunswick School, Princeton University, the Officer Candidate School at the United States Coast Guard Academy, and Harvard Business School. He served two years on the Coast Guard Search & Rescue duty in the Atlantic and one year as Commanding Officer of a LORAN station in the Pacific French Frigate Shoals on Tern Island, the smallest inhabited island in the world. He was a partner and managing director of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the investment counsel firm, with 35 years in the role of managing individual and institutional portfolios. His clients were domestic, European, and Middle Eastern. He was widely respected and admired in the investment counseling field and served as a highly regarded mentor to many of his colleagues at Scudder. He was a leader at Camp Dudley in Westport, NY and frequent visitor and supporter of Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, NY. He was a member of Round Hill Club, the Union Club, John's Island Club and Mill Reef Club. Present and past outside activities have included Board Membership in the "Save the Field" (Sabine Farm) program, "Return the Light" (Great Captains Island), American Bible Society, Naval War College Foundation, Historical Society of Greenwich, Greenwich Land Trust, Bruce Museum, Brunswick School, the Independent College Fund of New York and Indian River Land Trust. Memorial gifts may be made to Christ Church Greenwich or to the Bragg Memorial Academic Fund at the Naval War College Fdn., Cushing Road, Newport, RI 02841-1213. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT, on Saturday, November 9th at 11am.

BRADY--Richard A.,79, Senior Counsel at Covington & Burling LLP, passed away peacefully on October 22, 2013 surrounded by his family. Dick was born in Newark, NJ and graduated from Yale University in 1956 and Yale Law School in 1959. Dick spent his entire career as a tax lawyer at Covington & Burling, in addition to serving on active duty in the United States Army during the 1961 Berlin crisis. He was a trusted advisor to many clients over his career. Dick took special pride in mentoring young lawyers and was known by his colleagues as a thoughtful teacher. He was an avid reader of history, a world-class oenophile, and a devout Catholic. His greatest joy was spending time with his family at their house in Bethany Beach. Dick is survived by his wife Kathleen (Tink), four children, Cecilia Brady of New York, NY, Kathleen Brady of Fairfax, VA, Andrew Brady, and Joshua Brady, both of Chevy Chase, MD, and five grandchildren, Gavin, Colin, Amelia, Ava, and Grayson. Viewing is on Monday, October 28, 2013 between 6:00 - 8:00pm at Joseph Gawler's Sons Funeral Home, 5130 Wisconsin Ave, NW, Washington, DC. Funeral is on Tuesday, October 29, 2013 at 10:00am at St. Bartholomew's Catholic Church, 6900 River Rd, Bethesda, MD 20817.

BRADSHAW--Joanna, age 74, of Fort Lee, formerly of Manhattan, on Thursday, October 24, 2013. Born in New York City she was known as an "icon" in home furnishing retailing. She is survived by her brothers Gregory and Nicholas Bradshaw. Visiting Tuesday 10-11am at the Frank A. Patti and Kenneth Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main Street, Fort Lee. Religious Service will begin at 11:00am. For directions, or information call (201) 944-0100. www.frankpatti.com

BOWYER--Gordon, Loving and dedicated husband and father, died peacefully at his home in Vero Beach, FL on October 21 at the age of 80. Gordon and his wife Carolyn raised their family in Summit, New Jersey and also lived in New York City. For over forty years Gordon enjoyed a career in the investment management industry. He was President at Credit Suisse Asset Management in New York City; he advised clients and managed portfolios at James C. Edwards Company and Cole, Yeager & Wood among other firms. Gordon is survived by his wife Carolyn, his son Matthew of London, England, his daughter Elizabeth Laarouchi of New York City and four grandchildren. A service will be held at Christ Church in Summit, NJ on October 29 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made in Gordon's memory to The Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (JDRF).

ARESTY--David R.,56, on October 23rd, 2013. David was a loving husband, father, and Vice President of Distribution at Alfred Dunner, Inc. He survived a bone marrow transplant in 1989 and a liver transplant in 2012. Through strength, determination, and courage, he lived a full and beautiful life. He will be remembered for his love of Alabama football, family, and fast cars. He will be missed by Patti, Adam, Holly, Rachel, Danny, Benjamin and the family dogs Mandy, Marcy, Ace, and Olivia, as well as his extended family at Alfred Dunner and the community. His family is extremely grateful to Dr. Steven Papish of Morristown Medical Center, Dr. Jim Armitage and Dr. Phil Bierman of the University of Nebraska Medical Center, Dr. Michael F. Sorrell, Dr. Wendy Grant, and the entire transplant team at UNMC who gave him the gift of life. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Monday at Temple B'nai Or, 60 Overlook Rd. in Morristown, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the University of Nebraska Foundation c/o the David and Patti Aresty Fund, attn. Amy Volk 2285 S. 67th Street, Suite 200, Omaha NE, 68106. Services by Bernheim, Apter & Kreitzman Funeral Home of Livingston, NJ.

ANTHONY--Aristotle, Ph.D. Telly died peacefully at the age of 84 on Tuesday, October 22, 2013. Dearly loved and adored by his wife and best friend, Sari; his son, David and wife Mariann Lemke, and his daughter Jessie Anthony Weinberg and husband Lee. He was the adored "Poppie" to Sam and Toby Anthony and Charlie Weinberg. He is also survived by his sister, Thalia Hanson. Telly was an exceptional and compassionate psychologist in private practice for more than 50 years. In his work with children, adolescents and adults, he believed strongly that dreams and the human spirit had an important role in emotional healing. In the 1960s, as Director of Psychological Services in Ridgewood, NJ, he promoted art, music and play therapy for young children. An avid cross country runner, tennis player, and sailor, he spent years sailing the waters of Cape Cod and Long Island. He earned his Ph.D. at Columbia, where he was elected to the national research society of Sigma Xi. A celebration of his life will be held at his home on Friday, November 8 from 4pm to 8pm. Donations in his memory may be made to St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Division of Geriatric and Palliative Medicine, 1000 Tenth Avenue, Suite 3A-02, New York, NY 10019. His warmth and humor will be greatly missed by his family and friends.

ANGRIST--Jack, 92, of Lake Worth, FL, died October 19. Beloved husband of the late Florence Angrist. Devoted father of Karen Nannis, husband Mark and Richard Angrist, M.D. Grandfather of Kimberly, Kerri, Andrew and Brett. Great-grandfather of Brooke. Mr. Angrist served with distinction on the NYPD and retired as Deputy Chief Inspector. Expressions of sympathy may be sent to Chabad of West Palm Beach, 2112 N. Jog Rd., Suite 101, West Palm Beach, FL 33411.

WEINBERG-GARCIA--Carol, passed away on October 26, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Trev. Devoted mother of Danielle Garcia. Loving sister of Paul, Barbara (Myles) and Richard (Chris). Cherished daughter of the late Mildred and Robert Weinberg and daughter-in-law of Sally and Lou Garcia. Carol brought joy to all who knew her and we were blessed to have had her in our lives. Services Monday 9:45am on October 28, 2013 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

VAUGHAN--William Nulty, 93, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and formerly of Greenwich, CT, passed away on October 22, 2013. Bill, also known as "Willy" was the son of William W. Vaughan and Alice M. Vaughan of Red Bank, NJ. He graduated from Lawrenceville in 1938 and Princeton in 1942. Mr. Vaughan was a sergeant in the US Army during WWII. He became a member of the NYSE in 1946 and worked there until he retired in 2005 at the age of 85. Mr. Vaughan is survived by his beloved daughter, Diane and his three grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife, Alice, in 2005. Funeral services were private.

SCHIFRIN--William, passed away on October 24, at age 95 in Pittsfield, MA. Known as the mayor of 47th Street and his passion for life leaves his wife Doris of 70 years, his two loving daughters Gayle (Herman) and Ivy (Andrew), and his two grandchildren Asher and Dustin. Request that any donations be sent to the Jewish War Veterans. Expressions of sympathy be sent to handgrow@aol.com

REICHMANN--Paul.We mourn the loss of a friend and mentor who shared our vision in the 1980's to build a formidable and beautiful traditional Jewish Living Center at one of our nation's premiere secular universities. The Senior Alumni of The Center for Jewish Living at Cornell University

REICH--Diane, 83, of Westbury, NY on October 26, 2013. Loving and beloved wife of the late Ismar Reich, mother of Helen Rothman, Arnold and Andrew Reich, mother-in-law of Donna LaMagna, grandfather of Jonathan and Jordan Rothman, sister of Marian Friedmann, sister-in-law of the late Peter Friedmann, aunt of Eric Friedmann, Irene Barbazetto, Elizabeth and Jessica Friedmann. Beloved by large and loving family of cousins, relatives and friends. Attained BA in History from Brooklyn College in 1952 and MBA from Hofstra University in 1981. Active in community organizations throughout her life. Services today, Monday, 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NYC (at Amsterdam Avenue).

PANZIRER--Grace. Our deepest condolences go to Craig Panzirer and his daughters Devon and Maren on the loss of their wife and mother, Grace. So many of us at CBRE are lucky to count Craig as a close industry colleague and a friend, and we join with Vornado and others across our industry and community in expressing our heartfelt condolences. The CBRE family

MARLIN--Stanley, died October 20, 2013 in Laguna Woods, California at age 86. Interior Designer. Graduate of High School of Music and Art and Pratt Institute. Masters, Columbia University. 1970's to 1980's Administrator at Julia Richman High School and Director of Talent Unlimited High School. Survived by loving wife, Eileen, sister Lyda and spouse Robert Frielich, children Beth, David, Evan, their spouses George Lichter, Debra Marlin, Marian Marlin, and grandchildren Rachael, Hannah, Rebekah, Ciara, Ian, Joseph and spouse Bianca.

LINDAU--David S.The Board, staff and clients of Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services has lost a friend, trusted advisor and past President of our Board in David. His sage advice as a labor attorney was invaluable, and his devotion to the children we serve, especially at our campus in Hawthorne, was legendary. He will be sorely missed, and we mourn his loss alongside his many friends and children, Dan, Maggie and Peter. His memory will surely be a blessing at JBFCS.
KAISER--Ita (nee Schwarz), Beloved sister, Holocaust survivor of Bergen-Belsen and other camps. Herman Schwarz and Family

KAISER--Ita, on October 26, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Steven and Alan, and daughters-in-law Vivian and Debbie. Cherished grandmother of Emily, Kara, Jeffrey, Jonathan and Abby. In lieu of flowers, the Kaiser family respectfully requests donations be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage.

FORSTEN--MICHELE I.,age 59, passed away on October 23. From Coney Island, Michele will be remembered by all who loved her for her work in communications and as a creative writer, singer, jokester, and loyal friend. She is survived by her spouse, Barbara, sister Marla, cousins Binky, Jeanie, Robin and Joan, and her many good friends.

COOPER--Nathalie B. (Seid), died peacefully on October 25, 2013. Her 95th birthday on September 5 was celebrated with much loved family. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Harry. She is survived and cherished by her daughter Patty and David Raff, adored grandchildren Kenny Raff and Sherri and Todd Gordon, precious great-grandchildren Jake and Danielle Gordon, and her sister Eugenie S. Kroop and loving nieces Elizabeth and Susan and nephew Steven. Services today at 1:30pm at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels Hewlett, LI.

CARO--Sir Anthony, OM, CBE, 1924-2013, British sculptor who pioneered the practice of liberating sculpture from the pedestal and pushing the limits of sculptural abstraction. His prolific career spanned more than six decades, during which he was widely renowned as Britain's most important sculptor. David Nash, Lucy Mitchell-Innes and the directors and staff of Mitchell-Innes & Nash gallery send their condolences to Sheila Girling, his wife of 64 years, his sons, Timothy and Paul Caro, and the staff of the Caro/Girling studio.

BRODLIEB--Barbara. Cherished daughter of the late Theodore and Gertrude, step-daughter of Shirley, beloved mother of Oliver and Taryn, loving sister of Ken and Marc, dear aunt of Tim, Kim, Andrew, and Samantha, adoring grandmother of Charlie. Let your soul live free. Services Tuesday, 12pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, LI. Interment to follow at the NewMontefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

BRODER--Gloria Kurian, died in Marin County, CA on October 18, 2013. Born in 1927, she was raised in Detroit, MI. She received a BA from the University of Michigan and an MA in English and Creative Writing from Stanford University. She published stories in Harper's, Ploughshares, Bellevue Literary Review, Literary Imagination, and other literary magazines. Her story, "Elena, Unfaithful," was anthologized in Little Brown's "Great American Love Stories." She and her husband Bill Broder co-authored a novel, "Remember This Time." Her book of short stories, "Their Magician and Other Stories," was published in 2005. Gloria was known and loved for her remarkable ability to listen and respond to the humanity of others. Her survivors include her husband of 57 years, two children, a grandson, three sisters and many others who understood the unique beauty of her character. The family invites you to an open house at 68 Central Avenue, Sausalito, CA from 4pm to 7pm on Sunday, November 3, 2013. Food, drinks and parking assistance will be provided. No flowers please.

BARNETT--Sally Ellen, 86, recently of Manhattan, died in Ridgefield, Connecticut on Sunday, October 27. Daughter of Pearl and A.N. Barnett of Brooklyn, she is survived by her devoted children Patricia Zohn and Robert Zohn, her adoring grandchildren Camilla, Nicholas, Abigail and Patrick and her loving sister Barbara Goldfarb. She was predeceased by her sister Dr. Marjorie Barnett of Chicago and her former husband Arnold Zohn, a publishing executive. She was the editor of the Lincoln Log at Abraham Lincoln High School and continued her literary endeavors at the University of Wisconsin. Also a talented painter, tennis player and dedicated distance walker, Sally edited the Dimonstein Express Newsletter and was a residential broker at Douglas Elliman. Her family, along with many friends, will remember her generosity and kindness, her elegance and beauty, her love of culture and the arts and a keen and curious mind. Services at the Riverside Memorial Chapel (180 West 76th St at Amsterdam Ave.) Tuesday at 9:30am.

AULETTA-ARMENISE--Dr. Giovanni. Appeal of Conscience Foundation mourns our dedicated International Trustee whose commitment to religious freedom, inter-religious cooperation and tolerance will remain an inspiration. Sincere condolences to his son Giampiero (Marika) and family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, President Archbishop Khajag Barsamian Cardinal Theodore R. McCarrick, Vice Presidents

AULETTA-ARMENISE--Dr. Giovanni. We shall miss our beloved Nino, man of faith, wisdom and heart, who touched our lives with love, friendship and devotion. To his devoted son Giampiero (Marika), grandchildren, our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur and Elisabeth Schneier
ARESTY--David. Thank you for your love and friendship. Marcia and I will never forget you. You are in our hearts always. Rest in Peace. Marcia and Ted Davis

ARESTY--David R.,56, on October 23rd, 2013. David was a loving husband, father, and Vice President of Distribution at Alfred Dunner, Inc. He survived a bone marrow transplant in 1989 and a liver transplant in 2012. Through strength, determination, and courage, he lived a full and beautiful life. He will be remembered for his love of Alabama football, family, and fast cars. He will be missed by Patti, Adam, Holly, Rachel, Danny, Benjamin and the family dogs Mandy, Marcy, Ace, and Olivia, as well as his extended family at Alfred Dunner and the community. His family is extremely grateful to Dr. Steven Papish of Morristown Medical Center, Dr. Jim Armitage and Dr. Phil Bierman of the University of Nebraska Medical Center, Dr. Michael F. Sorrell, Dr. Wendy Grant, and the entire transplant team at UNMC who gave him the gift of life. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Monday at Temple B'nai Or, 60 Overlook Rd. in Morristown, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the University of Nebraska Foundation c/o the David and Patti Aresty Fund, attn. Amy Volk 2285 S. 67th Street, Suite 200, Omaha NE, 68106. Services by Bernheim, Apter & Kreitzman Funeral Home of Livingston, NJ.
