ZUFLACHT--Jerome, MD.,(Jerry) passed peacefully at age 94 October 27th. For 42 years adoring husband of Gloria, his true soul mate, loving father to Robert, Kathie, Richard (Debbie), special father to Alvin (June), Marlene (Mark) and Michael. Blessed with 13 grandchildren, three great-grandchildren. A dedicated physician, Director of Surgery, founder of Franklin Medical Center. Avid reader, wordsmith, world traveler, Yankee fan. Naval lieutenant in the Pacific. Epitome of a gentleman and scholar loved by all. Private funeral services. Shiva observed at his NY home October 29-31. Donations can be sent to UJA-Federation in his memory.

VERDI--Robert A.,on October 27, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Lillian F. Verdi. Loving father of Paul (Patricia) Verdi and Peter (Nancy) Verdi. Cherished grandfather of Christopher, Alessandra and Matthew. Dear brother of Maryann McInerney. Owner of Bermuda Limousine International, Inc. (Est. 1941). Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd Street. Visiting hours Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral mass Thursday at St. Josaphat RC Church at 10:00am. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

SPENCER--Catherine Jean, passed away October 22, 2013 at 57. She spent more than 30 years in marketing, including The (Bend, OR) Bulletin, where she worked more than 20 years, and The Newspaper Network. She co-founded the marketing services company PayneSpencer with her husband Warren Payne in 1998. Cathy is survived by Warren; father, Ray Spencer; sisters, Connie, Cindy, and Deanne; children, Cara and Sean; and grandson, Tristan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Central Park Conservancy.

REICHMANN--Paul.We mourn the loss of a friend and mentor who shared our vision in the 1980's to build a formidable and beautiful traditional Jewish Living Center at one of our nation's premiere secular universities. The Senior Alumni of The Center for Jewish Living at Cornell University

REED--Lou. BAM mourns the loss of an intrepid and longtime artistic colleague. Lou's work on our stages revealed his powerful, unique creative spirit. His untimely passing is a loss for us all, and we send heartfelt condolences to his family and to our friend Laurie Anderson. Karen Brooks Hopkins, Joseph V. Melillo, and the BAM staff

POWER--Anne V. Anne Power loved life and all the people in it. She was surrounded by her family and friends on Saturday, October 26, 2013 when she lost her brief battle with breast cancer at home. She was 54. Professionally Anne began work as Assistant Director of Human Resources at The Sheraton in Boston and later Director at Bal Harbor in Florida. A move to New York City earned a position at The St. Regis Hotel, in the development offices of Starwood Corporation, Director of Human Resources at The Palace and lastly, The Westin Hotel. She excelled in her work and won the respect and admiration of colleagues at all levels wherever she worked. Mourning her loss but grateful for the gift she was in their lives are her brother, Gregory R. Power and his wife, Elana R. Peled, and her niece, Alma, all of Georgetown; her aunts and uncle, John and Elinor Butler of Potomac, MD, Ruth M. Power of Bedford and Janice Power of Norwood; numerous cousins and a host of friends. Anne did the weekly New York Times Sunday crosswords in pen; she always knew the dates of anniversaries for birth, life and death without the aid of a calendar. She was well read; loved music and the opera, and beginning with her first Bruce Springsteen concert in 1980 she remained one of his biggest fans; she was the family historian and true to her heritage she loved all things Irish. Although she lived in Manhattan for over twenty years, she proudly drove her car with a New York license plate wrapped in a Boston Red Sox plate frame and just last week attended a playoff game at Fenway to see her much loved Red Sox win one last time; she loved her MG convertible; her time in Harwichport and Nantucket. Family and friends will honor and remember Anne's life by gathering for calling hours in The Joyce Funeral Home, 245 Main Street (Rte. 20), Waltham on Wednesday October 30th from 4 to 9pm and again at 9:30am on Thursday morning before leaving in procession to Saint Mary's Church, 133 School Street, Waltham where her Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10:30am. Burial will be private. Memorials may be made to St. Boniface Haiti Foundation, 400 N. Main Street, Randolph, MA 02368. To view Anne's online tribute, share a memory or offer condolences please visit www.joycefuneralhome.com

PANZIRER--Grace. Newmark Grubb Knight Frank wishes to extend its sincerest condolences and heartfelt sympathies to our industry colleague Craig Panzirer and his family, on the tragic and untimely loss of his beloved wife Grace Panzirer. May her memory be a blessing.
MICHALSON--Robert. Bob, we will always treasure the memories we shared together. You were truly one of the "Good Guys" . Lois, Bruce, Bob, Joan, Claudia

MICHALSON--Robert Lloyd, age 81 on October 26. Cherished husband of Nancy George-Michalson, devoted father of Debra (Michael) and Hope (Randy), loving grandfather of Stefanie, Brett and Haleigh and adored pets Callie and Melodie. Korean War veteran. Golf, boating, backgammon, (and touch football), Bob was a true Champion. His warmth, charm, and friendship will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Donations in memory of Bob can be made to Ronald McDonald House- NY or Angel on a Leash, www.angelonaleash.org

LERNER--Sonia, beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Ian (Liora), Todd (Georgia), and Seth (Ruth). Cherished grandmother of Ivan, Jonathan, Adeline, Abby, Charles, Clark, Gabriel, and Kayla. She died Sunday on her 79th birthday. A devoted educator, who began her career in 1957 at J.H.S. 50 in Williamsburg, retired in 2005 from James Madison High School where she was instrumental in the expansion of law-related education. Services today 10am at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

LERER, Carol (Reddin, Schmidt), died peacefully on October 26, age 80, at Englewood Hospital, NJ. She was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother and friend. A longtime resident of Englewood Cliffs, NJ, she grew up in Teaneck, NJ. She graduated Teaneck High School in 1951, then attended the University of Wisconsin and Columbia University. For many years she was an integral part of Bergen County community; she served as president of Englewood Cliffs PTA, president of the Regional Chapter of Women's ORT, as well as serving for many years on the Board of Education. She was for a longtime volunteer for the Meals on Wheels program. An avid tennis player, constant theatergoer, she loved classic movies, modern art, history devoted to World War II, and she was often frustrated by the Sunday New York Times crossword. She touched her many friends with her humor, compassion and boundless generosity, and will be deeply missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her husband Nathan Lerer, her brother Christian Yegen and sister Laura Kahl, her children, Keith and Scott Reddin, David Schmidt, Karyn Bloom and Kenneth, Jonathon, Matthew Lerer and her eleven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 2, from 12 to 2:30pm at the Clinton Inn, Tenafly, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to the Roundabout Theater, New York.

LEFCOURT--Florence. The New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy mourns the passing and celebrates the life of our dear friend, first executive director, and society matriarch Florence Lefcourt. For 40 years, Florence provided continuity and administrative leadership to the society as it grew from eight pioneers to the nation's largest regional gastrointestinal endoscopy society. She was tireless in directing her exceptional energies toward the education of young endoscopy trainees and more than any other non-physician, influenced the quality of endoscopy education and impacted the lives and practices of gastroenterologists in the greater New York area and around the country. She is much loved and will be long remembered.

KAISER--Ita, on October 26, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Steven and Alan, and daughters-in-law Vivian and Debbie. Cherished grandmother of Emily, Kara, Jeffrey, Jonathan and Abby. In lieu of flowers, the Kaiser family respectfully requests donations be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage.

GERARD--Joseph, on October 27, 2013. Founder of the SFM Media Corp. in NYC. Visitation at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive Tenafly on Tuesday 2:00pm-4:00pm and 7:00pm-9:00pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday 10:00am Mt. Carmel R.C. Church Tenafly. Interment Westwood Cemetery Westwood. For directions visit www.barrettfuneralhome.net.

FISHBEIN--Lila, nee Gusman, 89, of Tinton Falls, NJ, October 25. Devoted wife, sister, aunt, grandmother, and friend. A lifelong resident of New York and New Jersey, she is survived by her daughter, Phyllis Sandler, son-in-law Ira, grandchildren Matthew and Shelby, four great-grandchildren, and son Michael, daughter-in-law Mary Ann. Contributions in her memory to Aid for Cancer Research, Box 376, Newton Centre, MA, 02459.

FINARDI--Eloise D.,died on October 26th, 2013. Devoted mother, adoring grandmother and inspiring voice teacher. Eloise was married to Enzo Finardi for 53 years. She lived and taught in Milano, Italy before moving to Massachusetts to teach at Smith and Amherst College. Her daughter Marilu and son-in-law Michael, son Eugenio and wife Patrizia, grandchildren: Elettra, Philip, Emanuele, Federica and Francesca cannot but grieve her loss. At 94, Eloise was still surrounded by devoted pupils who remember her as a creative and gifted mentor. Her joie de vivre was contagious and her wit and humor drew everyone to her side. A memorial will be held in late December.
EPHRAIMSON-ABT--Hans. Our very good friend and mentor, extraordinary mensch and father. We'll miss him dearly. Peter & Renee Schindler

BRUML--Norman, born on December 18, 1924 died peacefully at home on Saturday October 26, 2013. He was an army air corps pilot veteran and a Renaissance man. He is survived by his loving family with whom he shared his incredible passion for life and especially the sea. He will be dearly missed. May he rest in peace.

BRODLIEB--Barbara. Cherished daughter of the late Theodore and Gertrude, step-daughter of Shirley, beloved mother of Oliver and Taryn, loving sister of Ken and Marc, dear aunt of Tim, Kim, Andrew, and Samantha, adoring grandmother of Charlie. Let your soul live free. Services Tuesday, 12pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, LI. Interment to follow at the NewMontefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

BELSITO--Maria C. Tapia, age 59, of Bronxville, NY passed away suddenly on Wednesday, October 23, 2013. Beloved wife of Dr. Donald Belsito and adoring mother of daughters Monica, Vanessa, and Christina. Cherished sister of Marcos Tapia, Gustavo Tapia, Fabian Tapia, and Grace Ranken and devoted daughter of the late Alfonso and Lucitania Tapia. She was also dearly loved by her many in-laws, cousins, nieces, nephews and friends. Professionally, Maria was a successful Certified Fund Raising Executive at various organizations in New York and in Kansas City, including The Allen-Stevenson School, The Pembroke Hill School, American Lung Association, Rose Brooks Center, Mattie Rhodes Center, Futuro Media Group, and The Wartburg Adult Care Community. A native of Ecuador, Maria was an avid volunteer of her considerable talents and always looked for ways to give back, especially to Latino organizations. While living in Kansas City, Maria was active with MANA, the Hispanic Chamber's Latinos of Tomorrow, the League of United Latin American Citizens and its National Educational Services Centers, and El Centro Girl Scout Troop. In 2010, she was honored by The Women's Foundation of Greater Kansas City for her outstanding community service. In New York, she served as a board member of the Mount Vernon Star Scholars, volunteered at El Centro Hispano, and aided the parish van service for the Church of St. Joseph in Bronxville. An active alumnus of Vassar College, she served as the Co-Chair of the Annual Fund. She was a role model and inspiration to all. A Mass of Christian Burial was held on Monday, October 28 at the Church of St. Joseph. Remembrances may be made in Maria's name to Mount Vernon Scholars Program, Inc., 90 Brookfield Road, Mount Vernon, NY 10552 or The Wartburg Foundation, 1 Wartburg Place, Mount Vernon, NY 10552.

BARNETT--Sally Ellen, 86, recently of Manhattan, died in Ridgefield, Connecticut on Sunday, October 27. Daughter of Pearl and A.N. Barnett of Brooklyn, she is survived by her devoted children Patricia Zohn and Robert Zohn, her adoring grandchildren Camilla, Nicholas, Abigail and Patrick and her loving sister Barbara Goldfarb. She was predeceased by her sister Dr. Marjorie Barnett of Chicago and her former husband Arnold Zohn, a publishing executive. She was the editor of the Lincoln Log at Abraham Lincoln High School and continued her literary endeavors at the University of Wisconsin. Also a talented painter, tennis player and dedicated distance walker, Sally edited the Dimondstein Express Newsletter and was a residential broker at Douglas Elliman. Her family, along with many friends, will remember her generosity and kindness, her elegance and beauty, her love of culture and the arts and a keen and curious mind. Services at the Riverside Memorial Chapel (180 West 76th St at Amsterdam Ave.) Tuesday at 9:30am.

ANTONY--Michael, age 96 of Wilmington, DE, died Friday, October 25, 2013. Son of the late Frank and Anastasia (Thorakos) Antony. Preceded by his wife Mary Gregorios, one sister, Ann DeRosa, one brother, Thomas F. Antony. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY he held a private dental practice there for many years. Father of Michael Greg and Paul George Antony, grandfather of Danielle, Michael and Janie Antony, companion of Barbara Lewnes. Funeral Services, Thursday, October 31, 2013 at 2pm in Wilmington, DE. Interment, Friday, November 1, 2013 at 11:00am at Green-Wood Cemetery, 500 25th St., Brooklyn, NY, 11231. Memorial contributions to a favorite charity. For online condolences, please visit Chandler Funeral Homes & Crematory chandlerfuneralhome.com (302) 478-7100

ZUFLACHT--Jerome, MD.,(Jerry) passed peacefully at age 94 October 27th. For 42 years adoring husband of Gloria, his true soul mate, brother to Betty, loving father to Robert, Kathie, Richard (Debbie), special father to Alvin (June), Marlene (Mark) and Michael. Blessed with 13 grandchildren, three great-grandchildren. A dedicated physician, Director of Surgery, founder of Franklin Medical Center. Avid reader, wordsmith, world traveler, Yankee fan. Naval lieutenant in the Pacific. Epitome of a gentleman and scholar loved by all. Private funeral services. Shiva observed at his NY home October 29-31. Donations can be sent to UJA-Federation in his memory.

SALOMON Rosalind Salzberg. 20 years after her passing we remember her as a wife and mother and gratefully recall her love, beauty, grace and tenderness. We will carry her memory in our hearts forever. Chester and Danny

VERDI--Robert A.,on October 27, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Lillian F. Verdi. Loving father of Paul (Patricia) Verdi and Peter (Nancy) Verdi. Cherished grandfather of Christopher, Alessandra and Matthew. Dear brother of Maryann McInerney. Owner of Bermuda Limousine International, Inc. (Est. 1941). Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd Street. Visiting hours Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral mass Thursday at St. Josaphat RC Church at 10:00am. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

SPENCER--Catherine Jean, passed away October 22, 2013 at 57. She spent more than 30 years in marketing, including The (Bend, OR) Bulletin, where she worked more than 20 years, and The Newspaper Network. She co-founded the marketing services company PayneSpencer with her husband Warren Payne in 1998. Cathy is survived by Warren; father, Ray Spencer; sisters, Connie, Cindy, and Deanne; children, Cara and Sean; and grandson, Tristan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Central Park Conservancy.
RAPPS--Alvin, passed Saturday October 26. Long time stock broker. Survived by wife Trudy, daughter Bonnie and two grandchildren.

McKEE--Victoria Alexandra Lippman, (61), daughter of musical publicist Alix Williamson, died October 20th. A 'free spirit' who freelanced for UK and US newspapers, she was also a singer/songwriter. She is survived by her children and her husband, Jack Pearson.

McGUIRE--Helen, on October 28, 2013, in Brooklyn in her 98th year. Survived by her beloved daughters Janice McGuire (Charlie Niessner) and Nancy Valente; granddaughter Cris (Sean) Grace; and three special great-grandsons; Sullivan, Braden, and Devin. Her generosity, wit, caring and enthusiasm for life will be sorely missed by them as well as numerous other family, neighbors, and friends. A memorial gathering will be held at a later date. Please visit: CobbleHillChapels.com or contact Cobble Hill Chapels directly for further info.

KIRSHNER--Stephen. The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our member Stephen Kirshner. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Elayne and family. Jack Irushalmi, President
JAFFE--Sarai Sherman, artist, designer and fighter against oppression. She lives on in her work and our hearts.

GURIAN--Leah (Lil), on October 29, 2013 in her 92nd year. Beloved wife of the late Elias Gurian, adored and adoring mother of Stephen Gurian, Bonny and Marvin Rosen, Donald and Karen Gurian. Cherished grandmother of Alyson and Steven Justman, Melanie and Robert Gallucci, Justin Gurian and Ariel Gurian; great-grandmother of five. Extraordinary aunt to many nieces and nephews. Resident of Boca Raton, FL, previously of Lawrence, NY. Graveside services at Old Montefiore Cemetery on Springfield Blvd. in St. Albans, Queens, at 11am on Thursday, October 31. She had an incredible life and will be deeply missed by all who knew her.

BRUML--Norman, born on December 18, 1924 died peacefully at home on Saturday October 26, 2013. He was an army air corps pilot veteran and a Renaissance man. He is survived by his loving family with whom he shared his incredible passion for life and especially the sea. He will be dearly missed. May he rest in peace.

BOGARDUS--Sidney Tuttle, on October 27, 2013, leaving his wife Sully, his sons Sidney Jr., Peter and Andrew, eight grandchildren and his brother Hal. Services private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Bernard's School, 4 E. 98th St., New York 10029, St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave., New York 10021, or VNSNY Hospice, 1250 Broadway, New York 10001.

WEINBERG--James. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of James Weinberg, an esteemed leader and friend. Jimmy was respected for his guidance and devotion as president of New York United Jewish Appeal from 1976-1978 and a leader in negotiations for UJA in the merger of UJA and Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. In 1980, he served as Chairman of UJA-Federation Joint Campaign where he was appointed Life Trustee. He and his late wife, Bunny, leave behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Jimmy's children, Adam (Lorraine), Jed, Nina (Bruce); his brother, Marshall; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

WEINBERG--James, The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed Founding Member and Past President. We extend deepest sympathy to his children Adam, Jed and Nina, sister-in-law Adele, and to the entire family. Aubrey L Glazer, Rabbi Norton D. Shargel, Rabbi Emeritus Israel Singer, Cantor Abby Mendelsohn, Martin Rogowsky, Co-Pres.

WEINBERG--James L. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn with great sadness the passing of James L. Weinberg, beloved father of our dear Director Adam Weinberg. James and his late wife Bunny were devoted advocates of arts and culture, a passion that they passed down to their son Adam. James served as Chairman of The Jewish Museum from 1979-1987 during a time of great transformation for the institution and remained committed to the Museum as Chairman Emeritus and Life Trustee. He lived life with enthusiasm, compassion, gratitude and humor. His warmth touched all who knew him and he will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children Jed; Nina, her husband Bruce Doran; Adam, his wife Lorraine; grandchildren Daniel, Zoe and Kira; and brother Marshall. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President

WEINBERG--James L.,The Jewish Museum deeply mourns the passing of James L. Weinberg, Life Trustee. Jim joined the Board in 1977 and served as Chairman from 1979-1987, overseeing extraordinary institutional growth. Under his leadership, the Museum expanded its educational outreach and presented many critically acclaimed exhibitions. He received the Mayer Sulzberger Award in 1986 and was appointed a Life Trustee in 1991. Jim's legacy at The Jewish Museum continues with the recent establishment of the James L. Weinberg Distinguished Lecture endowed by his brother Marshall M. Weinberg. His devotion to The Jewish Museum and wise counsel will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt condolences go to his brother Marshall, his children Adam and Lorraine, Jed, Nina and Bruce, and grandchildren Daniel, Zoe and Kira. Robert Pruzan, Chairman Claudia Gould, Helen Goldsmith Menschel, Director

WEINBERG--James L.,of Harrison NY, died peacefully at home on October 29, at age 91, surrounded by his adoring family. He was grandson of celebrated Yiddish orator Zvi Hirsch Masliansky, and son of Dr. Harold and Anna Weinberg. Weinberg graduated from NYU and served on an Army hospital ship in the Atlantic theater in WWII. He was President of American Tack and Hardware Company which he ran alongside his beloved late brother Edward for 50 years. Like his grandfather, parents, and brothers, he was an active leader in Jewish causes. In the 1940's he helped send munitions to Palestine in association with the Haganah in support of Israel's establishment and was asked by NY Governor Lehman to chair the new Junior Division of NY United Jewish Appeal (UJA). He was President of NY UJA in 19761978 and later lead negotiations for UJA in the merger of UJA and Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. In 19801981 he served as Chairman of UJA-Federation Joint Campaign where he was appointed Life Trustee. He also served on the Boards of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS), the Jewish Theological Seminary, The Jewish Agency, the Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) and the New York Association for New Americans (NYANA). He was especially proud to have joined the Board of The Jewish Museum, NY, in 1977 where, as its Chairman 19791987, he oversaw unprecedented growth in its staff and programs. He received the Mayer Sulzberger Award for his achievement in 1986, and in 1991 was appointed Life Trustee of the Museum. He was a founder of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison and its President 19681970, in time voted a Lifetime Honorary Trustee. Most of all, he loved his friends of all ages and life with his family: wife of 57 years, the late Edith "Bunny" (nee Zickerman); children Adam, Jed, and Nina; daughter-in-law Lorraine and son-in-law Bruce; grandchildren Daniel, Zoe and Kira; and surviving brother Marshall. Funeral Services will be held at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison (914-835-2850) on Friday, November 1 at 11am. Donations in his memory may be made to The Jewish Museum NY.

WECHTER--Dena B.,97. New York, NY, died at home October 25, 2013. Loving aunt and devoted friend. Active for years in the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union and Workmen's Circle. Worked for social and economic justice. Volunteer at the Center for Jewish History. Graveside interment Sunday November 3, 10:30am, Wellwood Cemetery. Calling hours at her apartment 2-4pm. Contributions may be made to ORT, YIVO or charity of choice.

THALER--Grace Ashwell Yeomans, age 58, died of pancreatic cancer on October 27, 2013 with her beloved husband, Thomas W. Thaler, by her side. A longtime resident of Beacon Hill and Wellfleet, MA, Grace was born in New York City, grew up in West Hartford, CT and summered in Dublin, NH. She was an independent decorative arts appraiser and consultant who began her career at Sotheby's New York in its Oriental Carpet Department; she was later Assistant to the Chairman. For many years Grace was Director of Decorative Arts of Grogan & Company of Dedham, MA. She was widely regarded for her expertise in Chinese Export porcelain. She leaves her sisters Carol Conard and Tyler Madden and many adored nieces, nephews and cousins. Memorial service on November 8 at 2pm at Trinity Church Boston. Memorial donations may be made to the National Society of Colonial Dames in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, 55 Beacon St., Boston, MA 02108.

SPENCER--Catherine Jean, passed away October 22, 2013 at 57. She spent more than 30 years in marketing, including The (Bend, OR) Bulletin, where she worked more than 20 years, and The Newspaper Network. She co-founded the marketing services company PayneSpencer with her husband Warren Payne in 1998. Cathy is survived by Warren; father, Ray Spencer; sisters, Connie, Cindy, and Deanne; children, Cara and Sean; and grandson, Tristan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Central Park Conservancy.

ROSENBAUM--Max, Ph.D.,October 29 at age 90, of Palm Beach, FL and Kent Lakes, NY. A pioneer group psychotherapist and a renowned clinical psychologist-psychoanalyst, author, educator, scholar and lecturer whose career spanned half a century. A WWII veteran, he was a proud graduate of Townsend Harris High School and the City University of New York with graduate work at NYU. He was student of Erich Fromm and Martin Buber with myriad passions and vast knowledge and interests including philosophy, ethics, politics, home construction, and Jewish studies. A loving father of Rebecca, Joshua, Adam and Judith and grandfather of Gabriel, he is survived by his beloved wife of 64 years, Belle. Funeral services October 31 at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, NYC.

LOWY--Ruth Bondy, 90, of Larchmont, NY, died on October 29, 2013. Daughter of Irene and Eugene L. Bondy of New Rochelle, she is survived by her children and their spouses, Donald Lowy (Angela), Susan Darby (Jay), Patricia Lowy (Daniel Frank), Alison Lowy (Peter Dopsch); her grandchildren, Jasper, Jennifer, Victoria, Lucas, Isabelle, Cole, Sarah, Emma, Henry; and her companion, Walter Levi. She was predeceased by her husband Lawrence Lowy. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College, she received her MA from Sarah Lawrence/ Bank Street. Life-long resident of Larchmont, she swam every summer day at Manor Beach. A celebration of her life will be held at her home November 1, 2-4pm, 6-9pm. A memorial will be held in late December. Donations may be made to Cancer Support Team, 2900 Westchester Ave., Suite 103, Purchase, NY 10577.
NOOGER--Hazel (Carniol), passed away peacefully on October 30th. World traveler, teacher and music lover will be dearly missed. Graveside services at Montefiore Cemetery at 1:00pm on November 1st.

LEIMAN--Leonard. The Jewish Foundation for Education of Women wishes to express its sorrow on the passing of Leonard Leiman, beloved father of our Executive Director, Elizabeth Leiman Kraiem. Our condolences to Elizabeth, her mother Joan, her brother Alan and the entire Leiman family. May his memory be a blessing. Jill W. Smith, President Sharon L. Weinberg, Chair

LEIMAN--Leonard, The Board at 1125 Park Avenue mourns the passing of Leonard Leiman. He was a highly valued past board member and long time good neighbor and will be remembered with fondness and respect. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Joan and the entire Leiman family. 1125 Park Avenue Corp.

LEIMAN--Leonard M.,age 82, peacefully, at home, on October 30th. Loving husband, father, grandfather, uncle and great uncle, a lawyer's lawyer and accomplished angler, respected for his integrity, intelligence, quick wit and sound judgment. Born and raised in Maspeth, Queens, he was a graduate of Wesleyan University and the Harvard Law School where he was an editor of the Harvard Law Review. Leonard served as a law clerk for Judge Learned Hand of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, and Justice John Marshall Harlan of the United States Supreme Court. He joined the former Reavis & McGrath in 1956, becoming a partner in 1963, played an important role in the firm's merger with Fulbright & Jaworski, and remained of counsel to the Norton Rose Fulbright firm. Leonard practiced securities law and advised many nonprofits, particularly in the Jewish world. Many companies relied on his advice and counsel to navigate the complex regulatory environments in which they operated and raised capital. He was a member of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, a member of the Legal Affairs Committee of the New York Stock Exchange and was past chair of the Committee on Securities Regulation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. He taught corporations and securities law as a visiting professor at the University of Pennsylvania, Yale, and New York Law Schools. He is survived by his wife of 58 years Joan (Maisel), his children Elizabeth (Ruben Kraiem), Alan (Annette Ooyevaar), grandchildren Renee, Ari, Leon, sister Joan (Leiman Jacobson), sister-in-law and brother-in-law Alice Jo and Marshall Lichtman, nieces Anne Cowett, Susan Uriarte, Joanne Lichtman, Pam Reading, and nephew Fred Cowett. Funeral Service Friday, November 1st at 9:30am at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street. The family will be at home receiving visitors at 1125 Park Ave. on Saturday evening from 7pm, and on Sunday afternoon from 4pm. Donations, in lieu of flowers, to Wesleyan University, or Madison River Foundation, Odell Project, Ennis, MT.
KIRSHNER--Stephen. We mourn our esteemed member's passing and send heartfelt sympathy to his family. Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre

KATZ--Robert L. The workers of UnWrapped, Inc. offer their condolences to your family and express their gratitude for your guidance, experience, smarts and style. Your indomitable spirit is with us every day.

KATZ--Robert L.,November 12, 1928 - October 28, 2013. Adored husband of Peggy; father of Jon, Andrew, Susan, Stephen and Peter; grandfather and GrandBob to many. Born and raised in the Bronx; resided in Manhattan, later California and for the past 35 years Atlanta. A survivor if ever there was one. Graced many with his warmth, his smile, his fun-loving nature.
IASON--John Williams. We will always remember John as a loving brother-in-law, Wonderful Uncle to Eric and Jon and their families and beloved friend. Patty and Bobby Weiner and Family
JAFFE--Sarai Sherman, artist, designer and fighter against oppression. She lives on in her work and our hearts.

IASON--John Williams. Loving husband of Valorie, extraordinary father of Scott and Lizzie, treasured father-in-law of Ali and Teo, adoring grandfather of Drew and Kate. John was an alumnus of the Phillips Exeter Academy and of the University of North Carolina where he played varsity lacrosse. John was the much loved son of the late Girard Iason and the late Jeanne Iason. He was the devoted brother of Larry and Barbara. John was a successful businessman who worked with his father at N. Erlanger Blumgart, a textile converter. John was an excellent athlete who played tennis, squash and golf. He had many wonderful friends, but most of all he lived for his family, and his family adored him. John and Valorie were married for over 43 years. They had a love affair that enriched their lives until the end.

GURIAN--Leah (Lil), on October 29, 2013 in her 92nd year. Beloved wife of the late Elias Gurian, adored and adoring mother of Stephen Gurian, Bonny and Marvin Rosen, Donald and Karen Gurian. Cherished grandmother of Alyson and Steven Justman, Melanie and Robert Gallucci, Justin Gurian and Ariel Gurian; great-grandmother of five. Extraordinary aunt to many nieces and nephews. Resident of Boca Raton, FL, previously of Lawrence, NY. Graveside services at Old Montefiore Cemetery on Springfield Blvd. in St. Albans, Queens, at 11am on Thursday, October 31. She had an incredible life and will be deeply missed by all who knew her.

CLAUSS--Kathryn Haag, a loving mother and grandmother to five children and six grandchildren, passed away in Greenwich, CT, on October 29, 2013, in the warm company of her family. She actively raised and fiercely loved her five children, Bryan, Melissa, Lindsay, Ashley and Duncan, and instilled in them an unwavering sense of loyalty and commitment to each other. She was a committed and loving wife to Roy Stuart Clauss for 25 years. To the end, family meant everything to her. She was especially close to her siblings, Jan, Jon, Larry and Martha; their spouses, John Veryzer, Kelley Dominique, Susan Fisher Haag, and Jean Mills; and her mother, Audrey Lucille Haag, who passed away in June. She also leaves her sons-in-law, Matthew Malone and Thomas J. Sheehy, daughter-in-law Sasha North-Clauss, and her father, Ray Haag, of Bay Shore, NY, as well as her grandchildren-- Madeleine, Ellie, Quinn, Teddy, Cooper and Adelaide, who adored her. She will be missed, celebrated, and never forgotten. She would have it no other way. Services to be held on Saturday, November 2nd at 11am at Christ Church in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Adopt-A-Bench Program of Central Park Conservancy in Kathryn's name or to B*Cured.

YANCEY--Mary Anne. The Board and staff of BRIC express our profound grief on the passing of Mary Anne Yancey, Board Chair of BRIC from 2002- 2007, and founder of the BRIC Rotunda Gallery Friends Committee. Mary Anne was a beloved friend and a gifted and dedicated leader, who led BRIC through challenging times to a bright future. The recent opening of BRIC House, a major new cultural facility in Brooklyn, was one of many successes made possible by her leadership. Our deepest condolences to her husband Dick and the entire Yancey family. Hilary Ackermann, Chair Leslie Schultz, President

YANCEY--Mary Anne. Sister, aunt, great-aunt and great friend, we will miss your love and counsel. You were a mainstay of our family and an inspiration to all who knew you. You will be missed, always loved and never forgotten. Monte, Denise, Richard, Lorie, Chris, Debbie, Mikah, Zach and Jacob

YANCEY--Mary Anne. It is with great sadness that the Brooklyn Youth Chorus Academy bids farewell to Mary Anne Yancey, one of our staunchest advocates and greatest benefactors. Mary Anne was intelligent, kind, formidable, and fiercely dedicated to her adopted borough of Brooklyn. She had many gifts which she shared generously with her friends and colleagues. Since 2002, Mary Anne has been a Trustee of the Brooklyn Youth Chorus Academy, and served as an articulate and inspiring leader for the board, staff, and students. During her three years as Chair, she presided over an extraordinary period of advancement, both academically and artistically. Under her leadership BYCA doubled the number of children served, tripled the amount of financial aid offered to families in need, embarked on our most adventurous artistic projects, attracted a new generation of supporters, and created a dynamic and challenging blueprint to lead our organization to its 25th anniversary. Mary Anne was very proud of BYCA's feature performances with renowned artists such as the New York Philharmonic, Elton John, Barbra Streisand, Harolyn Blackwell and Kronos Quartet, and delighted in bringing her friends and family to see BYCA's young singers on prestigious stages such as Radio City Music Hall, Carnegie Hall and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. She was extremely proud of BYCA's impressive record of commissioning new works from celebrated composers such as Nico Muhly and Pulitzer Prize winners Caroline Shaw, David Lang and Paul Morevec. Mary Anne's commitment to her family and community will never be forgotten, and we will honor her legacy by continuing her efforts, carrying forth her incredible dedication to the Brooklyn Youth Chorus Academy and the borough that she loved.

YANCEY--Mary Anne, The board of directors of the Brooklyn Chamber Music Society mourns the loss of our friend and patron Mary Anne Yancey. Our deepest condolences to her husband Dick, our fellow board member, and to their children and grandchildren. Carmit Zori, Director

YANCEY--Mary Anne,81, of Brooklyn Heights, NY, passed away unexpectedly October 25, 2013. Born in Walla Walla, Washington to a ranching family, she moved to NYC in 1954 after graduating from Whitman College. She married in 1956, raised her family in Brooklyn Heights, and earned three Masters degrees from Columbia University. She was a leader and a sustaining force behind a diverse array of vital community organizations, including most recently serving as Chair (2009-2013) of the Brooklyn Youth Chorus Academy, a Grammy award winning music school and arts producer; and Chair (2002-2007) of BRIC Arts Media Brooklyn, which presents contemporary art, performing arts and community media programs that reflect Brooklyn's creativity and diversity. Previously, Mary Anne was the first woman Chair of the NYC Hospital Visiting Committee for the United Hospital Fund of NY, and the first woman President of the Plymouth Church Council. In the 1980's, she served as Director of Marketing for the City's largest home ownership program, at the Partnership for New York City. She is survived by her loving husband of 57 years, Richard, a former Managing Director of the investment banking firm Dillon, Read & Co. Inc., her brother Monte G. Shaffer, of Prosser, WA, her three children, Leslie of Whitefish, MT, Jennifer Young (Brian) of Taos, NM, and Richard Jr. (Inger) of Brooklyn, NY, as well as her five beloved grandsons, Gavin, Connor, Oliver, Felix and Neal. Mary Anne will be greatly missed by us all. A memorial service will be held the afternoon of November 15th, at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Brooklyn Youth Chorus Academy's Mary Anne Yancey Memorial Fund. (www.byca.org/support)
WEINBERG--James L.,Friends for 80 years. We will miss you. Fred and Rita Richman

WEINBERG--James L.,The Jewish Museum deeply mourns the passing of James L. Weinberg, Life Trustee. Jim joined the Board in 1977 and served as Chairman from 1979-1987, overseeing extraordinary institutional growth. Under his leadership, the Museum expanded its educational outreach and presented many critically acclaimed exhibitions. He received the Mayer Sulzberger Award in 1986 and was appointed a Life Trustee in 1991. Jim's legacy at The Jewish Museum continues with the recent establishment of the James L. Weinberg Distinguished Lecture endowed by his brother Marshall M. Weinberg. His devotion to The Jewish Museum and wise counsel will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt condolences go to his brother Marshall, his children Adam and Lorraine, Jed, Nina and Bruce, and grandchildren Daniel, Zoe and Kira. Robert Pruzan, Chairman Claudia Gould, Helen Goldsmith Menschel, Director

WEINBERG--James. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, James Weinberg, and extend sincere condolences to his family. Alan Fischer, President
WEINBERG--James L. Your love and warmth will never be forgotten. June and Ira Gelb

WECHTER--Dena B.,97. New York, NY, died at home October 25, 2013. Loving aunt and devoted friend. Active for years in the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union and Workmen's Circle. Worked for social and economic justice. Volunteer at the Center for Jewish History. Graveside interment Sunday November 3, 10:30am, Wellwood Cemetery. Calling hours at her apartment 2-4pm. Contributions may be made to ORT, YIVO or charity of choice.

STEIN--Mark, 70, A business pioneer of Brooklyn, NY, died Thursday, October 31, 2013. Mark was born to Jacob Stein (deceased) and Matilda Stein (Maiden name Priceman) in Brooklyn, NY and graduated Lincoln High School in 1960 and went on to receive bachelor and master degrees in Architecture, Engineering, and City Planning from NYIT, University of Oklahoma, and Ohio State University. Mark had numerous hobbies and interests from playing the piano to earning a private pilot license but tropical fish was the hobby he loved the most. After a number of years as a practicing architect he started his own tropical fish import/ export business which he grew over the past 40 plus years to be the oldest and most respected in the industry pioneering many of the methods used in this field today. Mark was a founding board member of the industry group Ornamental Fish International (OFI) and his insight and knowledge was sought by ichthyologists from across the world. Mark, along with his wife Analesa, was an active member of the Madison Jewish Center where he served as a Vice President. Mark is survived by his mother, Matilda, wife Analesa, brother Allan, son's David and Brian, and three granddaughters. Funeral services will be held Sunday, November 3, 9:30am at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11234 (718)338-1500.

ROSENBAUM--Max, Ph.D.,October 29 at age 90, of Palm Beach, FL and Kent Lakes, NY. A pioneer group psychotherapist and a renowned clinical psychologist-psychoanalyst, author, educator, scholar and lecturer whose career spanned half a century. A WWII veteran, he was a proud graduate of Townsend Harris High School and the City University of New York with graduate work at NYU. He was student of Erich Fromm and Martin Buber with myriad passions and vast knowledge and interests including philosophy, ethics, politics, home construction, and Jewish studies. A loving father of Rebecca, Joshua, Adam and Judith and grandfather of Gabriel, he is survived by his beloved wife of 64 years, Belle. Funeral services October 31 at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, NYC.

NORVELL--Patricia (Patsy). We mourn the loss of our dear friend. An extraordinary artist of both public and intimate works. An advocate for women's art, co-founder of A.I.R. Gallery, generous mentor and the best of friends. Our love to Amelia and all of Patsy's family. Sarah Draney, Amy Ehrlich, Susannah (Sukey) Eldridge, Louise Fishman, Harmony Hammond, Sarah Hart, Lewis Knauss, Joel Mason, Jessica May, Ingrid Nyeboe, Jody Pinto, Reeva Potoff, Theresa del Pozzo, Jenny Snider, Elizabeth Weatherford.

MCKIM-SMITH--Gridley, died on October 18, 2013 from an acute bacterial infection. Born in Clinton, IA on March 14, 1943. She studied at Tulane (BA 1965) and Harvard (PhD 1974). She was married to Benjamin Franklin Smith III (Frank) from 1969 until his death in 1990. In 1982, while serving as a Senior Fellow at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., she came to Bryn Mawr College as Assistant Professor, becoming Mellon Professor in 1999. Gridley was a trailblazer in Latin American, costume and gender studies and in her emphasis on technical scientific examination of works of art. Examining Velazquez (1988) was the first publication of this kind at the Prado Museum. Undeterred by over 40 years of multiple sclerosis, Gridley taught ardently, traveled extensively and will be remembered lovingly by all who knew her. She will be buried in Quincy, FL, next to her husband. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a later date. Donations in her name will be gratefully accepted by The Gift of Sunshine (thegiftofsunshine.org), the organization that trained two of Gridley's service dogs.
MANN--Shelley, NCJW Peninsula mourns the passing of our beloved Board Member. Forever in our hearts.

LOWY--Ruth Bondy, 90, of Larchmont, NY, died on October 29, 2013. Daughter of Irene and Eugene L. Bondy of New Rochelle, she is survived by her children and their spouses, Donald Lowy (Angela), Susan Darby (Jay), Patricia Lowy (Daniel Frank), Alison Lowy (Peter Dopsch); her grandchildren, Jasper, Jennifer, Victoria, Lucas, Isabelle, Cole, Sarah, Emma, Henry; and her companion, Walter Levi. She was predeceased by her husband Lawrence Lowy. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College, she received her MA from Sarah Lawrence/ Bank Street. Life-long resident of Larchmont, she swam every summer day at Manor Beach. A celebration of her life will be held at her home November 1, 2-4pm, 6-9pm. A memorial will be held in late December. Donations may be made to Cancer Support Team, 2900 Westchester Ave., Suite 103, Purchase, NY 10577.

LEIMAN--Leonard. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Leonard Leiman. He leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Leonard's wife, Joan; his children, Elizabeth (Ruben) and Alan (Annette); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

LEIMAN--Leonard, The Board at 1125 Park Avenue mourns the passing of Leonard Leiman. He was a highly valued past board member and long time good neighbor and will be remembered with fondness and respect. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Joan and the entire Leiman family. 1125 Park Avenue Corp.

LEIMAN--Leonard M. The partners, attorneys and staff of Norton Rose Fulbright mourn the passing of our esteemed partner, colleague and friend, Leonard M. Leiman. Leonard joined the firm of Reavis & McGrath in 1956, becoming a partner in 1963 and serving on its management committee for many years. Leonard played an important role in the firm's merger with Fulbright & Jaworski in 1989, served on the Executive Committee from 1989 to 1996 and remained active as of counsel to Norton Rose Fulbright until his death. Leonard's dedication to the firm and our clients, as well as to all of us who worked with him, was unwavering over his more than 50 years practicing with us. He was a graduate of Wesleyan University and the Harvard Law School where he was an editor of the Harvard Law Review. He served as a law clerk for Judge Learned Hand of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, and Justice John Marshall Harlan of the United States Supreme Court. Leonard focused his practice primarily on corporate and securities law, advising publicly traded corporations, as well as private and non-profit corporations. His clients greatly valued his experience and advice, as did his many friends. Over the course of his distinguished career, Leonard served the profession and the public in a variety of key positions including as executive assistant to the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, D.C. In that role, he worked closely with the chairman, staff members and Commissioners on general programs, as well as specific issues. He also had served as chair of the Committee on Securities Regulation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, as a public member of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, and as a member of the Legal Affairs Committee of the New York Stock Exchange. We will miss Leonard's keen intellect, his wise advice and counsel and his friendship. Our condolences, to his wife Joan, children Alan and Elizabeth and the entire Leiman family.

LEIMAN--Leonard M.,age 82, peacefully, at home, on October 30th. Loving husband, father, grandfather, uncle and great uncle, a lawyer's lawyer and accomplished angler, respected for his integrity, intelligence, quick wit and sound judgment. Born and raised in Maspeth, Queens, he was a graduate of Wesleyan University and the Harvard Law School where he was an editor of the Harvard Law Review. Leonard served as a law clerk for Judge Learned Hand of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, and Justice John Marshall Harlan of the United States Supreme Court. He joined the former Reavis & McGrath in 1956, becoming a partner in 1963, played an important role in the firm's merger with Fulbright & Jaworski, and remained of counsel to the Norton Rose Fulbright firm. Leonard practiced securities law and advised many nonprofits, particularly in the Jewish world. Many companies relied on his advice and counsel to navigate the complex regulatory environments in which they operated and raised capital. He was a member of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, a member of the Legal Affairs Committee of the New York Stock Exchange and was past chair of the Committee on Securities Regulation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. He taught corporations and securities law as a visiting professor at the University of Pennsylvania, Yale, and New York Law Schools. He is survived by his wife of 58 years Joan (Maisel), his children Elizabeth (Ruben Kraiem), Alan (Annette Ooyevaar), grandchildren Renee, Ari, Leon, sister Joan (Leiman Jacobson), sister-in-law and brother-in-law Alice Jo and Marshall Lichtman, nieces Anne Cowett, Susan Uriarte, Joanne Lichtman, Pam Reading, and nephew Fred Cowett. Funeral Service Friday, November 1st at 9:30am at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street. The family will be at home receiving visitors at 1125 Park Ave. on Saturday evening from 7pm, and on Sunday afternoon from 4pm. Donations, in lieu of flowers, to Wesleyan University, or Madison River Foundation, Odell Project, Ennis, MT.

HALPERN--Sam. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of its New Jersey National Vice Chair Sam Halpern. Sam was a Benefactor of Yad Vashem, Jerusalem. His leadership and dedication to passing the torch of remembrance was a model for his family and the entire community. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his children Fred; to our Treasurer, David; to Murray and Jack and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leonard A. Wilf, Chairman Rabbi Eric M.Lankin, Executive Director/CEO

Halpern--Sam. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the loss of Holocaust survivor Sam Halpern, who devoted his life to Holocaust memory and education. He was a longtime friend of the Museum and played a pivotal role in its creation. Our heartfelt condolences go to his wife, Gladys; his sons and daughters-in-law Fred and Museum Council Member Cheryl, David and Sharon, Murray and Batsheva, and Jack; and his many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Tom A. Bernstein, Chairman Joshua B. Bolten, Vice Chairman Sara J. Bloomfield, Director The United States Holocaust Museum

FOLTZ--William J.,H.J. Heinz Professor Emeritus of African Studies and Political Science, Yale University, died Sunday, 27 October at his home in New Haven, CT. Foltz directed Yale's Center for International and Area Studies and Council on African Studies. Foltz was also a Senior Fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and served on the National Intelligence Council as the National Intelligence Officer for Africa in the Clinton administration. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Anne-Marie Foltz, sons Peter W. Foltz (Adrienne Lee), Boulder, CO, and Jeremy D. Foltz (Erin McBride), Madison, WI, two grandchildren, Miranda Lee-Foltz and W. Kieran Foltz, his sister Jean Gibson (Bob Gibson), Albuquerque, NM, and brothers Bob Foltz, Deep River, CT, and David Devlin-Foltz (Betsy Devlin-Foltz), Silver Spring, MD. Memorial service: 9 November, 4pm, Dwight Chapel, Yale. Donations in William J. Foltz's memory may be made to Neighborhood Music School, New Haven or Thousand Islands Land Trust, Clayton, NY.

BARBARISI--Dr. Vincent Edward, 66, of Rye Brook, NY, passed away suddenly but peacefully on October 23. Vincent was born in New York City, son of the late Dr. Edward and Susan (Perrella) Barbarisi. He graduated from Manhattan College in 1969, and Columbia Dental School in 1973. He entered into practice with his father, also a dentist. He is survived by his beloved wife, Barbara Goodstein, and children, Daniel and Rachel. He is interred at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY.

WOOD--Thomas E. Age 74, of Devon, PA, and Cushing, ME, died peacefully at his home in Devon, October 21, 2013, of pancreatic cancer. Born April 20, 1939, in Los Angeles, CA, he was a California boy, endowed with wit and wisdom and a love of surfing. Through his father's vaudeville band, The California Collegians, he spent time with Henry Fonda, Fred MacMurray and his godmother, Harriet Nelson, of Ozzie and Harriet fame. Graduate of The Harvard School for Boys, Studio City, CA, Amherst College ('61) and The University of Pennsylvania Law School ('66). He practiced corporate and securities law for over 40 years with the Philadelphia firm, Drinker, Biddle & Reath. He served on the board of Turner Investments, Inc., and as Board Member and General Counsel for Vertex, Inc. He was the longest serving volunteer for Easttown Township (37 yrs) where he was Chairman of the Zoning Hearing Board, and was a former trustee of The Baldwin School, Bryn Mawr, PA. In Maine, he served on the board of The Maine Maritime Museum, Bath, and co-chaired the board of The Apprenticeshop, Rockland. A voracious reader, gifted writer, poet and true gentleman, he loved to sail, hike and engage in lively conversation. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Sally; his daughters, Julia W. DeVuono of Devon (Jeff) and Melissa W. Brewster of Seattle, WA (George); six grandchildren, Jack, Anna and Grace DeVuono; Quinton, Hadley and Davis Brewster. A memorial gathering will be held Saturday, November 23, 2013, 11am, at the Main Line Unitarian Church in Devon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Maine Maritime Museum or The Apprenticeshop.

FOLTZ--William J.,H.J. Heinz Professor Emeritus of African Studies and Political Science, Yale University, died Sunday, 27 October at his home in New Haven, CT. Foltz directed Yale's Center for International and Area Studies and Council on African Studies. Foltz was also a Senior Fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and served on the National Intelligence Council as the National Intelligence Officer for Africa in the Clinton administration. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Anne-Marie Foltz, sons Peter W. Foltz (Adrienne Lee), Boulder, CO, and Jeremy D. Foltz (Erin McBride), Madison, WI, two grandchildren, Miranda Lee-Foltz and W. Kieran Foltz, his sister Jean Gibson (Bob Gibson), Albuquerque, NM, and brothers Bob Foltz, Deep River, CT, and David Devlin-Foltz (Betsy Devlin-Foltz), Silver Spring, MD. Memorial service: 9 November, 4pm, Dwight Chapel, Yale. Donations in William J. Foltz's memory may be made to Neighborhood Music School, New Haven or Thousand Islands Land Trust, Clayton, NY.

BARBARISI--Dr. Vincent Edward, 66, of Rye Brook, NY, passed away suddenly but peacefully on October 23. Vincent was born in New York City, son of the late Dr. Edward and Susan (Perrella) Barbarisi. He graduated from Manhattan College in 1969, and Columbia Dental School in 1973. He entered into practice with his father, also a dentist. He is survived by his beloved wife, Barbara Goodstein, and children, Daniel and Rachel. He is interred at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY.

YANCEY--Mary Anne. SUNY Downstate Medical Center mourns the passing of Mary Anne Yancey, who served on Downstate's Campus Council for 34 years, including many as its chair.
