Williams President, SUNY Downstate Medical Center Dr. Monica Sweeney SUNY Downstate Council Chair

YACHNESS--Chane. With shock and deep sorrow the Blaichman and Gellman family mourns our beloved Chane'leh. Lover of life, laughter, music and Mameh Loshen. Yiddish was her song. Memorial Monday November 4, 7pm, Workmen's Circle, 247 W 37st, NY.
WURTMANN--Arthur Otto, of Brookfield, CT, died October 25, 2013. Lieutenant United States Navy and Office of Strategic Services, Yale '49. Worked for BBD&O and Reader's Digest.

WOOD--Thomas E. Age 74, of Devon, PA, and Cushing, ME, died peacefully at his home in Devon, October 21, 2013, of pancreatic cancer. Born April 20, 1939, in Los Angeles, CA, he was a California boy, endowed with wit and wisdom and a love of surfing. Through his father's vaudeville band, The California Collegians, he spent time with Henry Fonda, Fred MacMurray and his godmother, Harriet Nelson, of Ozzie and Harriet fame. Graduate of The Harvard School for Boys, Studio City, CA, Amherst College ('61) and The University of Pennsylvania Law School ('66). He practiced corporate and securities law for over 40 years with the Philadelphia firm, Drinker, Biddle & Reath. He served on the board of Turner Investments, Inc., and as Board Member and General Counsel for Vertex, Inc. He was the longest serving volunteer for Easttown Township (37 yrs) where he was Chairman of the Zoning Hearing Board, and was a former trustee of The Baldwin School, Bryn Mawr, PA. In Maine, he served on the board of The Maine Maritime Museum, Bath, and co-chaired the board of The Apprenticeshop, Rockland. A voracious reader, gifted writer, poet and true gentleman, he loved to sail, hike and engage in lively conversation. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Sally; his daughters, Julia W. DeVuono of Devon (Jeff) and Melissa W. Brewster of Seattle, WA (George); six grandchildren, Jack, Anna and Grace DeVuono; Quinton, Hadley and Davis Brewster. A memorial gathering will be held Saturday, November 23, 2013, 11am, at the Main Line Unitarian Church in Devon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Maine Maritime Museum or The Apprenticeshop.
WEISS--Phyllis Joan, 84, October 27, 2013. Loving wife of Sheldon, mother to Mitch and Suzinn. Grandson, Harrison. We will miss her dearly.

WEINBERG--James L. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn with great sadness the passing of James L. Weinberg, beloved father of our dear Director Adam Weinberg. James and his late wife Bunny were devoted advocates of arts and culture, a passion that they passed down to their son Adam. James served as Chairman of The Jewish Museum from 1979-1987 during a time of great transformation for the institution and remained committed to the Museum as Chairman Emeritus and Life Trustee. He lived life with enthusiasm, compassion, gratitude and humor. His warmth touched all who knew him and he will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children Jed; Nina, her husband Bruce Doran; Adam, his wife Lorraine; grandchildren Daniel, Zoe and Kira; and brother Marshall. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President

VISLOCKY-STEIGERWALD--Dorothy, a renowned and cherished member of the dance community, died suddenly on October 26 of a brain hemorrhage. She was an extraordinary woman, recognized internationally as a master dance artist/teacher, pioneer in dance kinesiology, and a founding member of the American Dance Therapy Association. Dorothy was an alumna of Hunter College who pursued a professional career in the dance world first as a founding member of the Alwin Nikolais Dance Company and then as artistic director of her own dance company, People/Dorothy Visloky. As Professor of Dance at Hunter College, she founded the undergraduate dance program that flourishes today and which she directed from 1972-1986. The world has lost an exceptional artist, teacher, mentor, visionary leader and cherished friend who will be truly missed. She is survived by her brother John Vislocky of Virginia Beach, her neices Debra Vislocky Ewanciw, Anne Vislocky Carney, Helen Vislocky Coker and nephews Nicholas J. Vislocky, Mark W. Vislocky and Michael Vislocky and stepchildren Jill Martin and John Steiger. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., on Sunday November 10 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Dorothy's memory may be made to Greenpeace Fund Inc., of Suffolk County.

VAN RAALTE--Enid Godnick, passed away on October 31, 2013. Cherished wife of the late Byron (Buddy). Beloved mother of Dr. Polly Vaan Raalte and Susan and Dr. Elliott Hershman. Loving grandmother of Todd and Danny. Adored sister of the late Natalie Ressner and Robert Godnick. It is not how she died, but how she lived. Graveside service Today, 11:30am, Beth Moses Cemetery, West Babylon. Contributions may be made to Music for Autism or SNACK and Friends, Inc.

SYMON--James (Jim), of Saratoga Springs, died peacefully Saturday, October 26, 2013. He will be sadly missed by his wife Shelia and children, William, Geraldine, James and Victoria and by his five beautiful grandchildren. Jim was a giant in his family and in his advertising career. In lieu of flowers please send donations in his name to Mary's Haven, 35 New St., Saratoga Springs, NY 12866. Services are under the direction of the William J. Burke & Sons/Bussing & Cunniff Funeral Homes of 628 North Broadway, Saratoga Springs (518-584-5373). Online remembrances may be made at www.burkefuneralhome.com.

SULLIVAN--Stewart, of New York, NY, died unexpectedly on October 28 at age 84. He will be forever cherished by Judith Alspaugh Sullivan, his beloved wife and best friend of 50 years; his daughter Karen Sullivan, and adoring granddaughter Willa Sullivan. A long-time New Yorker, he was born in Chicago to Humphrey Sullivan and Elizabeth Druce Sullivan. He graduated from Princeton University in 1949, where he was captain of the fencing team. After serving as second lieutenant in the U.S. Army, he joined Pfizer, where his work in International Labor Relations sparked his love of worldwide travel. He retired in 1993. He remained active in his field after retirement, but family was the center of his life. Gathering with loved ones over good meals, cooking, and baking brought him joy. He was a true NY Yankees fan, but remained optimistically loyal to his dear Chicago Cubs. He is also survived by his brother Humphrey Sullivan Jr. and wife Lois; his nieces; nephew; sisters-in-law; and great- nieces and nephews. Donations may be made to: Friends of Princeton Fencing, Attn: Diana Dreyfus, 330 Alexander St. Princeton, NJ, 08540.

STEIN--Mark, 70, A business pioneer of Brooklyn, NY, died Thursday, October 31, 2013. Mark was born to Jacob Stein (deceased) and Matilda Stein (Maiden name Priceman) in Brooklyn, NY and graduated Lincoln High School in 1960 and went on to receive bachelor and master degrees in Architecture, Engineering, and City Planning from NYIT, University of Oklahoma, and Ohio State University. Mark had numerous hobbies and interests from playing the piano to earning a private pilot license but tropical fish was the hobby he loved the most. After a number of years as a practicing architect he started his own tropical fish import/ export business which he grew over the past 40 plus years to be the oldest and most respected in the industry pioneering many of the methods used in this field today. Mark was a founding board member of the industry group Ornamental Fish International (OFI) and his insight and knowledge was sought by ichthyologists from across the world. Mark, along with his wife Analesa, was an active member of the Madison Jewish Center where he served as a Vice President. Mark is survived by his mother, Matilda, wife Analesa, brother Allan, son's David and Brian, and three granddaughters. Funeral services will be held Sunday, November 3, 9:30am at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11234 (718)338-1500.

SILVERSTEIN--Dr. Ira, 74, of Laguna Beach, CA passed away on October 9 after an accident while traveling overseas. He grew up in New Jersey where he graduated from Hillside High as class valedictorian. At Princeton, he was pre-med but majored in English. After graduating from Univ of Pennsylvania Medical School, he did an internship in medicine at Yale and completed a psychiatric residency at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center where he was Chief Resident. He spent two years in the Air Force in Japan. In 1970, moving back to Manhattan, he entered private practice in psychiatry and taught at Columbia Univiersity. In 1988, he relocated to South Orange County, CA, continued a private practice, teaching at Univ of California-Irvine and attending at various hospitals. His many friends, family and colleagues will remember him as literate, wryly humorous, artistic person, a student of classical piano and as an adept, though amateur, painter. He learned early that travel was an essential experience in life and spent his holidays exploring the historic and beautiful places on the planet. He is survived by his life partner, Paul Martin, several cousins and many friends. Donations may be made to American Cancer Society (Mosaic page) or a charity of your choice. A memorial service is planned for November 17 in Laguna Beach, CA.

SIGERSON--Yola Miller, aged 96, died peacefully on October 24, 2013 in New York, after a brief illness. She is survived by her son Davitt Sigerson, daughter-in-law Ana-Rosa Aboitiz and granddaughters Lio and Milena, as well as her husband's children, their spouses and grandchildren, whom she adored: Andra Patterson, Jon Goldstein, Julia and Christopher Gaebler; Gabriel Sigerson; Adam Sigerson, Ann Compton, Andrew Sigerson and Jennifer Sigerson; and also her treasured cousins, nieces and nephews. Yola was generous, opinionated, pleasure-loving, organized, joyous, voraciously well-read, overprotective and perpetually optimistic. In her work life of 70 years, Yola was a researcher on the Federal Theatre Project; lighting designer of The Original Ballet Russe; stage manager and lighting designer on Broadway; producer and director of live events for many progressive causes, including Franklin Roosevelt's re-election campaigns, World War II Victory Bonds, Russian War Relief and We Will Never Die, mostly presented at Madison Square Garden and the Hollywood Bowl; interior decorator; biographer and memoirist. The love of her life was Richard Sigerson, her husband of 47 years. In the event that they are reunited in some sort of afterlife, their delight will be rivaled only by irritation at having their atheism disproven. We will be celebrating Yola's 97 passionate years early in 2014. To get in touch, please email yolasigersonpeople@ gmail.com.

SEEGER--Lou. 91, Port Washington, NY, died October 30, at the home he shared with Shirl Marblestone. Beloved father to Carol, Joshua, and Julie. Devoted uncle, grandfather, great-grandfather and friend. Poet, scholar, athlete - a true renaissance man. Funeral Sunday, November 3, 1:30, Community Synagogue.

SCALETTAR--Josie Michelle, on October 30, 2013. Beloved and cherished daughter of Linda and Eric. Loving sister and best friend of Lilli. Adored Granddaughter of Edie and Marvin Schur and Howard Scalettar and the late Gloria. Services, Monday November 4, 2013, 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC. Shiva to be held at the family residence Monday until 9:00pm and Tuesday 2pm-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Josie's memory to Nassau AHRC, Collide, Maimondies Medical Center.

SAVOY--Sara. Born September 4, 1940. Passed away peacefully in her home Friday, November 1, 2013. Loving and beloved wife of Fred, mother of Marc and Michelle, sister of Judi and Nancy, grandmother of six. Services Monday at Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY.
SAREMSKY--Jean (Goldman), 1923-2013. Beloved wife of Leonard for 66 years, mother of Carol and Andrea, grandmother, great-grandmother and friend. She will be missed by all.

RUSKIN--Sol, well known in the health and beauty industry for many years, died on October 31 at age 92 after a long illness. Born in Warsaw, Poland, he emigrated at age 7 to New York City. He leaves behind his wife Elinor, his children Cheryl Sandler, Eileen Sandler Reich, son-in-law Larry Reich, grandchildren Jamie Doochin, Brian Doochin, Julie Reich and Amy Reich.

POWERS--Claire (Tuohy), of Chappaqua. Passed away peacefully at home on November 1st, 2013. Widow of the loving Arthur. Adored mother of Mary Beth. Cherished sister of Mildred Milligan (nee Tuohy), and the late Mary Gleason, Francis and Arthur. Beloved by her many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, friends and family are asked to make donations to the Humane Society or the Neuberger Museum of Art at SUNY Purchase.

POWELL--William W. "Bill" 76, passed away on October 24, 2013 in Palm Beach, FL. He was born in Woodbury, NJ and raised in Haverford, PA and Buffalo, NY. He attended Amherst Central High in Snyder, NY and went on to become a very proud son of Princeton, graduating Magna Cum Laude, Political Science, in 1959. Bill spent his time between New York City, Palm Beach, Sandisfield, MA and Santa Fe, NM. The majority of Bill's career was with the Colgate - Palmolive Company which contributed to making him a man of the world, a renaissance man. He spoke French and Italian fluently and lived at various times in his life in London, Paris, Zurich, Milan, St. Jean Cap Ferrat, Boston and New York. Bill retired from Colgate in 1985 as Senior Executive Vice President, having served in various management positions as Chief of R&D, President of Colgate - Italy, and President of The Kendall Company. During this period Bill was a member of the Young Presidents Organization, The Commercial Club of Boston, The Longwood Cricket Club, The American Egyptian Chamber of Commerce and The Wianno Club. Bill's later careers took him to the United Nations Development Program and INSEAD, in France. Most recently, he was a member of the University Club, The Princeton Club, The Sailfish Club of Florida and a Board member for 15 Years of the Palm Beach Zoo. Bill was an energetic, world traveler who loved good food, wine, and conversation as well as his alma mater, family and friends. A voracious reader, he was always interested in the news of the day, politics and the latest movies. Bill was a good and generous friend and we will miss his intelligent input, keen wit and zest for life. He is survived by his wife and partner of 30 years, Joanne Paladino, his sister, Maryanne Powell Jones, her husband Bob of Vienna, VA and their family. He also leaves his many great and good friends, Colgate pals, cousins and extended family. A memorial service will be held at 4pm on Wednesday, December 11, 2013 at Saint James Episcopal Church, 71st Street & Madison Avenue, New York, NY. The family request no flowers and donations in his memory may be sent to: Palm Beach Zoo, Presidents Office, 1301 Summit Boulevard, West Palm Beach, FL 33405.

PLATT--Judith Van der Gracht, of Sneden's Landing, NY, who helped co-found the One to One Learning program in Rockland County and served as Head Mistress of the Lower School at The Collegiate School in Manhattan, died of a heart attack on Sunday, October 27th, 2013. Mrs. Platt was 80. She is survived by her husband Frank Cheney Platt, her sons Roger and Arthur Platt and her daughter Sophie Pollok as well as her grandchildren Benjamin and Hilary Platt and Lucas and Esther Pollok. She was predeceased by her sisters Elizabeth Mayer and Josephine Goodden. Mrs. Platt was born in Washington, D.C. on November 22nd, 1932, the daughter of Esther and Arthur Van der Gracht of Little Falls, NY. She attended Milton Academy and Radcliffe College where she graduated Magna cum Laude. She also earned a Masters Degree from Teachers College at Columbia University. She married Frank Platt on July 21st, 1957 in Little Falls NY. In addition to her role at One to One Learning (an English as second language program) and The Collegiate School, Mrs. Platt also worked at School Volunteers, a New York City wide program, and at the Brearly School in Manhattan. A Funeral Service was held on November 2nd at Our Lady of the Sacred Heart in Tappan, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to One to One Learning (www.one2one-learning.org) would be greatly appreciated.

PARKER--Chauncey Goodrich, III, 86, died peacefully on October 7, 2013 in Orlando, FL. Father, Marine, author, professor, banker, adviser to Adlai Stevenson during the Cuban Missile Crisis, Parker graduated from St. Paul's School, Harvard University and Harvard Business School. He spent the latter part of his life teaching English to eager young college students at Valencia College. Married twice, he is survived by his children, Cecilia Mercer, Chauncey G. Parker, IV, Stuart S. Parker and seven grandchildren. He was buried privately.

NORVELL--Patsy. It is with regret and sorrow that the founding members of AIR Gallery and those artists who have shown there in the ensuing years note the untimely death of early member Patsy Norvell on October 12, 2013. Prescient artist, pioneer, feminist, math wiz, loving mother and fine empathic human being. It is our hope in the future that the breadth and depth of her work will be acknowledged and celebrated.

NOLAN--Diane, on October 29, 2013. Wife of the late Raymond. Loving Companion of Joel Small. Dear friend of Paula Reich Memorial Mass Wednesday November 6, 2013 10:00am St. Paul the Apostle Church, NYC.

NICOLAU--Siobhan, 82. Of New York City and Banteer, Ireland, died peacefully in Ireland on September 23, 2013, with her husband George Nicolau, three of her children and a granddaughter at her side. The cause of death was a rare form of cancer. At the Ford Foundation from 1969 to 1981, where she was the first female Senior Program Officer in National Affairs, her portfolio included both Hispanic and Native American organizations. Fluent in Spanish, Mrs. Nicolau, then known as Siobhan Oppenheimer, was instrumental in nurturing the National Council of La Raza, now the largest Hispanic civil rights and advocacy organization in the United States. She also funded and advised the National Congress of American Indians, as well as numerous tribal organizations, including those in Alaska, assisting them in the Alaskan Natives land grant settlement. In 1981, Mrs. Nicolau founded the Hispanic Policy Development Project, a policy analysis group dedicated to Hispanic-American issues. A consultant to Ewing Marion Kauffman in his establishment of the Kauffman Foundation, she became a Trustee of that organization at Mr. Kauffman's request in 1993 and, until her resignation in 2012, was its longest serving Trustee. She was also a Board member of Public/Private Ventures, the Enterprise Foundation, and the only non-Native American Board member of the First Nations Development Institute. She also conducted the annual Aspen Institute Seminar on Hispanic Americans and the Business Community, and, along with John Gardner and Waldemar Nielson, founded the National Film Archive of Philanthropy, and was instrumental in creating HEAF, the Harlem Education Activities Fund. A nationally recognized authority on philanthropy and a champion of minorities and human rights, Siobhan was one of the authors of the "Glass Ceiling" report for the US Department of Labor and provided consulting services to a number of family foundations as well as Univision, Hallmark, Levi Strauss, the Walton Foundation, and the Daniel and Joana S. Rose Fund. She is survived by her husband, their children, Trudy, David and John Oppenheimer and Brien and Anthony Nicolau and six grandchildren, Ben and Mason Fields, Andreas Nicolau, and Megan, Mikaela and Adelaide Oppenheimer and her brother, Jack Caffrey. A Celebration of Life service will be held at St. Marks Church, 10th Street and 2nd Ave. in New York on Saturday, December 7th, at 1:00 to 4:00pm. Mrs. Nicolau had asked, in lieu of flowers, that donations be made to Human Rights First, defender of freedom, justice and the rule of law throughout the world.

MYERS--Fred, 87. We are devoted to you in memory as you were to us in life. We will miss so much about you, especially your humor. Dottie is now lucky to have you again. Your loving kids, the Myers, Schrage, and Orenstein families.

MIGEL--Peter Forshew M.D.,age 68, died on Sunday, October 27, 2013 at his home outside of San Diego, California. He was surrounded by his wife, his three children, and all of his grandchildren. In 1976, Dr. Migel was a founding partner of Tenafly Pediatrics in Tenafly, New Jersey where he practiced for twenty years. In 1996, he began his own practice specializing in Developmental and Behavioral Pediatrics in New Jersey. During these years he was affiliated with Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York City where he served as Chief Resident in Pediatrics in 1975 1976, and with Englewood Hospital, Englewood, New Jersey, where he also served as Chief of Pediatrics at from 1988 to 1990. Throughout his life, Dr. Migel was dedicated to his family and his patients. Dr. Migel is survived by his wife of 48 years, Terry, his daughters, Thea and Naomi (Lafata), his son Noah and his wife Gwendolyn (Ty) as well as his grandchildren: Katie, age 13, Jacob, age 11, Sophia, age seven, Oscar, age four, and Delanie, age 18 months. The family held a private service to celebrate Peter's life on Tuesday, October 29, 2013. Any and all condolences and communications may be sent to: InMemoryOfPeterMigel@ gmail.com In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Children's Defense Fund Attn: Development Department, 25 E. Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20001 Visit: www.childrensdefense.org/ support-our-work/other- giving-options

MCKIM-SMITH--Gridley, died on October 18, 2013 from an acute bacterial infection. Born in Clinton, IA on March 14, 1943. She studied at Tulane (BA 1965) and Harvard (PhD 1974). She was married to Benjamin Franklin Smith III (Frank) from 1969 until his death in 1990. In 1982, while serving as a Senior Fellow at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., she came to Bryn Mawr College as Assistant Professor, becoming Mellon Professor in 1999. Gridley was a trailblazer in Latin American, costume and gender studies and in her emphasis on technical scientific examination of works of art. Examining Velazquez (1988) was the first publication of this kind at the Prado Museum. Undeterred by over 40 years of multiple sclerosis, Gridley taught ardently, traveled extensively and will be remembered lovingly by all who knew her. She will be buried in Quincy, FL, next to her husband. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a later date. Donations in her name will be gratefully accepted by The Gift of Sunshine (thegiftofsunshine.org), the organization that trained two of Gridley's service dogs.

McGUIRE--Helen, on October 28, 2013, in Brooklyn in her 98th year. Survived by her beloved daughters Janice McGuire (Charlie Niessner) and Nancy Valente; granddaughter Cris (Sean) Grace; and three special great-grandsons; Sullivan, Braden, and Devin. Her generosity, wit, caring and enthusiasm for life will be sorely missed by them as well as numerous other family, neighbors, and friends. A memorial gathering will be held at a later date. Please visit: CobbleHillChapels.com or contact Cobble Hill Chapels directly for further info.

MALCOLM-NARIZZANO--Aileen M.,passed away July 31, 2013. Artist, writer, actress, lover, mother, sister, friend, world traveler, activist, inspiration and so much more, is sorely missed. A celebration of life memorial service will be held on January 10th, 2014 on Tortola, BVI. Contact: aileensmemorial@gmail.com

MALCOLM-NARIZZANO--Aileen M.,passed away July 31, 2013. Artist, writer, actress, lover, mother, sister, friend, world traveler, activist, inspiration and so much more, is sorely missed. A celebration of life memorial service will be held on January 10th, 2014 on Tortola, BVI. Contact: aileensmemorial@gmail.com

LERNER--Frank, 97, of New York and formerly also of Westhampton Beach. Beloved husband of the late Rosalind Lerner and brother of the late fine art publisher Harry H Lerner. Professional free-lance photographer who was the first to photograph the Michelangelo ceilings of the Sistine Chapel in its entirety, on assignment for Life Magazine shortly after WWII---half life-size illuminations of his photographs of those ceiling paintings were on display every Easter in the Time-Life building for more than 20 years; and the only western photographer to photograph the Hermitage art collection in Moscow in 1957 during the height of the Cold War, on assignment for Time Magazine. Avid sailor and early proponent and enthusiast for racing catamarans. Leaves his sons Kenneth and Michael; two beloved nephews, Jonathan Strong and Franklin Silverman; beloved niece, Judith Taylor; best friend Katie Karkus and grandsons Josh and Jonah.

LEIMAN--Leonard. The Jewish Foundation for Education of Women wishes to express its sorrow on the passing of Leonard Leiman, beloved father of our Executive Director, Elizabeth Leiman Kraiem. Our condolences to Elizabeth, her mother Joan, her brother Alan and the entire Leiman family. May his memory be a blessing. Jill W. Smith, President Sharon L. Weinberg, Chair

LEIMAN--Leonard. In loving memory of our dear friend and long time board member, Leonard Leiman, the Siebert Financial Corp family extends their heartfelt condolences to Joan, Elizabeth, Alan and the entire family.

LEIMAN--Leonard M.,age 82, peacefully, at home, on October 30th. Loving husband, father, grandfather, uncle and great uncle, a lawyer's lawyer and accomplished angler, respected for his integrity, intelligence, quick wit and sound judgment. Born and raised in Maspeth, Queens, he was a graduate of Wesleyan University and the Harvard Law School where he was an editor of the Harvard Law Review. Leonard served as a law clerk for Judge Learned Hand of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, and Justice John Marshall Harlan of the United States Supreme Court. He joined the former Reavis & McGrath in 1956, becoming a partner in 1963, played an important role in the firm's merger with Fulbright & Jaworski, and remained of counsel to the Norton Rose Fulbright firm. Leonard practiced securities law and advised many nonprofits, particularly in the Jewish world. Many companies relied on his advice and counsel to navigate the complex regulatory environments in which they operated and raised capital. He was a member of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, a member of the Legal Affairs Committee of the New York Stock Exchange and was past chair of the Committee on Securities Regulation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. He taught corporations and securities law as a visiting professor at the University of Pennsylvania, Yale, and New York Law Schools. He is survived by his wife of 58 years Joan (Maisel), his children Elizabeth (Ruben Kraiem), Alan (Annette Ooyevaar), grandchildren Renee, Ari, Leon, sister Joan (Leiman Jacobson), sister-in-law and brother-in-law Alice Jo and Marshall Lichtman, nieces Anne Cowett, Susan Uriarte, Joanne Lichtman, Pam Reading, and nephew Fred Cowett. Funeral Service Friday, November 1st at 9:30am at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street. The family will be at home receiving visitors at 1125 Park Ave. on Saturday evening from 7pm, and on Sunday afternoon from 4pm. Donations, in lieu of flowers, to Wesleyan University, or Madison River Foundation, Odell Project, Ennis, MT.

LANDES--Carmela Dr.,Dalton mourns the loss of Dr. Carmela Landes, mother of Hannah Landes '13 and Michael Landes '15, a dedicated doctor, mother and committed friend. She will be greatly missed. We send deepest sympathy to Hannah, Michael, their father Robert O'Sullivan and their extended family. Ellen C. Stein, Head of School

KURTIN--Dr. Stephen Brill, died November 2, 2013, in his home in Atlanta after a long battle with prostate cancer. He was 74 years old. Born in New York City on March 21, 1939, to Lillian and Dr. Abner Kurtin, he attended The Fieldston School and graduated cum laude from Princeton University in 1961. Dr. Kurtin received his medical degree from Columbia P&S, interned at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, and did his residency in dermatology at NYU Hospital. He was in private practice in Manhattan from 1969 until 2006. Dr. Kurtin then moved to Atlanta, where he joined a private dermatology group, before retiring in 2011. With teaching his first love, Dr. Kurtin joined the Department of Dermatology of Mount Sinai School of Medicine in 1965 and remained an active member of the staff until his death. He participated in the training of over 200 residents, several of whom said they chose to become dermatologists after taking an elective with him during their medical school training. He was twice named "Teacher of the Year." In 2012 he received the "Lifetime Achievement Award" "for decades of teaching and mentorship to the next generation of dermatologists." Dr. Kurtin was a competitive swimmer and an All-American and Princeton record holder. He continued to compete in Masters Swimming up until his 60s and achieved top rankings many times. He is survived by his children Abner of Chestnut Hill, MA, Sarah Levy of Atlanta, GA, and Elizabeth Steinberg of New York City as well as by grandchildren Catherine, Alexander, and Anna Kurtin; Alexa and Dylan Levy; and Nicole and Olivia Steinberg. He is also survived by his brother Jonathan of New York City, and sisters Joan Tobin of Westport, CT, and Dr. Laura Alpern of El Paso, TX, and his sons-in-law Dr. Jason Levy and Mathew Steinberg. The time and location of a memorial service will be announced shortly. Please add your memories at: www.imorial.com/popopdoc.
KUCKER--Heidi. Christie's colleagues, past and present, mourn the loss of a wonderful friend and colleague.

KELLOGG--Joan Cantelo. Daughter of Samuel and Eva Cantelo of Quincy, MA. She died suddenly in her home on October 30. She is survived by her husband Dwight and her children and spouses Kim K. Devoe (Alan), David D. (Shannon) and Jenny E. (Ryan Miller) and by her grandchildren Malcolm, Bryce and Cameron Devoe and Nathaniel D. Kellogg. She was a graduate of Boston University and devoted her life to her family and community. She loved life and all those in her life. She uplifted us all. A memorial service will be held at Rye Presbyterian Church on November 23.

IASON--John Williams. Loving husband of Valorie, extraordinary father of Scott and Lizzie, treasured father-in-law of Ali and Teo, adoring grandfather of Drew and Kate. John was an alumnus of the Phillips Exeter Academy and of the University of North Carolina where he played varsity lacrosse. John was the much loved son of the late Girard Iason and the late Jeanne Iason. He was the devoted brother of Larry and Barbara. John was a successful businessman who worked with his father at N. Erlanger Blumgart, a textile converter. John was an excellent athlete who played tennis, squash and golf. He had many wonderful friends, but most of all he lived for his family, and his family adored him. John and Valorie were married for over 43 years. They had a love affair that enriched their lives until the end.

HOWARD--Robert Thomas. Ending a life that many would have envied, Robert Thomas Howard passed away peacefully at Senior Star Memory Care in Romeoville, Illinois on October 31, 2013. He was 90 years old. He is survived by his children, Karen (Matt) Kazmierski of Bolingbrook, Geoffrey (Fanny) Howard of New York, Leslie Howard of California and his wife, Barbara Howard, of Boynton Beach, Florida. After earning his degree at George Washington University, Bob joined the Navy and served in the Pacific during WWII as a Lt. JG. After the Navy, Bob began his long career in sales in the floor covering industry. Memorial services are private. It is requested that those wishing to honor Bob's memory visit his online memorial at: http://memorialwebsites. legacy.com/robertthoward/ homepage.aspx.

HOFFMAN--Jean, formerly of Brooklyn and South Hempstead, NY, died October 24, 2013 after enthusiastically embracing life for 94 years. Mom gave her children, Susan and Ed, their families, as well as her late husband, Jerry, boundless love and great memories.

HEISLER--Leslye Mathes. Leslye M. Heisler, of Wilmington, DE and Palm Beach, FL passed away on October 22, 2013 at home with her family present. Mrs. Heisler was 83 years old. She was born in St. Louis, Missouri and spent her early childhood in Shreveport, Louisiana. The family moved back to St. Louis where she attended Mary Institute for her middle and high school years. Leslye attended Washington University and graduated with honors. In the summer of 1952 while visiting the East Coast, she met her future husband on a blind date and six months later married him and moved to Wilmington, Delaware. Leslye was deeply loved by her family. She became active in community service work; her favorites included the Junior Board of the Medical Center of Delaware, President of the Auxiliary of the Kutz Home and DIAL, a hotline for young children. In time several women's stores asked her to model clothes. She modeled clothes in New York, Philadelphia and Wilmington. Leslye took up golf and over the next 50 years she became a very good golfer with a low handicap. She played Team Golf for two different country clubs as well as playing the great golf courses throughout the United States and Europe. In her later years, she took up bridge and became a Bronze Life Master, playing Tournament Bridge and still playing golf. The theater, arts and literature all benefited from her enthusiastic support. Leslye loved clothes and had the natural ability to understand how colors, fabrics and design blended together to create style and fashion. She believed in being well dressed at all times regardless of age, and she was! Leslye and her husband, Jerome S. Heisler Sr., had just returned from a safari trip to South Africa and Zimbabwe when she was stricken with lung cancer. She is survived by her husband, Jerome S. Heisler, Sr., her daughter Carla Graeff (Stephen) and her son Jerome S. Heisler, Jr. (Rebecca) and four grandchildren; Jen Graeff, Kate Graeff, Joshua Heisler and Rachel Heisler. Funeral services were private. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in Leslye's name to the American Cancer Society, 92 Read's Way, Suite 205, New Castle, DE 19720. Services by Chandler Funeral Home www.chandlerfuneralhome. com

HALPERN--Sam. The board, officers and staff of Development Corporation for Israel/Israel Bonds mourn the passing of Sam Halpern. A man of courage and resolve, Mr. Halpern survived the horrors of the Holocaust to become a successful businessman, generous philanthropist and inspiring mentor. Motivated by the precept "Never Again," he was a determined supporter of Israel through Israel Bonds. He passionately imparted his beliefs to his children, who today are prominent leaders in their own right. Mr. Halpern was an outstanding member of a unique generation, and his achievements will be remembered with admiration and respect. The Bonds organization offers heartfelt condolences to the Halpern family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion. Richard Hirsch, Chairman of the Board Izzy Tapoohi, President & CEO
GRAYSON--Joy Kahn. We sadly mourn your sudden passing. Your smile, your charm and loving kindness will forever be in our hearts and memory. Anita and Norton Waltuch

GRANEY--Lisa, 1923 - 2013 Lisa Graney died Sunday, October 27th, in Las Cruces, New Mexico. The cause of death was complications due to lung disease. Lisa was an active member of Temple Avoda in Fairlawn, New Jersey, Vassar Temple in Poughkeepsie, New York, and Temple Shaaray Tefila, in New York City. She led a life of service to all around her. Liselotte Margarete Susman was born January 11, 1923 in Mannheim, Germany. She lived with her family in Landau in der Pfalz until 1931, when the rise of the Nazi party forced the family's move to Milan, Italy. In 1938, Lisa went to London. Early in World War II, Lisa, a German citizen, was interned on the Isle of Man. Released in the summer of 1941, Lisa completed her nanny training. In 1945, she became a U.S. Army postal censor in occupied Germany. Stationed in Berlin, she eventually ended up in New York City. Her 1951 marriage to John F. Graney, Jr. ended in divorce, but she remained a Graney to the end of her days. In addition to her husband, Ronald Hahn, Lisa is survived by her son John (Laurel), granddaughters Rachel and Robin Graney of Great Barrington, Massachusetts, and her son Daniel (Wendy), and granddaughters Rebecca and Naomi Graney, of East Quogue, New York. She leaves two stepsons, Dave Hahn of Taos, New Mexico and Harold Hahn of Kingston, New York, and stepdaughter Carolyn Hahn, of New York City. Lisa's older brother, Peter, died in 1975. Her younger brother, George, died in 1957. A memorial service will be held at Vassar Temple, 140 Hooker Avenue, Poughkeepsie, on Sunday, November 24, 2013 at 1pm. Interment will be private. Lisa was a contributor to the Leo Baeck Institute Center for Jewish History, where donations may be made in her memory. 15 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011.
GAFFNEY--Robert E.,died on October 25th at age 67. Retired direct marketing executive and avid woodworker, he is missed by his wife of 32 years and three children, Catherine, Jules, and Brendan.

FOX--Jerrold B.,72, of New York City passed away suddenly Tuesday, October 15th, 2013. Beloved husband and father of Judith and Aram. Survived by his brother, Michael, and sister, Rosie. The quintessential New Yorker, Jerry was born in Manhattan, considered his years in Queens an aberration and returned in 1968 for the rest of his life. Expressions of sympathy may be made to SHARE: Dedicated, Experienced Support for Women Facing Breast and Ovarian Cancer, 1501 Seventh Avenue, Suite 704A, New York, NY 10036. (212) 719-0364.

FOLTZ--William J.,H.J. Heinz Professor Emeritus of African Studies and Political Science, Yale University, died Sunday, 27 October at his home in New Haven, CT. Foltz directed Yale's Center for International and Area Studies and Council on African Studies. Foltz was also a Senior Fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and served on the National Intelligence Council as the National Intelligence Officer for Africa in the Clinton administration. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Anne-Marie Foltz, sons Peter W. Foltz (Adrienne Lee), Boulder, CO, and Jeremy D. Foltz (Erin McBride), Madison, WI, two grandchildren, Miranda Lee-Foltz and W. Kieran Foltz, his sister Jean Gibson (Bob Gibson), Albuquerque, NM, and brothers Bob Foltz, Deep River, CT, and David Devlin-Foltz (Betsy Devlin-Foltz), Silver Spring, MD. Memorial service: 9 November, 4pm, Dwight Chapel, Yale. Donations in William J. Foltz's memory may be made to Neighborhood Music School, New Haven or Thousand Islands Land Trust, Clayton, NY.

FAGENSON--Morton I. Passed away on Wednesday, October 30 with his son and daughter-in-law by his side. Predeceased by his wife Suzanne J. Gerton Fagenson and daughter Ellen A. Fagenson Eland. Survived by son Lawrence M. (Lauren White) Fagenson, granddaughter Kelly Eland, son-in-law David Kodner, nieces Leslie and Dawn Fagenson, Ginger Gerton and nephew Dr. Manny Gerton, cousin Lucille Butler Gray and many friends at Belmont Park.

ERICKSON--Mitchell, who was passionate about life and the theater, died peacefully in his home in Portland, OR on October 22. He was 92. Born in Duluth, MN, he lived there until he joined the Navy. During WWII, he was stationed in Hawaii. After the war, he majored in drama at the University of Hawaii and graduated in 1948. He then moved to NYC and began a long, illustrious career as an actor and stage manager. He worked on many Broadway plays, including Judgment at Nuremberg, The Sunshine Boys, The Gin Game, Long Day's Journey into Night, You Can't Take it with You, Private Lives, Luther and The Best Man. He worked with some of the best actors, playwrights and directors of our time: Ian McKellen, Jason Robards, Woody Allen, Maggie Smith, Julie Harris, Uta Hagen, Tony Randall, Eileen Atkins, Tennessee Williams, Tom Stoppard, John Wood, Sigourney Weaver & Deborah Kerr. But his most cherished role was that of a wonderful son, brother, uncle and friend. His sense of humor, enthusiasm and generosity enriched the lives of everyone around him. He was deeply and sincerely loved. He is survived by his sister Kay Lindberg and her husband Bob Lindberg; nieces Kathy Abel, Andrea Carlson and Robin Coyle; nephews Scott and Tom Lindberg; 12 grandnieces and nephews and three great-grandnieces. A memorial service is being planned. Donations in his name can be made to St. Jude Children's Hospital.

ENTMACHER--Doris, of Clearbrook, Monroe Township, NJ; Westbury, NY; and New York City, on October 24 at 93. Beloved mother of Rita Entmacher Cohen and Joan Entmacher, grandmother of Evan Cohen, and wife of the late Jack Entmacher. Served on the Zoning Board and led other community and charitable activities for many years.

ENGORON--Edna June Fredericks. Passed away peacefully at home on November 1st, 2013 at the age of 89. Predeceased by her loving husband Malcolm, Sr., son, Malcolm, Jr. (Elan) and daughter-in-law, Debbi. Dear mother of Arthur (Dawn), Frank (Ida), Daniel (Sara) and Gerald (Diane). Beloved grandmother of Stacey, Ian, Eric, Jack, Victoria, Aaron and Ashley. Graveside services Sunday, 11am, at Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, NY.
DUNN--Michael J.,89, Psychologist, of Pittsburgh, PA. He loved New York. WWII Veteran, Anzio, Three Purple Hearts. Painfully missed by soulmate, wife Joanne.

DEMPSEY--Michael G, DO, NYC and Saylorsburg, PA, died Monday, 28 October. Dr. Dempsey maintained a private practice, Manhattan Rehab in NYC for 29 years. Most recently he worked for Coordinated Health, Stroudsburg, PA. He will be deeply missed by his wife, PJ (Haduch) Dempsey, brother "Jack," sister Betty Jane, family members and patients. He will be remembered for his humanity, honesty, empathy, integrity, expertise, and wicked sense of humor. A memorial mass will be held at St. Xavier, St. Mary Chapel, 55 West 15th St, NYC, noon, on November 19.

CHASE--Chris. Died peacefully at home on October 31st. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. Chris was a model, an actor in starring roles on stage, in films and television. She wrote eight books, including several best-sellers. She could sing, dance and was a brilliant storyteller. She was smart, funny and beautiful. Chris is survived by her husband Michael L. Chase; brother Paul Greengard (Ursula Von Rydingsvard); sister Linda Stein (Howard Stein); nephew Glen Olsheim (Elizabeth); and niece Aiinslie Kaufer; all of whom loved her and will miss her very much.

BOGART--Agnes, died October 4, 2013, age 97. Married Leo Bogart 1948. Labor Activist, worked for Reuther Brothers, Industrial Relations Research Counselors, American Management Association, Equitable Life Assurance. Editor, master chef, yoga enthusiast, she leaves behind her children Michele and Greg Bogart, and grandson Nicholas Pauly.

BARRON--Dr. Kevin, died October 28, 2013. Survived by wife, Lisa, son Kevin, daughter Sheila, four grandchildren, brother Robert. BARR--Ellie, star of stage, screen and radio. Bank Street Cary Fellow. Extraordinary educator. Extraordinary friend. Janie Lou

BALLA--John T.,70, of Jackson Heights, Queens, native of Nanticoke, PA died October 28, 2013. Graduating from Nanticoke High School in 1960 and Wilkes College, Wilkes-Barre, PA in 1965, John was employed by the United States Treasury Department for many years and last as a Computer Audit Specialist with U.S. Customs Service in New York for 26 years. He was a member of the Wagner Society of New York as well as the Appalachian Mountain Club and the Central Park folk dance group. Surviving are three sisters, several nieces and nephews and ex-spouse, the former Linda Ricci. Memorial Service on Tuesday, November 26, 2013 at 11:30am in St. John Slovak Lutheran Church, 604 S. Hanover St., Nanticoke, PA 18634. Davis-Dinelli Funeral Home, 170 E.Broad St., Nanticoke, PA (570)735-5370.

AISENBERG--Alan C.,MD, PhD, on October 27th in New York City at age 86. Beloved husband for 47 years of the late Nadya Margulies Aisenberg; devoted father of Dr. James and Suzanne Aisenberg of New York and Dr. Margaret K. Aisenberg of Cambridge, MA; cherished grandfather of Jonathan, Nathaniel and Penelope; dear brother of the late Bernard Aisenberg. Scientist, scholar, physician, mentor, citizen. We love you and thank you for all that you have given us. Donations may be made to the Harvard Medical School for the Alan C. Aisenberg, MD, PhD, '50 Financial Aid Fund. LEVY--Peter A.,a Celebration of Peter's Life will be held at the Metropolitan Club (One East 60th) on Monday, November 4th from 05:30pm 08:00 pm with a short remembrance at 06:30pm. Jacket and tie is required for gentlemen.
WURTMANN--Arthur Otto, of Brookfield, CT, died October 25, 2013. Lieutenant United States Navy and Office of Strategic Services, Yale '49. Worked for BBD&O and Reader's Digest.

THIER--Ronald Saul, DDS, 83 years old, born in Brooklyn, passed away November 1, 2013. He died as he lived, with grace and dignity. He leaves behind a grateful family that will love him and cherish his memory forever: his wife of 60 years, Connie, his children: Adrienne and Alan, Jonathan and Virginia, Joshua and Sandra, and grandchildren: Matthew, Zachary, Alixandra, Ryan, Jane, Grace, Hannah and Sophie. Donations in his memory can be made to: Polio Connections of America, PO Box 182, Howard Beach, NY 11414.

STOTTER--Herbert James, Jr.,"Jim" of Scarsdale, NY, passed away peacefully after a brief illness on November 2nd, 2013 at age 88, surrounded by his loving family. A proud native of Shaker Heights, OH, won his first golf club championship at Oakwood Country Club at age 16, was the captain of the Northwestern University golf team and 12-time club champion at Sunningdale Country Club. Served as president of the Westchester Golf Association, Metropolitan Golf Association and the Chicago Gift Show. With his partner H. William Ettelson, Jr., ran H.J. Stotter, Inc., manufacturers of plastic tabletop and decorative accessories. Jim is survived by his daughters Nan Zinaman (Steve), Wendy Stotter, Cindy Weichert (Peter), granddaughters Sara Cetron (Brad), Stefanie Weichert, great-grandson Isaac Cetron, and his sister, Sandra Ettelson (Bill). He was predeceased by his wives S. Patricia Rosenthal Stotter and Patricia Jacobs Stotter. A gathering to honor his life will be held at Sunningdale Country Club: 300 Underhill Road, Scarsdale, NY on Wednesday, November 6th, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Greenberg Nature Center, Jim Stotter Playground Fund, 99 Dromore Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

SIGERSON--Yola Miller, aged 96, died peacefully on October 24, 2013 in New York, after a brief illness. She is survived by her son Davitt Sigerson, daughter-in-law Ana-Rosa Aboitiz and granddaughters Lio and Milena, as well as her husband's children, their spouses and grandchildren, whom she adored: Andra Patterson, Jon Goldstein, Julia and Christopher Gaebler; Gabriel Sigerson; Adam Sigerson, Ann Compton, Andrew Sigerson and Jennifer Sigerson; and also her treasured cousins, nieces and nephews. Yola was generous, opinionated, pleasure-loving, organized, joyous, voraciously well-read, overprotective and perpetually optimistic. In her work life of 70 years, Yola was a researcher on the Federal Theatre Project; lighting designer of The Original Ballet Russe; stage manager and lighting designer on Broadway; producer and director of live events for many progressive causes, including Franklin Roosevelt's re-election campaigns, World War II Victory Bonds, Russian War Relief and We Will Never Die, mostly presented at Madison Square Garden and the Hollywood Bowl; interior decorator; biographer and memoirist. The love of her life was Richard Sigerson, her husband of 47 years. In the event that they are reunited in some sort of afterlife, their delight will be rivaled only by irritation at having their atheism disproven. We will be celebrating Yola's 97 passionate years early in 2014. To get in touch, please email yolasigersonpeople@ gmail.com.

STERN--Walter H.,of Roslyn Harbor, NY and Boca Raton, FL, on November 2nd, 2013, age 88. Former Reporter and Assistant Real Estate Editor for the New York Times. Public relations executive for Mobil Oil and numerous firms. Author of six books. Former City of Glen Cove Commissioner of Assessments. Beloved husband of Donata for 62 years. Father of Roger (Gail) and Claudia (Ed). Grandfather of Jeremy and Hillary Gemma. Service at the North Country Reform Temple (#

SALTZMAN--Winifred (Loeb), age 101, of Natick, MA, formerly of Passaic, NJ, entered into rest early Wednesday morning, October 30, 2013. Predeceased by her beloved husband J. Bernard Saltzman in 1978, she is survived by her son, Peter R. Saltzman, MD, and his wife Betty of Natick; her sister, Norma Ehrenberg of Natick; and her loving grandchildren and great-grandchildren. For the full obituary and to leave condolences for the Saltzman Family, please visit: www.everettfuneral.com.

PULAKOS--Milton, on October 31. Of NYC and Columbia County, New York. 88. Beloved husband of Barbara Poska. Devoted father of Carla (Steve) Palumbo, Christopher (Charlene) and Peter Pulakos. Cherished grandfather of Paul, Chris, Katie, Alex, Nick, Noah, and step-grandson Keith. Great-grandfather of Elizabeth. Dear brother of Elaine Adam and George Pulakos (deceased). Service at Judson Memorial Church, Greenwich Village from 12-5pm, November 5. Donations may be made to American Friends Service Committee, Central Park Conservancy or Habitat for Humanity.

POWERS--Claire (Tuohy), of Chappaqua, on November 1st, 2013. Widow of the loving Arthur. Adored mother of Mary Beth. Cherished sister of Mildred Milligan (nee Tuohy). Resting Monday from 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Beecher Flooks Funeral Home 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10am at St. John and St. Mary Church (Little Church), Chappaqua, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends and family are asked to make donations to the Humane Society or the Neuberger Museum of Art at SUNY Purchase.

MURRAY--Lennie Roker, January 16, 1932 - October 31, 2013. Born in NYC to Leonard and Bertha Roker, retired from NYC MTA. Mother of Gregory and Larry. Married Paul Murray 1981. Survived by grand kids Sascha, Lemar and Kareem Roker; Jeron and Yolanda Brown.

MARCUS--Arthur C.,97. A fine, wonderful man. Predeceased by Gertrude, his adored wife of 63 years. Companion to his darling Doris Zimmer. Cherished father of Joan Rosenberg and Steven Marcus. Beloved grandfather of Scott and Ali Rosenberg, Stacey and James Gordon, Jamie and Jimmy Schwartz and Kimberly and Jeff Moskowitz. Proud great-grandfather of Jake, Ryan, Emma, Brett, Charlie, Carly, Sam, Jack, William, Tori, Gillian, Juliet, Alex, Kate, Phoebe and Tyler. And dear friend and confidant of Paula Joseph. Arthur was a man of impeccable integrity. He was charming, engaging, smart, generous and tough. He loved life, he loved people, he loved to talk and he loved to walk. He was a textile executive for 39 years at Cohn Hall Marx, Inc., where he brought double knits to America. He disdained hypocrisy, yet refused to be a harsh judge of others. He was so thrilled with his 16 great-grandchildren, and loved his family deeply. He will be terribly missed but constantly remembered.

LEIMAN--Leonard. In loving memory of our dear friend and long time board member, Leonard Leiman, the Siebert Financial Corp family extends their heartfelt condolences to Joan, Elizabeth, Alan and the entire family.

MAFFEI--Robert A.,retired Special Agent, FBI, of Scarsdale on November 1, 2013. Beloved husband of Patricia. Loving father of Mary Elizabeth (Dan) Hennessy, Anne Catharine (Roger) Fitton, Robert (Lynn) and Patricia. Devoted grandfather of Grace and Emily. Brother of Alice Forrest Peschel. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of Fatima Church, Scarsdale, on Wednesday, November 6 at 10am.

KURTIN--Dr. Stephen Brill, died November 2, 2013, in his home in Atlanta after a long battle with prostate cancer. He was 74 years old. Born in New York City on March 21, 1939, to Lillian and Dr. Abner Kurtin, he attended The Fieldston School and graduated cum laude from Princeton University in 1961. Dr. Kurtin received his medical degree from Columbia P&S, interned at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, and did his residency in dermatology at NYU Hospital. He was in private practice in Manhattan from 1969 until 2006. Dr. Kurtin then moved to Atlanta, where he joined a private dermatology group, before retiring in 2011. With teaching his first love, Dr. Kurtin joined the Department of Dermatology of Mount Sinai School of Medicine in 1965 and remained an active member of the staff until his death. He participated in the training of over 200 residents, several of whom said they chose to become dermatologists after taking an elective with him during their medical school training. He was twice named "Teacher of the Year." In 2012 he received the "Lifetime Achievement Award" "for decades of teaching and mentorship to the next generation of dermatologists." Dr. Kurtin was a competitive swimmer and an All-American and Princeton record holder. He continued to compete in Masters Swimming up until his 60s and achieved top rankings many times. He is survived by his children Abner of Chestnut Hill, MA, Sarah Levy of Atlanta, GA, and Elizabeth Steinberg of New York City as well as by grandchildren Catherine, Alexander, and Anna Kurtin; Alexa and Dylan Levy; and Nicole and Olivia Steinberg. He is also survived by his brother Jonathan of New York City, and sisters Joan Tobin of Westport, CT, and Dr. Laura Alpern of El Paso, TX, and his sons-in-law Dr. Jason Levy and Mathew Steinberg. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 10th at 10am in theGoldwurm Auditorium, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, 1425 Madison Avenue. Please add your memories at: www.imorial.com/popopdoc.

KUCKER--Heidi, a dear friend and colleague of the original Special Client Group at Christie's. Always kind and concerned for the welfare of others, she enriched our lives and the lives of our clients with her wit, charm and joy of life. We will remember the hard work and laughter we shared. Heidi was a star, we loved her very much, and she will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Susan Rolfe and Kim Solow

GOLDSTEIN--Seymour L.,CPA, of Manhattan died November 2nd at age 96. Cherished great-uncle of Eric Friedman and Randi Austell. Seymour was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Esther Iger, and niece Ruth Friedman. A WWII veteran and graduate of Baruch College, Uncle Seymour was beloved by the Friedman and Chernev families and his devoted caregivers. Donations to Ruth and Fred Friedman Scholarship fund at Brandeis University.

FEINMAN--Elaine Galin, 90, mother of Michael and Meredith, adored grandmother of Phoebe, Joshua, Abby and Sarah. Graveside family service. Shiva at home of Meredith Feinman and Eric Seiff, November 6, 7, 6-9pm.

BENDEL--John Henri, of Boston and formerly of New York City, died peacefully on October 31, at Massachusetts General Hospital after a brief illness surrounded by his loving wife and family of friends. Mr. Bendel was the President and Owner of Belgian Shoes in New York City. He is survived by his wife of 33 years, Diana "Dee" Bendel. He was the son of the late Henri and Lillian Bendel. Services will be private. Expressions of sympathy may be made to the Massachusetts General Hospital Development Office, 100 Cambridge St, Suite 1310, Boston, MA 02114, designated to Dr. Peter Fagenholz and the Churchill team. To make an online guestbook entry, please visit www.BostonHarborsideHome.com.

It was only a matter of time before Providence, R.I., long a petri dish for eggheads, design wunderkinds and culinary aspirants, would get its very own vintage-y, self-consciously cool hotel. The Dean, 52 rooms housed in a historic building from 1911 that was once a brothel, reflects the state’s bookish and somewhat gritty impulses toward homegrown authenticity. The lodging’s original mosaic tile flooring is intact, as is the old-timey brick facade, and rooms are furnished mostly with flea market finds. While the hotel’s name is an ode to the area’s academic community — it’s close to R.I.S.D. and Brown University — its arrival signals Providence’s continued cultural renaissance outside campus gates.

THALHEIM--Jay. Jay was truly a gentleman. He was the devoted husband of 48 years to his deceased wife Beth. They were always a team, and worked alongside one another for over forty years to build one of the largest trade show and exposition management companies in the U.S. Jay will always be remembered as one of the true pioneers in the exposition industry and served as Chairman of the Board of Thalheim Expositions, Inc. He will be deeply missed by his children, David and Alison Thalheim, Amy and William Handwerker, and Neil and Susan Thalheim. They will always remember the fond moments spent together with their Dad. His grandchildren, Lindsay and Ian, Adam and Francine, Michael, Marc, Benjamin and Goldi, Shira and Robert, Rena and Shmuel, Eliana, Raphael and Akiva and his eight great-grandchildren will also miss the wonderful times and lessons learned from Jay. Donations may be made to Beth Thalheim Asthma Clinical Research Center at North Shore Health Systems, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021.

STOTTER--Herbert James, Jr.,"Jim" of Scarsdale, NY, passed away peacefully after a brief illness on November 2nd, 2013 at age 88, surrounded by his loving family. A proud native of Shaker Heights, OH, won his first golf club championship at Oakwood Country Club at age 16, was the captain of the Northwestern University golf team and 12-time club champion at Sunningdale Country Club. Served as president of the Westchester Golf Association, Metropolitan Golf Association and the Chicago Gift Show. With his partner H. William Ettelson, Jr., ran H.J. Stotter, Inc., manufacturers of plastic tabletop and decorative accessories. Jim is survived by his daughters Nan Zinaman (Steve), Wendy Stotter, Cindy Weichert (Peter), granddaughters Sara Cetron (Brad), Stefanie Weichert, great-grandson Isaac Cetron, and his sister, Sandra Ettelson (Bill). He was predeceased by his wives S. Patricia Rosenthal Stotter and Patricia Jacobs Stotter. A gathering to honor his life will be held at Sunningdale Country Club: 300 Underhill Road, Scarsdale, NY on Wednesday, November 6th, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Greenberg Nature Center, Jim Stotter Playground Fund, 99 Dromore Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

SOMERS--Harry. Renowned painter and Holocaust survivor Harry Somers passed away at age 91. He created thousands of works in his lifetime which are featured in museums worldwide. "Learn how to forgive! The more you hate, the more you die," he said in an interview for a film about his life www.harrysfilm.com.

SIGERSON--Yola Miller, aged 96, died peacefully on October 24, 2013 in New York, after a brief illness. She is survived by her son Davitt Sigerson, daughter-in-law Ana-Rosa Aboitiz and granddaughters Lio and Milena, as well as her husband's children, their spouses and grandchildren, whom she adored: Andra Patterson, Jon Goldstein, Julia and Christopher Gaebler; Gabriel Sigerson; Adam Sigerson, Ann Compton, Andrew Sigerson and Jennifer Sigerson; and also her treasured cousins, nieces and nephews. Yola was generous, opinionated, pleasure-loving, organized, joyous, voraciously well-read, overprotective and perpetually optimistic. In her work life of 70 years, Yola was a researcher on the Federal Theatre Project; lighting designer of The Original Ballet Russe; stage manager and lighting designer on Broadway; producer and director of live events for many progressive causes, including Franklin Roosevelt's re-election campaigns, World War II Victory Bonds, Russian War Relief and We Will Never Die, mostly presented at Madison Square Garden and the Hollywood Bowl; interior decorator; biographer and memoirist. The love of her life was Richard Sigerson, her husband of 47 years. In the event that they are reunited in some sort of afterlife, their delight will be rivaled only by irritation at having their atheism disproven. We will be celebrating Yola's 97 passionate years early in 2014. To get in touch, please email yolasigersonpeople@ gmail.com.

Scarangello, Sr. A long-time supporter of North Shore-LIJ and Staten Island University Hospital, Frank was known for his commitment to strengthening health care on Staten Island. He was a long-serving board member and supporter of Richmond Memorial Hospital in the years leading up to the 1987 merger with Staten Island Hospital. His business acumen and instincts helped guide the organization through several decades, and he never settled for anything less than the highest standards of quality, service and safety for patients. Frank was predeceased by his wife Mary Elizabeth and daughter Leslie. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughters Elizabeth and Penelope, and sons Frank Jr. and Thomas. Richard D. Goldstein, Chair, Board of Trustees Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO North Shore-LIJ Health System Frank Besignano, Chair, Staten Island University Hospital Executive Committee

ROTTENBERG--Herman, died November 4, 2013 at home in Manhattan, age 97. Predeceased by his beloved wife Lenore; survived by sons Daniel and Robert and their wives, Barbara and Rachel; grandchildren Lisa Yellin and Julie, Elijah and Rebekah Rottenberg; grandsons-in-law David Yellin and Ben Rubin; and great-grandchildren Edward and Ella Yellin and Thelma and Roscoe Rubin-Rottenberg. In 1962 this remarkable man sold his prosperous knitted wear company to devote himself to fostering international goodwill through folk dancing. A folk dance class he taught at International House in New York evolved into the Allnations Dance Company, which over the next 35 years toured the globe, spreading its motto-- "Joy in Every Land"-- in as many as 300 performances a year. At International House, he also enriched the lives of resident students by creating a broad range of cultural programs and events that he ran until 2008. Graveside service private; a memorial service will be held at a future date.

MLOTEK--Chana, The Workmen's Circle / Arbeter Ring mourns the passing of Chana Mlotek, matriarch of the Mlotek family, musicologist and passionate champion of the preservation of Yiddish music and culture. A lifelong activist, Chana co-authored the Workmen's Circle songbooks. She was the definitive source of knowledge of Yiddish music. Together with her husband Yosl Mlotek, z"l, our legendary Education Director, she was ever-present at all Workmen's Circle activities. Her sons, Zalmen, Folksbiene Artistic Director and Moish, former President of the Workmen's Circle, and daughters-in-law Debbie and Audrey are stalwarts of our movement. Our hearts go out to them and their families. Madelon Braun, President Ann Toback, Executive Director

MLOTEK--Chana Eleanor Gordon, peacefully at home, Monday November 4, at age 91. Esteemed Yiddish scholar, long time archivist at the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, columnist for the Jewish Daily Forward, leading anthologist of Yiddish poetry and song, author of multiple published anthologies which have played a key role in inspiring an international revival of Klezmer, Yiddish music and culture. Together with her late husband, the noted writer, teacher, and communal leader Joseph Mlotek, she published a column, "Pearls of Yiddish Poetry," in the Yiddish Forward which unearthed treasures of Yiddish culture contributed by readers from all over the world. Nobel laureate Isaac Bashevis Singer called her the "Sherlock Holmes of Yiddish song," and Theodore Bikel wrote that "Chana and Yosl Mlotek are to be counted among our national treasures." Born and raised in the Bronx, Chana was a graduate of Hunter College. Soon after graduating, she worked as a personal assistant to the founder of the YIVO Max Weinreich, and thereafter devoted her professional life to the preservation of Yiddish culture. She was a wellspring of knowledge that drew scholars, authors, musicians and educators from all over the world to make use of her unique, sometimes uncanny expertise and memory. Chana is survived by her sons Zalmen and Mark, their wives Debby and Audrey, grandchildren Lee, Marissa, Avram, Elisha, Sarah, great-granddaughter Revaya, granddaughter-in-law Yael, and a loving extended family. The funeral will take place at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, on Tuesday, November 5, 11:45am. Shiva plans will be announced at the funeral.

MARCUS--Arthur C.,97. A fine, wonderful man. Predeceased by Gertrude, his adored wife of 63 years. Companion to his darling Doris Zimmer. Cherished father of Joan Rosenberg and Steven Marcus. Beloved grandfather of Scott and Ali Rosenberg, Stacey and James Gordon, Jamie and Jimmy Schwartz and Kimberly and Jeff Moskowitz. Proud great-grandfather of Jake, Ryan, Emma, Brett, Charlie, Carly, Sam, Jack, William, Tori, Gillian, Juliet, Alex, Kate, Phoebe and Tyler. And dear friend and confidant of Paula Joseph. Arthur was a man of impeccable integrity. He was charming, engaging, smart, generous and tough. He loved life, he loved people, he loved to talk and he loved to walk. He was a textile executive for 39 years at Cohn Hall Marx, Inc., where he brought double knits to America. He disdained hypocrisy, yet refused to be a harsh judge of others. He was so thrilled with his 16 great-grandchildren, and loved his family deeply. He will be terribly missed but constantly remembered.

MITCHELL--Cecile, of West Lebanon, NH, and formerly of New York City and New Rochelle, NY, died peacefully at home on November 3rd. She was 95 and is survived by her husband Sydney Mitchell. She died just a month short of their 73rd wedding anniversary. She is also survived by her daughter Susan (Lewis Greenstein,) daughter Andrea (Alan Greenspan), son Arthur (Nancy Mitchell), granddaughter Dr. Rachel Mitchell (Matthew Haber), grandson Joshua Mitchell, granddaughter Sara Greenstein (Angie Hinton,) and great-grandchildren Adara Greenstein and Isaac Haber, and many nieces and nephews. She was beloved by all who knew her for her irreverent and "can-do" spirit, her creativity and generosity. In New Rochelle, she was an early proponent of teaching children with developmental difficulties through music and dance. An accomplished pianist, she served as president of the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester and was a lifetime supporter of the arts. She and her husband were active members of Beth El Synagogue. After years as a homemaker and community volunteer, she had a second career working for the New Rochelle Superintendent of Schools, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, and the New York Institute of Technology. Following her retirement as a school administrator, she returned to school to become a licensed interior designer, developing an active practice that she enjoyed immensely. Cecile was a talented writer and strong advocate for equal rights and social justice. Burial and graveside service Tuesday at 2pm Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ.

Mr. Mandel first joined the Board in 2003, and served as its Chair from 2008. As an actuary and insurance industry executive, Mr. Mandel's grasp of numbers and of financial issues was legendary. As a long-time hospital administrator, he brought to the Board an understanding of the health care field that was invaluable. His wise counsel and financial acumen were always very much appreciated, as was his dry wit. He will be missed by all of us who knew him. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Joy, and to his entire family. Donations may be made in his memory to the Stanley S. Mandel Student Scholarship Fund at the New York College of Podiatric Medicine, 53 East 124th Street, New York, NY 10035. Louis L. Levine, President and CEO Maj. Gen. William F. LIBERMAN--Lester, Chairman of the HealthCare Foundation of New Jersey, philanthropist, engineer, real estate developer died today at age 83. Funeral services will be Wednesday November 6, 10:30am at Congregation Beth El, 222 Irvington Ave, South Orange, NJ. Interment will follow to Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Arrangements made with Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ. Mr. Lieberman was Chairman of the Board of Newark Beth Israel Hospital in 1996 when he became concerned about the decline of inner-city hospitals. To insure the financial health of the hospital, he orchestrated the sale of Newark Beth Israel to St. Barnabas Healthcare Systems. The Healthcare Foundation of New Jersey was created with the assets derived from this sale. The Foundation has awarded over $100 million in grants since its inception, focusing its efforts on improving access to quality healthcare for the vulnerable populations in greater Newark, NJ and the Jewish community of MetroWest NJ. As a tribute to Lester Lieberman's commitment to humanism in medicine, the Foundation honors employees, students, and faculty in healthcare who demonstrate extraordinary compassion and kindness in their treatment of patients and families with the Lester Z. Lieberman Humanism in Healthcare Award. Lester Lieberman served on the board of Beth Israel for 27 years, including nine years as Chairman. Mr. Lieberman became devoted to Newark Beth Israel Hospital in 1964 after his youngest daughter, Jane, was treated at Newark Beth Israel and survived a severe case of spinal meningitis. Lester Lieberman was born and raised in Newark, New Jersey. He graduated from Weequahic High School and received a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from Newark College of Engineering (now New Jersey Institute of Technology/NJIT). Money was scarce in his family and he worked several jobs to make his way through college, including janitor and shoe salesman. In 1960, Mr. Lieberman founded Atmos Engineering, designing air conditioning and heating systems for commercial properties. He subsequently sold Atmos Engineering to Clarkson Industries, a multinational engineering firm owned by the British conglomerate BTR, Inc. Mr. Lieberman became a director of BTR and President and CEO of Clarkson Industries, based in New York City and responsible for engineering work in 65 countries. Mr. Lieberman was also a founder of Dowel Realty, a real estate company located in Morristown, NJ, that built, owned and operated commercial properties in New Jersey. He has been a principal in more than 100 real estate ventures over the past 50 years. Mr. Lieberman was a trustee emeritus of Clarkson University, a past member of the Board of Cives Corporation, the Lazard Funds, Inc, and the Northside Power Transmission Co. He was the past chair of Newark Beth Israel Medical Center and Irvington Hospital, a past member of the New Jersey State Investment Council and the Board of United Jersey Bank. He received honorable doctorates from Clarkson University and UMDNJ. Mr. Lieberman had served on the board of MetroWest New Jersey's Jewish Vocational Service, Community Foundation, and Federation. He served on the Council of Advisors at New Jersey Medical School, NJPAC and Public Health Research Institute at UMDNJ. Lester Lieberman is survived by his wife, Judith and his children, Jane Lieberman Rubin and her husband, Michael D'Amato, Susan Lieberman Smotrich and her husband Gary Smotrich, MD, as well as his four grandchildren, Tye, Zachary, Daniel, and Jonathan.

KLEIN--Walter Charles. Born May 11, 1918 in New York City, died October 28, 2013 in New York City. A towering figure, both in stature and in personality, Walter led a very happy and accomplished life. Born to successful Austrian immigrants, he attended Horace Mann School, then attended a secondary school in Vienna (where he learned German for the first time), before returning to the United States to graduate from Harvard in three years. He married the former Mary Kennard Eddy (1921-92) of St. Louis, whom he met while he was at Harvard and she was at Wellesley. Walter was devoted to Mary and they had a 50-year partnership, including the raising of three children: Walter Charles Klein, Jr. (1943-2009); John Eddy Klein; and Margaret Kennedy Klein. Walter first worked for Swift & Company in Chicago and Buenos Aires and then, in 1947, joined Bunge Corporation in New York City, the North American arm of what is now Bunge, Ltd. Over the next 43 years, he transformed a small commodity business into a powerful integrated agribusiness operation in North America, with grain elevators, oilseed and grain processing plants, and river barges focused along the Mississippi River and tributaries south of St. Louis. He also was the force behind Bunge's international expansion in Asia, including Japan and China. Walter was a builder, and his entrepreneurial approach and risk-taking, his involvement in the business, and his dynamic personality were all important to his success. He was a long-time resident of Maplewood and then Short Hills, NJ, where he was a member of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, Short Hills Club and Baltusrol Golf Club. In New York City, he was an enthusiastic member of the Knickerbocker Club. Walter was an entertaining story teller; a loyal Harvard alumnus and Wellesley supporter; an inveterate collector of artworks and early US stamps; an extensive traveler for business and pleasure; and a gifted linguist, speaking German, French and Spanish and studying Italian up until his death. Among many other gifts, Walter endowed a Harvard professorship and Harvard student scholarships and provided funding for a wing of Harvard's Barker Center for the Humanities, each bearing his name. He was also actively involved with the Fogg Museum at Harvard, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the New York Public Library. After his first wife Mary died, Walter married the former Virgilia Heimsath Pancoast, with whom he had become friends in New York. They were happily married for 20 years, took many wonderful trips together, and shared a love of art. Walter enjoyed Virgie's children and grandchildren as well as his own. After Walter had a stroke, Virgie devoted her full attention to his well-being. Walter is survived by his wife Virgie Klein of New York City; his son John Klein of Washington DC; his daughter Margaret Klein of New York City; Virgie's son John Pancoast of New Haven, CT; Virgie's daughters Star Eonnet of Paris, France and Stacy Clark of Dallas, Texas; three grandchildren Jennifer Klein Seaman, Thomas Klein and Laurie Klein Shanahan; and Virgie's five grandchildren Robin and Claire Pancoast, Estelle and Eloise Eonnet, and Dylan Clark. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on Monday, December 2 at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 71st Street. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts should be directed to Central Park Conservancy or Planned Parenthood of Metropolitan New Jersey.

CAGNEY--Judy, RSCJ, died Sunday, November 3, 2013. Born July 26, 1938 in Evanston, Illinois to Richard D. and Mary Lynch Cagney, she is survived by her sister, Joan Meyer, of Northfield, Illinois and brother, Richard Cagney, of Evanston. A sister, Toni Norkett, predeceased her. Sister Cagney served as director of finance for the Little Sisters of the Assumption in Harlem, 2001-2010. Previously, she served on two provincial teams and as treasurer for the United States Province of the Society of the Sacred Heart. Visit www.rscj.org. Services: Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, November 6 at 5:00pm, chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, 91st Street, New York. Burial at Kenwood in Albany, November 7, 11:30am.

Two weeks ago, while researching Michael Moss’s cover story about broccoli’s image problem, I learned about the Kitchen Community, a Colorado-based nonprofit that has put up, in low-income neighborhoods, billboards with simple recipes to encourage people to cook. Cool idea, except that the broccoli recipe struck me as wrong: “Olive oil & salt, 350° oven, 1 hour.” Broccoli is a favorite in my house. During the week, I boil the florets in two inches of water, drain and add butter and salt. Sometimes, if I’ve had enough sleep, I go wild and sauté it after parboiling — this adds char and brings out sweetness. My husband can steam it with scientific precision. None of these methods take an hour; maybe 15 minutes.
