HEINEMAN--Andrew D. Andy was one of the people who, in over 60 years of service to the Proskauer firm, made it what it is today. We were all the better for his wisdom and humanity, his loyalty, his unstoppable good humor (yes, despite the puns) and his high sense of purpose. He never forgot what the firm was to its lawyers, its non-legal staff and, above all to its clients. Morton M. Maneker

HEINEMAN--Andrew D.,Esq. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of Andrew D. Heineman Esq., a dedicated member of the Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees since 1975. For more than 35 years, Andy served Mount Sinai faithfully and with distinction. He devoted much of his time to serving on the Boards' Medical Education, Legal, Employee Relations, Patient Care and Quality Assurance, Student Affairs, and Community Affairs Committees, as well as on the Advisory Board of the Center for Multicultural and Community Affairs (CMCA) and as Trustee Liaison to The Mount Sinai Alumni Association. Andy was a far-seeing and steadfast champion of Mount Sinai's role in the world community. His leadership and generosity supported this vision, most notably through the CMCA, Global Health Program Fund, Medical Education Fund, and key institutional initiatives aimed at expanding the institution's capabilities and reach. Mount Sinai has benefited tremendously from Andy's wisdom, compassion and fairness over the many years of his involvement. We will remember him fondly, and miss him dearly. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to Andy's nieces and nephews, Deborah, Katheryn, Annemarie, Matthew, Stephen and Thomas, his beloved grandnieces and grandnephews, his many close and lifelong friends, and all those whose lives he enriched by his kindness. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai; President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System

HEINEMAN--Andrew D. The Board of Trustees and staff of Jewish Home Lifecare deeply mourn the passing of Life Trustee Andrew D. Heineman. For over 65 years, the Heineman family has provided a legacy of support and leadership to Jewish Home. Andy's relationship with Jewish Home began when he would visit with his father, Bernard, who was a trustee. Andy joined the Board in 1967 and served as chair from 1993-1997. He spearheaded Jewish Home's first capital campaign and was later named a Life Trustee in recognition of his unselfish and distinctive commitment to Jewish Home. We will miss Andy's wise counsel and great wit. Our thoughts are with his family during their time of loss. Elizabeth Grayer Chairman of the Board Audrey S. Weiner, DSW President/CEO

HALPERN--Sam. The Yeshiva University family is profoundly grieved by the passing of our cherished long time major supporter Sam Halpern, of blessed memory. Sam's leadership and commitment has made a profound impact on Jewish life both in America and Israel. Together with his late brother, Arie Halpern, z'l, they established the Sam and Arie Halpern Scholarship Fund for deserving and needy students including the descendants of Holocaust survivors. He and Gladys also established scholarship funds in their names and supported Holocaust studies at YU. A man of compassion and vision, he was revered by all who were privileged to know him. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife (Gladys), to his children, Fred (and Cheryl), David (and Sharon), Jack, Murray (and Batsheva) and to their many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May the entire Halpern family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

GRANAT--David Bruce, 68, of Paramus, NJ died on November 4, 2013. Born in the Bronx, NY and raised in New Rochelle, NY, Mr. Granat has lived in Paramus for 37 years. He owned and operated Leinow Printing which then became Bruce Graphics. His passions were his family, computers, and home improvement. Beloved husband of Marylin Granat (nee Schiff), loving father of Karen Barbara (Jerry) of Riverdale, NJ, and Danielle Mirsky (Steven) of Berkeley Heights, NJ, devoted grandfather of David, Nathan, and Tyler, cherished brother of Richard Granat (Nancy) of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, and brother-in-law of Frances and Tom Wills of Ossining, NY. Service for Mr. Granat are at 11:30am today at Gutterman-Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, Hackensack, NJ (201-489-3800). Interment at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Donations may be made in Mr. Granat's memory to the Jewish Community Center of Paramus or the Cardiac Units of Hackensack University Medical Center or Robert Wood Johnson Medical Center.

CUNNINGHAM--Dr. Mary O'Donoghue, of New York City died peacefully in her home on Sunday, November 3. Dr. Cunningham, a teacher, psychologist and lawyer was born and raised in northern Manhattan. She earned a teaching degree from Fordham University and taught elementary school before starting a family with her husband, the late Patrick Cunningham. For most of their life together, the Cunninghams lived in the Bronx and kept a second home in Southampton, Long Island. Dr. Cunningham earned a PhD in psychology from Columbia University and practiced for several years before joining the Carter Administration in the U.S. State Department's Office of International Affairs. She then earned a law degree from Georgetown University and finished her career in the Brooklyn court system. The daughter of Irish immigrants, Dr. Cunningham was a lifelong devotee of Irish music and culture, a passionate feminist and a constant source of love and support to her family. Survivors include her brother John, her five children, Stephen, Philip, Christine, Peter and Patrick, and 11 grandchildren. A memorial service for Dr. Cunningham will be held in the coming weeks.

WALSH--Edward P.,"Ted", In an Ottawa hospital, Sunday, November 3, 2013, Ted Walsh, age 89, born September 7, 1924 in Quebec City. The fourth child of Edward Michael Walsh and Clara Bussiere. Ted will be dearly missed by his beloved wife of 62 years, Rowena (Mercer). Cherished father of Ann (Adi Kropfel), Brian (Angela Brown), Rosemary (Bruce Desarmia), Maureen (Terry Parent), and Robert (Brenda Vialoux). Special "Da" to David Kropfel, Matthew, Erin, John, and Michael Walsh; Eric Desarmia, Christina, Robert, and Michael Parent, and Elijah and Mercer Walsh. He leaves behind many nieces, nephews and life-long friends. Ted is predeceased by his parents, brothers, Percy and Henry and his sister, Georgette. Admired for integrity and vision throughout his career, Edward served as the President and CEO of Donohue for 22 years until retiring in 1988. Under his leadership, the company's earnings grew from $1.6 million to $112 million and created thousands of good jobs. In recognition of his many contributions, Edward received the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association's lifetime achievement award. A devout Catholic, Edward was dedicated to his wife and family. He played hockey and bicycled well into his eighties and enjoyed travelling, fishing, painting and reading. His family thanks the staff at the Queensway-Carleton Hospital for their compassionate care during his final days. Friends may pay respects at the Kelly Funeral Home, Kanata Chapel: 580 Eagleson Rd., Kanata ON K2M 1H4. (613) 591-6580. www.kellyfh.ca. Friday, November 8, 2013 from 3 to 5pm and 6:30 - 8:30pm. Funeral Saturday, November 9, 2013 at St. Patrick's Church, 15 Steeple Hill Cres., Fallowfield, ON for Mass of Christian Funeral at 10am. Interment to follow in the Parish Cemetery. In memoriam donations to St. Patrick's Church, Fallowfield, Royal Ottawa Hospital Foundation or Alzheimer's Society appreciated.

TORON--Miles L.,on November 4. Beloved husband of Carlene. Loving father of Michael (Karyn) and David (Lisa). Adored grandfather of Jason, Brandon, Nicole and Dylan. Loved and missed by all. Services: Boulevard Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, NY 11:30am Thursday, November 7.

THALHEIM--Jay. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club mourn the loss of our esteemed member, Jay. The Thalheims were members of Fresh Meadow for 40 years. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his children David Thalheim (Alison), Amy Handwerker (William), Neil Thalheim (Susan) and his ten grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Michael Lamoretti, President David Finkelstein, Secretary

THALHEIM--Jay. Jay was truly a gentleman. He was the devoted husband of 48 years to his deceased wife Beth. They were always a team, and worked alongside one another for over forty years to build one of the largest trade show and exposition management companies in the U.S. Jay will always be remembered as one of the true pioneers in the exposition industry and served as Chairman of the Board of Thalheim Expositions, Inc. He will be deeply missed by his children, David and Alison Thalheim, Amy and William Handwerker, and Neil and Susan Thalheim. They will always remember the fond moments spent together with their Dad. His grandchildren, Lindsay and Ian, Adam and Francine, Michael, Marc, Benjamin and Goldi, Shira and Robert, Rena and Shmuel, Eliana, Raphael and Akiva and his eight great-grandchildren will also miss the wonderful times and lessons learned from Jay. Funeral services were held at noon on Tuesday November 5 at ''Gutterman's'', located at: 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Donations may be made to Beth Thalheim Asthma Clinical Research Center at North Shore Health Systems, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021.

TELESMANIC--Nicholas, on November 3, 2013. Beloved husband of Ruza (nee Kozulic). Loving father of Robert J. Cherished grandfather of James and Nicholas. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd Street. Visiting hours: Wednesday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass: Thursday at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church at 10am. Interment: Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America, Inc.

SCHLESINGER--Albert. It is with sad hearts that we say goodbye to our dear friend, Albie. He was a wonderful part of our lives and we will miss him every day. Our love is with Sue, Kim, Jill and their family. Sue and Lew and Family

ROTTENBERG--Herman "H.R.", The Board of Trustees, staff, resident members and alumni of International House note with great sorrow the passing of Life Trustee Herman Rottenberg. A dedicated Board member for 42 years, he will be greatly missed, and our heartfelt sympathy is extended to the Rottenberg family. Frank G. Wisner, Chairman Calvin Sims, President

SCHLESINGER--Albert E.,on November 4, 2013. Loving and admiring husband of Susan (Gordon) for 52 years. Adoring and proud father of Kim (Evan Meyers), Jill (Jacqueline LiCalzi) and grandfather of Emily, Douglas and Jane. Steadfast brother of Donald Schlesinger (Charles Estes). Predeceased by his parents, Alma and Theodore Schlesinger and his in-laws, Ada and Julian Gordon. Mr. Schlesinger was a graduate of Riverdale Country Day School and Washington and Lee University. He spent his career as a trader and specialist on the American Stock Exchange, where he later served as a board member. After a three-decade career as a trader, he turned his efforts to funding and operating small businesses. Albie's passion was his family. He was most proud of his daughters and the strength, poise and beauty of his wife. He approached life with strong points of view, paired with a sense of humor. He invariably provoked spirited conversations about current events and sports the man was never boring. Albie was a deeply loyal and supportive friend, whose candor and sensitivity combined to provide counsel to many. His concern for the plight of others was expressed through his various charitable endeavors, including his longtime membership on the board of Jewish Senior Services of Fairfield County, as well as through personal outreach and giving. The family will be holding a private service and burial. Expressions of sympathy can be made to NYU Langone Medical Center (Memo: ICU Nursing Research IMO Albert Schlesinger), NYU Langone Medical Center, Attn: Donna Marino 1 Park Avenue, 17th Floor New York, NY 10016.

ROTTENBERG--Herman, died November 4, 2013 at home in Manhattan, age 97. Predeceased by his beloved wife Lenore; survived by sons Daniel and Robert and their wives, Barbara and Rachel; grandchildren Lisa Yellin and Julie, Elijah and Rebekah Rottenberg; grandsons-in-law David Yellin and Ben Rubin; and great-grandchildren Edward and Ella Yellin and Thelma and Roscoe Rubin-Rottenberg. In 1962 this remarkable man sold his prosperous knitted wear company to devote himself to fostering international goodwill through folk dancing. A folk dance class he taught at International House in New York evolved into the Allnations Dance Company, which over the next 35 years toured the globe, spreading its motto-- "Joy in Every Land"-- in as many as 300 performances a year. At International House, he also enriched the lives of resident students by creating a broad range of cultural programs and events that he ran until 2008. Graveside service private; a memorial service will be held at a future date.

PARNES--Claire. Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her husband Richard, son Stephen, and their loved ones. May her memory be for blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Michael Starr, President
MOUNTS--Kimberly, 48, died on October 25 in Newport Beach, California. Kim was CEO of an investment company titled MAP. Services will be held at Oakdale Mortuary in Glendora, CA.

MOLDOVAN--Dr. Alfred, 92, died on November 4, survived by sons Joseph and Micah, their wives Susan and Rebecca, grandchildren Daniel and Jessica, nephew David, niece Sharon. Lived life with a passion for social justice, medicine, and family. Captain, US Army Air Corp., bomber group, WWII. Practiced medicine in Harlem for over 47 years. In 1964, helped found the Medical Committee for Human Rights to "lend a medical presence" to the Civil Rights Movement. On Bloody Sunday, March 7, 1965, was the only doctor who made it onto the Pettus Bridge to care for the beaten and bloodied on the march from Selma to Montgomery. Fought to desegregate the AMA. Tended to Columbia students who were beaten while protesting against the Vietnam War. With his wife Jean, was a major Judaica collector and scholar. Totally devoted to his family, extended family and friends. Funeral: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam, November 7, 10:30am.

MLOTEK--Chana The Hunter College community mourns the passing of our illustrious alumna Chana Mlotek, Class of 1946. Chana was inducted into Hunter's Hall of Fame in 2009 in recognition of her central role in the revival of Yiddish music in North America and her long association with the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research. Our sincerest condolences to her sons Zalmen and Mark, as well as her niece, Fay Rosenfeld, of our Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College.

MLOTEK--Chana, The Board of Directors and staff of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research express our deep sorrow at the passing of our dear colleague Chana Gordon Mlotek z"l. Chana was affiliated with YIVO and its mission for close to seventy years. As YIVO's Music Archivist, Chana generously shared her unparalleled knowledge of Jewish music and the YIVO music collections with generations of music scholars and the general public. Her passing is a profound loss and she will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt condolences to her sons, Zalmen and Moish, and their entire family.

MITCHELL--Cecile, of West Lebanon, NH, and formerly of New York City and New Rochelle, NY, died peacefully at home on November 3rd. She was 95 and is survived by her husband Sydney Mitchell. She died just a month short of their 73rd wedding anniversary. She is also survived by her daughter Susan (Lewis Greenstein,) daughter Andrea (Alan Greenspan), son Arthur (Nancy Mitchell), granddaughter Dr. Rachel Mitchell (Matthew Haber), grandson Joshua Mitchell, granddaughter Sara Greenstein (Angie Hinton,) and great-grandchildren Adara Greenstein and Isaac Haber, and many nieces and nephews. She was beloved by all who knew her for her irreverent and "can-do" spirit, her creativity and generosity. In New Rochelle, she was an early proponent of teaching children with developmental difficulties through music and dance. An accomplished pianist, she served as president of the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester and was a lifetime supporter of the arts. She and her husband were active members of Beth El Synagogue. After years as a homemaker and community volunteer, she had a second career working for the New Rochelle Superintendent of Schools, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, and the New York Institute of Technology. Following her retirement as a school administrator, she returned to school to become a licensed interior designer, developing an active practice that she enjoyed immensely. Cecile was a talented writer and strong advocate for equal rights and social justice. Burial and graveside service Tuesday at 2pm Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ.

MINSKY--Bess, on November 5, 2012 at the age of 96. Survived by her devoted daughter Sondra Berman and many family members. Graveside service will be held on Thursday, November 7, 2013 at 1pm at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Services by Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel.

MANDEL--Stanley S.,The Board, President, Dean, Faculty and Students of the New York College of Podiatric Medicine are saddened by the passing of their longtime Board Chair, Stanley S. Mandel. Mr. Mandel first joined the Board in 2003, and served as its Chair from 2008. As an actuary and insurance industry executive, Mr. Mandel's grasp of numbers and of financial issues was legendary. As a long-time hospital administrator, he brought to the Board an understanding of the health care field that was invaluable. His wise counsel and financial acumen were always very much appreciated, as was his dry wit. He will be missed by all of us who knew him. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Joy, and to his entire family. Donations may be made in his memory to the Stanley S. Mandel Student Scholarship Fund at the New York College of Podiatric Medicine, 53 East 124th Street, New York, NY 10035. Louis L. Levine, President and CEO Maj. Gen. William F. Ward, Jr., A.U.S. (Ret.), Vice Chair Rock G. Positano, DPM, MSc, MPH, Deputy Chair Keith A. Greathouse, Secretary Joel A. Sturm, Chief Operating Officer Michael J. Trepal, DPM, Vice President for Academic Affairs & Dean

LIEBERMAN--Lester, Z. The Board of the Lazard Funds is deeply saddened by the passing of Lester Z. Lieberman, a philanthropist deeply committed to the health care industry. Les served on the Board since 1991 and will be greatly missed by his fellow directors. We send our heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends.

LIEBERMAN--Lester Z. The Trustees and Staff of The Healthcare Foundation of New Jersey mourn the passing of our Founder and Chairman, Lester Lieberman. Les was a visionary whose commitment to improving access to quality healthcare for the most vulnerable and underserved in our community was the driving force behind the mission of the Foundation. Under his leadership, the Foundation awarded more than $100 million in the last 17 years. In recognition of Mr. Lieberman's commitment to humanism in the practice of medicine, the Lester Z. Lieberman Awards for Humanism in Healthcare were established and are presented annually to people in direct patient care for their extraordinary display of compassion with the patients whose lives they touch. Les will be truly missed.

KILSTEIN--Claire, on November 2, 2013 at age 94. Formerly of NYC and Deerfield Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of her late darling George. Loving mother of Lewis and Saul (Deborah). Devoted Daughter of Sylvia Goldshine. Cherished sister of the late Bessie G. Sekeres and Sadie Mann. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. Dear aunt and cousin. Graveside funeral service will be held today 1pm at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hadassah.

JEGER--Maurice, Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Maurice Jeger, beloved husband of our member, Maidy Jeger. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

ILBERMAN--Mel. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Mel Ilberman. He leaves behind a legacy of exceptional philanthropic commitment. We extend our condolences to Mel's wife, Adele; his children with late wife, Shirley: Judith (Robert), Alan (Caroline), and Debra (Mark); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

ILBERMAN--Mel. Husband of Adele and of the late Shirley. Father of Alan Ilberman, Debra Hoffman, and Dr. Judith Hirsch, father-in-law of our Chair, Rob Hirsch, and adored grandfather of Ramah Berkshires alumni. His values will live on through his children and grandchildren. Hamakom yinachem otam b'toch shaar avalei tziyon v'yerushalyim. Camp Ramah in the Berkshires Dr. Hugh Pollack, President Rabbi Paul Resnick, Director Rabbi Jerome Abrams, Director Emeritus

ILBERMAN--Mel, The Schechter School of Long Island mourns the passing of our longtime friend and benefactor. Mel's seven grandchildren (Avi, Joshua, Oren, Sigal, Sarah, Rachel and Max) have all been educated from K-12th grade at SSLI and each carries within them Mel's love of Israel, Torah and the Jewish People. We mourn with his wife Adele, daughters Dr. Judy Hirsch (Robert) and Debra Hoffman (Dr. Mark) and son Alan (Caroline). May the family be comforted among all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

ILBERMAN--Mel. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member, Mel Ilberman. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to his family. Scott N. Bolton, Rabbi Diane Okrent, President

WALSH--Edward P.,"Ted", In an Ottawa hospital, Sunday, November 3, 2013, Ted Walsh, age 89, born September 7, 1924 in Quebec City. The fourth child of Edward Michael Walsh and Clara Bussiere. Ted will be dearly missed by his beloved wife of 62 years, Rowena (Mercer). Cherished father of Ann (Adi Kropfel), Brian (Angela Brown), Rosemary (Bruce Desarmia), Maureen (Terry Parent), and Robert (Brenda Vialoux). Special "Da" to David Kropfel, Matthew, Erin, John, and Michael Walsh; Eric Desarmia, Christina, Robert, and Michael Parent, and Elijah and Mercer Walsh. He leaves behind many nieces, nephews and life-long friends. Ted is predeceased by his parents, brothers, Percy and Henry and his sister, Georgette. Admired for integrity and vision throughout his career, Edward served as the President and CEO of Donohue for 22 years until retiring in 1988. Under his leadership, the company's earnings grew from $1.6 million to $112 million and created thousands of good jobs. In recognition of his many contributions, Edward received the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association's lifetime achievement award. A devout Catholic, Edward was dedicated to his wife and family. He played hockey and bicycled well into his eighties and enjoyed travelling, fishing, painting and reading. His family thanks the staff at the Queensway-Carleton Hospital for their compassionate care during his final days. Friends may pay respects at the Kelly Funeral Home, Kanata Chapel: 580 Eagleson Rd., Kanata ON K2M 1H4. (613) 591-6580. www.kellyfh.ca. Friday, November 8, 2013 from 3 to 5pm and 6:30 - 8:30pm. Funeral Saturday, November 9, 2013 at St. Patrick's Church, 15 Steeple Hill Cres., Fallowfield, ON for Mass of Christian Funeral at 10am. Interment to follow in the Parish Cemetery. In memoriam donations to St. Patrick's Church, Fallowfield, Royal Ottawa Hospital Foundation or Alzheimer's Society appreciated.

SCHLESINGER--Albert E.,on November 4, 2013. Loving and admiring husband of Susan (Gordon) for 52 years. Adoring and proud father of Kim (Evan Meyers), Jill (Jacqueline LiCalzi) and grandfather of Emily, Douglas and Jane. Steadfast brother of Donald Schlesinger (Charles Estes). Predeceased by his parents, Alma and Theodore Schlesinger and his in-laws, Ada and Julian Gordon. Mr. Schlesinger was a graduate of Riverdale Country Day School and Washington and Lee University. He spent his career as a trader and specialist on the American Stock Exchange, where he later served as a board member. After a three-decade career as a trader, he turned his efforts to funding and operating small businesses. Albie's passion was his family. He was most proud of his daughters and the strength, poise and beauty of his wife. He approached life with strong points of view, paired with a sense of humor. He invariably provoked spirited conversations about current events and sports the man was never boring. Albie was a deeply loyal and supportive friend, whose candor and sensitivity combined to provide counsel to many. His concern for the plight of others was expressed through his various charitable endeavors, including his longtime membership on the board of Jewish Senior Services of Fairfield County, as well as through personal outreach and giving. The family will be holding a private service and burial. Expressions of sympathy can be made to NYU Langone Medical Center (Memo: ICU Nursing Research IMO Albert Schlesinger), NYU Langone Medical Center, Attn: Donna Marino 1 Park Avenue, 17th Floor New York, NY 10016.

SCHLESINGER--Albert. It is with sad hearts that we say goodbye to our dear friend, Albie. He was a wonderful part of our lives and we will miss him every day. Our love is with Sue, Kim, Jill and their family. Sue and Lew and Family

ROZBRUCH--Frieda. Holocaust survivor, passed away at the age of 91 on Friday, November 1st, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother to Jacob and Marsha, Alfred and Hedy, Robert and Yonina. Adoring grandmother to Alison and Brett, Josh and Lauren, Andrew, Jenny and Eric, Jason, and Libby. Courageous at death as in life, she leaves behind a legacy of love and strength.

OBIN--Ruth Baum, daughter of Rose and Jacob Baum, sister of Eva and Harry died on November 5, 2013 at the age of 93. She leaves behind her husband of 70 years, Julius, and her children Nancy Sukenik (Richard) and Martin. MOLDOVAN--Alfred. Yeshiva University Museum mourns with deep sadness the passing of Alfred Moldovan, an enthusiastic collector of books and Judaica, an early museum board member, and a longstanding friend of the museum and of countless people interested in Judaism's rich visual legacy. Al was devoted to celebrating and preserving Jewish heritage evident in the remarkable collection of children's books collected by Al and his wife, Jean Sorkin Moldovan, of blessed memory, and in the objects he brought together, lent to exhibitions, and spoke about to members of the Jewish community worldwide. We extend our warmest sympathies to the entire Moldovan family. May his memory be a blessing. Yeshiva University

MOLDOVAN--Dr. Alfred, The Library of The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Dr. Alfred Moldovan, a member of the Library Advisory Board. An expert and master sleuth in identifying rare Jewish books, Dr. Moldovan volunteered his wisdom to The Library for a decade, helping classify priceless volumes that were damaged nearly 50 years ago in a fire. His friends and colleagues at JTS will miss him. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. David Kraemer Joseph J. and Dora Abbell Librarian, JTS Dorothy Tapper Goldman, Chair Library Advisory Board

MOLDOVAN--Dr. Alfred, The Jewish Museum mourns the passing of Dr. Alfred Moldovan, a passionate Judaica collector who was a long-standing member of the Museum's Acquisitions Committee and a donor to the collection. Dr. Moldovan was also founder of the Harry G. Friedman Society, a group of prominent Judaica collectors. His knowledge and dedication to the field of Judaica will be greatly missed, and we extend condolences to his family. Robert Pruzan, Chair Claudia Gould, Helen Goldsmith Menschel Director

MOLDOVAN--Dr. Alfred, 92, died on November 4, survived by sons Joseph and Micah, their wives Susan and Rebecca, grandchildren Daniel and Jessica, nephew David, niece Sharon. Lived life with a passion for social justice, medicine, and family. Captain, US Army Air Corp., bomber group, WWII. Practiced medicine in Harlem for over 47 years. In 1964, helped found the Medical Committee for Human Rights to "lend a medical presence" to the Civil Rights Movement. On Bloody Sunday, March 7, 1965, was the only doctor who made it onto the Pettus Bridge to care for the beaten and bloodied on the march from Selma to Montgomery. Fought to desegregate the AMA. Tended to Columbia students who were beaten while protesting against the Vietnam War. With his wife Jean, was a major Judaica collector and scholar. Totally devoted to his family, extended family and friends. Funeral: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam, November 7, 10:30am.

MLOTEK--Chana, The Board of Directors and staff of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research express our deep sorrow at the passing of our dear colleague Chana Gordon Mlotek z"l. Chana was affiliated with YIVO and its mission for close to seventy years. As YIVO's Music Archivist, Chana generously shared her unparalleled knowledge of Jewish music and the YIVO music collections with generations of music scholars and the general public. Her passing is a profound loss and she will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt condolences to her sons, Zalmen and Moish, and their entire family.

LEBENHART--Stanley (Zdenek), age 89, passed away peacefully on November 5, 2013. Funeral service November 7 2pm at Star of David Chapel in West Babylon, NY. Donations can be made to yadvashem.org or ushmm.org. For more info go to www.jewish-funeral-home.com

Memorial service on December 2nd at 1:30 pm, Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington at 66th St. Contact: Heidiwkuckerlivingtrust@ gmail.com.

IYOG--Corazon C.,age 99, wife of the late Cruz D. Iyog died peacefully among family and friends on November 5, 2013 in New York. HEINEMAN--Andrew D.,Esq. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital deeply mourns the passing of our devoted friend and long-standing member. Mr. Heineman served as wise counsel to the AAS and was a quiet voice of reason for several decades. He exemplified the spirit of generosity and altruism, and he was a consummate humanitarian and philanthropist. A man of extraordinary intelligence and integrity, he also possessed great charm. He made us laugh and he made us think. He helped lead the AAS through challenging times in health care policy and was vigorously involved in all aspects of patient care and the community. Andy was a wonderful person who will be remembered for his kindness and his loyalty to the institution. The AAS salutes his great legacy and we extend our sincere condolences to his family and many friends. Gila Leiter, MD, President Eric Neibart, MD, 1st Vice President Mark Reiner, MD, 2nd Vice President Harold Bronheim, MD, Secretary/Treasurer Amy J. Weinstein, Administrator

HEINEMAN--Andrew David, passed away peacefully on November 5, 2013, his 85th birthday, at Mt. Sinai Hospital (where he served as a dedicated trustee from 1975 to the present). Son of Bernard and Lucy (Morgenthau), brother of the late Bernard Jr. and William, Andy was a native New Yorker who spent every summer from 1935 to 2012 at the family home in the Thousand Islands. He attended the Horace Mann School, received his BA from Williams College in 1950, and his Law degree from Yale University in 1953. Andy had a distinguished law career at Proskauer Rose LLP (Associate 1953-1963; Partner 1963-2002). A world traveler and avid birder, Andy devoted his life to his family and philanthropic work. In addition to his work for Mt. Sinai, he served as a trustee of his beloved Williams College, and continued his father's commitment to the Jewish Lifecare System (formerly the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged) as a member of the Board of Directors from 1967 to the present, serving stints as Chairman and Vice Chairman. He is survived by his sister-in-law, Harriet, his dear nieces and nephews, Deborah, Matthew, Kathryn, Stephen, Annemarie and Thomas as well as numerous grand-nieces and nephews who loved him well. Memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, NY on Thursday, November 7, from 4:00pm 8:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Williams College, Mt. Sinai Center for Multicultural and Community Affairs, or the Jewish Lifecare System. Most of all Andy will be remembered for his marvelous sense of humor and one of his favorite expressions --"C'est La Vie!"

HAYMAN--Anna Marie Gogo, of Hallandale Beach, Florida, died November 5th, 2013. Proceeded by her husband, Arthur Hayman and her daughter, Karen Pauline Hayman. She is survived by her son, Nicholas Bryan Hayman and daughter, Laura Gogo Hayman. Also her sister, Betty Vukojevich, niece, Paula Payne and two grand- nephews. Also nephew, Jonathan Hayman, niece, Valerie Hayman and niece Ellen Gellman. A fond farewell to her countless cousins, relatives and friends from L.A., FL and NY. I loved you all. I love New York! Special Thanks to Liza Ruiz, my friend and caretaker.

Services for Mr. Granat were held yesterday at Gutterman-Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, Hackensack, NJ (201-489-3800). Interment at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Donations may be made in Mr. Granat's memory to the Jewish Community Center of Paramus or the Cardiac Units of Hackensack University Medical Center or Robert Wood Johnson Medical Center.

CAREY--Patricia M.,died peacefully at home in East Hampton of a neurological illness. She is survived by her husband of 53 years W. Ward Carey, her five children Ann Diaz of Madrid, Ward Carey of Hillsborough, CA, Alex Carey of New York, Daphne Jarrett of East Hampton, Cynthia Schwartz of Lenox, MA, and their spouses. Her great love in life was her sixteen grandchildren (13 boys and three girls). She was a member of the Maidstone Club in East Hampton and the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach. STEIN--Michael. The Washington Institute for Near East Policy extends condolences to the family of Michael Stein, our visionary co-founder, chairman emeritus, and former president. Mike was a giant - a man of great ideas, boundless energy, and profound devotion to principle. His passing is a grievous loss.

STEIN--Michael. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and past President, Michael Stein, and extends sincere sympathy to his children, grandchildren and other members of his family. William L. Mack, President Alan Curtis, Secretary

STEIN--Michael. Michael Stein was born in 1925 in New York City, graduated from Valley Forge Military Academy 1942 and from Harvard College 1946, married Louise Rosenberg in 1948 and, thus, began one of the most idyllic marriages ever known that lasted 64 years until Louise passed away on May 24, 2013. For Mike, life without Louise lost most of its meaning. In 1948, Mike joined the Bali company, a family business started by his mother and father, Sara and Sam Stein, became president in 1955, and later took the company public after considerably expanding its manufacturing base and international sales. Under Mike, Bali became the unquestioned leader in its industry. Even so, Mike delighted in telling audiences the "Sara and Sam" story, how they started the business with $39 on the front porch of a little bungalow on a dirt street in Brooklyn. Apart from business, Mike devoted himself with considerable passion to the fields of healthcare, public service and foreign policy, focusing on Israel and the Middle East. His first job as head of a philanthropic agency came when he was only 36 years old and was selected to become the founding president of the Gustave Hartman YM-YMHA. Eventually he became a Vice President of the Associated Y's of greater New York, the parent agency. In healthcare, Mike became the youngest trustee upon joining the board of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in 1963. There he rose quickly through the ranks, chairing major committees, and became the first Vice Chairman of the Medical Center. Mike was also a founding trustee of the Community Health Program of Queens and Nassau and served on the board of the Children's Medical Fund of New York. This led to the creation of its Children's Hospital. Mike chaired the committee that planned the Children's Hospital and helped oversee the process that led it to become one of the finest medical facilities for children in the country. After becoming a Florida resident in 1978, Mike became a founding trustee of the Morse Geriatric Center in West Palm Beach and of the Kramer Senior Resource Center. He was appointed a Medical Care Commissioner of the Town of Palm Beach and served in that capacity throughout the term of the commission. He continued working on health care for his community by chairing the Health Care Committee of the Palm Beach Civic Association where he also served on its executive committee. Mike's other communal activities in Florida included secretary-treasurer of the Palm Beach Police Foundation, president of the Palm Beach Country Club and chairman of the Palm Beach board of the Florida Philharmonic orchestra. Mike was perhaps best known in his community for his work on behalf of Israel and the United States/Israel relationship. The founding of the state of Israel in 1948 had great meaning for him. He was a leader in philanthropic fundraising for Israel both in his community and his industry. Mike became a national officer of AIPAC in 1973 after organizing support for Israel during the Yom Kippur war. He served in that capacity until 1985 when he and his dear friend and colleague, Barbie Weinberg, founded the Washington Institute for Near East policy. The Institute is an educational foundation dedicated to helping foreign service officers and others engaged in foreign policy to better understand the facts and realities of the Middle East and the importance of the US - Israel relationship in achieving American interests in that region. He served the Institute as its president for eight years, then chairman, and finally Chairman emeritus. Mike's interest in Israel also led him to become involved with the Hebrew University of Jerusalem where he served on its Board of Regents and was awarded an honorary Fellowship in 2008. The singular quality that drove Mike Stein was "passion" for a cause he deemed worthwhile. Now he has taken his passion with him in search of Louise, where they will lie side by side under a headstone that says "together forever". Mike said many times that he has had a long and very good life, the best possible 64 year marriage to Louise and no regrets except to leave his many works of passion, his colleagues whose friendships he cherished, and his wonderful family that demonstrated the ultimate in love and caring, especially during the final days of his and Louise's lives. He is survived by his children, Linda and Martin Waldman, and Robert Stein; his grandchildren, Jason Waldman, Jackie and Steve Berlowski, Alea Stein, Sylvie Stein and his great-grandchildren, Madison Waldman and Tyler Berlowski to whom he bequeaths a world full of wonders and his blessings for a good life in which they might occasionally think of mamaLouise and papaMike and the very special love they all shared. Online Condolences may be offered at www.starofdavidfunerals.com Funeral Services 11:00am, Sunday, November 10, 2013 at Temple Beth-El, 2815 North Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, Florida. Interment to follow at the Star of David Cemetery of the Palm Beaches, 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, FL 33412 (561) 627-2277.

OBIN--Ruth Baum, daughter of Rose and Jacob Baum, sister of Eva and Harry died on November 5, 2013 at the age of 93. She was a graduate of James Monroe High School and Hunter College and a tennis enthusiast. Formerly a resident of Delray Beach, FL and Scarsdale, NY. She leaves behind her husband of 70 years, Julius, and her children Nancy Sukenik (Richard) and Martin. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York City Thursday, November 7th at 11am.

LUTZ--Beverly A. (White), Age 72, of Cohasset, MA, died October 4, 2013, at home after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Beverly is survived by her two sisters, Brenda Baumann of Kingston, MA and Barbara Ferreira of Wesley Chapel, Florida, and many loved nieces and nephews. She was born in Holbrook, MA, received a Bachelor of Science and a Master of Education in Administration from Bridgewater State College. She earned a Master of Arts in English from Boston College and spent the majority of her professional career in the Weymouth, MA school system as a teacher and administrator, where she was a creative and gifted mentor to her students and colleagues. Although a private person, she touched her many friends, colleagues and students with her humor, limitless enthusiasm for learning, and generosity in sharing her love of literature. After her retirement from Weymouth, she continued to teach at Quincy College and Fisher College. Beverly loved her Pekinese, theater, opera, classic movies, travel, professional tennis, good food, collecting books, and convertibles. Burial was private on October 8, 2013 at Woodside Cemetery in her beloved Cohasset. A gathering of colleagues and friends will be held at her home on November 15th from 3:00pm to 6:00pm. She will be remembered as direct, smart, funny, clever, sensitive and stylish a great friend to those privileged to have shared her life. For an online guestbook, please visit www.mcnamara-sparrell.com

CAREY--Patricia M.,died peacefully at home in East Hampton of a neurological illness. She is survived by her husband of 53 years W. Ward Carey, her five children Ann Diaz of Madrid, Ward Carey of Hillsborough, CA, Alex Carey of New York, Daphne Jarrett of East Hampton, Cynthia Schwartz of Lenox, MA, and their spouses. STEIN--Michael. Michael Stein was born in 1925 in New York City, graduated from Valley Forge Military Academy 1942 and from Harvard College 1946, married Louise Rosenberg in 1948 and, thus, began one of the most idyllic marriages ever known that lasted 64 years until Louise passed away on May 24, 2013. For Mike, life without Louise lost most of its meaning. In 1948, Mike joined the Bali company, a family business started by his mother and father, Sara and Sam Stein, became president in 1955, and later took the company public after considerably expanding its manufacturing base and international sales. Under Mike, Bali became the unquestioned leader in its industry. Even so, Mike delighted in telling audiences the "Sara and Sam" story, how they started the business with $39 on the front porch of a little bungalow on a dirt street in Brooklyn. Apart from business, Mike devoted himself with considerable passion to the fields of healthcare, public service and foreign policy, focusing on Israel and the Middle East. His first job as head of a philanthropic agency came when he was only 36 years old and was selected to become the founding president of the Gustave Hartman YM-YMHA. Eventually he became a Vice President of the Associated Y's of greater New York, the parent agency. In healthcare, Mike became the youngest trustee upon joining the board of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in 1963. There he rose quickly through the ranks, chairing major committees, and became the first Vice Chairman of the Medical Center. Mike was also a founding trustee of the Community Health Program of Queens and Nassau and served on the board of the Children's Medical Fund of New York. This led to the creation of its Children's Hospital. Mike chaired the committee that planned the Children's Hospital and helped oversee the process that led it to become one of the finest medical facilities for children in the country. After becoming a Florida resident in 1978, Mike became a founding trustee of the Morse Geriatric Center in West Palm Beach and of the Kramer Senior Resource Center. He was appointed a Medical Care Commissioner of the Town of Palm Beach and served in that capacity throughout the term of the commission. He continued working on health care for his community by chairing the Health Care Committee of the Palm Beach Civic Association where he also served on its executive committee. Mike's other communal activities in Florida included secretary-treasurer of the Palm Beach Police Foundation, president of the Palm Beach Country Club and chairman of the Palm Beach board of the Florida Philharmonic orchestra. Mike was perhaps best known in his community for his work on behalf of Israel and the United States/Israel relationship. The founding of the state of Israel in 1948 had great meaning for him. He was a leader in philanthropic fundraising for Israel both in his community and his industry. Mike became a national officer of AIPAC in 1973 after organizing support for Israel during the Yom Kippur war. He served in that capacity until 1985 when he and his dear friend and colleague, Barbie Weinberg, founded the Washington Institute for Near East policy. The Institute is an educational foundation dedicated to helping foreign service officers and others engaged in foreign policy to better understand the facts and realities of the Middle East and the importance of the US - Israel relationship in achieving American interests in that region. He served the Institute as its president for eight years, then chairman, and finally Chairman emeritus. Mike's interest in Israel also led him to become involved with the Hebrew University of Jerusalem where he served on its Board of Regents and was awarded an honorary Fellowship in 2008. The singular quality that drove Mike Stein was "passion" for a cause he deemed worthwhile. Now he has taken his passion with him in search of Louise, where they will lie side by side under a headstone that says "together forever". Mike said many times that he has had a long and very good life, the best possible 64 year marriage to Louise and no regrets except to leave his many works of passion, his colleagues whose friendships he cherished, and his wonderful family that demonstrated the ultimate in love and caring, especially during the final days of his and Louise's lives. He is survived by his children, Linda and Martin Waldman, and Robert Stein; his grandchildren, Jason Waldman, Jackie and Steve Berlowski, Alea Stein, Sylvie Stein and his great-grandchildren, Madison Waldman and Tyler Berlowski to whom he bequeaths a world full of wonders and his blessings for a good life in which they might occasionally think of mamaLouise and papaMike and the very special love they all shared. Online Condolences may be offered at www.starofdavidfunerals.com Funeral Services 11:00am, Sunday, November 10, 2013 at Temple Beth-El, 2815 North Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, Florida. Interment to follow at the Star of David Cemetery of the Palm Beaches, 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, FL 33412 (561) 627-2277.

RAWLINGS--Ann Haynes, Director of Public Outreach at The Interfaith Center, New York City, passed away November 2nd after snorkeling in Mexico. Memorial Service: November 12th, 2pm, James Memorial Chapel, Union Theological Seminary.

LOEB--Carl M. III, 80, passed away peacefully at his home on November 7th, 2013. Cherished husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife Hadassah, daughters Dahlia and Alee, and granddaughters Gabrielle and Natalie. We are blessed to have had you in our lives. We love you muchly. Take good care. Bye bye for now.

KUCKER--Heidi. Heidi's poise, glamour, wit and savoir faire were a dazzling combination in a colleague, as was her loyalty and humor as a friend. Always curious, always interested, always au courant, Heidi was a delight to be with. While she will be missed by so many, her light shines on, sparkling brilliantly, like a diamond. Andrea Fiuczynski

KUCKER--Heidi. Our hearts are saddened by the passing of our dear friend Heidi Kucker. Her boundless cheer, vivacious style and joyful laughter will always be remembered. Patrick Cooney and Karl Buchberg
GOTTFRIED--Dr. Arthur C.,NYC dentist for 40 years, died November 5, 2013 at age 93. Leaves loving wife Rita three devoted sons and their wives, and six terrific grandchildren.

KUCKER--Heidi, a dear friend and colleague of the original Special Client Group at Christie's. Always kind and concerned for the welfare of others, she enriched our lives and the lives of our clients with her wit, charm and joy of life. We will remember the hard work and laughter we shared. Heidi was a star, we loved her very much, and she will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Susan Rolfe and Kim Solow

FROMSTEIN--Mitchell, The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of it's esteemed member, Mitchell Fromstein, and extends sincere sympathy to his wife, children, grandchildren and other members of his family. William L. Mack, President Alan Curtis, Secretary

COFFEEN-VANDEVEN--Myriamne. Smart, funny, kind, beautiful to the end. Mommy extraordinaire to Mikayla, Theo and Anya, loving wife and best friend to Mark, cherished Nami-Nami of Yola and David, fiercely protective sister of Daniel and Jonathan, devoted friend to hundreds. Lawyer, activist, educator, antique dealer. There is no one of whom we could be prouder. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Child Mind Institute through www.childmind.org. Memorial service: Sunday, November 10, 2013, 11am, Temple Beth Shalom, 740 North Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

BREVETTI--Dr. Teresa Morrone, was born on July 14, 1930 in Taranto, Italy to Giuseppe Morrone and Elvira DeCaro. She died in Brooklyn on November 7, 2013. She was raised in Mondragone, Italy and graduated from The University of Naples with a Doctorate in Pharmacy. During her schooling, she met Gregorio Brevetti who was to become her husband of 60 years. After several years of working in her family's pharmacy in Italy, she married and immigrated to the United States via the Andrea Doria. First settling in East Harlem, the family moved to Park Slope, Brooklyn in 1961 where she resided until the time of her passing. She is survived by her beloved husband, Dr. Gregorio C. Brevetti, and had five children, Salvatore (deceased), Rossella, Esther (Bruno), Gregory (Elaine), and Teresa (Phillip). A loving grandmother, she is survived by her grandchildren, Christina, Stephanie, Michelle, Nicholas, Lorenzo, Giulia, Ely, Arianna, and Isabella Teresa.

Loving sister to Laurie (Richard) Lichtenstein, Richard (Jan) Bass, aunt to Dena (Mark) Feinsand, Eric Lichtenstein, Jeremy (Karen) Bass, Jamie Bass, great aunt to Ryan and Zack Feinsand. Donations to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.
